Tanya

Part I; Likkutei Amarim

Title Page

<small>SEFER</small><br>LIKKUTEI AMARIM<sup class="footnote-marker">*</sup><i class="footnote">For an introduction to the <i>Tanya</i>, see Addendum, p. a8.</i>
PART ONE
ENTITLED
SEFER SHEL BENONIM
Compiled from (sacred) books and from sages, exalted saints, whose souls are in Eden; based on the verse “For it is exceedingly near to you, in your mouth and in your heart, to do”;<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 30:14.</i> to explain clearly how it is exceedingly near, in a lengthy and short way, with the aid of the Holy One, blessed be He.

Approbation



Chapter 1

APPROBATION<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Note that the name of the author was withheld both from the front cover as well as from the Approbations in the first seven editions. Only beginning with the eighth edition (Shklov ‘574 [1814]), the author’s name was included in the title cover posthumously, when also the Approbation by the author’s sons first appeared.</i>
by the famous rabbi and chasid, G–dly man, of saintly renown, our teacher Rabbi <i>Meshulam Zusil</i> of Anipoli:<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The author’s colleague and a disciple of Rabbi Dov Ber of Miezricz.</i>
I have seen the writings of this rabbi and gaon, G–dly man, saintly and pure, lucid speculum, and well he did, G–d in His wonderful kindness having put into his pure heart to accomplish all this in order to show the G–dly people His holy ways.
It was [the author’s] intention not to publish these writings in print, since it is not his custom. However, because these <i>kuntresim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">See below, p. 907.</i> have spread in the midst of all Israel in numerous copies by sundry copyists, and, as a result of the many transcriptions, the copyists’ errors have multiplied exceedingly, he was impelled to bring these <i>kuntresim</i> to the printing press.
And G–d has aroused the spirit of the [two] partners, the outstanding and distinguished scholar R. Sholom Shachne,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The author’s son-in-law and father of Rabbi Menachem Mendel of Lubavitch, third leader of Chabad.</i> the son of R. Noah, and the outstanding and distinguished scholar R. Mordechai, the son of R. Shmuel haLevi, to bring these <i>kuntresim</i> to the printing house in Slavita. So I said of this good deed, more power to you.
However, they were apprehensive of the growing number of printing establishments which are wont to cause damage and ruin to the accredited ones. In view of this, we have resolved to give this approbation so that no man should dare lift his hand and foot to cause any damage, Heaven forfend, to the said printers by encroaching upon their exclusive right in any manner.
It is to restrain any person from reprinting this book without the knowledge of the said printers for a period of five full years from the date below. He who will heed these, my words, will be blessed with good.
These are the words of one who demands this for the glory of the Torah, this day, the third, twice blessed with “it is good,”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 1:10, 12.</i> of the weekly portion <i>Tavo</i>, in the year פדותינו (556).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., 5556; it is customary to omit the millennial.</i>
The insignificant MESHULAM ZUSIL of Anipoli

Chapter 2

APPROBATION
by the famous rabbi and chasid, G–dly man, of saintly renown, our teacher Rabbi <i>Yehudah Leib haCohen</i>:<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">A disciple of Rabbi Dov Ber of Miezricz and a colleague of the author.</i>
The wisdom of the man illumines the face of the earth<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 8:1.</i>—on seeing the work of the saintly hands of the author, rabbi and gaon, G–dly man, saintly and pure, pious and humble, whose hidden [powers] had been revealed long ago, when he dwelled in the council of the wise with <i>our lord</i>,<i> master and teacher</i>,<i> the world gaon</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">The reference is to Rabbi Dov Ber of Miezricz, hinted also by the word “מבאר” in מבאר מים חיים—“from the well of living waters.”</i> and drew water from the <i>well of living waters</i>. Now, <i>Israel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Alluding to Rabbi Israel Baal Shem Tov.</i> shall rejoice as his saintly words are revealed in this compiled work, which is about to go to press, to teach the people of G–d the ways of holiness, as anyone can see in the inwardness of [the author’s] words.
That which is common knowledge requires no proof. Only because of the apprehension of a wrong, lest a loss be caused to the printers, I come to confer sanction and prohibition that no man lift up his hand or foot to reprint this work for a period of five years from the below date. Whoever will heed these, my words, will be blessed with good.
These are the words of one who speaks for the glory of the Torah, this third day of the weekly portion <i>Tavo</i>, 556.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">See above, note 6.</i>
YEHUDA LEIB HACOHEN

Chapter 3

APPROBATION<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">First published in the Shklov, 5574 (1814) edition. See above, p. xxi, note 1.</i>
by the rabbis (long may they live), the sons of the gaon the author (of blessed memory, whose soul is in Eden).
Whereas it has been agreed by us to give authorization and prerogative to bring to the printing press, for a remembrance unto the children of Israel, the written words of uprightness and truth, the words of the Living G–d, authored by our lord father, teacher, and master, of blessed memory, recorded personally in his saintly expression, whose words are all burning coals to set the hearts aflame to bring them closer to their Father in heaven; they are entitled <i>Iggeret Hakodesh</i> (“Holy Epistle”), being mostly epistles sent by his holy eminence, to teach the people of G–d the way by which to walk and the deed which they should do;
And inasmuch as he has made references, in many places, to the <i>Sefer Likkutei Amarim</i>, since the words of the Torah are scanty in one place and ample in another,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 3:5.</i> especially also as he introduced new material in the <i>Kuntres Acharon</i> on certain chapters which he wrote when he composed the <i>Sefer Likkutei Amarim</i>, profound discussions on passages in the <i>Zohar</i>, <i>Etz Chaim</i>, and <i>Pri Etz Chaim</i>, which [passages] appear contradictory to one another, but he, with his inspired perception, has reconciled them, each statement in its own manner, as he has written in the <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, we have seen fit and proper to join them with the <i>Sefer Likkutei Amarim</i> and <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Note that <i>Shaar Hayichud VehaEmunah</i> (part II of the <i>Tanya</i>) is not mentioned here; neither is it mentioned in the title cover.</i> of his saintly eminence, our lord father, teacher, and master, of blessed memory;
[Therefore], we come to place a great fence and the rabbinic injunction of נח"ש<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">נדוי, חרם, שמתא—three forms of excommunication.</i> (excommunication), for which there is no remedy, that no man lift his hand to reprint them in their present form, or in part, for a period of five years from the date below.
However, this should be made known: To our misfortune the manuscripts written by his personal saintly hand, which were composed with great punctiliousness, without a superfluous or deficient letter, have become extinct; only this little has remained from the abundance, and it has been carefully collected one by one from the <i>copies</i> spread among the disciples. Should, therefore, an error be discovered (“who can understand [and prevent] errors?”)<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 19:13.</i>, the evident error will be identified as a scribe’s error, but the meaning will be clear.
Today is the 5th day [Thursday], 22 Iyar, [5]574
<i>Declared</i> by DOV BER, the son of my lord father, teacher and master, gaon and chasid, saint of Israel, our teacher and master SCHNEUR ZALMAN of blessed memory, his soul rests in the hidden treasures of heaven.
<i>Also declared by</i> CHAYIM ABRAHAM, the son of my lord father, teacher and master, gaon and chasid, our teacher and master SCHNEUR ZALMAN, the memory of the <i>tzaddik</i> be blessed, his soul rests in the hidden treasures of heaven.
<i>Also declared by</i> MOSHE, the son of my lord father, teacher and master, gaon and chasid, SCHNEUR ZALMAN, of blessed memory, his soul rests in the hidden treasures of heaven.

Compiler's Foreword

COMPILER’S FOREWORD<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hakdamat Hamelaket</i>—for the author considers himself merely a “compiler.”</i><br>Being an Epistle sent to the Communities of our Faithful. May the Almighty guard them.
To you, O men, do I call. Listen to me, you who pursue righteousness, who seek the L–rd; and may G–d hearken to you, both great and small, all the faithful in our land and those adjacent to it. May each in his place achieve peace and eternal life for ever and ever. Amen. May this be His will.
Behold, it is known as a saying current among people—all our faithful—that listening to words of moral advice is not the same as seeing and reading them in books. For the reader reads after his own manner and mind and according to his mental grasp and comprehension at that particular time. Hence, if his intelligence and mind are confused and wander about in darkness in G–d’s service, he finds difficulty in seeing the beneficial light that is concealed in books, even though the light is pleasant to the eyes and [brings] a healing to the soul.
Apart from this, the books on piety, which stem from human intelligence,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">As contrasted with books which the author considers divinely inspired, of which he speaks in the following part.</i> certainly have not the same appeal for all people, for not all intellects and minds are alike, and the intellect of one man is not affected and excited by what affects [and excites]<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">In the Hebrew text the word ומתעורר (“and excites”) is added according to <i>Luach HaTikkun</i> (<i>List of Text Emendations in the Tanya</i>), by the Lubavitcher Rebbe (below, p. 781).</i> the intellect of another. Compare with what our Rabbis, of blessed memory, have said<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 58a.</i> with reference to the blessing of the “Wise One in secrets” (חכם הרזים) upon beholding 600,000 Jews, because their minds are dissimilar from one another, and so on.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The blessing praises G–d, Who knows the secrets in the hearts of all men.</i> As also Rabbi Moses ben Nachman, of blessed memory, [explains the reason for this blessing] in <i>Milchamot</i>, elaborating on the commentary of the <i>Sifrei</i> concerning Joshua, who is described as “a man in whom there is spirit,”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 27:18.</i> “who can meet the spirit of each and every one,”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Rashi’s commentary on said verse.</i> and so on.
But even the books on piety, whose basis are in the peaks of holiness, the <i>Midrashim</i> of our Sages, of blessed memory, through whom the spirit of G–d speaks and His word is on their tongue; and [although] the Torah and the Holy One, blessed is He, are one and the same, and all the 600,000 general [souls]<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">In the Hebrew text the word נשמות (“souls”) is added according to <i>Luach HaTikkun</i>.</i> of Israel with their individual [offshoots] down to the “spark” in the most worthless and least estimable members of our people, the children of Israel, are thus bound up with the Torah, and the Torah binds them to the Holy One, blessed is He, as is known from the holy <i>Zohar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">III:73a, see <i>Some Aspects of Chabad Chassidism</i>, pp. 18 ff. Revised edition: <i>On the Study of Chasidus—A Trilogy of Chasidic Essays</i> (Kehot, 1997), pp. 7 ff.</i>—this [bond] pertains [only] in a general way to the community of Israel as a whole.
[As for the individual,] although the Torah was given to be interpreted, in general and in particular down to the minutest detail, to [apply to] each individual soul of Israel, which is rooted in it [so that these books pertain to every person], nevertheless not every person is privileged to recognize his individual place in the Torah.
[A further difficulty is the complexity of Torah interpretation.] Even in the case of the laws governing things prohibited and permitted, which have been revealed to us and to our children,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The expression “revealed to us and to our children” is taken from Deuteronomy 29:28. The first part of this verse is quoted by the author later. See also below, beg. ch. 44.</i> we find and witness differences of opinion among Tanaim and Amoraim from one extreme to the other. Yet “these as well as these are the words of the living G–d.”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Eruvin</i> 13b.</i> The plural<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Elokim chayim</i>, rather than <i>eloka chay</i>.</i> is used as a reference to the source of life for the souls of Israel, which are generally divided into three categories—right, left, and center, namely, kindness (<i>chesed</i>), might (<i>gevurah</i>), and so on,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The third category is <i>tiferet</i> (“beauty”). See <i>Iggeret Hakodesh</i>, sect. 15.</i> so that the souls, whose roots originate in the category of kindness, are likewise inclined toward kindness in the leniency of their decisions, and so forth,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">See ibid., sect. 13 for more light on the subject.</i> as is known.
All the more, <i>a minori ad mains</i>, in the case of those things which are hidden [yet revealed only] to the L–rd our G–d,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">See above, note 11.</i> these being the awe and love that are in the mind and heart of each and every one according to his capacity, i.e., according to his heart’s estimation,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">A reinterpretation of the word <i>shi’ur</i> (“an estimated measure”) and <i>shaar</i> (“gate”) in the Biblical quotation following.</i> as explained in the holy <i>Zohar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">I:103a-b.</i> on the verse, “Her husband is known in the gates (<i>she’arim</i>)….”<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 31:23.</i>
I speak, however, of those who know me well, each and every one of our faithful who lives in our country and in lands adjacent to it, with whom words of affection have been frequently exchanged and who have revealed to me all the secrets of their heart and mind in the service of G–d, which is dependent on the heart.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Taanit</i> 2a. Cf. Bachya’s Introduction to his <i>Duties of the Heart</i>.</i> May my word percolate to them, and my tongue be as the pen of the scribe in these <i>kuntresim</i> that are entitled <i>Likkutei Amarim</i> (Selected Discourses), which have been selected from books and teachers,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">On the sources of the <i>Tanya</i> see Introduction (Addendum, p. a<?>).</i> heavenly saints, whose souls are in Eden, and who are renowned among us.
[The subjects of] some of [these discourses] are hinted to the wise, in the sacred epistles of our teachers<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Schneur Zalman regarded some of his senior colleagues, the disciples of R. Dov Ber of Miezricz (among whom he himself was the youngest) as his “teachers,” esp. R. Mendel Horodoker.</i> in the Holy Land, may it be built and established speedily in our days, Amen; some of them I have heard from their saintly mouth when they were here with us; and all of them are responsa to many questions which all our faithful in our country have constantly asked, seeking advice, each according to his station, so as to receive moral guidance in the service of G–d, since time no longer permits of replying to everyone individually and in detail on his particular problem. Furthermore, forgetfulness is common.
I have, therefore, recorded all the replies to all the questions, to be preserved as a signpost and to serve as a visual reminder for each and every person, so that he will no longer press for admission to private conference with me. For in these [responsa] he will find peace for his soul and true counsel on every matter that he finds difficult in the service of G–d. His heart will thus be firmly secured in the L–rd, Who completes everything for us.
As for him whose mind falls short in the understanding of the counsel given in these <i>kuntresim</i>, let him discuss his problem with the foremost scholars of his town, and they will elucidate it for him. And I beg of them not to lay their hand on their mouth to conduct themselves with false meekness and humility, G–d forbid. It is known what bitter punishment is his who withholds food [i.e., knowledge], and the greatness of the reward [in the opposite case], from the Rabbinic teaching<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Temurah</i> 16a.</i> relating to the Scriptural text, “The L–rd lightens the eyes of them both,”<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 29:13.</i> for G–d will cause His face to shine upon them, with the light of the Countenance of the King, [the Source of] life. May the Giver of life to the living make us worthy to live to see the days when “no longer shall one man instruct the other…for all shall know Me…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 31:33.</i> “for the world shall be full of the knowledge of G–d…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 11:9.</i> Amen. May this be His will.
Since the said <i>kuntresim</i> have been disseminated among all our faithful, as mentioned above, by means of numerous transcriptions by the hands of various and sundry scribes, the multitude of transcriptions brought about an exceedingly great number of copyists’ errors. Therefore the spirits of the noble men, named on another page, have generously moved them to a personal and financial effort to have the said <i>kuntresim</i> published, cleared of chaff and errors, and thoroughly checked. I congratulate them on this worthy deed.
And inasmuch as there is an explicit verse, “Cursed be he who removes his neighbor’s landmark”<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 27:17.</i>—and “cursed” includes both damnation and shunning,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shevuot</i> 36a.</i> G–d forbid—therefore, “like Judah and Scripture in addition”<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kiddushin</i> 6a.</i> I come to invoke a strict prohibition on all publishers against printing the said <i>kuntresim</i>, either themselves or through their agency without the authority of the above-named, for a period of five years from the day that this printing is completed. And it will be well with those who conform, and they will be blessed with good.
These are the words of the compiler of the said <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>.





Chapter 1

It has been taught [<i>Niddah</i>, end ch. 3]: An oath is administered to him [before birth, warning him]: “Be righteous and be not wicked; and even if the whole world tells you that you are righteous, in your own eyes regard yourself as if you were wicked.”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Niddah</i> 30b. The “oath” is also explained in terms of a delegation of power to the soul so that it be able to fulfill its destiny in life on earth. Cf. <i>Kitzurim V’Hearot L’Sefer Likkutei Amarim</i>, ed. Rabbi Menachem Mendel of Lubavitch (Kehot, 1948; 1989), pp. 66f.</i>
This requires to be understood, for it contradicts the Mishnaic dictum [<i>Avot</i>, ch. 2], “And be not wicked in your own estimation.”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Avot</i> 2:13.</i>
Furthermore, if a man considers himself to be wicked he will be grieved at heart and depressed, and he will not be able to serve G–d joyfully and with a contented heart; while if he is not perturbed by this [self-appraisal], it may lead him to irreverence, G–d forbid.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The apparent contradiction between the two sources is explained in ch. 13. The meaning of both the <i>Baraita</i> and Mishnah is expounded in chs. 13, 14, 29, and 34.</i>
However, the matter [will be understood after a preliminary discussion]. We find in the Gemara<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Berachot</i> 7a; cf. <i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 16b.</i> five distinct types—a righteous man who prospers, a righteous man who suffers, a wicked man who prospers, a wicked man who suffers, and a <i>benoni</i> (an intermediate person).<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The author borrows this term for the alternative name of his work, <i>Sefer shel Benonim</i>, but he uses the term in a different sense.</i>
It is there explained that the “righteous man who prospers” is the perfect <i>tzaddik</i>; the “righteous man who suffers” is the imperfect <i>tzaddik</i>. In <i>Raaya Mehemna</i>, <i>Parashat Mishpatim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Zohar</i> II:117b.</i> it is explained that the “righteous man who suffers” is one whose evil nature is subservient to his good nature,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> This is a play on the words rendered literally “the evil (belongs) to him,” i.e., he is master of the evil nature in him.</i> and so on. In the Gemara, end of ch. 9 of <i>Berachot</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Berachot</i> 61b.</i> it is stated that the righteous are judged by their good nature…and the wicked by their evil nature, while the intermediate are judged by both, and so on.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. beg. ch. 9.</i> Rabbah declared, “I, for example, am a <i>benoni</i>.” Said Abbaye to him, “Master, you do not make it possible for anyone to live,” and so on.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Since there was none greater than Rabbah, it would mean that there was not even one <i>tzaddik</i> in the world, and all who are of lesser stature than Rabbah would be placed in the Book of the Wicked to be condemned to immediate death (<i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 16b).</i>
To understand all the aforesaid clearly an explanation is needed, as also to understand what Job said [<i>Bava Batra</i>, ch. 1], “Master of the universe, You have created righteous men and You have created wicked men…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Bava Batra</i> 16a.</i> for it is not preordained whether a man will be righteous or wicked.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Niddah</i> 16b. The answer to this question will be found in ch. 14.</i>
It is also necessary to understand the essential nature of the rank of the <i>benoni</i>. Surely that cannot mean one whose deeds are half virtuous and half sinful, for if this were so, how could Rabbah err in classifying himself as a <i>benoni</i>? For it is known that he never ceased studying [the Torah], so much so that the Angel of Death could not overpower him;<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>Bava Metzia</i> 86a.</i> how, then, could he err to have half of his deeds sinful, G–d forbid?
Furthermore, [at what stage can a person be considered a <i>benoni</i> if] when a man commits sins he is deemed completely wicked [but when he repents afterward he is deemed completely righteous]? Even he who violates a minor prohibition of the Rabbis is called wicked, as it is stated in <i>Yevamot</i>, ch. 2, and in <i>Niddah</i>, ch. 1.
Moreover, even he who has the opportunity to forewarn another against sinning and does not do so is called wicked [ch. 6, <i>Shevuot</i>].<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Shevuot</i> 39b.</i>
All the more so he who neglects any positive law which he is able to fulfill, for instance, whoever is able to study Torah and does not, regarding whom our Sages have quoted,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Sanhedrin</i> 99a.</i> “Because he has despised the word of the L–rd…[that soul] shall be utterly cut off….”<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"> Numbers 15:31.</i> It is thus plain that such a person is called wicked, more than he who violates a prohibition of the Rabbis.
If this is so, we must conclude that the <i>benoni</i> is not guilty even of the sin of neglecting to study the Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"> The reiteration of the sin of neglect of Torah study is due to its prevalent nature and the difficulty of avoiding it completely (cf. end ch. 25). The author is emphasizing that the <i>benoni</i> is innocent even of this and certainly of transgressions more easily avoidable.</i> Hence Rabbah could have mistaken himself for a <i>benoni</i>.
<small>NOTE: As far what is written in the <i>Zohar</i> III, p. 231: He whose sins are few is classed as a “righteous man who suffers”;<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"> The contradiction is in the implication that “few sins” are not inconsistent with the rank of <i>tzaddik</i>.</i> this is the query of Rav Hamnuna to Elijah. But according to Elijah’s answer, ibid., the explanation of a “righteous man who suffers” is as stated in <i>Raaya Mehemna</i> on <i>Parashat Mishpatim</i>, which is given above. And the Torah has seventy facets [modes of interpretation].<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"> Hence the reason for Rav Hamnuna’s query. <i>Otiot d’Rabbi Akiva</i>: comp. <i>Bamidbar Rabbah</i> 14:12.</i></small>
And as for the general saying<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Teshuvah</i> 3:1; <i>Rashi</i>, <i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 16b.</i> that one whose deeds and misdeeds are equally balanced is called <i>benoni</i>, while he whose virtues outweigh his sins is called a <i>tzaddik</i>, this is only the figurative use of the term in regard to reward and punishment, because he is judged according to the majority [of his acts] and he is deemed “righteous” in his verdict, since he is acquitted in law. But concerning the true definition and quality of the distinct levels and ranks, “righteous” and “intermediate,” our Sages have remarked<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Berachot</i> 61b.</i> that the righteous are motivated [solely] by their good nature, as it is written, “And my heart is a void within me,”<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"> Psalms 109:22.</i> that is, void of an evil nature, because he [David] had slain it through fasting.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. beg. ch. 9.</i> But whoever has not attained this degree, even though his virtues exceed his sins, cannot at all be reckoned to have ascended to the rank of the <i>tzaddik</i>.
This is why our Sages have declared in the Midrash, “The Holy One, blessed is He, saw that the righteous were few, so He planted them in every generation…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>Yoma</i> 38b.</i> [for,] as it is written, “The <i>tzaddik</i> is the foundation of the world.”<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"> Proverbs 10:25.</i>
The explanation [of the questions raised above] is to be found in the light of what Rabbi Chaim Vital wrote in <i>Shaar HaKedushah</i> [and in <i>Etz Chaim</i>, Portal 50, ch. 2] that in every Jew, whether righteous or wicked, are two souls, as it is written,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"> Hebrew text should read וכדכתיב instead of דכתיב as amended (see <i>Luach HaTikkun</i>), because the Biblical text is here only loosely interpreted, for the word “souls” refers to the collective noun, not to two souls.</i> “The <i>neshamot</i> (souls) which I have made,”<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"> Isaiah 57:16.</i> [alluding to] two souls. There is one soul which originates in the <i>kelipah</i> and <i>sitra achara</i>, [and] which is clothed in the blood of a human being, giving life to the body, as is written, “For the life of the flesh is in the blood.”<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"> Leviticus 17:11.</i> From it stem all the evil characteristics deriving from the four evil elements which are contained in it. These are: anger and pride, which emanate from the element of Fire, the nature of which is to rise upward; the appetite for pleasures—from the element of Water, for water makes to grow all kinds of enjoyment; frivolity and scoffing, boasting and idle talk from the element of Air; and sloth and melancholy—from the element of Earth.
From this soul stems also the good characteristics which are to be found in the innate nature of all Israel, such as mercy and benevolence.
For in the case of Israel, this soul of the <i>kelipah</i> is derived from <i>kelipat nogah</i>, which also contains good, as it originates in the esoteric “tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil.”<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:12b.</i>
The souls of the nations of the world, however, emanate from the other, unclean <i>kelipot</i> which contain no good whatsoever, as is written in <i>Etz Chaim</i>, Portal 49, ch. 3, that all the good that the nations do is done from selfish motives. So the Gemara<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Bava Batra</i> 10b.</i> comments on the verse, “The kindness of the nations is sin”<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote"> Proverbs 14:34.</i>—that all the charity and kindness done by the nations of the world is only for their own self-glorification, and so on.

Chapter 2

The second soul of a Jew is truly a part of G–d above,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Job 31:2; cf. also Psalms 16:5; 73:26; Jeremiah 10:16.</i> as it is written, “He breathed into his nostrils a soul of life,”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Genesis 2:7; comp. Nachmanides’ Commentary, ad loc.</i> and “You have breathed it [the soul] into me.”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Liturgy, Morning Prayer. <i>Berachot</i> 60b.</i> And it is written in the <i>Zohar</i>, “He who blows, blows from within him,” that is to say, from his inwardness and his innermost, for it is something of his internal and innermost vitality that man emits through exhaling with force.
So, allegorically speaking, have the souls of Jews risen in the [Divine] thought,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 1:4.</i> as it is written, “My firstborn son is Israel,”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Exodus 4:22.</i> and “You are the children of the L–rd your G–d.”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Deuteronomy 14:1.</i> That is to say, just as a child is derived from his father’s brain, so—to use an anthropomorphism—the soul of each Israelite is derived from His thought and wisdom, blessed be He. For He is wise—but not through a knowable wisdom,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 12b.</i> because He and His wisdom are one; and as Maimonides says
<small>NOTE: And the Sages of the Kabbalah have agreed with him as is stated in <i>Pardes</i><sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Shaar Mehut VeHanhagah</i>, ch. 13.</i> of Rabbi Moshe Cordovero. Also according to the Kabbalah of the Arizal<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Rabbi Yitzchak Luria Ashkenazi, of blessed memory (1534-1572).</i> this is substantiated in the mystic principle of the “clothing of the light” of the <i>En Sof</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>En Sof</i>: The Endless, or Infinite. A term frequently used in the <i>Zohar</i> and later Kabbalistic works to indicate the Unknowable G–d.</i> blessed is He, through numerous contractions within the vessels of <i>chabad</i><sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>ChaBaD</i> is an acronym formed of the initial letters of the Hebrew words <i>chochmah</i> (“wisdom”), <i>binah</i> (“understanding”), and <i>daat</i> (“knowledge”), the first three of the ten <i>sefirot</i>. The corresponding faculties of the soul are defined in ch. 3.</i> of [the world of] <i>Atzilut</i> (Emanation), but no higher than that.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> Above the World of <i>Atzilut</i>, the Unknowable G–d cannot be defined.</i> For, as is explained elsewhere, the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, is infinitely exalted over, and transcends, the essence and level of <i>chabad</i>, which in relation to Him are regarded as a material action,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> Accordingly, in terms of the Kabbalistic scale, Maimonides had nothing to say about G–d except from the World of <i>Atzilut</i> and “down.” It is in the world of <i>Atzilut</i> where Kabbalah and Maimonides first meet, so to speak.</i> as is written, “You have made them all with wisdom.”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> Psalms 104:24.</i></small>
that “He is the Knowledge and Knower…and this is not within the power of any man to comprehend clearly…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah</i> 2:10.</i> as it is written, “Can you find G–d by searching?”<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"> Job 11:7.</i> And it is also written, “For My thoughts are not your thoughts….”<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"> Isaiah 55:8.</i>
And though there are myriads of different gradations of souls (<i>neshamot</i>), rank upon rank, <i>ad infinitum</i>, as with the superiority of the souls of the Patriarchs and of Moses our Teacher above the souls of our own generations who live in the period preceding the coming of the Messiah, which are as the very soles<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"> A play on the word עקבתא, “soles.”</i> of the feet compared with the brain and head, so in every generation there are the leaders of the Jews, whose souls are in the category of “head” and “brain” in comparison with those of the masses and the ignorant. Likewise [are there distinctions between] <i>nefashot</i> and <i>nefashot</i>, for every soul consists <i>of nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:206a; II:141b, etc.; also <i>Shnei Luchot HaBrit</i> I, 9b.</i>
Nevertheless, the root of every <i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i>, from the highest of all ranks to the lowest that is embodied within the illiterate and the most worthless, all derive, as it were, from the supreme mind which is <i>chochmah ilaah</i> (supernal wisdom).<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"> The doctrine that all souls are related in that they all come from the same source was given much emphasis by the founder of Chasidut, the Baal Shem Tov, and was a major issue of contention between the protagonists and antagonists of Chasidut. The author elaborates on it in ch. 32 (לב).</i>
[The manner of this descent is] analogous to that of a son who is derived from his father’s brain, in that [even] the nails of his feet come into existence from the very same drop of semen, by being in the mother’s womb for nine months, descending degree by degree, changing continually, until even the nails are formed from it.
Yet [after all this process] it is still bound and united with a wonderful and essential unity with its original essence and being, which was the drop [as it came] from the father’s brain. And even now, in the son, the nails receive their nourishment and life from the brain that is in the head. As is written in the Gemara <i></i>[<i>Niddah</i>, <i></i>ibid.],<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Niddah</i> 31a.</i> “from the white of the father’s drop of semen are formed the veins, the bones, and the nails.” [And in <i>Etz Chaim</i>, <i>Shaar HaChashmal</i>, it is likewise stated, in connection with the esoteric principle of Adam’s garments in the Garden of Eden, that they [the garments] were the “nails” [derived] from the cognitive faculty of the brain].
So, as it were, is it actually true of the root of every <i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i> and <i>neshamah</i> in the community of Israel on high: in descending degree by degree, through the descent of the worlds <i>of Atzilut</i> (Emanation), <i>Beriah</i> (Creation), <i>Yetzirah</i> (Formation) and <i>Asiyah</i> (Action) from His wisdom, blessed be He, as it is written, “You have made them all with wisdom,”<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"> Psalms 104:24.</i> the <i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i> of the ignorant and unworthy come into being.
Nevertheless they remain bound and united with a wonderful and essential unity with their original essence and entity; namely, the extension of <i>chochmah ilaah</i> (supernal wisdom), inasmuch as the nurture and life of the <i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i> of the ignorant are drawn from the <i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i> of the saints and sages, the heads of Israel in their generation.
This explains the comment of our Sages on the verse, “And to cleave to Him”<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"> Deuteronomy 30:20.</i>—“He who cleaves to a scholar [of the Torah] is deemed by the Torah as if he had become attached to the very <i>Shechinah</i> (Divine Presence).”<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Ketuvot</i> 111b.</i> For, through attachment to the scholars, the <i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i> of the ignorant are bound up and united with their original essence and their root in the supernal wisdom, He and His wisdom being one, and “He is the Knowledge….”<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"> See above, note 15.</i>
[As for those who willfully sin and rebel against the Sages, the nurture of their <i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i> comes from behind the back,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"> I.e., ungraciously, or unwittingly. The concept is more fully explained in ch. 22.</i> as it were, of the <i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i> of the scholars].
As for what is written in the <i>Zohar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>Zohar</i> II:204b ff.; III:80-82.</i> and in <i>Zohar Chadash</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Bereishit</i>, p. 11.</i> to the effect that the essential factor is to conduct oneself in a holy manner during sexual union, which is not the case with the children of the ignorant, and so on, it is to be understood as meaning that since there is not a <i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i> which has not a garment of the <i>nefesh</i> of its father’s and mother’s essence, and all the commandments that it fulfills are all influenced by that garment…, and even the benevolence that flows to one from heaven is all given through that garment—hence, through self-sanctification, one will cause to descend for the <i>neshamah</i> of one’s child a holy garment; and however great a soul it may be, it still needs the father’s sanctification….
But as for the soul itself, it sometimes happens that the soul of an infinitely lofty person comes to be the son of a despised and lowly man…. All this has been explained by the Arizal<sup>9</sup> in <i>Likkutei Torah</i> on <i>Parashat Vayera</i> and in <i>Taamei Hamitzvot</i> on <i>Parashat Bereishit</i>.

Chapter 3

Now, each distinction and grade of the three—<i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i>—consists of<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Elsewhere (e.g., <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Bamidbar</i> 1a; 51b; <i>Shir Hashirim</i> 16d) the author makes it clear that the soul does not “consist” of the ten faculties, but rather manifests itself through them, since the soul itself is essentially unknowable.</i> ten faculties, corresponding to the supernal <i>ten sefirot</i> (Divine manifestations),<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> The ten <i>sefirot</i> are more fully discussed by the author in the fourth part of the book, <i>Iggeret Hakodesh</i>, sect. 15 and elsewhere.</i> from which they have descended, which are subdivided into two, namely, the three “mothers” and the seven “multiples,” namely, <i>chochmah</i> (wisdom), <i>binah</i> (understanding), and <i>daat</i> (knowledge); and the “seven days of Creation”: <i>chesed</i> (kindness), <i>gevurah</i> (power), <i>tiferet</i> (beauty), and so on.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Ibid.</i>
Similarly is it with the human soul, which is divided in two—<i>sechel</i> (intellect) and <i>middot</i> (emotional attributes).
The intellect includes <i>chochmah</i>, <i>binah</i>, and <i>daat</i> (<i>chabad</i>), while the <i>middot</i> are love of G–d, dread and awe of Him, glorification of Him, and so forth.
<i>Chabad</i> [the intellectual faculties] are called “mothers” and source of the <i>middot</i>, for the latter are “offspring” of the former.
The explanation of the matter is as follows: The intellect of the rational soul, which is the faculty that conceives any thing, is given the appellation of <i>chochmah</i>—כ“ח מ“ה—the “potentiality” of “what is.”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Zohar</i> III:28a; 34a. A play on the Hebrew word חכמה—כ“ח מ“ה. It is also to be understood as “pure” or creative reason in potentia.</i>
When one brings forth this power from the potential into the actual, that is, when [a person] cogitates with his intellect in order to understand a thing truly and profoundly as it evolves from the concept which he has conceived in his intellect, this is called <i>binah</i>.
These [<i>chochmah</i> and <i>binah</i>] are the very “father” and “mother” which give birth to love of G–d, and awe and dread of Him.
For when the intellect in the rational soul deeply contemplates and immerses itself exceedingly in the greatness of G–d, how He fills all worlds and encompasses all worlds,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> I.e., both immanently and transcendency. <i>Zohar</i> III:225a.</i> and in the presence of Whom everything is considered as nothing<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Zohar</i> I:11b.</i>—there will be born and aroused in his mind and thought the emotion of awe for the Divine majesty, to fear and be humble before His greatness, blessed be He, which is without end or limit, and to have the dread of G–d in his heart.
Next, his heart will glow with an intense love, like burning coals, with a passion, desire and longing, and a yearning soul, toward the greatness of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He.
This constitutes the culminating passion of the soul, of which Scripture speaks, as “My soul yearns, indeed it pines…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Psalms 84:3.</i> and “My soul thirsts for G–d…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Psalms 42:3.</i> and “My soul thirsts for You….”<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> Psalms 63:2.</i>
This thirst is derived from the element of Fire, which is found in the divine soul. As students of natural science affirm, and so it is in <i>Etz Chaim</i>, the element of Fire is in the heart, while the source of [the element of] Water and moisture is in the brain, which is explained in <i>Etz Chaim</i>, Portal 50, to refer to the faculty of <i>chochmah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Water descends from high places. It is symbolically identified with <i>chochmah</i>, the highest of the ten <i>sefirot</i>, and also with <i>chesed</i>, the first of the <i>middot</i>.</i> called “the water of the divine soul.”
The rest of the <i>middot</i> are all offshoots of fear and love and their derivations, as is explained elsewhere.
<i>Daat</i>, the etymology of which is to be found in the verse, “And Adam knew (<i>yada</i>) Eve,”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Genesis 4:1.</i> implies attachment and union. That is, one binds his mind with a very firm and strong bond to, and firmly fixes his thought on, the greatness of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, without diverting his mind [from Him].
For even one who is wise and understanding of the greatness of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, will not—unless he binds his knowledge and fixes his thought with firmness and perseverance—produce in his soul true love and fear, but only vain fancies.
Therefore <i>daat</i> is the basis of the <i>middot</i> and the source of their vitality; it contains <i>chesed</i> and <i>gevurah</i>, that is to say, love with its offshoots and fear with its offshoots.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> Love and fear (awe) are two basic emotions latent in the soul, which are produced by contemplation. The faculty of <i>daat</i> stimulates these higher emotions to seek an outlet through the three “garments” of the soul, discussed in the following chapter.</i>

Chapter 4

In addition,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Having outlined in ch. 3 the intrinsic faculties of the soul, the author goes on to explain how they express themselves through the three outer “garments,” or instruments.</i> every divine soul (<i>nefesh elokit</i>) possesses three garments, viz., thought, speech, and action, [expressing themselves] in the 613 commandments of the Torah. For, when a person <i>actively</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> All italics are the translator’s.</i> fulfills all the precepts which require physical action,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Note that “action” is put first.</i> and with his power of <i>speech</i> he occupies himself in expounding all the 613 commandments and their practical application, and with his power of <i>thought</i> he comprehends all that is comprehensible to him in the <i>Pardes</i><sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Literally meaning “orchard,” it is taken as an acronym of the four Hebrew words פשט, רמז, דרוש, סוד, meaning: plain sense, intimation, homiletical exposition, and esoteric meaning, respectively, the four levels of Scriptural interpretation.</i> of the Torah—then the totality of the 613 “organs” of his soul<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> The physical organism of the human body consists of 248 members and 365 blood vessels, corresponding to the 248 positive and 365 prohibitive commands (<i>Tanchuma Hakadum</i>, <i>Teitzei; Makkot</i> 24a). The soul contains the spiritual counterparts of these 613 “organs.” (See below, ch. 51.)</i> are clothed in the 613 commandments of the Torah.
Specifically: the faculties of <i>chabad</i> in his soul are clothed in the comprehension of the Torah, which he comprehends in <i>Pardes</i>, to the extent of his mental capacity and the supernal root of his soul. And the <i>middot</i>, namely fear and love, together with their offshoots and ramifications, are clothed in the fulfillment of the commandments in deed and in word, namely, in the study of Torah which is “equivalent to them all.”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Mishnah, <i>Peah</i> 1:1.</i>
For love is the root of all the 248 positive commands, all originating in it and having no true foundation without it, inasmuch as he who fulfills them in truth truly loves the name of G–d and desires to cleave to Him in truth; for one cannot truly cleave to Him except through the fulfillment of the 248 commandments which are the 248 “organs of the King,”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 30.</i> as it were, as is explained elsewhere;<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Below, ch. 23.</i> while fear is the root of the 365 prohibitive commands, fearing to rebel against the Supreme King of kings, the Holy One, blessed is He;
or a still deeper fear than this—when he feels <i>ashamed</i> in the presence of the Divine greatness to rebel against His glory and do what is evil in His eyes, namely, any of the abominable things hated by G–d, which are the <i>kelipot</i> and <i>sitra achara</i>, which draw their nurture from man below and have their hold in him through the 365 prohibitive commands [that he violates].
Now these three “garments,” deriving from the Torah and its commandments, although they are called “garments” of the <i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i>, their quality, nevertheless, is infinitely higher and greater than that of the <i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i> themselves,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The soul itself, as the subject loving and fearing G–d, must remain apart from G–d; it is only through its “garments” that it attains true identity with G–d, as further explained in ch. 35.</i> as explained in the <i>Zohar</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> I:24a; II:60a. See below, beg. ch. 23.</i> because the Torah and the Holy One, blessed is He, are one. The meaning of this is that the Torah, which is the wisdom and will of the Holy One, blessed is He, and His glorious Essence are one, since He is both the Knower and the Knowledge, and so on, as explained above in the name of Maimonides.
And although the Holy One, blessed is He, is called <i>En Sof</i> (“Infinite”), and “His greatness can never be fathomed,”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Psalms 145:3.</i> and “no thought can apprehend Him at all,”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 17a.</i> and so are also His will and His wisdom, as it is written, “There is no searching of His understanding”<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> Isaiah 40:28.</i> and “Can you find G–d by searching?”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> Job 11:7.</i> and again, “For My thoughts are not your thoughts”<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"> Isaiah 55:8.</i>
—nevertheless, it is in this connection that it has been said: “Where you find the greatness of the Holy One, blessed is He, there you also find His humility.”<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"> Megillah 31a. This is interpreted to mean that G–d combines the powers of expansion (“greatness”) and contraction (“humility”), which come into play in the process of <i>tzimtzum</i>. Cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:140a; II:99a; III:58a, 159a.</i> For the Holy One, blessed is He, has compressed His will and wisdom within the 613 commandments of the Torah and in their laws, as well as within the combination of the letters of the Torah, the books of the Prophets and the Writings, and in the exposition thereof which are to be found in the <i>Aggadot</i> and <i>Midrashim</i> of our Rabbis of blessed memory.
All this in order that each <i>neshamah</i>, or <i>ruach</i>, and <i>nefesh</i> in the human body should be able to comprehend them through its faculty of understanding, and to fulfill them, as far as they can be fulfilled, in act, speech, and thought, thereby clothing itself with all its ten faculties in these three garments.
Therefore has the Torah been compared to water,<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"> Bava Kama 17a.</i> for just as water descends from a higher to a lower level, so has the Torah descended from its place of glory, which is His will and wisdom, blessed be He; [for] the Torah and the Holy One, blessed is He, are one and the same and no thought can apprehend Him at all.
From there [the Torah] has progressively descended through hidden stages, stage after stage, with the descent of the worlds, until it clothed itself in corporeal substances and in things of this world, comprising almost all of the commandments of the Torah, their laws, and in the combinations of material letters, written with ink in a book, namely, the 24 volumes of the Torah, Prophets, and Writings; all this in order that every thought should be able to apprehend them, and even the faculties of speech and action, which are on a lower level than thought, should be able to apprehend them and be clothed in them.
Thus, since the Torah and its commandments “clothe” all ten faculties of the soul with all its 613 organs from head to foot, it [the soul] is altogether truly bound up in the Bundle of Life with G–d,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"> I Samuel 25:29.</i> and the very light of G–d envelops and clothes it from head to foot, as it is written, “G–d is my Rock, I will take refuge <i>in Him</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"> Psalms 18:3.</i> and it is also written, “You will envelop him with favor (<i>ratzon</i>—will) as with a shield,”<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"> Psalms 5:13.</i> that is to say, with His will and wisdom, blessed be He, which are clothed in His Torah and its commandments.
Hence it has been said: “Better is one hour of repentance and good deeds in this world than the whole life of the World to Come.”<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Avot</i> 4:17.</i> For, the World to Come is that state where one enjoys the effulgence of the Divine Presence,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Berachot</i> 16b.</i> which is the pleasure of comprehension, yet no created being—even celestial—can comprehend more than some reflection of the Divine light; that is why the reference is to “effulgence of the Divine Presence” (<i>Ziv haShechinah</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"> I.e., the “glow” of the <i>Shechinah</i>, not the <i>Shechinah</i> itself. Note the author’s interpretation of זיו in this context as a remote gleam, a mere reflection.</i> But as for the essence of the Holy One, blessed is He, no thought can apprehend Him at all, except when it apprehends, and is clothed in, the Torah and its <i>mitzvot</i>; only then does it truly apprehend, and is clothed in, the Holy One, blessed is He, inasmuch as the Torah and the Holy One, blessed is He, are one and the same.
For although the Torah has been clothed in lower material things, it is by way of illustration, like embracing the king. There is no difference, in regard to the degree of closeness and attachment to the king, whether while embracing the king, the latter is then wearing one robe or several robes, so long as the royal person is in them.
Likewise, when the king, for his part, embraces one with his arm, even though it is dressed in his robes; as it is written, “And His right hand embraces me,”<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"> Song of Songs 8:3.</i> which refers to the Torah which was given by G–d’s right hand,<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"> Deuteronomy 35:2.</i> which is the quality of <i>chesed</i> and water.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"> In Kabbalah, the “right” hand or side is the side of benevolence. <i>Chesed</i> and water are synonymous of Divine benevolence. See note 10, ch. 3.</i>

Chapter 5

Let us explain further and fully elucidate the expression <i>tefisa</i> (apprehension) in the words of Elijah, “No thought can apprehend You.”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 17a.</i>
Now, when an intellect conceives and comprehends a concept with its intellectual faculties, this intellect grasps the concept and encompasses it. This concept is [in turn] grasped, enveloped, and enclothed within that intellect which conceived and comprehended it.
The mind, for its part, is also clothed in the concept at the time it comprehends and grasps it with the intellect.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> This point is demonstrated by the fact that when the mind is preoccupied with one thing, it cannot at the same time engage in another.</i> For example, when a person understands and comprehends, fully and clearly, any <i>halachah</i> in the Mishnah or Gemara, his intellect grasps and encompasses it and, at the same time, is clothed in it.
Consequently, as the particular <i>halachah</i> is the wisdom and will of G–d, for it was His will that when, for example, Reuben pleads in one way and Simeon in another, the verdict as between them shall be thus and thus;
and even should such a litigation never have occurred, nor would it ever present itself for judgment in connection with such disputes and claims, nevertheless, since it has been the will and wisdom of the Holy One, blessed is He, that in the event of a person pleading this way and the other [litigant] pleading that way, the verdict shall be such and such—now therefore, when a person knows and comprehends with his intellect such a verdict in accordance with the law as it is set out in the Mishnah, Gemara, or <i>Poskim</i> (Codes), he has thus comprehended, grasped, and encompassed with his intellect the will and wisdom of the Holy One, blessed is He, Whom no thought can grasp, nor His will and wisdom, except when they are clothed in the laws that have been set out for us. [Simultaneously] the intellect is also clothed in them [the Divine will and wisdom].
This is a wonderful union, like which there is none other and which has no parallel anywhere in the material world, whereby complete oneness and unity, from every side and angle, could be attained.
Hence the special superiority, infinitely great and wonderful, that is in the commandment of knowing the Torah and comprehending it, over all the commandments involving action, and even those relating to speech, and even the commandment to study the Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> As distinct from knowledge of the Torah.</i> which is fulfilled through speech.
For, through all the commandments involving speech or action, the Holy One, blessed is He, clothes the soul and envelops it from head to foot with the Divine light. However, with regard to knowledge of the Torah, apart from the fact that the intellect is clothed in Divine wisdom, this Divine wisdom is also contained <i>in it</i>, to the extent that his intellect comprehends, grasps, and encompasses, as much as it is able so to do, of the knowledge of the Torah, every man according to his intellect, his knowledgeable capacity, and his comprehension in <i>Pardes</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Set ch. 4, note 4.</i>
Since, in the case of knowledge of the Torah, the Torah is clothed in the soul and intellect of a person and is absorbed in them, it is called “bread” and “food” of the soul.
For just as physical bread nourishes the body as it is absorbed internally, in his very inner self, where it is transformed into blood and flesh of his flesh, whereby he lives and exists—so, too, it is with the knowledge of the Torah and its comprehension by the soul of the person who studies it well, with a concentration of his intellect, until the Torah is absorbed by his intellect and is united with it, and they become one. This becomes nourishment for the soul and its inner life from the Giver of life, the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, Who is clothed in His wisdom and in His Torah that are [absorbed] in it [the soul].
This is the meaning of the verse, “And Your Torah is in my innards.”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Psalms 40:9.</i> It is also stated in <i>Etz Chaim</i>, Portal 44, ch. 3, that the “garments” of the soul in <i>Gan Eden</i> are the commandments while the Torah is the “food” for the souls which, during life on earth, had occupied themselves in the study of the Torah for its own sake. It is [similarly] written in the <i>Zohar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> II:210a ff.</i>
As for the meaning of “for its own sake,”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> See below, chs. 39, 40, and 41, for a further elaboration. We have here a departure from the conventional concepts of <i>lishemah</i> and <i>shelo</i> <i>lishemah</i>.</i> it is [study with the intent] to attach one’s soul to G–d through the comprehension of the Torah, each one according to his intellect, as explained in <i>Pri Etz Chaim</i>.
[The “food” [of the soul] is in the nature of “inner light,” while the “garments” are in the nature of “encompassing light.” Therefore our Rabbis, of blessed memory, have said, “The study of the Torah is equivalent to them all.”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> Mishnah, <i>Peah</i> 1:1.</i> For the commandments are but “garments” whereas the Torah is both “food” as well as “garment”<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The “food” would correspond to the knowledge absorbed and “digested”; the “garment”—to that knowledge which is not thoroughly assimilated and remains external as it were, yet retaining the quality of the Divine precept, like all other religious acts which are conceived as “garments” of the soul.</i> for the rational soul, in which a person is clothed during learning and concentration. All the more so when a person also articulates, by word of mouth; for the breath emitted in speaking [the words of the Torah] becomes something in the nature of an “encompassing light,” as is explained in <i>Pri Etz Chaim</i>.]

Chapter 6

“G–d has made one thing opposite the other.”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Ecclesiastes 7:14. In general, things in the realm of holiness have their opposite in the realm of the profane, or “the other side” (<i>sitra achara</i>). Similarly, everything in the physical world has its spiritual counterpart from which it derives its existence and vitality—a popular concept in Chabad, as in Kabbalah generally. Cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:47b.</i>
Just as the divine soul consists of ten holy <i>sefirot</i> and is clothed in three holy garments,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Thought, speech, and deed.</i> so does the soul which is derived from the <i>sitra achara</i> of the <i>kelipat nogah</i>, which is clothed in man’s blood, consist of ten “crowns of impurity.”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:41a; 70a.</i> These are the seven evil <i>middot</i> which stem from the four evil elements mentioned above,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> End of ch. 1.</i> and the intellect begetting them which is subdivided into three, viz., wisdom, understanding, and knowledge, the source of the <i>middot</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Here, unlike ch. 3, the <i>middot</i> precede <i>sechel</i> to indicate the secondary role of the intellect in the animal soul, where passion predominates.</i> For the <i>middot</i> are according to the quality of the intellect. Hence a child desires and loves petty things of inferior worth, for his intellect is too immature and deficient to appreciate things that are much more precious. Likewise is he provoked to anger and vexation over trivial things; so, too, with boasting and other <i>middot</i>.
Now these ten unclean categories, when a person meditates in them or speaks them or acts by them, his thought—which is in his brain; and his speech—which is in his mouth; and the power of action—which is in his hands, together with his other limbs—all these are called the “impure garments” of these ten unclean categories wherein the latter are clothed at the time of the action, speech, or thought.
It is these that constitute all the deeds that are done under the sun, which are all “vanity and striving after the wind,”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Ecclesiastes 1:14.</i> as interpreted in the <i>Zohar</i>, <i>Beshalach</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> II:59a.</i> in the sense of a “ruination of the spirit….”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> A reinterpretation of רעות רוח.</i> So, too, are all utterances and thoughts which are not directed toward G–d and His will and service. For this is the meaning <i>of sitra achara</i>—“the other side,” i.e., not the side of holiness.
For the holy side is nothing but the indwelling and extension of the holiness of the Holy One, blessed is He, and He dwells only on such a thing that abnegates itself completely to Him, either actually, as in the case of the angels above, or potentially, as in the case of every Jew down below, having the capacity to abnegate himself completely to the Holy One, blessed is He, through martyrdom for the sanctification of G–d.
That is why our Sages have said that “Even when a single individual sits and engages in the Torah the <i>Shechinah</i> rests on him”<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Avot</i> 3:6.</i> and “On every gathering of ten [Jews] the <i>Shechinah</i> rests”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Sanhedrin</i> 39a.</i> always.
However, that which does not surrender itself to G–d, but is a separate thing by itself, does not receive its vitality from the holiness of the Holy One, blessed is He, that is, from the very inner essence and substance of the holiness itself, but from “behind its back,” as it were,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. note 25, ch. 2.</i> descending degree by degree, through myriads of degrees with the lowering of the worlds, by way of cause and effect and innumerable contractions,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. ch. 48; <i>Iggeret Hakodesh</i>, ch. 20.</i> until the light and life is so diminished through repeated diminutions that it can be compressed and incorporated, in a state of exile as it were, within that separated thing, giving it vitality and existence <i>ex nihilo</i>, so that it does not revert to nothingness and nonexistence as it was before it was created.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> Evil is thus conceived as a creation <i>ex nihilo</i>, like everything else, except that it was not created for its own sake; hence it is merely tolerated. The monistic aspect of creation, despite the apparent dualism in the world, is thus emphasized, particularly in ch. 24, below.</i>
Consequently, this world, with all its contents, is called the world of <i>kelipot</i> and <i>sitra achara</i>. Therefore all mundane affairs are severe and evil,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. ch. 24.</i> and wicked men prevail, as explained in <i>Etz Chaim</i>, Portal 42, end of ch. 4.
<small>NOTE: To be sure, there are contained in it [this world] the ten <i>sefirot</i> [of the world] of <i>Asiyah</i> (Action) of the side of holiness, as is written in <i>Etz Chaim</i>, Portal 43, and within these ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Asiyah</i> are the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Yetzirah</i> (Formation), and in them the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Beriah</i> (Creation), and in them the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> (Emanation), in which abides the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He. Thus the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, pervades this lower world through being clothed in the ten <i>sefirot</i> of the Four Worlds, namely those of <i>Atzilut</i>, <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>, as explained in <i>Etz Chaim</i>, Portal 47, ch. 2, and in <i>Sefer Hagilgulim</i>, ch. 20.</small>
However, the <i>kelipot</i> are subdivided into two grades, one lower than the other.
The lower grade consists of the three <i>kelipot</i> which are altogether unclean and evil, containing no good whatsoever. In the chariot of [the prophet] Ezekiel they are called “whirlwind,” “great cloud”….<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"> “…and a flaring fire.” Ezekiel 1:4.</i>
From them flow and derive the souls of all the nations of the world, and the existence of their bodies, and also the souls of all living creatures that are unclean and unfit for consumption,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"> Leviticus 11; Deuteronomy 14.</i> and the existence of their bodies, as well as the existence and vitality of all forbidden food in the vegetable kingdom, such as <i>orlah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"> First three years’ harvest of fruit of a tree. Cf. Leviticus 19:23.</i> and mixed seeds in the vineyard,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"> Cf. Deuteronomy 22:9.</i> and so on, as explained in <i>Etz Chaim</i>, Portal 49, ch. 6, as also the existence and vitality of all actions, utterances, and thoughts pertaining to the 365 prohibitions and their offshoots, as is explained, ibid., at the end of ch. 5.

Chapter 7

On the other hand,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> The author continues to expound the doctrine of the <i>kelipot</i>, and his definitions of good and evil, distinguishing an intermediate category.</i> the vitalizing animal soul in the Jew, that which is derived from the aspect of the <i>kelipah</i>, which is clothed in the human blood, as stated above,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> Ch. 1.</i> and the “souls”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> The quotes are the translator’s. According to Lurianic doctrine all things, including inanimate objects, possess a “soul,” which is the creative and preserving force of the Creator, the thing’s reality. This doctrine was adopted and expounded by the Baal Shem Tov and Rabbi Schneur Zalman. See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, ch. 1 ff.</i> of the animals, beasts, birds, and fish that are clean and fit for [Jewish] consumption, as also the existence and vitality of the entire inanimate and entire vegetable world which are permissible for consumption, as well as the existence and vitality of every act, utterance, and thought in mundane matters that contain no forbidden aspect—being neither root nor branch of the 365 prohibitive precepts and their offshoots, either on the explicit authority of the Torah or by Rabbinic enactment—yet are not performed for the sake of Heaven but only by the will, desire, and lust of the body; and even where it is a need of the body, or its very preservation and life, but his intention is not for the sake of Heaven, that is, to serve G–d thereby —all these acts, utterances, and thoughts are no better than the vitalizing animal soul itself; and everything in this totality of things flows and is drawn from the second gradation [to be found] in the <i>kelipot</i> and <i>sitra achara</i>, namely, a fourth <i>kelipah</i>, called <i>kelipat nogah</i>. In this world, called the “World of <i>Asiyah</i> (Action),”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> See Addendum, Glossary.</i> most, indeed almost all, of it [the <i>kelipat nogah</i>] is bad, and only a little good has been intermingled within it [from which come the good qualities contained in the animal soul of the Jew, as is explained above.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> Ch. 1.</i>]
This [<i>kelipat nogah</i>] is an intermediate category between the three completely unclean <i>kelipot</i> and the category and order of holiness.
Hence it is sometimes absorbed within the three unclean <i>kelipot</i> [as is explained in <i>Etz Chaim</i>, Portal 49, beginning of ch. 4, on the authority of the <i>Zohar</i>], and sometimes it is absorbed and elevated to the category and level of holiness, as when the good that is intermingled in it is extracted from the bad, and prevails and ascends until it is absorbed in holiness.
Such is the case, for example, of he who eats fat beef and drinks spiced wine in order to broaden his mind for the service of G–d and His Torah; as Rava said, “Wine and fragrance [make a man’s mind more receptive],”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Yoma</i> 76b.</i> or in order to fulfill the command concerning enjoyment of Shabbat and the Festivals.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Shabbat</i> 30:7; <i>Hilchot Yom Tov</i> 6:16. Rabbi Schneur Zalman, <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, <i>Orach Chaim</i> 242:1; 529:1, 3.</i> In such a case the vitality of the meat and wine, originating in the <i>kelipat nogah</i>, is distilled and ascends to G–d like a burnt offering and sacrifice.
So, too, when a man utters a pleasantry in order to sharpen his wit and rejoice his heart in G–d, in His Torah and service, which should be practiced joyfully, as Rava was wont to do with his pupils, prefacing his discourse with some witty remark, to enliven the students thereby.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Pesachim</i> 117a.</i>
On the other hand, he who belongs to those who gluttonously guzzle meat and quaff wine in order to satisfy their bodily appetites and animal nature, derived from the so-called element of water of the four evil elements contained therein, from which comes the vice of lust—in such case the energy of the meat and wine consumed by him is degraded and absorbed temporarily in the utter evil of the three unclean <i>kelipot</i>, and his body temporarily becomes a garment and vehicle for them, until the person repents and returns to the service of G–d and His Torah. For, inasmuch as the meat and wine were kosher, they have the power to revert and ascend with him when he returns to the service of G–d. This is implied in the terms “permissibility” and “permitted” (<i>muttar</i>),<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> The Hebrew term מותר literally means “released.”</i> that is to say, that which is not tied and bound by the power of the “extraneous forces”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Another term for <i>kelipot</i> and <i>sitra achara</i>.</i> preventing it from returning and ascending to G–d.
Nevertheless, a trace [of the evil] remains in the body. Therefore the body must undergo the Purgatory of the grave, as will be explained later.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> Ch. 8.</i>
So, too, with regard to the vitality of the drops of semen emitted from the body with animal lust, by him who has not conducted himself in a saintly manner during intimacy with his wife in her state of purity.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> This paragraph is added according to <i>Luach HaTikkun</i> (below, p. 781).</i>
Such is not the case, however, with forbidden foods and coition, which derive from the three <i>kelipot</i> that are entirely unclean. These are tied and bound by the extraneous forces forever and are not released until the day comes when death will be swallowed up forever, as is written, “And I will cause the unclean spirit to pass from the land,”<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> Zechariah 13:2.</i> or until the sinner repents to such an extent that his premeditated sins become transmuted into veritable merits, which is achieved through “repentance out of love,” coming from the depths of the heart, with great love and fervor, and from a soul passionately desiring to cleave to G–d, blessed be He, and thirsting for G–d like a parched desert soil. For inasmuch as his soul had been in a barren wilderness, and in the shadow of death, which is the <i>sitra achara</i>, and infinitely removed from the light of the Divine Countenance, his soul now thirsts [for G–d] even more than the souls of the righteous, as our Sages say, “In the place where penitents stand, not even the perfectly righteous can stand.”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Berachot</i> 34b.</i>
It is concerning the repentance out of such great love that they have said, “The penitent’s premeditated sins become, in his case, like virtues,”<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 29a.</i> since thereby he has attained to this great love.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"> This religious experience is unknown to the perfect <i>tzaddik</i>, who never sinned and consequently has never experienced the remorse and yearning of a repentant soul. This does not mean, however, that the <i>tzaddik</i> cannot experience my kind of <i>teshuvah</i>, for in a broader and truer sense (and as the Hebrew term indicates) it means “return” to the Source, which is of infinite scope. (Cf. <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, beg. <i>Haazinu</i>.)</i>
However, repentance that does not come from such love, even though it be true repentance and G–d will pardon him, nevertheless his sins are not transformed into merits and they are not completely released from the <i>kelipah</i> until the end of time, when death will be swallowed up forever.
Yet the vitality which is in the drops of semen that issue wastefully, even though it has been degraded and incorporated in the three unclean <i>kelipot</i>, nevertheless it can ascend from there by means of true repentance and intense <i>kavanah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"> “Intention,” i.e., concentration and devotion in prayer, study, or the performance of a ritual precept. Cf. below, chs. 38, 40, and 41, for an elaboration of the term.</i> during the recital of the <i>Shema</i> at bedtime, as is known from the Arizal<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"> See above, ch. 2, note 9.</i> and is implied in the Talmudic saying, “He who recites the <i>Shema</i> at bedtime is as if he held a double-edged sword…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Berachot</i> 5a.</i> wherewith to slay the bodies of the extraneous forces that have become garments for the vitality which is in the drops [of semen], so that this vitality may ascend, as is known to the students of Kabbalah.
Therefore the sin of wasteful emission of semen is not mentioned in the Torah among the list of forbidden coitions, although it is even more heinous than they, and this sin is greater because of the enormity and abundance of the uncleanness and of the <i>kelipot</i> which he begets and multiplies to an exceedingly great extent through wasteful emission of semen, even more than through forbidden coitions.
