But the category of the higher wisdom of <i>Atzilut</i>, consisting of the totality of the Torah as it is epitomized in the Decalogue, has clothed itself in <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> and of <i>Beriah</i> alone, and they alone, united as they are with the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, that is within them, are referred to as the “<i>Shechinah</i>” which rested in the Holy of Holies of the First Temple, through its clothing itself in the Ten Commandments, which were engraved in the Tables [reposing] in the Ark, by miraculous means and by the work of the Living G–d [this being the “hidden” world which nests in the world of <i>Beriah</i>, as is known to to the students of Kabbalah].
As for the Second Temple, in which did not repose the Ark and Tables [of the Decalogue],<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Yoma</i> 21b.</i> our Rabbis, of blessed memory, said that the <i>Shechinah</i> did not abide there.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"> Ibid. 96.</i> This refers to the category of the <i>Shechinah</i> which used to abide in the First Temple—which was not of the ordinary descent of the worlds. But in the Second Temple it abided according to the order of gradual descent, of <i>malchut d’Atzilut</i> vested in <i>malchut d’Beriah</i> and the latter in <i>malchut d’Yetzirah</i>, and the latter in the shrine of the Holy of Holies of <i>Asiyah</i> which in turn was clothed in the Holy of Holies of the Temple here below. In it rested the <i>Shechinah</i>, i.e., <i>malchut d’Yetzirah</i>, which was clothed in the Holy of Holies of <i>Asiyah</i>. Therefore no man was permitted to enter there, except the High Priest on the Day of Atonement. However, since the Temple was destroyed, there remains to the Holy One, blessed is He, but “the four cubits of <i>halachah</i> alone.”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Berachot</i> 6a.</i> Hence each individual who sits by himself and occupies himself in the Torah, the <i>Shechinah</i> is with him, as is stated in the first chapter of <i>Berachot</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"> Ibid.</i> The phrase “the <i>Shechinah</i> is <i>with</i> him” means in the order of the gradual descent and investment of <i>malchut d’Atzilut</i> in <i>malchut d’Beriah</i>, and <i>Yetzirah</i> and <i>Asiyah</i>.
For the 613 commandments of the Torah are by and large active precepts, as are also those which are fulfilled by word and thought, such as Torah study, Grace after meals, the recital of the <i>Shema</i> and Prayer, for it has been ruled that contemplation has not the validity of speech, and one has not fulfilled one’s obligation by contemplation and <i>kavanah</i> alone, until he gives utterance with his lips; and it has been ruled that the motion of the lips is considered an “action.”
The 613 commandments of the Torah, together with the seven commandments of our Rabbis, combine to total the numerical equivalent of כתר (“crown”) which is the the will of the Supreme One, blessed is He, which is clothed in His wisdom, blessed be He, and they are united with the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, in a perfect union. “The L–rd has founded the earth with wisdom,”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"> Proverbs 3:19.</i> which refers to the Oral Law that is derived from the higher wisdom, as is written in the <i>Zohar</i>, “The Father [<i>chochmah</i>] begat the daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Zohar</i> III:248a; 256b.</i> [i.e., <i>malchut</i>, the Oral Law].”
And this is what the <i>Yenuka</i> meant when he said that “the supernal light that is kindled on one’s head, namely, the <i>Shechinah</i>, requires oil,”<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Zohar</i> III:187a. Cf. <i>Tanya</i>, chs. 35, 51.</i> that is, to be clothed in wisdom, which is called “oil from the holy anointing,”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"> Exodus 30:31.</i> as is explained in the <i>Zohar</i>, that “these are the good deeds,” namely, the 613 commandments, which derive from His wisdom, blessed be He. Thereby the light of the <i>Shechinah</i> can cling to the wick, i.e., the vivifying soul in the body, which is metaphorically called a “wick.” For just as in the case of a material candle, the light shines by virtue of the annihilation and burning of the wick turning to fire, so does the light of the <i>Shechinah</i> rest on the divine soul as a result of the annihilation of the animal soul and its transformation from darkness to light and from bitterness to sweetness in the case of the righteous, or at least through the destruction of its garments, which are thought, speech, and action, and their transformation from the darkness of the <i>kelipot</i> to the Divine light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, which is clothed and united in the thought, speech, and action of the 613 commandments of the Torah, in the case of <i>benonim</i>.
For as a result of the transformation of the animal soul, originating from the <i>kelipat nogah</i>, [a transformation] from darkness to light, and so forth, there is brought about the so-called “ascent of the feminine waters”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"> See above, end ch. 10.</i> to draw the light of the <i>Shechinah</i>, i.e., the category of the “revealed” light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He—over one’s divine soul [principally dwelling] in the brain of the head. Thereby will also be clearly understood the text “For the L–rd Your G–d is a consuming fire,”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"> Deuteronomy 4:24.</i> as is explained elsewhere.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Shelach</i> 40b; <i>Re’eh</i> 34c; <i>Haazinu</i> 78d, et al.</i>
CONCLUSION OF THE FIRST PART WITH THE HELP OF G-D, MAY HE BE BLESSED AND EXALTED.

Part II; Shaar HaYichud VehaEmunah

Chinukh Katan

LIKKUTEI AMARIM<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Collected Discourses. For an introduction to this part of the <i>Tanya</i>, see Addendum, p. a<?>.</i> PART TWO
Called<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The following is the author’s introduction which is called <i>Chinuch Kattan</i>. The complete work is referred to as <i>Shaar Hayichud VehaEmunah</i>.</i> “<i>Chinuch Kattan</i>”
Compiled from books and from Sages, exalted saints, whose souls are in Eden. Based on the first section of the Recitation of the <i>Shema</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>Shema</i> consists of three sections of the Torah: Deuteronomy 6:4-10, 11:13-22, and Numbers 15:37-42. Following the first verse of the first section, our Sages instituted the recital of the verse, <i>Blessed be the name of the glory of His kingdom for ever and ever</i>. See <i>Pesachim</i> 56a.</i>
“Educate the child according to his way, even when he will be old he will not depart from it.”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 22:6.</i> Since it is written “According to <i>his</i> way,” it is understood that it is not the path of perfect truth, hence of what merit is it that “Even when he will be old he will not depart from it?”
It is well-known that fear (awe) and love are the roots and foundations of the service of G–d.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Commentary on Maimonides’ <i>Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah</i> 2:10; <i>Reishit Chochmah</i>, beg. of <i>Shaar HaAhavah</i>; Rabbi Schneur Zalman, <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, <i>Hilchot Talmud Torah</i> 4:6.</i> Fear is the root and basis of “Turn away from evil,”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 34:15; i.e., the fulfillment of the negative injunctions.</i> and love—of “and do good”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid.</i> and the observance of all the positive commandments of the Torah and the Rabbis, as will be explained in their proper place.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, chs. 4, 41. Originally, Rabbi Schneur Zalman intended to arrange <i>Shaar Hayichud VehaEmunah</i> before the first part of <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>; hence the future tense. See <i>Hearot V’Tikkunim</i> (below, p. 792).</i> (The commandment of educating a child includes also [training in the performance of] the positive precepts,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., in addition to the negative precepts. Therefore we are to educate a child in the fear and love of G–d which will be the inspiration for the performance of all the commandments.</i> as is stated in <i>Orach Chaim</i>, section 343.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">See Commentators <i>ad locum</i> and Rabbi Schneur Zalman, <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, <i>Orach Chaim</i> 343:2-3.</i>)
Concerning the love [of G–d] it is written at the end of the portion <i>Ekev</i>, “Which I command you to <i>do</i> it, to love G–d….”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 11:22.</i> It is necessary to understand how an expression of doing can be applied to love, which is in the heart.
The explanation, however, is that there are two kinds of love of G–d. One is the natural<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 19.</i> yearning of the soul to its Creator. When the rational soul prevails over the grossness [of the body],<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The natural yearning of the soul can manifest itself only after the soul has freed itself of all the influences of the material body in which it is clothed. This may be attained by relinquishing all tendencies toward the gratification of gross material desires and seeking only the service of G–d.</i> subdues and subjugates it, then [the love of G–d] will flare and blaze with a flame which ascends of its own accord, and will rejoice and exult in G–d its Maker and will delight in Him with wondrous bliss. Those who merit this state of <i>ahavah rabbah</i> (“great” love) are the ones who are called <i>tzaddikim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Sing. <i>tzaddik</i>, “perfectly righteous,” one whose innate evil nature has been converted to actual goodness and who is motivated by pure love of G–d. Cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 10.</i> as it is written, “Rejoice in the L–rd, you righteous.”<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 97:12.</i> Yet, not everyone is privileged to attain this state, for it requires a very great refinement of one’s physical grossness, and in addition a great deal of Torah and good deeds in order to merit a lofty <i>neshamah</i> which is above the level of <i>ruach</i> and <i>nefesh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The human soul comprises three grades: <i>nefesh</i> (vitality), <i>ruach</i> (spirit), and <i>neshamah</i> (soul). <i>Nefesh</i> is the lowest category of the three and is the vitality and life-force of the body. <i>Ruach</i> is the spiritual faculty which vivifies man’s emotion attributes and is the seat of the moral qualities. <i>Neshamah</i> is the most lofty and sublime of the three and is the Divine force which vivifies the human intellect, as it is written, “The <i>neshamah</i> of the Almighty gives them understanding” (Job 32:8). It is the most refined innermost spark of the soul and therefore the most divine part of man’s being. <i>Nefesh</i> is granted to all men; <i>ruach</i> may be acquired through the merit of observing the precepts of the Torah; but to realize <i>neshamah</i>, one must completely purify his physical coarseness. Cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:81a, 206a; II:141b; III:70b; <i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 14:9; <i>Shaloh</i> 1, 9b.</i> as explained in <i>Reishit Chochmah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">A popular ethico-kabbalistic work by Rabbi Eliyahu de Vidas, disciple of Rabbi Moshe Cordovero; completed in 1575.</i> <i>Shaar HaAhavah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Ch. 3.</i>
The second is a love which every man can attain when he will engage in profound contemplation in the depths of his heart on matters that arouse the love of G–d which is in the heart of every Jew.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">There is an innate, hidden love in the heart of every Jew which is an inheritance to us from the Patriarchs. See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, chs. 18, 44.</i> Whether [he contemplates] in a general way—that He is our very life,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Deuteronomy 30:20.</i> and just as one loves his soul and his life, so will he love G–d when he will meditate and reflect in his heart that G–d is his true soul and actual life, as the <i>Zohar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">III:67a, 68a. See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 44.</i> comments on the verse, “[You are] my soul, I desire You;”<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 26:9.</i> or in a particular way—when he will understand and comprehend the greatness of the King of kings, the Holy One, blessed is He, in detail, to the extent that his intellect can grasp and even beyond.
Then he will contemplate G–d’s great and wondrous love to us to descend to Egypt, the “obscenity of the earth,”<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 42:9. See <i>Yalkut Shimoni</i>, ad loc.; <i>Kohelet Rabbah</i> 1:4.</i> to bring our souls out of the “iron crucible,”<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:20; I Kings 8:51; Jeremiah 11:4. This concept is more fully explained by Rabbi Schneur Zalman in <i>Torah Or</i>, <i>Yitro</i> 74a ff.</i> which is the <i>sitra achara</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., “the other side,” the opposite of holiness. A frequent metaphor in Kabbalistic and Chasidic literature to denote the forces of evil.</i> may the All-Merciful spare us, to bring us close to Him and to bind us to His very Name,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">With the Giving of the Torah on Mount Sinai, for through the Torah the souls of Israel are bound to Him; and the Torah is His Name, as it is stated in <i>Zohar</i> II:90b; III:73a; etc.</i> and He and His Name are One.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid. II:90b.</i> That is to say, He elevated us from the nadir of degradation and defilement to the acme of holiness and to His infinite greatness, blessed be He. Then, “As in water, face reflects face,”<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 27:19. “…so does the heart of man to man.” I.e., the love of one man for another awakens a loving response toward himself in the heart of his friend. How much more so will reflection upon the manifestation of G–d’s love toward us inspire love for Him.</i> love will be aroused in the heart of everyone who contemplates and meditates upon this matter in the depths of his heart—to love G–d with an intense love and to cleave to Him, heart and soul, as was explained at length in its place.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 46.</i>
It is this love which Moses, our teacher, peace unto him, wished to implant in the heart of every Jew, in the section “And now Israel…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 10:12.</i> with the verse, “Behold, the heavens belong to G–d, your L–rd<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">See below, ch. 1, n. 5.</i>…only in your fathers did He delight…you shall circumcise…with seventy souls…[Therefore] you shall love….”<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 10:14-11:1.</i> Hence he concluded his words concerning this love “Which I command you to <i>do</i> it,”<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid. 11:22.</i> which is love that is produced in the heart through the understanding and knowledge of matters which inspire love. And this he had commanded previously [in the verse]: “And these words, which I command you this day, shall be upon your heart”<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid. 6:6.</i> so that through this [meditation] you will come to love G–d, as is stated in the <i>Sifrei</i> on this verse.
Thus, there can be applied to this second type of love an expression of charge and command, namely, to devote one’s heart and mind to matters which stimulate love. However, an expression of command and charge is not at all applicable to the first kind of love which is a flame that ascends of its own accord. Furthermore, it is the reward of the <i>tzaddikim</i> to savor of the nature of the World to Come in this world. That is the meaning of the verse, “I will give you the priesthood as a service of gift,”<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 18:7. The priesthood symbolizes the state of <i>Ahavah Rabbah</i> which is granted as a Divine gift to the perfectly righteous. Hence it is within the reach of every Jew and is not limited to those born of the priestly class. Cf. Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Shemitah veYovel</i> 11:13.</i> as will be explained in its proper place.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, chs. 14, 43; <i>Iggeret Hakodesh</i>, Epistle 18.</i>
Now, those who are familiar with the esoteric meaning of Scripture know [the explanation of] the verse, “For a <i>tzaddik</i> falls seven times and rises up again.”<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 24:16. For further elaboration of this subject see Rabbi Hillel of Paritch, <i>Pelech Harimon</i>, <i>Bereishit</i>, <i>Hosafot</i> p. 302 (Kehot, 1954).</i> Especially since man is called “mobile”<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Zechariah 3:7. See also <i>Torah Or</i>, <i>Vayeshev</i> 30a-d; Rabbi Schneur Zalman, <i>Likkutei</i> <i>Torah</i>, <i>Bechukotai</i> 45a; <i>Shelach</i> 38d ff. Man has been endowed with an unrestricted capacity for spiritual progress. All other creatures have a prescribed level which they cannot surpass.</i> and not “static,” he must ascend from level to level and not remain forever at one plateau. Between one level and the next, before he can reach the higher one, he is in a state of decline from the previous level.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Pelech</i> <i>Harimon</i>, <i>loc</i>. <i>cit</i>.</i> Yet, it is written, “Though he falls, he shall not be utterly cast down.”<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 37:24.</i> It is considered a decline only in comparison with his former state, and not, G–d forbid, in comparison with all other men, for he is still above them in his service [of G–d], inasmuch as there remains in it an impression of his former state. The root of his service, however, is from the love of G–d to which he has been educated and trained from his youth before he reached the level of <i>tzaddik</i>. This, then, is the meaning of “Even when he will be old….” And the first thing which arouses love and fear, and their foundation,<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The root and foundation of the observance of all the positive and negative precepts are love and fear of G–d, as explained above. And the basis of love and fear is faith. Thus, ultimately, faith is the foundation of the observance of the commandments. See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 33.</i> is the pure and faithful belief in His Unity and Oneness, may He be blessed and exalted.





Chapter 1

SHAAR HAYICHUD VEHAEMUNAH<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Portal of Unity and Belief.</i><br><small>Let us understand [at least] in a small measure the statement in the <i>Zohar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">I:18b. The <i>Zohar</i> is the most basic Kabbalistic work consisting of the mystical interpretation of the Pentateuch. It was written by Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai in the Mishnaic period.</i> that <i>Shema Yisrael</i>…<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 6:4. “Hear, O Israel.”</i> is y<i>ichudah ilaah</i> (“higher level Unity”) and <i>Baruch Shem Kevod Malchuto Leolam Vaed</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">“Blessed be the Name of the glory of His kingdom for ever and ever.”</i> is <i>yichudah tataah</i> (“lower level Unity”).</small>
“Know this day and take to your heart that <i>Havaya</i> is <i>Elokim</i> (G–d is the L–rd)<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The Ineffable Name—the Name of four letters, Y-H-V-H—is pronounced in conversation <i>Havaya</i>. The prescribed traditional reading in Scripture and prayer is <i>Ad-nay</i>. Hence, the usual English rendition of L–rd. However, the name <i>Havaya</i> refers to G–d the Infinite, transcending creation and nature, omnipresent, omnipotent, and omniscient. Therefore, it is here translated “G–d.” The name <i>Elokim</i> emphasizes G–d’s justice and rulership (see Rashi’s commentary, Genesis 2:5, 6:2), therefore it is translated “L–rd” instead of the usual rendition of G–d. The original Hebrew readings of both names, rather than their translations, are retained throughout this text as their definition and explanation form a basic part of this treatise and are fully explained in chs. 4 and 6, below.</i> in the heavens above and upon the earth below; there is no other.”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:39.</i> This requires explanation. For would it occur to you that there is a god “soaking” in the waters beneath the earth that it is necessary to negate it so strongly [as to say,] “Take to your heart?”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">A simple negative statement would suffice to repudiate the absurd polytheistic notion of a deity inhabiting the waters. Obviously, the emphasis upon the importance of meditation and contemplation that “there is no other” points to a rejection of something far more subtle. The answer to this question will be found in ch. 6. The first five chapters give the reader sufficient background to understand it.</i>
It is written: “Forever, O L–rd, Your word stands firm in the heavens.”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 119:89.</i> The Baal Shem Tov,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Yisrael Baal Shem Tov (1698-1760), founder of the Chasidic movement.</i> of blessed memory, has explained that “Your word” which you uttered, “Let there be a firmament in the midst of the waters…,”<sup class="footnote-marker"> 10</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 1:6.</i> these very words and letters<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the Divine creating forces which bring everything into existence <i>ex nihilo</i>. See below, ch. 11, for a full explanation of this concept. See also <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, chs. 20-22.</i> stand firmly forever within the firmament of heaven and are forever clothed within all the heavens to give them life, as it is written, “The word of our G–d shall stand firm forever”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 40:8.</i> and “His words live and stand firm forever….”<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Liturgy, Morning Prayer, Blessing after the Shema.</i> For if the letters were to depart [even] for an instant, G–d forbid, and return to their source, all the heavens would become naught and absolute nothingness, and it would be as though they had never existed at all, exactly as before the utterance, “Let there be a firmament.”
And so it is with all created things, in all the upper and lower worlds, and even this physical earth, which is the realm of the silent (inanimate).<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Life on our earth is generally classified into four “realms”: <i>Domem—</i>the “silent,” inanimate world, such as water, earth, etc.; <i>Tzomeach—</i>vegetable or plant life; <i>Chai—</i>living or animal life; <i>Medaber—</i>the speaking or human realm.</i> If the letters of the Ten Utterances<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"> <i> Avot</i> 5:1. “The world was created by means of Ten Utterances.” In the narration of the Creation in the first chapter of Genesis, the words “And G–d said, Let…,” occur nine times. The first word of the chapter, <i>Bereishit</i> (In the beginning), indicates the first Divine utterance of command which created the heavens, as it is written, “By the <i>word</i> of G–d the <i>heavens</i> were <i>made”</i> (Psalms 33:6). Cf. <i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 32a; <i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 17:1; commentaries on <i>Avot</i>, <i>ad locum</i>. See also <i>Maharsha</i>, <i>Rosh Hashanah</i>, loc. cit.</i> by which the earth was created during the Six Days of Creation were to depart from it [but] for an instant, G–d forbid, it would revert to naught and absolute nothingness, exactly as before the Six Days of Creation.
This same thought was expressed by the Arizal<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Yitzchak Luria Ashkenazi, of blessed memory (1534-1572)—in <i>Etz Chaim</i>, <i>Shaar Man U’Mad</i>, Section 3.</i> when he said that even in completely inanimate matter, such as stones or earth or water, there is a soul and spiritual life-force—that is, the enclothing of the “Letters of speech”<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">In contrast to the Divine “letters of thought” from which the “hidden” supernal worlds come into being. See below, ch. 11.</i> of the Ten Utterances which give life and existence to inanimate matter that it might arise out of the naught and nothingness which preceded the Six Days of Creation.
Now, although the name <i>even</i> (stone) is not mentioned in the Ten Utterances recorded in the Torah, nevertheless, life-force flows to the stone through combinations and substitutions of the letters which are transposed in the “two hundred and thirty-one gates,”<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Phrase used to denote the doctrine of “combination of letters” in all its aspects. Specifically, it refers to the arrangement of the twenty-two letters of the Hebrew alphabet in two-lettered combinations which yield a total of 462 combinations (22 x 21). Of these, half are the exact reverse of the other half, e.g., אב—בא, גד—דג. Hence, there are 231 two-lettered combinations in direct order and the same number in reverse order. Combinations of groups of three or more letters would, of course, yield a greater number of combinations. Combining the letters in this way involves only the arrangement of the same letters in a different order. According to certain systematic rules, the twenty-two letters may be interchanged and substituted one for another (see below, ch. 7, note 3), and they may subsequently be arranged in various combinations. Thus, the number of combinations is incalculable and gives rise to the multitudinous profusion of created beings.</i> either in direct or reverse order, as is explained in the <i>Sefer Yetzirah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Ch. 2:4-5. <i>Sefer Yetzirah</i> is one of the oldest Kabbalistic works.</i> until the combination of the name <i>even</i> descends<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">When rearranging the letters of any word into a new combination, the original thought is obscured. Similarly the rearrangements of the supernal letters into a new combination constitutes concealment and diminution of the original vitality and life-force. Since the name <i>even</i> (like all other things not mentioned in the account of creation) is a new combination of the letters of the Ten Utterances, it is on a lower level than those specifically mentioned in the process of creation. This is what is meant by the “descent” of a combination.</i> from the Ten Utterances, and is derived from them, and this is the life-force of the stone.
And so it is with all created things in the world—their names in the Holy Tongue are the very “letters of speech” which descend, degree by degree, from the Ten Utterances recorded in the Torah, by means of substitutions and transpositions of letters through the “two hundred and thirty-one gates,” until they reach and become invested in that particular created thing to give it life.
[This descent is necessary] because individual creatures are not capable of receiving their life-force directly from the Ten Utterances of the Torah, for the life-force issuing directly from them is far greater than the capacity of the individual creatures. They can receive the life-force only when it descends and is progressively diminished, degree by degree, by means of substitutions and transpositions of the letters and by <i>gematriot</i>, their numerical values,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Each Hebrew letter has its own numerical value, e.g., א equals 1, ב equals 2, and so forth. <i>Gematria</i> is the calculation of the numerical values of Hebrew words—for example, אחד equals 13. <i>Gematria</i> represents an even greater descent and diminution of the light and life-force than the combination, substitution, etc., of the Divine letters, for here the relationship between the two words is only a numerical one. See below, end ch. 7.</i> until the life-force can be condensed and enclothed and there can be brought forth from it a particular creature.
And the name by which it is called in the Holy Tongue is a vessel for the life-force<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Thus, a name is not merely an arbitrary method of distinguishing one person or object from another but is actually related to one’s soul. This elucidates the statement in the Talmud (<i>Yoma</i> 83b, <i>Tanchuma</i> <i>Hakadum</i>, <i>Bereishit</i> 30) that Rabbi Meir recognized the character and nature of a person merely by knowing his name. For further explanation see <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Behar</i> 41c; <i>Mayim Rabbim 5636</i>, ch. 22; <i>Sefer Hamaamarim 5708</i>, pp. 154-7.</i> condensed into the letters of that name which has descended from the Ten Utterances in the Torah that have power and vitality to create being <i>ex nihilo</i> and give it life forever. For the Torah and the Holy One, blessed is He, are one.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:240; II:60a. See also <i>Tikkunim</i> 6, 22. This is more fully explained by the author in <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, chs. 23, 24.</i>

Chapter 2

From the foregoing [exposition] the answer to the heretics [is deduced], and the root of the error of those who deny individual Divine providence and the signs and miracles recorded in the Torah is revealed. They err, making a false analogy, in comparing the work of G–d, the Creator of heaven and earth, to the work of man and his schemes. For, when a goldsmith has made a vessel, that vessel is no longer dependent upon the smith, and even when his hands are removed from it and he goes away, the vessel remains in exactly the same image and form as when it left the hands of the smith. In the same way, these fools conceive the creation of heaven and earth.
But their eyes are covered [and they fail] to see the great difference between the work of man and his schemes—which consists of making one thing out of another which already exists,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">In Hebrew: <i>yesh mi-yesh</i>.</i> merely changing the form and appearance from an ingot of silver to a vessel—and the making of heaven and earth, which is <i>creatio ex nihilo</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">In Hebrew: <i>yesh me-ayin</i>.</i>
Indeed, this is an even greater miracle than, for example, the splitting of the Red Sea. For then, G–d drove back the sea by a strong east wind all the night and the waters were divided and stood upright as a wall.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 14:21-22; 15:8.</i> If G–d had stopped the wind, the waters would have instantly flowed downward, as is their way and nature, and undoubtedly they would not have stood upright as a wall, even though this nature of water [to flow downward] is also created <i>ex nihilo</i>, for a stone wall stands erect by itself without [the assistance of] the wind, but the nature of water is not so.
[Thus, if for the miracle of the splitting of the Red Sea the continuous action of G–d was necessary] how much more so is it in the creation of being out of nothing which transcends nature and is far more miraculous than the splitting of the Red Sea, that with the withdrawal of the power of the Creator from the thing created, G–d forbid, it would revert to naught and complete nonexistence. Rather, the Activating Force of the Creator must <i>continuously</i> be in the thing created to give it life and existence. [These Forces] are the “letters of speech” of the Ten Utterances by which [beings] were created.
And that is the meaning of the verse: ואתה מחי' את כולם.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>VeAtah mechaye et kulam</i>, “And You give life to them all.” Nehemiah 9:6.</i> Read not מחי', give life, but מהוה, bring into being, i.e., <i>ex nihilo</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the life-force which in every created being not only gives it life and vivifies it, but continuously brings it into existence <i>ex nihilo</i>. The verse is thus interpreted, for the phrase “to give life” does not necessarily imply “to create,” as, for example, the soul which gives life to and vivifies the body, yet does not bring it into being. Whereas in Creation the life-force not only vivifies but also creates and must continuously flow into the created being, for without it, it would revert to nothingness. By giving life, He actually creates it <i>ex nihilo</i>. Hence, He constantly renews the existence of the world and all the creatures, creating them anew from nothing at every moment, just as at the beginning of Creation. So, in reality “to give life” and to “bring into being” are identical. See <i>Pardes</i>, <i>Shaar</i> 6, ch. 8; <i>Reishit Chochmah</i>, <i>Shaar HaKedushah</i>, end of ch. 7; <i>Shaloh</i>, <i>Shaar HaOtiot</i> 48b, 70a.</i> The word אתה, You, indicates all the letters from <i>alef</i> to <i>tav</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">The letter <i>alef</i> is the first and <i>tav</i> is the last of the letters in the Hebrew alphabet.</i> and the letter <i>hey</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The numerical value of <i>hey</i> is 5. See above, ch. 1, note 21.</i> the five organs of verbal articulation,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the larynx, palate, tongue, teeth, and lips.</i> the sources of the letters.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">The meaning of this verse is that “You” create, i.e., the Divine power which issues through the twenty-two letters of the alphabet, indicated in the word <i>Atah</i>. For there could not emerge from G–d, the Infinite, a limited and finite world.</i>
Although He has no bodily likeness<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah</i> 1:7-12; <i>Hilchot Teshuvah</i> 3:7; Commentary on <i>Mishnayot</i>, <i>Sanhedrin</i>, ch. 10.</i> yet, Scripture itself ascribes to Him [anthropomorphic terms<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">See below, beginning ch. 10.</i> such as] “And G–d spoke” or “And G–d said,” which denote the revelation of the twenty-two Supernal Letters to the Prophets and the enclothing [of the letters] in their intellect and comprehension in the prophetic vision, as well as in their thought and speech, as it is written, “The spirit of G–d spoke in me, and His word is upon my tongue,”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 23:2.</i> as has been explained by the Arizal<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Yitzchak Luria Ashkenazi, of blessed memory (1534-1572).</i> [in <i>Shaar Hanevuah</i>].
Similar to this is the investment of the letters in created things—as it is written, “By the word of G–d were the heavens made, and by the breath of His mouth all their host”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 33:6.</i>—the difference being that [the enclothing of the letters in created beings] is through numerous and powerful descents until [the letters] reach the corporeal [world of] <i>Asiyah</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">World of Action, our physical world—the lowest of all worlds. It is the final stage in the progressive diminution and concealment of the creative force of the Ten Utterances.</i> whereas the comprehension of the Prophets is in [the world of] <i>Atzilut</i><sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">World of Emanation, the highest spiritual world. It is in a state of unity and proximity with G–d and hence transcends human understanding. It is not a new creation, but only the revelation of the previously concealed.</i> as it becomes clothed in the world of <i>Beriah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">World of Creation, the first creation <i>ex nihilo</i>. It is finite and receives only a radiance of the infinite light of <i>Atzilut</i>, and it may therefore be apprehended by the human mind. Since <i>Atzilut</i> is united with G–d, it is above even prophetic vision until it is veiled and obscured by <i>Beriah</i>. This is still infinitely higher than the light of <i>Beriah</i> itself.</i>

Chapter 3

Now, following these words and the truth [concerning the nature of the Creation], every intelligent person will understand clearly that each creature and being is actually considered naught and absolute nothingness in relation to the Activating Force and the “breath of His mouth”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"> Allusion to Psalms 33:6, quoted above. This does not negate the reality of the universe or imply that the physical world is illusory. What is meant here is that the world does not possess <i>independent</i> existence; its true reality is the Divine force which continuously brings it into being.</i> which is in the created thing, continuously calling it into existence and bringing it from absolute nonbeing into being.
The reason that all things created and activated appear to us as existing<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., self-subsisting.</i> and tangible is that we do not comprehend nor see with our physical eyes the power of G–d and the “breath of His mouth” which is in the created thing. If, however, the eye were permitted to see<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">In the Time to Come, however, even man’s corporeal eyes will see G–dliness and the Divine force in every created thing. See Isaiah 40:5, 52:8; <i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 31a. <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Bechukotai</i> 47c; <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 37.</i> and to comprehend the life-force and spirituality which is in every created thing, flowing into it from “that which proceeds out of the mouth of G–d”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 8:3; cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:47b.</i> and “His breath,” then the materiality, grossness, and tangibility of the creature would not be seen by our eyes at all, for it is completely nullified in relation to the life-force and the spirituality which is within it, since without the spirituality it would be naught and absolute nothingness, exactly as before the Six Days of Creation. The spirituality which flows into it from “that which proceeds out of the mouth of G–d” and “His breath”—that alone continuously brings it forth from naught and nullity into being and gives it existence. Hence, there is truly nothing besides Him.
An illustration of this is the light of the sun which illumines the earth and its inhabitants. [This illumination] is the radiance and the light which spreads forth from the body of the sun and is visible to all as it gives light to the earth and the expanse of the universe. Now, it is self-evident that this light and radiance is also present in the very body and matter of the sun-globe itself in the sky, for if it can spread forth and shine to such a great distance, then certainly it can shed light in its own place. However, there in its own place, this radiance is considered naught and complete nothingness, for it is absolutely nonexistent in relation to the body of the sun-globe which is the source of this light and radiance, inasmuch as this radiance and light is merely the illumination which shines from the body of the sun-globe itself. It is only in the space of the universe, under the heavens and on the earth, where the body of the sun-globe is not present, that this light and radiance appears to the eye to have actual existence. And here, the term <i>yesh</i> (“existence”) can truly be applied to it, whereas when it is in its source, in the body of the sun, the term <i>yesh</i> (“existence”) cannot be applied to it at all, and it can only be called naught and nonexistent. There it is indeed naught and absolutely nonexistent, for there, only its source, the body of the sun, gives light, and there is nothing besides it.
The exact parallel to this illustration is the relationship between all created things and the Divine flow [of the life-force] from the “breath of His mouth,” which flows upon them and brings them into existence. G–d is their source, and they themselves are merely like a diffusing light and effulgence from the flow and spirit of G–d, which issues forth and becomes clothed in them and brings them from naught into being. Hence, their existence is nullified in relation to their source, just as the light of the sun is nullified and is considered naught and complete nothingness and is not [even] referred to as “existing” at all when it is in its source; only beneath the heavens, where its source is not present [can it be called “existing”]. In the same manner, the term <i>yesh</i> (“existence”) can be applied to all created things only [as they appear] to our corporeal eyes, for we do not see nor comprehend at all the source, which is the spirit of G–d, that brings them into existence. Therefore, it appears to our eyes that the materiality, grossness, and tangibility of the created things actually exist, just as the light of the sun appears to have actual existence when it is not within its source.
But in the following, the illustration is apparently not completely identical with the object of comparison. For in the illustration, the source [the sun] is not present at all in the space of the universe and upon the earth where its light is seen as actually existing. Whereas, all created things are always within their source, and it is only that the source is not visible to our physical eyes. [If so], why are they not nullified in their source? To understand this, some prefatory remarks are necessary.

Chapter 4

It is written: “For a sun and a shield is <i>Havaya Elokim</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 84:12.</i> The explanation of this verse [is as follows]: “Shield” is a covering for the sun, to protect the creatures so that they should be able to bear [its heat]. As our Sages, of blessed memory, have said, “In the Time to Come,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the Messianic Era.</i> the Holy One, blessed is He, will take out the sun from its sheath, the wicked will be punished by it….”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nedarim</i> 8b.</i> Now, just as the covering shields [i.e., conceals] the sun, so does the name <i>Elokim</i> shield [i.e., conceal] the name <i>Havaya</i>, blessed is He.
The meaning of the name <i>Havaya</i> is “That which brings everything into existence <i>ex nihilo</i>.” The prefix י [added to the stem הוה] modifies the verb, indicating that the action is present and continuous—as Rashi<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Acronym for Rabbi Shlomo Yitzchaki, the most famous biblical and Talmudic commentator.</i> comments on the verse, “In this manner does Job do יעשה all the days”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Job 1:5.</i>—i.e., the life-force which flows at every instant into all things created, from “that which proceeds out of the mouth of G–d” and “His breath,” and brings them into existence <i>ex nihilo</i> at <i>every moment</i>. For the fact that they were created during the Six Days of Creation is not sufficient for their continued existence, as explained above.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Ch. 2.</i>
In the enumeration of the praises of the Holy One, blessed is He, it is written, “<i>Hagadol</i>” (the Great), “<i>Hagibor</i>”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 10:17; Liturgy, <i>Amidah</i> Prayer.</i> (the Mighty), and the like. “<i>Hagadol</i>” refers to the attribute of <i>chesed</i> (kindness) and the spreading forth of the life-force into all the worlds and created things without end or limit<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">The characteristic of <i>chesed</i> is to bestow boundlessly.</i> so that they shall be created <i>ex nihilo</i> and exist through <i>chesed chinom</i> (gratuitous kindness). And [the attribute of <i>chesed</i>] is called <i>gedulah</i> (greatness) for it comes from the greatness of the Holy One, blessed is He, in His Glory and Essence, for “G–d is great and His greatness is unsearchable,”<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 145:3.</i> and therefore, He also causes life-force and existence <i>ex nihilo</i> to issue forth for an unlimited number of worlds and creatures, for “It is the nature of the beneficient to do good.”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Chacham Tzvi</i> (Responsa) 18, by Rabbi Tzvi Hirsch ben Yaakov Ashkenazi; <i>Shomer Emunim</i> 2, 14, by Rabbi Yosef Irgas, quoting the Kabbalists.</i>
Now, this attribute [of <i>chesed</i>] is the praise of the Holy One, blessed is He, alone, for no created thing can create a being out of naught and give it life.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">“Even if all mankind were to gather, they could not create even a small mosquito and vivify it” (<i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 39:14).</i> This attribute is also beyond the cognition of all creatures and their understanding. For it is not within the power of the intellect of any creature to understand and comprehend this quality and its ability to create a being out of nothing and vivify it. For <i>creatio ex nihilo</i> is a matter which transcends the intellect of the creatures inasmuch as it stems from the Divine attribute of <i>gedulah</i>. And the Holy One, blessed is He, and His attributes are a perfect unity, as the Holy <i>Zohar</i> states, “He and His attributes are One,”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction. Cf. <i>Iggeret Hakodesh</i>, Epistle 20.</i> and just as it is not possible for any creature’s mind to comprehend his Creator, so it is impossible for him to comprehend His attributes.
And just as it is impossible for any creature’s mind to apprehend His attribute of <i>gedulah</i>, which is the ability to create a being out of nothing and give it life, as it is written, “The world is built by kindness,”<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 89:3.</i> exactly so it is not possible for him to apprehend the Divine attribute of <i>gevurah</i> (might, restraint), which is the quality of <i>tzimtzum</i> (condensation, contraction, concentration) and restraint of the spreading forth of the life-force from His [attribute of] <i>gedulah</i> preventing it from descending upon and manifesting itself to the creatures, to give them life and existence in a revealed manner, but rather with His Countenance concealed.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 22.</i> For the life-force conceals itself in the body of the created being and [it appears] as though the body of the created being has independent existence and is not [merely] a spreading forth of the life-force and spirituality—as the diffusion of the radiation and light from the sun—but an independently existing entity.
Although, in reality, it has no independent existence, and is only like the diffusion of the light from the sun, nevertheless, this [concealment] is the very restraining power of the Holy One, blessed is He, Who is Omnipotent, to condense the life-force and spirituality which issues from the “breath of His mouth” and to conceal it, so that the body of the created being shall not become nullified.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The vitality emanating from <i>chesed</i> is too abundant and powerful for finite creatures to exist without its concealment and contraction.</i>
And it is not within the scope of the intellect of any creature to comprehend the essential nature of the <i>tzimtzum</i> and concealment [of the life-force] and that nonetheless the body of the creature be created <i>ex nihilo</i>—just as it is not within the capacity of any creature’s intellect to comprehend the essential nature of the creation of being out of nothing.
[The <i>tzimtzum</i> and concealing of the life-force is called <i>kelim</i> (“vessels”) and the life-force itself is called “light.”<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kelim</i> and light together comprise the <i>sefirot</i>. They are, respectively, the finite and infinite aspects of the <i>sefirot</i>. The <i>kelim</i> limit the infinite light, causing it to be revealed in proportion to the capacity of the finite beings. The <i>kelim</i>, then, perform the function of concealing and at the same time revealing the Divine light.</i> For just as a vessel covers that which is within it, so does the <i>tzimtzum</i> cover and conceal the light and the flowing life-force. And the <i>kelim</i> are the [Divine] letters<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">In the same way, letters serve to reveal thought, yet at the same time limit it. For speech cannot convey all that is in the mind of the thinker.</i> whose roots are the five [terminal] letters מנצפ"ך, which are the five restraining forces<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">These five letters terminate a word, and no other letters may follow them. Inasmuch as this is an act of limitation, it is an act of <i>gevurah</i>.</i> that divide and separate the breath and voice in the five organs of speech, in order that the twenty-two letters shall be formed. The source of the five restraining forces is <i>botzinah d’kardunita</i> “(light from dark”)<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., light which has been condensed and concealed through <i>tzimtzum</i>. It is the supernal limiting force which determines the quantity and quality of light and life-force in each world, <i>sefirah</i> and being—thereby imposing all the limitations and differentiations inherent in Creation.</i> which is the supernal <i>gevurah</i> of <i>atik yomin</i> (“ancient of days”);<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">The realm which transcends all worlds, including <i>Atzilut</i>.</i> and the source of the kindnesses is also <i>chesed</i> of <i>atik yomin</i>, as is known to the students of Kabbalah.]<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets are the author’s.</i>

Chapter 5

Concerning this our Sages of blessed memory said, “Originally it arose in [G–d’s] thought to create the world with the attribute of stern judgement;<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., with the attribute of <i>tzimtzum</i>, complete concealment of the Divine light. Judgment signifies an act of negation and an imposition of limits. Therefore, in Kabbalah it is a synonym for <i>tzimtzum</i> and <i>gevurah</i>.</i> He saw, however, that the world could not endure, [so] He combined with it the attribute of mercy,”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"> <i>Rashi</i>, Genesis 1:1. See <i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 12:15; <i>Pesikta Rabbati</i> 40:2.</i> that is, the revelation of G–dliness through the <i>tzaddikim</i> and the signs and miracles recorded in the Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Miracles are evidence of G–d’s “hand” in nature and demonstrate that He is the Master of all; all cosmic and natural powers are subservient to Him.</i>
And regarding this, it was stated in the <i>Zohar</i>, “Above, in the ‘side of supernal holiness,’ there is right and left,” namely, <i>chesed</i> and <i>gevurah</i>. This means that both are attributes of G–dliness, above the intellect and comprehension of the creatures, for “He and His attributes are One in the world of <i>Atzilut</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction.</i> Even the comprehension of Moses, our teacher, peace unto him, in his prophetic vision, was not in the world <i>of Atzilut</i> [itself], but only as it [<i>Atzilut</i>] becomes clothed in the world of <i>Beriah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See above, ch. 2, note 16.</i> and even then, was not of these two attributes, <i>chesed</i> and <i>gevurah</i>, but only as they become clothed in attributes which are of lower levels than they, viz., the attributes of <i>netzach</i> (victory, eternity), <i>hod</i> (majesty), <i>yesod</i> (foundation)<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Iggeret Hakodesh</i>, Epistle 15.</i> [as is explained in <i>Shaar Hanevuah</i>].<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets are the author’s.</i>
It is only the <i>tzaddikim</i> in <i>Gan Eden</i> who are granted the reward of comprehending the spreading forth of the life-force and light which issues from these two attributes, <i>chesed</i> and <i>gevurah</i>. And this [comprehension] is the “food”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Just as food is absorbed by the body and transformed into flesh and blood, so is the light of <i>Atzilut</i> comprehended and absorbed by the soul and united with it. This Divine light is the “food” or inner life of the soul. Cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 5.</i> of the souls of the <i>tzaddikim</i> who, in this world, occupied themselves with the study of Torah for its own sake.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">From pure and disinterested motives—to fulfill G–d’s command—and not for the purpose of reward or self-aggrandisement. In <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ibid., it is interpreted as “study with the intent to attach one’s soul to G–d through the comprehension of the Torah, each one according to his intellect.”</i> For from the spreading forth of these two attributes, a firmament<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shamayim</i>, the Hebrew word for heaven, is a combination of <i>esh</i> (fire) and <i>mayim</i> (water) which symbolize <i>gevurah</i> and c<i>hesed</i> respectively.</i> is spread over the souls in <i>Gan Eden</i>, and this firmament is called <i>razah d’oraytah</i> (“the secret of the Torah”). In it is the secret of the twenty-two letters of the Torah which was given from these two attributes, as it is written, “From His right hand He gave them a fiery Law.”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:2. “Right hand” indicates <i>chesed</i>, “fiery” indicates <i>gevurah</i>. It was necessary for the Torah, whose source is <i>chesed</i>—i.e., the issuing forth of the infinite light—to descend and become condensed through <i>tzimtzum</i> and <i>gevurah</i> until it could become clothed in the corporeal, material things of this world and could be comprehended and fulfilled by created beings. Cf. <i>Iggeret Hakodesh</i>, Epistle 10.</i> And from this firmament drops dew<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">The Torah is likened to dew (See Deuteronomy 32:2), which symbolizes the esoteric aspect of the Torah.</i> as “food” for the souls, i.e., the knowledge of the secret of the twenty-two letters of the Torah. For this firmament is the “secret of knowledge,” and the Torah is the “food” of the souls in <i>Gan Eden</i>; and the precepts are “garments” [of the souls], <sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The soul, being finite and limited, could not comprehend the light of <i>Atzilut</i>, which is infinite and beyond comprehension. The precepts serve as “garments” of the soul and veil and screen the infinite light so that it can be comprehended and absorbed by the soul, as, for example, one looks at a brilliant light through a veil. Cf. <i>Iggeret Hakodesh</i>, Epistle 29.</i> as all this is explained [in <i>Zohar Vayakhel</i>, pp. 209-210 and in <i>Etz Chaim</i>, <i>Shaar</i> 44, ch. 3].<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets are the author’s.</i>

Chapter 6

Now, the name <i>Elokim</i> is the name which indicates the attribute of <i>gevurah</i> and <i>tzimtzum</i>, hence it is also numerically equal to <i>hateva</i><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The numerical value of each word is 86. <i>Pardes</i>, <i>Shaar</i> 12, ch. 2. See also <i>Shaloh</i>, <i>Shaar HaOtiot</i>, 89a.</i> (nature), for it [<i>Elokim</i>] <i>conceals</i> the supernal light which brings the world into existence and gives it life, and it appears as though the world exists and conducts itself in a natural way.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., according to fixed, immutable laws, in no way dependent upon or influenced by anything supernatural. Divinity is not readily evident in nature.</i> And this name <i>Elokim</i> is a shield and a covering for the name <i>Havaya</i>, to conceal the light and life-force which flows from the name <i>Havaya</i> and brings creation into existence from naught, so that it [the light and life-force] should not be revealed to the creatures, who thereby would become absolutely nullified.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Since the light and life-force is too abundant and powerful for finite creatures to exist without its concealment and contraction.</i>
This quality of <i>gevurah</i> and <i>tzimtzum</i> is also a quality of <i>chesed</i> for through it [<i>tzimtzum</i> and <i>gevurah</i>] the world is built. And this is the quality of <i>gevurah</i> which is included in <i>chesed</i>.
From the inclusion of the attributes one in the other, it is evident that “He and His attributes are One,” for since they are in a complete unity with Him, they therefore unite with each other and are comprised of each other.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The attributes, or <i>sefirot</i>, are interconnected with each other and function harmoniously together. They are also mutually inclusive—each attribute contains all the others—and are differentiated only by the predominance of the particular quality which gives each its name. Cf. <i>Pardes</i>, <i>Shaar</i> 8, ch. 2.</i> As Elijah said, “You are He who binds [the attributes] together and unites them…; and aside from You there is no unity among those above….”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction.</i>
This, then, is the meaning of that which is written “And take to your heart that <i>Havaya</i> is <i>Elokim</i>”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:39. Here follows the answer to the question raised above, beginning of ch. 1.</i>—that is, these two names are <i>actually one</i>, for even the name <i>Elokim</i>, which contracts and conceals the light, is a quality of <i>chesed</i>, just as the name <i>Havaya</i>. For the attributes of the Holy One, blessed is He, unite with Him in a complete unity, and “He and His Name are One,”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> II:19b.</i> for His attributes are His Names.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">The attributes correspond to the specific Names of G–d, namely—<i>Havaya</i> corresponds to kindness and mercy, <i>Elokim</i> to might, <i>Ad-nay</i> to sovereignty, etc. Cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:10b, 11a.</i>
Since this is so, you will consequently know that “In the heavens above and on the earth below, <i>en od</i>—there is nothing else [besides G–d].”<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy, ibid. Thus, the unity of G–d does not mean only that there are no other gods, but that there is nothing apart from Him, i.e., there is no existence whatsoever apart from His existence; the whole Creation is nullified within Him as the rays of the sun within the orb of the sun. This is the meaning of y<i>ichudah ilaah</i> (higher level Unity), which will be further explained in ch. 7, below.</i> This means that even the material earth, which appears to the eyes of all to be actually existing, is naught and complete nothingness in relation to the Holy One, blessed is He. For the name <i>Elokim</i> conceals and contracts [the light and life-force] only for the lower [creatures], but not for the Holy One, blessed is He, since He and His Name <i>Elokim</i> are One. Therefore, even the earth and that which is below it are naught and complete nothingness in relation to the Holy One, blessed is He, and are not called by any name at all, not even the name <i>od</i> (else) which is an expression indicating a secondary, subordinate status, as the statement of our Sages of blessed memory, “<i>Yehudah v’od likrah</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kiddushin</i> 6a. In English: “Does a verse in the Torah require additional or secondary substantiation from the customs of the Land of Judah?”</i> [unlike] the body which is subordinate to the soul and life-force within it [and is referred to as <i>od</i>]. [And this is the meaning of the verse: “I will praise <i>Havaya</i> with my life (soul) and will sing to <i>Elokim be’odi</i>”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 146:3.</i> (with my body). For the soul is derived from the name <i>Havaya</i> and the <i>od</i>, which is the body, the subordinate (of the soul), from the name <i>Elokim</i>.]<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets are the author’s.</i> For the soul does not bring the body into existence <i>ex nihilo</i>, [hence it can be called <i>od</i> in relation to the soul], but the Holy One, blessed is He, Who brings everything into existence <i>ex nihilo</i>—everything is absolutely nullified in relation to Him, just as the light of the sun [is nullified] in the sun.
Therefore, it was necessary for Scripture to warn, “And know this day and take to your heart…,” <sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy, ibid.</i> so that it should not enter your mind that the heavens and all their host and the earth and all therein are separate entities in themselves, and that the Holy One, blessed is He, fills the whole world—in the same way as the soul is invested in the body, causing the flow of the vegetative force into the earth, and the force of motion into the celestial spheres, moving them and directing them according to His Will—just as the soul moves the body and directs it according to its will.
In truth, however, the analogy bears no similarity whatsoever to the object of comparison since the soul and the body are actually separate from each other in their very sources. The source of the body and its essence comes into being not from the soul, but from the seed of his father and mother, and even afterward, his growth is not from the soul alone, but through his mother’s eating and drinking all the nine months [of gestation], and subsequently through his own eating and drinking. This is not so, however, in the case of heaven and earth, for their very being and essence was brought into existence from naught and absolute nothingness, solely through the “word of G–d” and the “breath of His mouth,” blessed be He. And the word of G–d still stands forever [in all created things], and flows into them continuously at every instant and continuously brings them into existence from nothing, just as, for example, the coming into existence of the light from the sun within the very globe of the sun. Hence, in reality, they [heaven and earth] are completely nullified in relation to the “word of G–d” and the “breath of His mouth,” blessed be He, which are unified with His Essence and Being, blessed be He, as will be explained later,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Below, ch. 7.</i> just as the light of the sun is nullified in the sun.
Yet these are His restraining powers, to hide and conceal, through the attribute of <i>gevurah</i> and <i>tzimtzum</i>, the life-force which flows into them, so that heaven and earth and all their hosts should appear as if they were independently existing entities. However, the <i>tzimtzum</i> and concealment is only for the lower [worlds], but in relation to the Holy One, blessed is He, “everything before Him is considered as actually naught,”<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:11b.</i> just as the light of the sun in the sun. And the attribute of <i>gevurah</i> does not, Heaven forfend, conceal for Him, blessed be He, for it is not an independent entity—since <i>Havaya</i> is <i>Elokim</i>.

Chapter 7

With the above in mind, we may now understand<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Schneur Zalman here returns to elucidate the opening statement of the treatise.</i> the statement in the holy <i>Zohar</i>, that the verse <i>Shema Yisrael</i> is <i>yichudah ilaah</i> (“higher level Unity”), and <i>Baruch Shem Kevod Malchuto Leolam Vaed</i> is <i>yichudah tataah</i> (“lower level Unity”).<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:18b.</i> For <i>Vaed</i> is <i>Echad</i> through the substitution of letters.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:134a. According to the rules of Hebrew grammar, the letters in the alphabet are divided into various groups, i.e., according to their source in the organs of speech; the letters in each group are interchangeable. The letters <i>alef</i>, <i>hey</i>, <i>vav</i>, and <i>yud</i> fall into one group. Therefore, <i>alef</i> may be interchanged with <i>vav</i>. The letters <i>alef</i>, <i>chet</i>, <i>hey</i>, and <i>ayin</i> fall into another category. Thus, <i>chet</i> may be interchanged with <i>ayin</i>. Hence <i>echod</i> becomes <i>vaed</i>.</i>
The cause and reason for this <i>tzimtzum</i> and concealment that the Holy One, blessed is He, obscured and hid the life-force of the world to make the world appear as an independently existing entity [is as follows]: It is known to all that the purpose of the creation of the world is for the sake of the revelation of His kingdom, blessed be He, for “there is no King without a nation.”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer Hachaim</i>, <i>Geulah</i>, ch. 2; <i>Emek HaMelech</i>, <i>Shaar HaMitzvot</i>, beginning of ch. 1; <i>Rabbenu Bachya</i>, <i>Vayeshev</i> 38:2. Cf. <i>Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer</i>, ch. 3.</i> The word <i>am</i> (nation) is related etymologically to the word <i>ommemot</i> (concealed, dimmed),<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Rashi</i>, Judges 5:14. The nature of kingship requires the separation and concealment of the king from his subjects. He must stand aloof from them, or the relationship of sovereignty is destroyed. In the same way, the Infinite concealed Himself, and the world appears as a separate and independent entity; thus, He can exercise sovereignty over it.</i> for they are separate entities, distinct and distant from the level of the king. For, even if the king had very many sons, the name kingdom would not apply to them, nor even to nobles alone. Only “In a multitude of <i>people</i> is the glory of the king.”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 14:28.</i>
The name which indicates the attribute of His <i>malchut</i> (kingship, royalty), blessed be He, is the name <i>Adnut</i> (L–rdship), for He is the “L–rd of the whole earth.”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 3:11, 13.</i> Thus, it is this attribute and this Name which bring into existence and sustain the world so that it should be as it is now, a completely independent and separate entity, and not absolutely nullified. For with the withdrawal of this attribute and this Name, G–d forbid, the world would revert to its source in the “word of G–d” and the “breath of His mouth” and would be completely nullified there, and the name “world” could not be applied to it at all.
The term “world” can be applied solely to that which possesses the dimensions of space and time; “space” referring to east, west, north, and south, upward and downward, and “time” to past, present, and future.
All these dimensions have no relation to the holy supernal attributes.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the nine higher attributes, or <i>sefirot</i>. <i>Malchut</i> is the tenth and lowest attribute. See below, ch. 9, n. 7.</i> Only concerning the attribute of His <i>malchut</i>, blessed be He, is it possible to say that He, blessed be He, is King “above without end and below without limit,” and likewise in all four directions. The same is true concerning the dimensions of time, [as it is written,] “G–d reigns, G–d reigned, and G–d will reign.”<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, Morning Prayer. The quotation is a combination of Psalms 93:1, Ibid. 10:16, Exodus 15:18.</i> Thus, the life-force of space, and likewise of time, and their coming into being from nothingness,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Time is a creation <i>ex nihilo</i>, for it depends on the motion of created things; whatever is inseparable from things created must likewise be created. Cf. <i>Moreh Nevuchim</i> 2, ch. 13. Furthermore, time, which is divisible into finite parts, e.g., seconds, minutes, etc., cannot be infinite, for Infinity is indivisible. Since it is finite, it must be created <i>ex nihilo</i>. See <i>Derech Mitzvotecha</i> 57a-b.</i> and their existence as long as they shall exist, is from the attribute of His <i>malchut</i>, blessed be He, and the name <i>Adnut</i>, blessed is He.
Now, since the attribute of His <i>malchut</i>, blessed be He, is united with His Essence and Being in an absolute union, as will be explained,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Below, ch. 8.</i> therefore, space and time are also completely nullified in relation to His Essence and Being, blessed be He, as the light of the sun is nullified in the sun.
And this is the [meaning of] the intertwining of the [letters of the] name <i>Adnut</i> with the [letters of the] name <i>Havaya</i>. The name <i>Havaya</i> indicates that He transcends time, for “He was, He is, and He will be at the same instant,” as is explained [in <i>Raaya Mehemna</i><sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:257b. <i>Raaya Mehemna</i> is a part of the <i>Zohar</i> which explains the esoteric meaning of the precepts.</i> on the portion of <i>Pinchas</i>];<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets are the author’s.</i> and likewise [is He] above space, for He continuously brings into existence all the dimensions of space everywhere, from the uppermost to the lowermost [regions] and in the four directions.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">In the intertwining letters of the name <i>Adnut</i> into the letters of the name <i>Havaya</i>, the <i>Yud</i> of <i>Havaya</i> is the first letter, and therefore this name predominates. This indicates that time and space are nullified in relation to Him. This is <i>yichudah ilaah</i>. See also above, ch. 6, note 9. It is this Unity which is affirmed in the recital of “Hear O Israel…G–d is One,” i.e., One and Alone, for there is nothing apart from Him.</i>
Now, although He is supra-spatial and supra-temporal, nevertheless, He is also found below in space and time, that is, He unites with His attribute of <i>malchut</i> from which space and time are derived and come into existence.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., He is both transcendent and immanent. Through <i>malchut</i> He becomes immanent in creation.</i> And this is <i>yichudah tataah</i> [the intertwining of (the letters of the name) <i>Havaya</i> with (the letters of the name) <i>Adnut</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">In the intertwining of the letters of the name <i>Havaya</i> into the letters of the name <i>Adnut</i>, the <i>alef</i> of <i>Adnut</i> is first, and therefore this name prevails. This indicates that time and space exist, but they are permeated with <i>Havaya</i>, the Infinite. Therefore, the <i>Zohar</i> states that “Blessed be the Name of the glory of His kingdom forever and ever” is the expression of <i>yichudah tataah</i>. “Kingdom” points to finite, material existence, yet is filled with His Essence.</i> blessed is He],<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets are the author’s.</i> i.e., His Essence and Being, blessed be He, which is called by the name <i>En Sof</i> (“Infinite”), completely fills the whole earth temporally and spatially. In the heavens above and on the earth [below] and in the four directions, all are equally permeated with the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, for He is on the earth below exactly as in the heavens above. For all, [heaven and earth] are within the dimensions of space which are completely nullified in the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, which clothes itself in it through the attribute of His <i>malchut</i> that is united with him, blessed be He.
However, the attribute of his <i>malchut</i> is the attribute of <i>tzimtzum</i> and concealment, to hide the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, so that the existence of time and space should not be completely nullified and there will be no dimensions of time and space whatsoever, even for the lower [worlds].
Now, from the foregoing exposition the verse, “I, <i>Havaya</i>, have not changed,”<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Malachi 3:6.</i> will be understood. This means: there is no change [in Him] at all; just as He was alone prior to the creation of the world, so is He alone after it was created. And thus it is written, “You were the same before the world was created; You are the same…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, Morning Prayer; <i>Yalkut Shimoni</i>, <i>Va’etchanan</i> 835.</i> without any change in His Essence, nor in His Knowledge, for by knowing Himself, He knows all created things, since all come from Him and are nullified in relation to Him. And as Maimonides, of blessed memory, stated, that He is the Knower, He is the Known, and He is Knowledge itself—all are one. This is beyond the power of speech to express, beyond the capacity of the ear to hear, and of the heart of man to apprehend clearly.
For the Holy One, blessed is He, His Essence and Being, and His Knowledge are all absolutely one, from every side and angle, and every form of unity. His Knowledge is not superadded to His Essence and Being as it is in the soul of man, whose knowledge is added to his essence and is compounded with it. For when man studies a subject and knows it, his rational soul was already within him before he studied and knew it, and afterward, this knowledge was added to his soul. And so, day after day, “Days speak, and a multitude of years teach wisdom.”<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Job 32:7.</i> This is not a perfect unity, but a composite.
The Holy One, blessed is He, however, is a perfect unity, without any composition and plurality at all. Hence, perforce, His Essence and Being and His Knowledge are all absolutely one, without any composition. Therefore, just as it is impossible for any creature in the world to comprehend the Essence of the Creator and His Being, so it is impossible to comprehend the essence of His Knowledge; only to believe, with a faith which transcends intellect and comprehension,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">True belief implies pure faith, which transcends the realm of the intellect. First one must strive to understand to the extent of one’s intellectual capacities. Beyond that limit, he is to believe with simple faith. Simply stated, “where knowledge ends, faith begins.”</i> that the Holy One, blessed is He, is completely One and Unique. He and His Knowledge are all absolutely one, and knowing Himself, He perceives and knows all the higher and lower beings [even] until a small worm in the sea and a minute mosquito which will be in the center of the earth; there is nothing concealed from Him. This knowledge does not add multiplicity and composition to Him at all, since it is merely knowledge of Himself, and His Being and His Knowledge are all one.
Inasmuch as this is very difficult to envisage, therefore, the Prophet said, “For as the heavens are higher than the earth so are My ways higher than your ways, and My thoughts than your thoughts”;<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 55:9.</i> and it is written, “Can you by searching find G–d…?”<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Job 11:7.</i> and it is written, “Have You eyes of flesh, or do You see as man sees?”<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid. 10:4.</i>—for man sees and knows everything with a knowledge that is external to himself, and the Holy One, blessed is He, by knowing Himself. These are the words of Maimonides.
[See <i>Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">2:9-10, paraphrased and elucidated.</i> and the Sages of the Kabbalah have agreed with him, as is explained in <i>Pardes</i><sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shaar Mehut VeHanhagah</i>, ch. 13.</i> of Rabbi Moses Cordovero, of blessed memory.]<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets are the author’s.</i>
In the light of what has been said above<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the Unity of G–d and His knowledge.</i> it is possible to understand the error of some, scholars in their own eyes, may G–d forgive them, who erred and misinterpreted in their study of the writings of the Arizal,<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">See above, ch. 2, note 13.</i> and understood the doctrine of <i>tzimtzum</i>, which is mentioned therein literally—that the Holy One, blessed is He, removed Himself and His Essence, G–d forbid, from this world, and only guides from above, with individual providence, all the created beings which are in the heavens above and on the earth below.
