The <i>yud</i> and <i>hey</i> of G–d’s name indicate intellect, which is internal, united with the thinker, hence these letters are related to the “concealed” worlds. The <i>vav</i> and the latter <i>hey</i> are the extension of the process initiated in the first letter; they relate to “speech,” separateness, “revealed” worlds.</i> worlds…. You are Wise, but not with a knowable attribute of wisdom. You understand, but not with a knowable attribute of understanding….” All the attributes, the ten <i>sefirot</i>, are included and represented in their source, the Ineffable Name.
The Ineffable Name is composed of four letters: <i>yud</i>, <i>hey</i>, <i>vav</i>, and <i>hey</i>. The <i>yud</i>, a simple point, symbolizes His wisdom,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">See the Explanatory Notes to <i>On Learning Chassidus</i> for the Chabad exposition of the process of development of intellect and emotion.</i> the state of concealment and obscurity, before it develops into a state of expansion and revelation in comprehension and understanding. (The “thorn” on the <i>yud</i> indicates the will of the Supreme One, blessed is He, far superior to the level of <i>chochmah ilaah</i>, the higher wisdom, as is known.)
When the “point” evolves into a state of expansion and revelation of comprehension and understanding in the concealed worlds, it is then contained and represented in the letter <i>hey</i>. The shape of the letter has dimension, expansion in breadth, which implies the breadth of explanation and understanding, and expansion in length, to indicate extension and flow downward into the concealed worlds.
In the next stage this extension and flow are drawn still lower into the revealed worlds. This may be compared to one who wishes to reveal his thoughts to another through his speech, for example. This stage of extension is contained and represented in the final letters <i>vav</i> and <i>hey</i>.
<i>Vav</i>, in shape a vertical line, indicates downward extension. Also, this flow downward is effected through the divine traits of benevolence and goodness and His other sacred traits, included in general terms in the six attributes in the verse, “Yours O G–d is the greatness…” until “Yours O G–d is the dominion…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 29:11.</i> until, but not inclusive. His [seventh] attribute, <i>malchut</i> or dominion, is called the “Word of G–d,” as in the verse, “Wherever the word of the king holds sway.”<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 8:4; see <i>The Tzemach Tzedek and the Haskalah Movement</i>, p. 110, note 3.</i>
This attribute of dominion is contained and represented in the final <i>hey</i> of the Name of <i>Havaya</i>. The internal aspect and the source of speech is the breath that rises from the heart, then is molded by the five oral articulations<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer Yetzirah</i> 2:3.</i>—<i>alef</i>, <i>chet</i>, <i>hey</i>, and <i>ayin</i> from the throat, and so on. The <i>hey</i> implies this internal aspect of speech, for it is the pristine unvocalized breath, “a light letter without substance.”<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, the <i>Akdamot</i> hymn.</i>
Though He has no corporeal form, G–d forbid, the Torah speaks in the language of men. The word of G–d, with its twenty-two letters, would separate into the five articulations, and thus were all beings created. (For a discussion of these letters, see <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, ch. 11.)
Analogously, again considering the infinite separation between the two cases, these same four stages apply to the soul of man, i.e., the divine soul that “He blew from within Himself.” There is the initial state of hidden concept symbolized in the letter <i>yud</i>, with its potential of being revealed, thus understanding and conceiving of His true being and His greatness…each person according to his measure, according to the breadth of his intellect and understanding.
As man deepens his intelligence, as he broadens his mind and comprehension to contemplate His greatness, his now-developed understanding is indicated in the letter <i>hey</i>, that has breadth. The <i>hey</i> also has length to indicate downward extension, that from his understanding and contemplation of G–d’s majesty, he arouses love and fear and their ramifications in his mind and in the recesses of his heart.
In the following stage these emotions would actually become manifest in his heart. This leads to the true service of G–d, in Torah study and mitzvah observance, with voice and speech or with deed. This is the import of the letters <i>vav hey</i>….
Another meaning behind the four letters as applied to man: the contemplation endeavoring to understand and conceive of His true being derives also from Torah, for Torah proceeds from <i>chochmah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:85a, 121a.</i> represented by the <i>yud</i> of the Name of <i>Havaya</i>….

Chapter 5

Bringing the divine soul down into the physical world to invest itself within a human body derives from the internal aspect, the source, of speech. This is the “breath” of the Supreme One, indicated in the latter <i>hey</i> mentioned above. “He <i>breathed</i> into his nostrils a soul of life and man became a living soul,”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 2:7.</i> and “He who blows….”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">“…blows from within.” See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 2 (above).</i>
Let us return to a verse cited earlier. “For part of G–d is His people; Jacob is the cord of His inheritance.”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 32:10.</i> Jacob is compared to a rope, the upper end bound above and the lower end below.
The simple meaning of the verse “He breathed” is to show us that just as, for example, if one blows in some direction and there is any separation or obstruction there, then the exhaled breath will not reach that place at all—so precisely, if anything separates and obstructs between man’s body and the “breath” of the Supreme One.
The truth is though that nothing material or spiritual is a barrier before Him, for “Do I not fill heaven and earth!”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 23:24.</i> “All the world is full of His glory.”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 6:3.</i> “There is no place devoid of Him.”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 51.</i> “In the heavens above and on the earth below there is none else.”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:39. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, ch. 6 (above) explains this rendition, rather than “there is no other.”</i> “He fills all worlds….”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:255a.</i>
But Isaiah declares, “Only your sins separate you from your G–d.”<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 59:2.</i> The reason is that sins oppose the will of the Supreme One, blessed is He, Who gives life to all,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Nehemiah 9:6.</i> as in the verse, “Whatever G–d wills, He did in heaven and earth.”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 135:6.</i> (It has been noted above<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Chapter 4.</i> that the Will is the source of the benevolence issuing from the Name of <i>Havaya</i> and is represented in the “thorn” atop the letter <i>yud</i>.)
This is the significance of excision, the consequence of certain grave sins. The “cord,”<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the soul—or as the verse has it—Jacob.</i> drawn from the final <i>hey</i> in the Name of <i>Havaya</i>, blessed be He, is severed and cut off. In the [Torah] portion of <i>Emor</i> it is written, “That soul shall be cut off from before Me, I am the L–rd.”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 22:3.</i> The soul is cut off from <i>before Me</i>.
Other sins that do not incur excision do cause at least a defect in the soul, a “defect” being similar to the “defect” or nick that invalidates a blade for ritual slaughter.
Returning to the analogy of the cord—a thick rope woven of 613 thin strands parallels the Scriptural “cord,” the downward flow from G–d mentioned above, comprising 613 <i>mitzvot</i>. When man violates one of them, G–d forbid, a thin strand is severed….
But even if one has incurred excision or death, there yet remains an impression within him of his divine soul, and through this he may live until fifty or sixty years and no more. (The statement attributed to the Arizal,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">See above, ch. 2, note 9.</i> that a transcendent level of life-force enters him…is irrelevant to the life of the physical body<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Devarim</i> 62c; 83b.</i> and applies until fifty years, or to the contemporary period, as will be noted.)

Chapter 6

However, all this pertained when Israel was on a higher plane, when the <i>Shechinah</i> dwelled among Israel in the <i>Beit Hamikdash</i>. Then the vitality of the body came only through the divine soul, from the internal of the life-giving power issuing from the Infinite, through the the Name of <i>Havaya</i>, blessed is He, as described above.
But after that they had fallen from their estate, and through their actions caused the mystery of the “Exile of the <i>Shechinah</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Megillah</i> 29a.</i> “By your sins was your mother expelled,”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 50:1.</i> meaning that the benevolence flowing forth from the latter <i>hey</i> as mentioned descended far down, from plane to plane, until it entered into the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>nogah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The term <i>nogah</i> (brightness, or shining) is found in Ezekiel 1:4. Kabbalah and Chasidut tell of the “three <i>kelipot</i>” (husks or shells) that are evil, of the <i>sitra achara</i>, the “other side” in opposition to purity and holiness. <i>Nogah</i>, an intermediate stage between holiness and defilement, is composed of good and evil and can be directed either way. The prohibited (forbidden food, say), the evil, derives from the three impure <i>kelipot</i>, and the permitted from <i>nogah</i>. A <i>nogah</i> “neutral” (like permissible food) may satisfy a gross physical appetite and be degraded, or it might be consumed for a higher purpose and be elevated. (See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 7, et al.) In our text, the life-force that had issued from a state of purity and holiness now descends to this <i>nogah</i> state, and can fall even further, as the text proceeds to explain.</i> The benevolence and vitality proceed through the hosts of heaven and those charged over them to every living physical being in this world, even to vegetation. “There is no blade of grass that has no spirit….”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">“…on High that smites it and commands it: ‘Grow!’” <i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 10:6.</i>
Thus even the sinful and deliberate transgressors of Israel may receive vitality for their bodies and animal souls, exactly as other living beings do, for “They are compared and equal to beasts.”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 49:13.</i>
In fact, their nurture is granted them with even greater emphasis and force,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">A play on Genesis 49:3.</i> as explained in <i>Zohar</i>, <i>Pekudei</i>. Every benevolence and vitality granted mortal man while he commits evil in the eyes of G–d, in deed or speech, or by musing on sin…all issues to him from the chambers of the <i>sitra achara</i> described there in the <i>Zohar</i>.
Man possesses choice, whether he shall derive his nurture from the chambers of the <i>sitra achara</i> or from the chambers of holiness, from whom flow all good and holy thoughts….
For “G–d has made one thing opposite the other….”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 7:14.</i> The chambers of the <i>sitra achara</i> derive their vitality from the embodiment within them and the descent within them of the issue of the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>nogah</i> comprising “good and evil,” the Tree of Knowledge…,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Before Adam partook of the forbidden fruit, good and evil were distinct. Upon sinning, the demarcation became blurred with no pure good or pure evil in the world. Through his service of G–d, overcoming temptation to sin, for example, man separates good from evil, “purifying” the material world.</i> as known to the students of Kabbalah.
“Jacob is the cord of His inheritance.”<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 32:9.</i> The analogy is to a cord whose one end is above and its other end below. When one pulls the lower end, he will move and pull after it the higher end as well, as far as it can be pulled.
The root of the soul of man and its source is in the latter <i>hey</i>, as we have explained earlier. Through his evil deeds and thoughts he “pulls” and draws down the life-force issuing from the <i>hey</i> into the chambers of the <i>sitra achara</i>, as it were, from which he receives his thoughts and deeds. Because he, the sinful person, draws the flow of vitality into the <i>sitra achara</i>, he receives his “share” of vitality first.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., as stated above, “with even greater emphasis and force.”</i> This will suffice for the understanding.
Hence the statement,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 4:15.</i> “Not within our hands is the reason for either the tranquility of the wicked…”—in <i>our</i> hands, in this time of exile after the destruction. This is the sense of the “Exile of the <i>Shechinah</i>,” as it were, His granting benevolent life-force to the chambers of the <i>sitra achara</i> that He despises.
But when the sinner performs the appropriate penance, then he removes from them the life-force he brought to them originally through his deeds and thoughts. By his repentance, he returns the flow issuing from the <i>Shechinah</i> to its proper place.
This then is “<i>tashuv hey tataah</i>,” returning the latter <i>hey</i> from its state of exile. “G–d will return those of you who return,”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 30:3.</i> meaning <i>with</i> those who return. Our Sages have commented on this verse, “He shall <i>bring back</i> is not said….”<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Megillah</i> 29a “…but ‘He shall return.’” to teach us that the Holy One, blessed is He, returns with them from the exiles.”</i>

Chapter 7

In the true and direct path to the lower <i>teshuvah</i>, returning the latter <i>hey</i> noted above, there are two general elements.
The first is to awaken supreme compassion from the Source of mercy for his spirit (<i>neshamah</i>)<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">There are three elements in the soul, and it may be known by any of these names according to the context—<i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i>. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 1 describes the “animal <i>nefesh</i>” and ch. 2, the “Divine (or G–dly) <i>nefesh</i>.” (<i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 14:9; <i>Devarim Rabbah</i> 2:37) notes two more discussed at length in Chasidut—<i>chaya</i> and <i>yechidah</i>.</i> and divine soul (<i>nefesh</i>) that has fallen from a lofty peak, the true Life, into a deep pit, the chambers of defilement and <i>sitra achara</i>. [Divine compassion is] also to be aroused for the source [of the soul] in the Source of life, the Name of <i>Havaya</i>, blessed is He. “He shall return to G–d, and He will grant him mercy.”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 55:7.</i> “Him” would refer to G–d here, arousing mercies for the life-giving power issuing from His Name, that has descended into the chambers of the impure <i>sitra achara</i>, to give them vitality. This was brought about through the deeds of man, his scheming and evil thoughts. “The king is bound with tresses”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 7:6.</i> is interpreted as “bound with the tresses of the mind….”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 21b; 124b.</i> This is the “Exile of the <i>Shechinah</i>,” as noted above.
The auspicious time for this arousal of mercies is <i>Tikkun Chatzot</i>, the midnight prayers, as stated in the <i>Siddur</i>, in the Note;<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Siddur Im Dach</i> 151c (Kehot, 1965).</i> see there at length. We find there, “The crown of our head is fallen; woe to us, for we have sinned.”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 5:16.</i>
Therefore the Holy One is called the “humiliated King” in <i>Pirkei Hechalot</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Ch. 18.</i> as R. Moshe Cordovero wrote, for there is no humiliation deeper than this. Especially when a thoughtful person meditates on the greatness of the Infinite, who encompasses<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>On Learning Chassidus</i>, Explanatory Notes.</i> all worlds and permeates all worlds, each person according to the range of his intellect and understanding, will they be extremely grieved over this.
The second element is to crush and subdue evil, the <i>kelipah</i> and <i>sitra achara</i>, whose entire being is simply grossness and arrogance. “Though you exalt yourself as the eagle….”<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">“…from there I will bring you down, says the L–rd.” Obadiah 1:4 (cf. Jeremiah 49:16). See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 27.</i> This crushing and subjugation is to be absolutely to dust, for this is its death and nullification.
Evil is crushed through a broken and shattered heart, a sense of personal unworthiness, repugnance, and so forth. This is described in the <i>Zohar</i> on the verse, “The offerings of G–d (<i>Elokim</i>) are a broken spirit, a heart broken and shattered….”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 51:19.</i> All animal offerings are dedicated to G–d (<i>Havaya</i>), the attribute of mercies. To <i>Elokim</i>, the Name indicating the attribute of justice, no animal offering is brought. Instead the offering is the sundering and removing of the spirit of defilement and <i>sitra achara</i>. This is the meaning of a “broken spirit.”
How is the spirit of the <i>sitra achara</i> broken? When the heart is broken and crushed….
And how is the heart to be broken and crushed? Only a minor part of this can be through mortifications and fasts in our generations. We cannot fast as did King David. Our Sages remark on the verse, “My heart is a void within me”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 109:22.</i>—he destroyed it with fasts.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 61b; <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, chs. 1, 13, etc. David utterly destroyed the evil impulse within him.</i>
But the true humbling of the heart, that it be broken and crushed, and the removal of the spirit of impurity and <i>sitra achara</i>, is achieved through being of the “masters of accounts,”<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:178a.</i> with all the profundity of the mind. He must concentrate his intellect and understanding deeply for a period every day, or at night before <i>Tikkun Chatzot</i>, to realize that through his sins he wrought the exile of the <i>Shechinah</i>, as noted above. He will also ponder that he [caused] the uprooting of his spirit and divine soul from the true Life and demeaned it to a place of defilement and death, the chambers of the <i>sitra achara</i>. He must become deeply aware that his soul has become a vehicle for them, receiving from them vitality to endow his body, as noted above.
Our Sages declared that “The wicked while alive are dead.”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 18b.</i> Their ability to live is derived from the site of death and defilement. (Hence, the verse, “The dead will not praise…”<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 115:17.</i> is no mockery of the impoverished,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 17:5. <i>Berachot</i> 18a applies the verse to wearing <i>tefillin</i> in a cemetery, etc., a “mockery of the impoverished” who cannot perform the <i>mitzvah</i>.</i> G–d forbid. Rather, the reference is to the wicked who, while living, are called dead, for they are confused with alien thoughts while in their wickedness and do not desire repentance, as is known.)
One who has never violated a sin of excision or a sin incurring death by divine agency, for example, vain emission and the like, but other, less severe sins, nonetheless suffers a defect in the spirit and divine soul, as in the analogy of the defects and severance of the fine strands of cord, as noted above: Through an accumulation of sins, there can eventually be a defect as grave as from one prohibition involving excision or death. This would be true even when a single sin is repeated numerous times.
The prophet compares sins to a cloud that dims the light of the sun. “I have wiped away your transgressions like a cloud”<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 44:22. A discourse on this verse by Rabbi Menachem Mendel (1789-1866), author of <i>Tzemach Tzedek</i>, has been translated as a Supplement to <i>The Tzemach Tzedek and the Haskalah Movement</i>, p. 100. The reader is warmly urged to study that discourse, for it treats much of the material in this chapter of <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>. It was originally delivered before Jewish soldiers in the Czarist army in 1843 (ibid. p. 55).</i>—these are the grave sins [that are barriers] between the interior of the power flowing forth from G–d and the divine soul. This barrier is like the separation of a thick cloud that stands between the sun and the earth with its inhabitants. “And like a cloud your sins”—these are the lesser sins that man tramples under heel,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avodah Zarah</i> 18a; <i>Rashi</i> on Deuteronomy 7:12.</i> sins that separate as does a thin and wispy cloud.
In the illustration, if one obscures the sunlight streaming through a window with many fine and lacy curtains, they will darken as much as one thick curtain will, and even more. Exactly so is the parallel, with all those sins that man tramples indifferently, and certainly those well known from the words of our Sages to be actually like idolatry, immorality, and bloodshed.
Examples of these are sins like ignoring the needy<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Avot</i> 5:13.</i>—“Beware lest there be in your heart something <i>beliyaal</i> (unworthy)….”<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 15:9.</i> <i>Beliyaal</i> is used in reference to idolatry….<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 31b.</i> Or talebearing,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Shabbat</i> 33; <i>Bava Batra</i> 164b; <i>Erchin</i> 15b.</i> the evil tongue that is equated with idolatry, immorality, and bloodshed. The vile-tempered<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Shabbat</i> 105b; <i>Avot</i> 2:10.</i> is like the idolatrous, and so is the arrogant.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sotah</i> 4b.</i> There are many such described in the Talmud. Torah study equals them all,<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah, <i>Peah</i> 1:1.</i> as our Sages assert, “G–d has pardoned idolatry….”<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">See above, ch. 1 and note 18.</i>
For this reason the order of <i>Kriat Shema</i> at the bedside includes acceptance of the four executions of the Court…. Besides, according to the mystical interpretation of <i>sod</i>, impairing the <i>yud</i> of the Name of <i>Havaya</i> is like incurring lapidation; impairing the <i>hey</i> is like incurring burning; impairing the <i>vav</i> is like incurring the sword; and the latter <i>hey</i> is like incurring strangulation. Neglecting the <i>Shema</i> impairs the <i>yud</i>, and <i>tefillin</i> the <i>hey</i>, <i>tzitzit</i> the <i>vav</i>, and prayer the latter <i>hey</i>….
From this the intelligent, thoughtful person can infer for other sins and transgressions, and for neglect of Torah, which equals them all.

Chapter 8

After deeply considering all this, he can truly plead, from the innermost heart, “In Your great mercies, wipe away my sins….”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 51:3.</i> By then his heart is thoroughly impressed with the pathetic state of the spark of divinity within him, and above, as noted. This plea is to arouse supreme mercies, of the Thirteen Attributes of Compassion,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Exodus 34:6-7. The Lubavitcher Rebbe, Rabbi Menachem M. Schneerson, has made this observation: The original verse (Exodus 34:7) quoted here includes the word “<i>v’chataah</i>,” the unintentional sin, as well as the other two, intentional sins. <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i> omits this one word. The reason for the omission is that in our text the Thirteen Attributes of Compassion are called forth to “correct all defects,” referring to deliberate sins for which no offering is provided. Supreme mercies alone can avail the sinner. The <i>chataah</i>, unintentional sin, does have the <i>chatat</i> offering and is commuted without calling upon “supreme” mercies. On the other hand, the verse describing the Thirteen Attributes does include <i>chataah</i> because of the following words—“He cleanses, and cleanses not,” meaning that He forgives those who return, but not the recalcitrant, as our text will shortly note. Even for unintentional sins, the verse declares, “return” is required (<i>Likkutei Sichot</i>, vol. 4, p. 1058, note 14).</i> which come from the will of the Supreme One, blessed is He, symbolized in the “thorn” atop the <i>yud</i>, far transcending the flow issuing from the letters of His Name.
Because of their lofty origin these Attributes of Compassion correct all defects, as in the passage, “He bears sin and transgression, and cleanses.”<sup>2</sup> With this awakening of mercies following the contrition, there is no further nurture for evil and <i>sitra achara</i> from the life-force emanating from the lower <i>hey</i>, as noted. (The latter <i>hey</i> returns to its proper place, united as before with the <i>yud-hey-vav</i>. This will suffice for the knowing.)
As there is a “restoration” of the <i>hey</i> above, so, too, below in the divine soul within man, no more do “your sins divide.”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 59:2.</i> It is said, “He cleanses”—those who come back to Him,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yoma</i> 86a.</i> to lave and cleanse their souls of the soiled garments, the “extraneous forces” that the Talmud describes as “envelops….”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sotah</i> 3b. “Whoever commits one transgression in this world, it envelops him and precedes him for the Day of Judgment.” Man’s good works precede him in the World to Come, and his sins envelop him.</i>
After the cleansing spirit passes over and purifies them, then their souls are enabled to return unto G–d Himself, literally, to ascend the greatest heights, to their very source, and cleave to Him with a remarkable unity. This is the original unity, the ultimate in union, that existed before the soul was blown by the breath of His mouth to descend and be incorporated within the body of man. (To illustrate this unity: before one exhales, the breath is united with the person; he and his breath are not separable yet.) This is the perfect return, <i>teshuvah</i>.
This state of unity and this return are called <i>teshuvah ilaah</i>, the superior return, that follows <i>teshuvah tataah</i>, the inferior return. The <i>Zohar</i>, in <i>Raaya Mehemna</i> on <i>Nasso</i>, explains that <i>teshuvah ilaah</i> is being occupied with Torah study in reverence and fear of the Holy One…, for this is <i>ben yud-hey</i>—<i>binah</i>….<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">As noted earlier, <i>yud</i> or <i>chochmah</i> is the germ of the idea and <i>hey</i> or <i>binah</i> is its amplification and development. In <i>binah</i> there is the beginning of an emotive response to the intellectual comprehension, even before the emotions are actually manifest. This state of “intellectual” love and fear is <i>ben yud-hey</i>, the “offspring” of intellect, the same Hebrew letters as <i>binah</i>.</i> (Here, the superiority of the penitent over the perfectly saintly, as the <i>Zohar</i> states in <i>Chayei Sara</i>, is that “they draw upon themselves with a more intense longing of the heart, and with greater forcefulness, to approach the King….”)<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:129b; <i>Berachot</i> 34b.</i>

Chapter 9

The explanation of this subject is discussed frequently in <i>Zohar</i> and <i>Tikkunim</i>: <i>Binah</i> is the superior <i>teshuvah</i>—“The mother crouching over the chicks….”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 22:6. <i>Binah</i> is the “mother” and emotions the “offspring,” or as the verse has it, the “chicks.”
These emotions are man’s creations, the product of his efforts. They are results of intellectual endeavor, not gift or heritage.</i> He is to meditate profoundly and with concentration on the greatness of G–d, and through his intellectual comprehension arouse a sense of intellectual reverence and love on rational grounds. This love is that of the verse, “To love the L–rd your G–d” for “He is your life….”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 30:20.</i> He will not be content with the endowed,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 44, etc., and Part II, pp. 284-286, on the concealed and created love.</i> latent love alone…. So, too, with fear of G–d, and terror or shame…as is known. This is the import of “The mother crouching over the chicks….”
<i>Ahavah</i>, love, is primarily the cleaving of spirit to spirit, as “He kisses me with the kisses of his mouth…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 1:2.</i> as is known. This cleaving of spirit is the meaning of “With all your soul,”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 6:5.</i> with every aspect of your soul, with intellect, emotions, and their garbs of thought, speech, and deed. All cleave to Him.
Man’s emotional faculties are bound up with His—“as He is merciful….”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Peah</i> 1:1; <i>Sotah</i> 14a; <i>Shabbat</i> 133b; Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Deot</i> 1:5, 6.</i>
Man’s intellect adheres to His intellect and wisdom, assiduous Torah study, for “Torah issues from Wisdom.”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:85a.</i>
Man’s thought is devoted to G–d’s, and his speech is the word of G–d, the <i>halachah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Shabbat</i> 138b.</i> as in the passages, “I have placed My word in your mouth,”<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 51:16.</i> and “My words that I have placed in your mouth.”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid., 59:21.</i>
Man’s deeds shall be works of charity, to revive the spirit of the fallen,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid., 57:15.</i> thus cleaving to G–d’s actions, as in, “For six days G–d wrought….”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 20:11.</i> as is known elsewhere.
This is the cleaving of spirit to spirit—the ultimate attachment and union as a result of love…. Since the violation of the covenant through wasteful emission, to say nothing of stark immorality or unions prohibited by Torah or the Sages (for the words of the Sages are more grave…),<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Berachot</i> 4b; <i>Eruvin</i> 22b; <i>Sanhedrin</i> 88b.</i> causes a blemish in the mind, therefore his rectification is that he occupy himself with Torah that derives from <i>chochmah</i>.
In <i>Tanna Dvai Eliyahu</i> we find, “A man commits a sin and is liable to death before the Almighty, what shall he do and live? If he was accustomed to studying one page, he shall study two, to studying one chapter, he shall study two chapters….” This parallels the illustration of the cord severed and then reknotted—the place of the knot is so much thicker than the unaffected portion. So it is with the “cord of His possession.”
This is the meaning of the verse, “With kindness and truth is sin forgiven…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 16:6.</i> and “There is no ‘truth’ but Torah….”<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Berachot</i> 5b.</i>
Similarly, the sin of the house of Eli will not be atoned by sacrifices and offerings,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. I Samuel 3:14.</i> but will be pardoned through Torah and good deeds, as explained in <i>Rosh Hashanah</i>, end of ch. 1.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">18a.</i>

Chapter 10

This superior form of <i>teshuvah</i>, the cleaving of spirit to spirit through intellectual study of Torah and physical performance of acts of kindness, is in a mode of a flow from Above—so that the word of G–d shall actually be in his mouth, as in “I place my words in your mouth,”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 51:16.</i> and “His right hand embraces me”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 2:6.</i> because of man’s acts of kindness since “kindness is the right arm….”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction.</i>
But the mortal man must move from stage to stage, ascending gradually until he attains this superior <i>teshuvah</i> and cleaving of spirit to spirit. He ascends through the heart’s devoted prayer, particularly during <i>Shema</i> and its blessings, that he might in perfect truth say, “You shall love…with all your heart and with all your soul….”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 6:5.</i> Similarly, “These words shall be…you shall speak of them….”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid. vs. 6-7,</i> The word of G–d must truly be in his mouth, and “there is no truth….”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">“…but Torah.” Cf. <i>Berachot</i> 5b.</i> Similarly, to perform all the <i>mitzvot</i>, for “He has sanctified us with His commandments.”
This sanctification is identical with “You are sanctified to me.”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kiddushin</i> 5b; formula declaring betrothal.</i> This is the highest degree of sacredness, an expression of separation and apartness, that cannot be contained within Creation since “all are considered as naught before Him.”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:11b.</i> This sacredness attains to the state of encompassing all worlds, the will of the Supreme One, blessed is He…, as discussed in <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, ch. 46.
After prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the <i>Shemonah Esrei</i> (<i>Amidah</i>), the fulfillment of the <i>mitzvah</i> of prayer.</i> again we say, “To You, O L–rd, I lift my soul,”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 25:1.</i> that spirit cleave to spirit all through the day…. All this is brought about through meditation on the greatness of the Infinite, concentrating the mind deeply in the two blessings preceding <i>Shema</i> and in <i>Pesukei d’Zimra</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The Verses of Praise drawn mainly from the Psalms, which expound on G–d’s greatness as Creator, the beauty and magnitude of His works. Then in the blessings before <i>Shema</i> we recount the exalted fervor of the angels, their reverence and love of G–d. These are introductions to <i>Shema</i> and the <i>Shemonah Esrei</i> (<i>Amidah</i>) following.</i> as is known.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 49.</i>
Since the prayer is the state of <i>teshuvah ilaah</i>, the higher return, it must be preceded by <i>teshuvah tataah</i>, the lower return. This is what the Sages intended in the Mishnah,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 30b.</i> “One should not stand up to pray except from a state of awe.” Rashi explains, “Humility.” This is the state of <i>teshuvah tataah</i>, to arouse divine compassion, as noted above,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Ch. 7.</i> and as the Talmud infers from the passage, “She was embittered.”<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 1:10.</i>
At the same time we must note the Baraita<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 31a.</i> there, “Our Sages taught, ‘One should not stand up to pray except from a state of joy.’” In our bereaved generation, when not all are capable of turning their hearts instantly from the extreme of humility to joy, it is advised that the time for <i>teshuvah tataah</i> be designated at <i>Tikkun Chatzot</i>, as noted above.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup> Whoever cannot do this nightly should maintain an absolute minimum of once every week, before Shabbat. It is known to the knowledgeable that Shabbat is on the order of <i>teshuvah ilaah</i>, and the very letters of the word Shabbat<sup>17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 22.</i> spell <i>tashev</i>, as in, “You return man.”<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 90:3.</i> On Shabbat all the worlds ascend to their source…. The Shabbat prayer particularly is on the order <i>of teshuvah ilaah</i>. This will suffice for the intelligent.
(We can now understand the verse, “Return to Me, for I have redeemed you.”<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 44:22.</i> Since “I have wiped away your sins like a cloud”<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">First half of verse, ibid.</i>—removing the <i>sitra achara</i>, and “I have redeemed you” from evil through the arousal of the Supreme Compassion following the initiative taken by man below in his <i>teshuvah tataah</i>, as explained above—therefore, “Return to Me”—with <i>teshuvah ilaah</i>.)

Chapter 11

This subject, harboring [contrary emotions] simultaneously in the heart, humility—the state of <i>teshuvah tataah</i> as explained, and gladness as well, has already been discussed in <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, end of ch. 34. It has been illuminated by the <i>Zohar</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">II:255a; III:75a.</i> “Joy is lodged in one side of my heart….” Joined to this is the faith and confidence, the heart being firm and certain in G–d that He desires goodness,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Micah 7:18.</i> and is gracious and merciful<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Nehemiah 9:17.</i> and generously forgiving<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Isaiah 55:7.</i> the instant one pleads for forgiveness and atonement of Him. (“According to Your great mercies wipe away my sins; cleanse me, purify me, wipe away all my sins….”)<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 51:3, 4, 11.</i> Not the faintest vestige of doubt dilutes this absolute conviction.
For this reason, in every <i>Shemonah Esrei</i>, the moment we plead, “Forgive us…” we conclude, “Blessed are You, L–rd, gracious One, who pardons abundantly.” Without the certainty of pardon this would be a case of doubtful blessing, which we do not recite lest it be a blessing in vain.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 33a.</i> But there is no doubt here whatsoever, for we have asked, “Pardon us, forgive us.” Furthermore, were we not to repeat our transgressions we would be immediately redeemed,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Sanhedrin</i> 976.</i> in accordance with the blessing we recite, “Blessed are You, L–rd, Redeemer of Israel.”
Even by human standards this certainty of pardon is legitimate. One must forgive as soon as he is asked for pardon. He must not be cruel and vindictive, even when one mutilates another, as we find in <i>Bava Kama</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">92a.</i> end of ch. 8. If one has asked his fellow for forgiveness three times and has been rebuffed, he need not apologize further.
When King David<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 21.</i> asked the Gibeonites to forgive King Saul who had killed Gibeonites, they refused to pardon him. David decreed that they shall not enter the Congregation of G–d, who are merciful…. See <i>Yevamot</i>, end of ch. 8.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">78b and 79a.</i>
As a divine trait, forgiveness is as swift, and infinitely more so.
The praise and blessing addressed to G–d, “gracious One, who pardons abundantly,” emphasizes the word <i>marbeh</i>, “abundantly,” implying multiplicity. In Ezra<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The reference is not to the term but to the concept; see explanation by the Lubavitcher Rebbe in <i>Shiurim B’Sefer HaTanya</i>, p. 1212 ff.</i> [too], we find that G–d “pardons abundantly.” It is characteristic of men that if one injures another and asks his pardon, which is granted, and then repeats the misdeed, it becomes more difficult to grant pardon again, and certainly a third and fourth time.
But by the standard of G–d, there is no difference between once and a thousand times. Pardon is a manifestation of the attribute of mercy. Divine attributes are not bounded and finite; they are infinite as in the verse, “For His mercies have not ended.”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 3:22.</i> In terms of infinity, there is no difference whatsoever between a small number and a large one. Before Him all are considered as naught,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Daniel 4:32.</i> and He makes equal the small and the great….<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, High Holiday Musaf, <i>V’chol maaminim</i>.</i>
Therefore, “He removes our sins every year.”<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, Yom Kippur <i>Amidah</i>.</i> All the sins confessed in the <i>Al Chet</i> annually, though repeatedly violated, are again confessed on Yom Kippur in the coming year, and so on always. “Every year” is not necessarily a yearly pardon, for three times every day we pronounce, “Blessed are You, O G–d, gracious One, who pardons abundantly.”
Our Sages teach, “the prayers were introduced in place of the daily sacrificial offerings.”<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 26a.</i> The daily morning offering was to atone for the sins of the previous night, and the regular evening sacrifice atoned for the sins of the past day, and so on day by day constantly. “Every year” means only that Yom Kippur atones for the grave sins, while the regular offerings, the <i>olah</i>, atoned only for violations of positive commands.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">See ch. 2 above.</i> In our time, prayer with repentance replaces offerings, as noted above.
But this is not an attitude of “I will sin and later repent.”<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yoma</i> 85a.</i> That is relevant only if while committing the sin he could have overcome his impulse to evil, but depended in his heart on repenting later. Since the opportunity to repent caused him to sin, “He is not granted an opportunity….”<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup> And even then, he is not <i>granted</i> an opportunity. But if he pressed forcefully and overpowered his evil impulse and did repent, then his repentance is accepted.<sup>19</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yoma</i> 87a; <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, <i>Orach Chaim</i> 606:1.</i>
But we who plead daily, “Pardon us,” preface that prayer with “bring us back to You in wholehearted repentance,” that is, that we revert no more to folly. On Yom Kippur too we ask, “May it be Your will that I sin no more.”<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, Confession Prayers.</i> For us opportunity is granted, freely, as our Sages teach, “Whoever comes to purify himself is given assistance.”<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 104a.</i> Whoever <i>comes</i>, as soon as he comes, and the pardon and forgiveness are also granted forthwith.
“My sin is before me always”<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 51:5.</i> does not imply that one ought constantly to be melancholy, humiliated, G–d forbid, for a following verse declares, “Let me hear gladness and joy…and the free spirit shall uphold me….”<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 51:10, 14.</i> He ought all his days experience <i>teshuvah ilaah</i>, which is marked by great joy, as we noted above. “Before me” is the term <i>negdi</i>, as in “Stand <i>mineged</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 18:13.</i> and “<i>Mineged</i> around the Tent of Assembly shall they camp.”<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 2:2.</i> Rashi defines the term as “at a distance.” The intention of our verse is merely that his heart does not become haughty,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Deuteronomy 17:20.</i> that he be of humble spirit before all men,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Avot</i> 4:10 and 4.</i> for the remembrance is between his eyes<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Exodus 13:9.</i> that he has sinned before G–d.
In fact, as far as gladness is concerned, the remembrance will be especially effective in encouraging happiness in the face of whatever misfortunes threaten to overtake him, whether from Heaven or caused by man, whether in speech or in deed. (This constant awareness of one’s sins is good counsel to be immune to anger or any sort of resentment….) The Talmud<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 88b. “…they are meant in the verse: ‘Those who love Him (shall be) like the sun rising in full strength’ (Judges 5:31).”</i> declares, “Those humiliated who do not humiliate in turn, who hear their insult and do not retort, who perform out of love and are happy in affliction….” Whoever passes over his feelings, all his sins are passed over.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 17a.</i>

Chapter 12

The reason for happiness in the afflictions of the body<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Quoted end of last chapter.</i> is that they are a great and potent favor for the sinning soul to cleanse it in This World and to redeem it from purification in the next. (This is particularly true in our generations, when it is not possible to fast—in accordance with the prescriptions in the penances of the Arizal<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">See above, ch. 2, note 9.</i>—as imperative for the cleansing of the soul, to rescue it from cleansing in <i>Gehinom</i>.)
Nachmanides, in his Introduction to the Commentary on Job, writes that even the sufferings of Job for seventy years have absolutely no comparison to the suffering of a soul even briefly in <i>Gehinom</i>, for [physical] fire is one sixtieth….<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">“…of that of <i>Gehinom</i>.” <i>Berachot</i> 57b.</i> It is only that the world is built by kindness,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 89:3.</i> and through mild suffering in This World one is saved from severe judgments in the Coming World.
The movement of a shadow on earth of a few inches equals the sun’s movement in the heaven of thousands of miles…. Infinitely more so is this true in the parallel, in the descent of the worlds, from the most exalted heights until this physical world. We see this in the <i>Zohar’s</i> comments on the subject of the elevation of the higher worlds as a result of the initiative taken by man below. The <i>Zohar</i> describes the effects of the offering of one fowl, a dove or pigeon, or a handful of meal, on the altar. Such are the effects of all the <i>mitzvot</i> of performance, as known from the Arizal.
This too is our Sages’ comment on the verse, “Sanctify yourselves, and you shall be holy”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 11:44.</i>—man sanctifies himself only a little below, and he becomes sanctified in great measure from above….<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yoma</i> 39a.</i> (It was noted above<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Ch. 10.</i> in reference to “Who sanctified us with His commandments…” [that Israel’s sanctification through <i>mitzvot</i> is bound up with the Infinite, that] encompasses all worlds….)
Precisely so is it in reference to reward and punishment, as our Sages<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 4:2.</i> say, “The reward of a mitzvah is a mitzvah…” as discussed elsewhere. This knowledge is elementary to the understanding, and those with intelligence in this matter will discover good.

Part IV; Iggeret HaKodesh



Chapter 1

<b>ONE.</b> We begin with a benediction<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">This letter was written in reply to the “<i>good tiding</i>…referring to the completion of the whole Talmud,” etc.; the author, therefore, responds firstly with a benediction, in accordance with the Talmudic precept (<i>Berachot</i> 59b) that one is to laud G–d for glad tidings. Cf. <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, <i>Orach Chaim</i> 221:1; <i>Seder Birchot Hanehenin</i>, by the author, ch. 12.</i> to bless and to give thanks to the L–rd, for He is good:<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 106:1; etc.</i> my soul has heard and was revived<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 55:3.</i> by a good tiding—there is no Good but Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 4:3; <i>Berachot</i> 5a.</i> the Torah of the L–rd is whole<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 19:8.</i>—referring to the completion of the whole Talmud in most cities and congregations of the men of our chasidic brotherhood.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">In Hebrew אנשי שלומים (שלומינו), this is a term used to denote particular groups in general, and especially in frequent use among Chasidim, when referring to their own group(s). The term is of Biblical origin, cf. Jeremiah 38:22; Obadiah 1:7; cf. also Genesis 34:21. The study of the complete Talmud, to which this letter refers, was not an incidental occasion. R. Schneur Zalman demanded of his followers that this should be done annually, in every city and, where so applicable, by every congregation; see <i>Kuntres Acharon</i>, Essay 9.</i> Gratitude for the past, and a request for the future: may G–d grant and continue to strengthen their hearts among the mighty<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Amos 2:16, though relating it to <i>Avot d’R. Nattan</i> 23:1: “The mighty are none others than the mighty in Torah.”</i> with the might of Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Derech Eretz Zuta</i>, ch. 4: “There is no might but in Torah.” See also <i>Bamidbar Rabbah</i> 10:8.</i> in like manner from year to year and make known to mankind the might of the Oral Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">See previous note; also, in the scheme of the <i>sefirot</i>, the Oral Torah is related to the <i>sefirah</i> of <i>gevurah</i>—cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:253a; ibid. III:257a; <i>et passim</i>.</i> and its strong (עוז) power.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Lit.: וכחה עוז—“and her strong power.” The Torah is referred to as “power” and “strength” (<i>Zohar</i> II:58a and <i>Nitzutzei Orot</i>, by R. Chaim David Azulai, ad loc.; cf. below, note 42); see <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 36.</i>
King Solomon, peace be to him, explained: “She girds her loins with strength (עוז)….”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 31:17.</i> The “loins” are the faculty<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Text corrected according to L. H.</i> which supports the whole body, with the head that was put and stands over them; and they are the ones that take and bring (the body) to its desired destination.
And just as it is with the corporeality of the body, so it is with [the aspect of] the spiritual of the Divine soul. The true belief in the One G–d, the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He—[Who permeates all worlds and encompasses all worlds,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:225a.—With respect to the terms “permeates” and “encompasses all worlds” (referring to the immanence and transcendence of G–d), see <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, chs. 41, 48, and 51; Part II, ch. 7. Cf. below, Epistle 3, note 12.</i> and there is no place void of Him<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 57 (91b); 70 (122b).</i> above to no end and below to no limit, and likewise in all four directions, truly in a state of infinitude, and likewise in the aspects of “year” and “soul,”<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">See below, note 17.</i> as known.]
Now, this belief is referred to as the faculty of the “loins” which upholds and sustains<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Makkot</i> 24a: “Habakkuk came and based (all commandments) on one belief”; see <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 33. Thus faith is the foundation of all.</i> the “head,” meaning the intellect that contemplates and cogitates on the greatness of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, in the aspects of “world,” “year,” “soul,”<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">“World,” “year,” and “soul” are crucial concepts in <i>Sefer Yetzirah</i> (see there 3:3 ff.; <i>et passim</i>). Generally speaking they represent the concepts of <i>space</i> (world), <i>time</i> (year), and <i>life</i>, or vital force (soul). See <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Chukat</i> 64d; <i>Haazinu</i> 74d; <i>Shir Hashirim</i> 7b.—Above the author mentioned only “year” and “soul,” because “world” was already described in the “above, below, and all four directions.”</i> and on the magnitude of His kindness and His wonders with us, that we are “A people close to Him”<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 148:14. This passage, literally, may be translated: “the people that is <i>His relative</i>!” See <i>Midrash Tehillim</i> 4:3, 4; also <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Re’eh</i> 19d.</i> and truly “To cleave to Him.”<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., “able to cleave to Him”; see Deuteronomy 11:22, 30:20; Joshua 22:5 (cf. Deuteronomy 4:4, 10:20, 13:5; Job 23:8; Jeremiah 13:11).</i> (Thus it is) known from the saying:<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 4:17. See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 4.</i> “One hour of repentance and good deeds in this world is better than all the life of the World to Come,” for the World to Come is but a gleam and reflection of the [aspect called] <i>Shechinah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">The Divine Indwelling. See <i>Berachot</i> 17a and Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Teshuvah</i>, ch. 8.</i> “Who dwells…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 16:16—Paradoxically, the <i>Shechinah</i> itself dwells in this material world, while the (spiritual) World to Come is a mere “reflection,” or a “gleam,” of the <i>Shechinah</i>. Thus only in this world can one cleave to the <i>Shechinah</i> itself through “repentance and good deeds.” In the World to Come, one can attain no more than the “reflection” of the <i>Shechinah</i>. Cf. below, Epistle 8, note 23.</i> and was created by the single <i>yud</i> of His Name, blessed be He….<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Menachot</i> 29b; see below, Epistle 5.</i> Repentance and good deeds, however, truly bring Israel close to their Father in Heaven, to His Being and Essence, as it were, [the aspect of infinitude, indeed], and as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 148:13, 14; cf. <i>Midrash Tehillim</i> 4:3, 4 and <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Re’eh</i> 19d.</i> “His radiance is upon the earth and heavens. He raises the glory of His people…,” “Who has sanctified us (to Himself) with His commandments, and commanded us….”<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Text of benedictions uttered before the performance of many precepts. These words emphasize a special relationship between G–d and Israel; see <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 46; <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Derushim LiShemini Atzeret</i> 83c; cf. <i>Sefer</i> <i>Habahir</i> 57 (184).</i>
And as waters (reflect) the face…,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 27:19: “As waters (reflect) face to face, so is the heart of man to man.” In other words, there is an equal reflection and response. See <i>Yalkut Shimoni</i>, ad loc. (vol. 2, toward end of 961), and <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 46 and 49.</i> from this contemplation are born the intellectual or the natural awe and love,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 16 and 38 on the concepts (and the distinction between) <i>intellectual</i> and <i>natural</i> awe and love.</i> that there be a state of “Their heart cried to the L–rd,”<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Lamentations 2:18.</i> or a state of “Flashes of fire, a mighty flame”<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Song of Songs 8:6; cf. <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Chukat</i> 66b and references cited there; below, Epistle 29.</i>—on a level of “advance” (<i>ratzo</i>), and, afterward, on a level of “retreat” (<i>shov</i>)<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">See Ezekiel 1:14. “Advance” and “retreat” are two levels in the worship of G–d which—in their natural sequence—follow one upon the other, in this order. <i>Ratzo</i>, lit., running, signifies a fierce love and passion for G–d: “running” (advancing) toward G–d, in order to cleave unto Him. <i>Shov</i>, lit., returning, which follows upon and is a still higher level than <i>ratzo</i>, signifies the occupation with Torah and <i>mitzvot</i>, thus bringing the “advance” to its proper conclusion. By the “retreat” the Divine abundance is elicited and drawn earthward, in, and through the fulfillment of the Torah and the commandments. While advance signifies “love,” retreat includes “awe.” (Cf. <i>Torah Or</i>, <i>Bereishit</i> 1d-2a; 25b.) In <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Re’eh</i> 19d, the author applies these two levels to Deuteronomy 13:5: “You should go after the L–rd your G–d”—<i>ratzo</i>; “Him you shall fear. His commandments you shall keep,” etc.—<i>shov</i>.</i>—due to the fear of G–d in his heart and being abashed by His greatness…. This is the aspect of “the left hand parries,”<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Sotah</i> 47a.—An aspect of <i>gevurah</i>; withdrawal (cf. Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>).</i> as it is written of the Giving of the Torah:<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 20:15.</i> “The people saw and they trembled, and they stood from afar….” And these are the faculties of the arms<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">“Love” and “awe”; advance and retreat.</i> and the body of the soul.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the counterpart of the physical body in the soul; the harmony between love and awe. (See Addendum, ibid.)</i>
But what gives the power and strength to the faculty of the loins—to support and sustain the head and the arms? It is the occupation with, and the study of, the <i>halachot</i><sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Legal rulings.</i> in the Oral Torah—which is the [state of] manifestation of the Supernal Will.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">G–d’s will is expressed in the Torah. The legal rulings of the Oral Torah define and explicate (manifest) in detail the Divine will as expressed in the Torah.—See below, Epistle 29.</i> For though “the Torah derives from <i>chochmah</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:121a; ibid., 85a and III:81a; cf. <i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 17:5</i> its source and [its] root surpasses exceedingly the rank of <i>chochmah</i>, and is [that which is] referred to as the will of the Supreme One, blessed is He,<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">The Torah stems from <i>chochmah</i> while <i>chochmah</i> itself derives from the <i>supreme keter</i> which is also referred to as the <i>supreme ratzon</i>. See above, note 37; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 70 (127a); and cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 4.</i> as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 5:13.</i> “As with a shield <i>ratzon ta’etrenu</i> (You encompass him with favor)”—as a crown<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Atarah</i>, in Hebrew.</i> which is <i>over</i> the brains that are in the head [and as known from what has been explained on the verse “A woman of valor is the crown of her husband”<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 12:4.</i>—and “whoever repeats <i>halachot</i> every day…”<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">The author refers to his exposition appearing below, Epistle 29.</i>].
This is the meaning of “She girds her loins with <i>strength</i>”: there is no <i>strength</i> but Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sifrei</i>, Deuteronomy, sect. 343 (on Deuteronomy 32:2); <i>Shir Hashirim Rabbah</i> 1, s.v. <i>Meshacheni</i> 1; <i>Tanchuma</i>, <i>Berachah</i> 4; cf. above, note 10. See <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Shelach</i> 39d.</i> for it gives power and strength to the faculty of the loins—which are girded and embodied in it<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">In the Torah (the “body”; <i>tiferet</i>; cf. <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 21 (60a), and 70 (131a).</i> to strengthen and fortify its “arms,” namely the intellectual or natural awe and love, each one according to his measure. (As regards supporting and sustaining the faculty of the “head” of the soul, i.e., the intellect that contemplates… [Solomon] said:<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 31:18.</i> “She perceives that her trade is good,” as explained elsewhere.)
However, the occasion and time for the strengthening and fortification of the “arms” and the “head” is the time of the morning prayer. For above that is the time of compassion and a time of Supreme favor.<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:247b; III:204a. See also <i>Mechilta</i> on Exodus 14:24 and <i>Zohar Chadash</i> 8a.</i> And, therefore, that I will seek after from those who seek the L–rd: let them both contemplate and ponder, and have as a reminder between their eyes,<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Exodus 13:9.</i> all that I wrote them last year in general, and especially with respect to the devotion of prayer from the depth of the heart.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> II:63b.</i> Day after day they should seek the L–rd with all their heart and with all their soul,<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Deuteronomy 4:29.</i> to pour out their soul as water in the presence of the L–rd,<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Lamentations 2:19.</i> and as the saying of our Sages, of blessed memory, in <i>Sifrei</i>:<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sifrei</i> on Deuteronomy 6:3.</i> “To the extent of pressing out the soul….”
And now once more I put forth my hand a second time to an additional explanation and twofold request, extended and laid out before all men of the chasidic brotherhood,<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. above, note 6.</i> those close and those afar, to take upon themselves (the following):
On all weekdays, businessmen, who do not have so much time, should not descend before the Ark.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">That is, to lead the congregation in prayer.</i> Only from those who have the time [either teachers, or such as are supported by their parents] who are able to prolong the morning prayer to at least about an hour and a half on all weekdays shall one descend before the Ark, according to lot or by consent of the majority. And he should gather about him all those who are supported by their parents, or teachers, who are able to prolong like himself. This (arrangement) is not to be changed, I beg and beseech you!
On Shabbat and the Festivals, however, all the businessmen, too, have the time and opportunity to prolong their prayers with the devotion of their heart and soul to the L–rd. Moreover, theirs is the duty to do so with exceeding uplifting and abundant strength, as stated in <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, <i>Orach Chaim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Section 290:2 (glosses of R. Moses Isserles).</i> and as it is written in the Torah of Moses:<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 20:9, 10.</i> “Six days you shall work…and the seventh day is a Shabbat <i>to the L–rd your G–d</i>,” stating expressly that (Shabbat) is wholly to the L–rd.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">See Rabbi Schneur Zalman, <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, <i>Orach Chaim</i> 290:5.</i> On a Shabbat or Festival, therefore, they too can descend before the Ark, according to lot or by assent of the majority, as I wrote last year.
And it should be made known that, G–d willing, it is my intention to send spies secretly to all congregations,<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., <i>minyanim</i>—i.e., groups of ten or more men (the legally required quorum) gathered for the purpose of prayer, etc. In colloquial use, the term denotes not only the numbered groups but, where these gather regularly in a fixed place, to the congregation in general.</i> to find out and to inform about anyone who is able, and about anyone who has the time to prolong and meditate on prayer but is slothful. He shall be punished by estrangement, to be pushed away with both hands when he comes hither to hear the “words of the living G–d.”<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">A locution for the teachings of Chasidism.</i> And from the negative you can infer the positive.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">A Talmudic proposition; cf. <i>Nedarim</i> 11a.</i> But with those that shall obey it will be well, and the blessing of goodness shall come unto them—“there is no Good but Torah…”<sup>4</sup>

Chapter 2

<i>Upon his arrival from Petersburg</i><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">This letter the author sent to all his followers upon his release from imprisonment brought about by calumnies instigated by the opponents of Chasidism. The history of this letter, and the events of that important phase in the annals of Chasidism, form the contents of <i>The Arrest and Liberation of Rabbi Schneur Zalman of Liadi</i>, tr. J. I. Schochet (Kehot, 1964).</i>
<b>TWO.</b> “I have become small from all the favors and from all….”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 32:11.</i> This means that by every favor (<i>chesed</i>) that G–d bestows upon man, (man) is to become very humble. For “<i>chesed</i><sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Grace, favor, kindness.</i> is the right arm,”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">In the “man-image” of the <i>sefirot</i> (cf. Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>).—<i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 17a.</i> and “His right arm embraces me”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 2:6.</i>—which refers to the state of G–d actually bringing him close (to Himself), far more intensely than before. And whoever is close to G–d, with ever exceeding uplifting and elevation, must be ever more humble—to the lowliest plane,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Kitzurim V’Hearot L’Sefer Likkutei Amarim</i>, ed. Rabbi Menachem Mendel of Lubavitch (Kehot, 1948; 1989), pp. 40 and 149.</i> as it is written: “From afar the L–rd has appeared to me.”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 31:2.</i> And as known, “All that are <i>before Him</i> are esteemed as nothing.”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:11b (emphasis is the author’s).</i> Hence, whoever is more “before Him” is that much more as nothing, naught, and nonexistent.
And this is the rank of the “right side” of holiness and of “<i>chesed</i> to Abraham”<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Micah 7:20. Abraham signifies the attribute of <i>chesed</i>; see <i>Sefer Habahir</i> 48 (131); <i>Zohar</i> I:41a, II:51b; <i>Zohar Chadash</i> 27a; <i>et passim</i>.—The “right side,” too, signifies <i>chesed</i>; see Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>.</i> who said:<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 18:27.</i> “And I am dust and ashes.”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Chullin</i> 89a.</i> This (humility) is also the trait of Jacob, and therewith he justified himself for his fear of Esau and did not rely on the promise given to him—“And, behold, I am with you….”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 28:6.</i> (That is), because Jacob regarded himself as utterly insignificant<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., was very, very small in his (own) esteem.</i> [because of the multitude of favors, “for with my staff…”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 32:11.</i>], and as unfit and unworthy to be saved…and as the saying of our Sages, of blessed memory, “maybe sin will cause…,” for it appeared to him that he had sinned.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 4a.</i>
It is different, though, with the corresponding opposite,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">See Ecclesiastes 7:14: “G–d has made one thing opposite the other.” This verse is interpreted to mean that everything in one realm has its corresponding opposite in another realm. Thus every factor in the realm of “holiness” has a corresponding opposite in the “other side,” in the realm of the profane or evil.—See <i>Sefer Habahir</i> 9 (11); <i>Zohar</i> I:160a; ibid., III:282a; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 70 (125a); <i>et passim</i>. See also <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 25:1; <i>Or</i> <i>Hatorah</i>, <i>Nach</i>, vol. 2, p. 1128; below, Epistle 25, note 63.</i> i.e., Ishmael—“<i>chesed of kelipah</i>”<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">As Abraham signifies the attribute of <i>chesed</i> in holiness, so Ishmael signifies the attribute of <i>chesed</i> in <i>kelipah</i>; see <i>Zohar</i> III:246b (also ibid., 124a). Cf. <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Ekev</i> 18a.</i>: the more kindness (manifested to him), the more he grows in pride, haughtiness, and self-satisfaction.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Chullin</i> 89a and <i>Midrash Tehillim</i>, ed. Buber, 22:20, in the editor’s glosses, note 99.</i>
Therefore I come with a general announcement to inform all our followers regarding the multitude of favors—“The great things that the L–rd has done with us”<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 126:3.</i>: to hold on to the attributes of Jacob, the “remnant of His people”<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 11:11.</i> and the “remainder of Israel,”<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Jeremiah 6:9; 31:6; etc.</i> who regards himself truly as remnants and excess that is of no use.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Rosh</i> <i>Hashanah</i> 17a.</i> They are not to become haughty-minded in relation to their brethren…not to speak defiantly against them or hiss at them,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Alternately: to <i>whistle</i> at them; cf. <i>The Arrest and Liberation</i>, p. 65.</i> Heaven forfend. A strict warning: hold your peace! No mention is to be made!<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Amos 6:10.</i> Rather, they are to subdue their spirit and heart before everyone<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Avot</i> 4:10.</i> according to the attribute of “Truth (<i>emet</i>) to Jacob,”<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Micah 7:20. Jacob signifies the attribute of <i>truth</i> (which corresponds to <i>tiferet</i>); see <i>Sefer Habahir</i> 49 (137); <i>Zohar</i> II:267a; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 4b; <i>Zohar Chadash</i> 26c. Cf. <i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 78:14; and see below, Epistle 6.</i> with humility and a “Soft answer that turns away anger,”<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 15:8.</i> and with a restrained spirit…. And,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The following words did not appear in the original epistle and were added later by the author. See <i>Hayom Yom</i>, 10 Menachem Av.</i> maybe, through all that G–d will put into the heart of their brethren that “As waters (reflect) the face….”<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 27:19; see above, Epistle 1, note 26.</i>

Chapter 3

<b>THREE.</b> “And he garbed himself with <i>tzedakah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tzedakah</i> has two interrelated meanings: a) righteousness and b) charity (cf. <i>Moreh Nevuchim</i> 3:53). Though these two meanings are strictly interrelated, the emphasis in these writings is chiefly on the latter. As a Scriptural term it is, therefore, left untranslated (in this and subsequent sections) to avoid confusion.</i> as a coat of mail, and a helmet of salvation upon his head.”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 59:17.</i> (On this verse) our Sages, of blessed memory, commented: “Just as with chain mail each scale adds up to form a large mail, so it is with charity; each coin adds up to a great amount.”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 9b.</i> This means, just as the mail is made of scales over gaps, and these shield against any arrow entering through the gaps, so it is with the act of charity.
The meaning of this is (as follows). Charity is greater than all the commandments.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">“Charity is equal to all the commandments (together)”—<i>Bava Batra</i> 9a; <i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Peah</i>, end of ch. 4. See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 37.</i> (The performance of the commandments) produces “garments” for the soul.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The reward for observing Torah and <i>mitzvot</i> is the soul’s delighting in the splendor of the <i>Shechinah</i>. In the World to Come the soul will actually apprehend, in a manifest way, the very essence of the Divine vivification, thus Divinity Itself, as it were. The problem is that the soul is finite. Though its source is in Divinity, as it evolves and descends to become vested in the body, the soul becomes a created and distinct, thus finite entity. How then can this created entity apprehend creative Divinity, which is infinite and essentially inapprehensible? The mediating factor, which enables the soul to apprehend Divinity, is Torah and <i>mitzvot</i>. Torah and <i>mitzvot</i> are essentially Divine; their source is in the Supernal Will and the Divine <i>chochmah</i> which are not separate from, but absolutely one with, the G–dhead. <i>Torah</i> and <i>mitzvot</i> thus transcend even the level of the “splendor of the <i>Shechinah</i>.” When man performs the <i>mitzvot</i> as they are vested in physical objects (e.g., <i>tefillin</i> of leather; <i>tzitzit</i> of wool; <i>tzedakah</i> with money; etc.), he unites his soul with the <i>mitzvot</i> he performs. His soul is vested in the <i>mitzvot</i>; the <i>mitzvot</i> become garments for his soul. (Cf. <i>Bereishit</i> <i>Rabbah</i> 19:6) These garments serve like channels, or <i>kelim</i> (vessels), by means of which the soul, when in Eden, is able to apprehend Divinity, i.e., the splendor of the <i>Shechinah</i>. “The principle of this matter is: just as the soul is given a garment in which it vests itself (i.e., the body) in order to exist in this world, so it is given also a garment of supernal splendor wherewith to exist in the World to Come and to be able to gaze in the radiant speculum from that Land of Life.” <i>Zohar</i> I:65b ff.
