See below, Epistle 29; cf. <i>Etz</i> <i>Chaim</i> 44:3; <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 4; <i>Torah Or</i>, <i>Chayei Sara</i> 16a ff.; <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Shelach</i> 38d; below, Epistle 23.</i> (These garments) are elicited from the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, from the level of <i>sovev kol almin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Encircling (or: <i>encompassing</i>) all worlds; denoting the transcendence of G–d.</i> (<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>as the meaning of <i>memalei kol almin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Filling (or: permeating) all worlds; denoting the immanence of G–d.</i> and <i>sovev kol almin</i> has been explained in <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, see there<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Chapters 48 and 51. See below, note 12.</i>), by the “arousal from below,”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">That is, by an appropriate action of man; cf. below, Epistle 4, note 43.</i> i.e., the (performance of the) command of G–d and the will of Supreme One, blessed is He. The essence of this efflux from the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, is a garment and encompassing light (<i>or makif</i>) for the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i> [which evolve from cause to cause and from rung to rung…] referred to as <i>memalei kol almin</i>.
This means that the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, vests itself and radiates within the whole evolution of the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>, and it emanates the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, which evolve into <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>, by means of an immense contraction (<i>tzimtzum</i>) [explained in <i>Etz Chaim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">By R. Chaim Vital, containing the principal teachings of the Arizal. See <i>Etz Chaim</i> 1:2 ff. <i>et passim</i>. See Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, s.v. <i>Tzimtzum</i>.</i>], and is referred to as the inner light (<i>or pnimi</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Creation on all its levels is vitalized and sustained by a Divine force or emanation. The life-force is called <i>or pnimi</i> (inner light). As the soul animates the body, permeating and vitalizing all its organs, precisely so is the <i>or pnimi</i> the soul that permeates and vitalizes creation on all its levels. However, just as the soul is but a dimmed manifestation of actual Divinity (see below, Epistle 5, note 33), precisely so it is with the <i>or pnimi</i>. The <i>or pnimi</i> is but a dimmed manifestation, or radiation, of the actual light of the <i>En Sof</i>. The source of the <i>or pnimi</i> is the <i>or makif</i> (encompassing light). The <i>or makif</i> (also called <i>or</i> <i>sovev</i>) is the all-inclusive light which not only permeates (in concealed fashion, by way of <i>tzimtzum)</i>, but also encompasses or transcends creation. (Cf. Addendum, ibid.) The <i>or pnimi</i> denotes the Divine immanence: G–d as revealed or manifest in creation. The <i>or makif</i> denotes the Divine transcendence: the supra-revelatory aspect of G–d. Both these aspects are succinctly adduced in the Midrashic saying: “The L–rd is the place of His world, but His world is not His place!” (<i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 68:9; <i>Zohar</i> III:242a) In terms of the <i>sefirot</i> the <i>or makif</i> corresponds to <i>keter</i>, the supreme, transcendent <i>sefirah</i>; the <i>or pnimi</i> corresponds to <i>chochmah</i>, the basic <i>sefirah</i> which embodies <i>keter</i> and is the immanent foundation of all subsequent emanations. See ref. cited above, Epistle 1, note 13; below, Epistle 17; <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, Vayikra 22c.</i>
Now, by the fulfillment of the commandments the abovementioned <i>or makif</i> is elicited and radiates within the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>, thereby uniting itself with the <i>or pnimi</i>. This is referred to as the unification of the Holy One, blessed is He, and His <i>Shechinah</i>, as explained elsewhere.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 41. This “unification” establishes the essential oneness between the ranks of G–d the Transcendent and the <i>Shechinah</i> (G–d as He manifests Himself and is immanent in His creatures), so that there is complete unity above and below.</i> And from a reflection of a reflection from the abovementioned <i>or makif</i> [by means of a great contraction], a garment is made in the Lower and Higher Garden of Eden for the <i>nefesh-ruach-neshamah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">The three general planes in the soul. See below, Epistle 5, note 33.</i> of man, enabling them to derive pleasure and attain some apprehension and illumination from the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, as explained elsewhere.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. below, Epistles 17 and 29.</i>
And this is what our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “In this world, there is no reward for the commandments.”<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kiddushin</i> 39b.</i> For in this world, which is physical and in a state of limitation and a great and most immense contraction, it is impossible that any reflection of the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, should become invested, except by means of the ten <i>sefirot</i>, which, in the sacred <i>Zohar</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> II:123a; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 17a. (See Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>).</i> are referred to as the “body”: “<i>Chesed</i> is the right arm….”
For just as there is no comparison between the physical body and the soul, so is there no comparison whatsoever between the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> and the Supreme Emanator, the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He. For in relation to the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, even the supreme <i>chochmah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chochmah ilaah</i>.</i> which is the first (of the <i>sefirot</i>), is on the plane of a material action, as explained in <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Part II, ch. 9; cf. also Part I, ch. 2, in the author’s marginal gloss.</i>
Therefore, by the act of charity and the performance of kindness [the fruits of which man enjoys in this world<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Peah</i> 1:1.</i>] there appear, metaphorically speaking, gaps in the supernal garment that encompasses the Body—[the <i>kelim</i> (vessels) of the ten <i>sefirot</i><sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">See Addendum, ibid., for the meaning of this term.</i>]—through which to irradiate and to diffuse light and abundance: from “<i>chesed</i>, the right arm”<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">That is, from the <i>sefirah</i> of <i>chesed</i>.</i>—longevity in this physical world;<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">See Proverbs 3:16: “Length of days in her right arm.”</i> and from “the left arm”<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">That is, from the <i>sefirah</i> of <i>gevurah</i>.</i>—wealth and honor;<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 3:16: “and in her left arm, riches and honor.”</i> and likewise with beauty,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., beauty (as implied by the term <i>tiferet)</i> emanates from the <i>sefirah</i> of <i>tiferet</i>.</i> grandeur and majesty, and gladness.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Par. I Chronicles 16:27.—The Hebrew terms are: <i>hod</i> and <i>hadar</i>, and <i>chedvah</i>. <i>Hod</i> and <i>hadar</i> correspond to the <i>sefirot</i> of <i>netzach</i> and <i>hod</i> (see <i>Zohar</i> II:98a and <i>Hagahot</i> <i>R. Chaim Vital</i>, ad loc.—in the light of <i>Zohar</i> I:262a); grandeur and majesty thus emanate from the fourth and fifth attributes. <i>Chedvah</i> corresponds to the <i>sefirah</i> of <i>yesod</i> (see <i>Zohar</i> I:206b and III:5a); gladness thus emanates from the sixth attribute.—Cf. the interpretation of this verse in R. Chaim Vital, <i>Shaar Hakavanot</i>, s.v. <i>Derush Inyan Tefillat Hashachar</i> (ed. Tel Aviv, 1962, vol. 1, 107a).</i>
But to prevent the <i>chitzonim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Extraneous forces; i.e., extraneous (the furthest removed) in relation to holiness; thus, the forces of evil and impurity.</i> from drawing, above, from the light and abundance which evolves and descends netherward to this physical world, and likewise, below, to shield man, and to guard him and to save him from all physical and spiritual harm, the <i>or makif</i> reflects the light, and, figuratively speaking, fills the breach, for it is of the category of Infinitude and <i>sovev kol almin</i>, as mentioned above. And this is what our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “adds up to a <i>great</i> amount,”<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The author puts emphasis on the word “great”; cf. below, Epistle 30.</i> for “Great is the L–rd and exceedingly glorified”<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 48:2 (ibid. 145:3).—This effect of the <i>or makif</i>, in reward for the performance of kindness, stems from the infinite Greatness (<i>chesed</i>) of G–d.</i>—without end, limit, and restriction [<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>Heaven Forfend].
But what causes the descent to this physical world of the light and abundance from the ten <i>sefirot</i> [which are referred to as the “body”]? It is the abovementioned union, for it is an additional radiation and effluence from the level of the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, the Supreme Emanator, blessed is He, in a measure exceeding the radiation and effluence at the beginning of the emanation and evolution…. And the additional radiation and effluence starts at the beginning of the ten <i>sefirot</i>.
That is the meaning of “And a helmet of salvation upon his head”: <i>yeshu’ah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Salvation.</i> is of the etymon <i>of vayisha</i>—“And the L–rd <i>turned</i> to Abel and his gift,”<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 4:4.</i> which refers to the descent of the light and abundance of the “three hundred and seventy lights” mentioned in the sacred <i>Zohar</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:4b; III:133b; cf. <i>Etz Chaim</i> 13:14.—370 is the numerical equivalent (<i>gematria</i>) of ש”ע, the root letters of <i>yeshu’ah</i> and <i>vayisha</i>.</i> and as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 6:25.</i> “May the L–rd make His Countenance shine upon you”; “May He make His Countenance shine upon us forever”<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 67:2.</i>—<i>with us</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">That is, “with our participation”; thus, through an act from ourselves. See <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Tavo</i> 43d.</i> that is, through the act of charity.
And this is the meaning of “He sows <i>tzedakot</i> (charities), causes <i>yeshu’ot</i> to sprout forth.”<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, Morning Prayers.</i> So may the L–rd make His Face radiate toward them, “their <i>tzedakah</i> will endure forever”;<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 112:3.</i> and may their glory be exalted by the <i>yeshu’ah</i> of “He who causes the power of <i>yeshu’ah</i> to flourish,”<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, weekday <i>Amidah</i>.</i> the sprout of <i>tzedakah</i> from the “helmet of <i>yeshu’ah</i>”—mentioned above, as is the wish (of he) who seeks it.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Lamentations 3:25.</i>

Chapter 4

<b>FOUR.</b> Israel shall be redeemed only through <i>tzedakah</i>, as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 1:27.</i> “<i>Veshaveha</i>—and her repatriates,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">See below, note 55.</i> through <i>tzedakah</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 139a; <i>Sanhedrin</i> 98a.</i> It is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 85:14.</i> “<i>Tzedek</i> <i>lefanav</i> <i>yehalech</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tzedek</i> (righteousness; here in the sense of charity) shall go before Him.</i> Now, it should really say: <i>yelech</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">This would be the proper grammatical form for the conventional translation and sense, rather than the causative “<i>yehalech</i>.”</i> But the idea is according to what is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 27:8.</i> “My heart said for You, ‘Seek <i>panay</i> (My face),’”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., “my heart said in Your (G–d’s) name: ‘Seek My Face’”; see commentaries, ad loc.</i> that is: “Seek the <i>pnimiyut</i><sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Inwardness; the innermost point, identical with essence (see below, note 26).—פנים (face) is etymologically related to פנים (interior); cf. Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah</i> 1:10.</i> of the heart.” For in the heart <sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i> [the element of the Divine fire that is in the heart]<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">V. L.: for in the flame, the element, etc. (reading בלהב instead of בהלב).</i> there are two aspects: the aspect of <i>chitzoniyut</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Outwardness, externality; the antonym of <i>pnimiyut</i>; the degree furthest removed from <i>pnimiyut</i>, the essence. See Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, s.v <i>Chitzoniyut</i>.</i> and the aspect of <i>pnimiyut</i>.
The <i>chitzoniyut</i> of the heart is the enthusiasm that flares up on account of the understanding (<i>binah</i>) and the knowledge (<i>daat</i>) of the greatness of the L–rd, the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, by contemplating<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">V. L.: to cause them to contemplate.</i> on His greatness, and from this contemplation giving birth to a strong love resembling “flashes of fire….”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Song of Songs 8:6; cf. above, Epistle 1, note 29.</i>
The <i>pnimiyut</i> of the heart is the innermost point in the heart and depth of the heart which transcends the aspect of knowledge and contemplation that man can contemplate in his heart on the greatness of the L–rd; and as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 130:1.</i> “From the depths I call to You, O L–rd,” i.e., from the depth of the heart.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:63b.</i> (<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>It is, for example, so with worldly matters: sometimes there is an extremely important matter upon which the whole vitality of man hinges and touches him as far as, and including, the innermost point of the heart, and it causes him to perform acts and say things without any reason whatsoever.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">In most texts, the brackets close here. But it would appear quite obviously from the context that the passage to be enclosed by the brackets ends further on. The Lubavitcher Rebbe, Rabbi Menachem M. Schneerson, notes in H. V. that in the Shklov edition of the <i>Tanya</i> (1814) there do not appear any brackets at all.</i>
And “the one corresponds to the other,”<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 7:14. See above, Epistle 2, note 16.</i> it is precisely so with the “service of the heart.”<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the worship of G–d, as opposed to the pursuit of worldly matters.</i> This is because the faculty of the innermost point of the heart transcends the faculty of reason (<i>daat</i>)—which extends and vests itself in the attributes born of wisdom, understanding, and knowledge (<i>chabad</i>), as known.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">The seven (emotive) attributes <i>chesed</i>, <i>gevurah</i>, <i>tiferet</i>, etc., are the offsprings of the three intellectual faculties of <i>chochmah</i>, <i>binah</i>, and <i>daat</i> (cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 3); <i>daat</i> in particular exerts a determinative influence upon the attributes (cf. below, Epistle 15). See also <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, ch. 8.</i> It is,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">The faculty of the <i>pnimiyut</i> of the heart.</i> rather, an aspect of the radiation from the supreme <i>chochmah</i>, which transcends <i>binah</i> and <i>daat</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Both of which are rooted in <i>chochmah</i>.</i> and in which there is vested and concealed the actual light of G–d, as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 3:19.</i> “The L–rd with <i>chochmah</i>….”<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">“The L–rd <i>by chochmah</i> founded the earth,” or “the L–rd <i>in chochmah</i>,” etc. <i>Chochmah</i>, the “hyle” of the creation (cf. Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, s.v. <i>Chochmah</i>), “embodies,” as it were, Divinity. Hence the soul contains a spark of Divinity in its faculty of <i>chochmah—</i>which ultimately originates in the Supreme <i>chochmah</i>. See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 18; cf. <i>Etz Chaim</i> 42:3.</i> And this precisely is the aspect of the spark of Divinity in every soul of Israel.)
The reason that not every person merits this rank [of the service of the heart from the depth of the heart in a state of <i>pnimiyut</i>] is because this aspect is with him in a state of exile and captivity.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pnimiyut</i> is the innermost point; the essence. (See Addendum, ibid., s.v. <i>Pnimiyut</i>) Intellect and emotion are external to soul; they are its expression and manifestation. <i>Chochmah</i>, a state of nascence rather than an external entity, is as close to essence of soul as is attainable. Its revelation is the expression of the soul’s essence and is naturally uncommon. As the text explains, it is in a “state of exile,” the spark of Divinity within it prevented from manifesting itself, remaining more potential than effective in ordering actual life.</i> And this is actually the state of the exile of the <i>Shechinah</i>, for this precisely is the aspect of the spark of Divinity that is in his divine soul. The cause of the exile is as our Sages, of blessed memory, said:<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Megillah</i> 29a.</i> “They were exiled to Babylon, and the <i>Shechinah</i> went with them”; i.e., (man) has vested the aspect of the innermost point of his heart in the corresponding opposite,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., in the corresponding opposite of the love and worship of G–d.</i> namely in the soiled garments of mundane matters and worldly desires, which are referred to as “Babylon,”<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 17, with respect to <i>Edom</i>.</i> and is the aspect of the prepuce that covers the covenant and the innermost point of the heart. Of this it was said:<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 10:16. (“Excise” in Hebrew is the same term used for “circumcise.”)</i> “And you shall excise the prepuce of your heart.”
Now, in circumcision there are two grades: <i>milah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Excision.</i> and <i>periah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Uncovering (as in Numbers 5:18; see <i>Ibn Ezra</i>, ad loc.).</i> which (apply respectively to) the coarse prepuce and the thin membrane. With respect to the prepuce of the heart there are likewise coarse and delicate desires. These require <i>milah</i> and <i>periah</i>, and “having circumcised and not having uncovered is tantamount to not having circumcised,”<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 137b.</i> because, after all, the innermost point of the heart is still covered in a garment of thin sackcloth: in a state of exile and captivity.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 23:17, s.v. <i>Periah</i>.</i>
Now, concerning the excision of the prepuce itself it is written: “And you shall excise the prepuce of your heart,” i.e., <i>you</i>, by yourselves. But the removal of the thin membrane is a difficult matter for man, and of this it was said that with the coming of the Messiah “<i>the L–rd</i>, <i>your G–d</i>, will circumcise your heart…to love the L–rd your G–d with all your heart and all your soul, <i>for the sake of your life</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 30:6. See the commentary of Nachmanides, ad loc.</i> i.e., because the L–rd alone is literally your whole life.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">This unique interpretation may be better understood by quoting a passage from <i>Kuntres Hahitpaalut</i>, by the author’s son, R. Dov Ber of Lubavitch, where this oft-quoted principle is elucidated: “It is written (Deuteronomy 30:20): ‘to love the L–rd your G–d, for He is your life.’ (The verse uses the masculine term for ‘He’—הוא, translit.: <i>Hu</i>.) It is impossible to explain that ‘for <i>Hu</i> is your life’ refers to ‘to love the L–rd’—i.e., that this love is your life. For if so, it would have to say ‘for היא (translit.: <i>He</i>, the feminine gender, since the Hebrew for love—<i>ahavah</i>—is a feminine word)…. Why then does it say ‘for <i>Hu…</i>’? No doubt that the meaning of this passage is intelligible to all, that is, that ‘for <i>Hu</i> is your life’ is a reason given: <i>why</i> should you love (<i>the L–rd</i>)? Because ‘<i>He</i> is your life.’” (Beginning of <i>Kuntres Hahitpaalut</i>; see also <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 9.)</i> That is why this love<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">The love spoken of in the verse quoted, which follows after the Divine excision of the heart’s thin membrane.</i> stems from the depth of the heart, from the truly innermost point, as mentioned above, and transcends the faculty of <i>daat</i>.
Therefore, too, the Messiah will come when generally “unexpected<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hessech Hadaat</i>, lit., removal (or lack) of <i>daat</i>. The interpretation here is that the lack of <i>daat</i> comes through a transcendence of <i>daat</i> rather than the conventional inference of forgetfulness.</i> by Israel,”<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 97a.</i> which is the manifestation of the general innermost point, and the emergence of the general <i>Shechinah</i> from the exile and captivity forever more. Similarly, every individual spark of the <i>Shechinah</i>, inherent in the soul of every one of Israel, emerges for the moment from the exile and captivity during the “momentary life—meaning prayer,”<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Prayer is termed “momentary life” because it deals with requests for momentary needs (of the momentary life on earth) in opposition to the study of Torah (eternal life), the benefit of which is not for the moment only but for eternity. (<i>Shabbat</i> 10a, see comment by Rashi and <i>Maharsha</i>, ad loc., though see <i>Kuntres Acharon</i>, Essay 4.)</i> and the service of the heart from the depth of the heart, (i.e.,) from the aspect of the innermost point [which becomes revealed from the prepuce and soars upward to cleave unto Him with a fierce passion, in a mode of “for the sake of your life”].
And this, too, is considered a state of <i>hessech daat</i><sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Absentmindedness; see above, note 38.</i> of man. For that rank<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">The revelation of this innermost spark, the <i>Shechinah</i> residing within man in concealment.</i> transcends the <i>daat</i> of man and his contemplation on the greatness of the L–rd; it is, though, a sort of gift given by the L–rd from Heaven from the radiation of the [aspect of the] Supreme Countenance, as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 6:25; see above, note 9.</i> “May the L–rd make His Countenance shine upon you,” and as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 30:6.</i> “And the L–rd, your G–d, will circumcise….”
But it is well known that an arousal from above comes only in response to an arousal from below,<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">“Arousal—(or: stimulation, initiative)—from below” refers to an act undertaken by man, a human effort, while “arousal from above” refers to the Divine efflux, issuing from Above. Generally, to elicit this Heavenly effusion one needs to “arouse” it. This is done by an appropriate, benevolent act on earth. Cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:77b, 86b, 88a; III:110b; <i>et passim</i>. See also below, notes 46 and 47, and below, Epistle 5, notes 83-90 (and the text to which these notes apply).</i> in the mode of an elevation of <i>mayin nukvin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Feminine waters.—See <i>Zohar</i> I:29b: “The earth is fed from the waters of the heaven, and its waters are poured into it. However, these waters are masculine, and the nether ones are feminine; and the nether ones are fed from the masculine ones. The nether waters call to the upper, like a female that receives the male…,” see there and ibid. 60b. The essentially Lurianic concept of the elevation of the feminine waters (<i>mayin nukvin</i>) is the “arousal from below” (see previous note), which consequently elicits the masculine waters (<i>mayin duchrin</i>)—the “arousal from above,” to issue and effuse netherward, “to feed, and be received by, the category of the feminine.” See <i>Etz Chaim</i> 39:1 ff. and <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, end of ch. 10 and end of ch. 53.</i> as our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “No drop (of rain) descends from above….”<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">“…without two corresponding drops first ascending from below.”—<i>Zohar</i> III:247b; <i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 13:13.</i> It is, therefore, necessary that man perform first the <i>milah</i> by himself, to remove the prepuce of the heart and the coarse and thin husks which clothe and cover the innermost point of the heart [i.e., the aspect of the love of the L–rd in a mode of “for the sake of your life,” which is in exile among the desires of this world, which are also in a mode of “for the sake of your life” by way of “the one corresponding to the other,”<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 7:14. See above, Epistle 2, note 16.</i> as mentioned above].
And this is done by the giving of charity to G–d from his money which is his vitality, especially with him whose substance is limited and who is very hard-pressed at the time, for he gives of his very life;<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 37.</i> and more specifically, when he earns by the toil of his hands. For it is not possible that one does not work oftentimes in a mode of “the innermost point of the heart,” i.e., from the depth of the heart, as is the way of the world in their occupations with business and the like.
Thus, now, at the time that he disburses the fruits of his toil and gives unto the L–rd with joy and gladness, he, thereby, redeems his soul from the pit.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Job 33:28.</i> That is, (he redeems) the innermost point of his heart which was in a state of exile and captivity within the coarse or thin husk (<i>kelipah</i>), as it is written: “Guard your heart from every <i>mishmar</i>”<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 4:23.</i>—the meaning <i>of mishmar</i> being a prison.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Rashi</i> on Genesis 42:17.</i> Thus, now, through this charity, it was redeemed from the <i>chitzonim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">The forces of evil; see above, Epistle 3, note 28.</i> This is also <i>periah</i>, a notion of “removing a debt,”<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Mishnah, <i>Bava Batra</i> 10:7, <i>Shevuot</i> 7:7; <i>Bava Batra</i> 174a; etc.</i> for he had become indebted and subjected to the <i>chitzonim</i> that ruled in him over the innermost point of his heart. And this is the meaning of “and her captives (<i>shaveha</i>),<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">The word שביה may be traced to the root שוב, <i>to return</i> (thus reading: her repatriates), or to the root שבה <i>to capture</i> (thus reading: her captives).</i> through <i>tzedakah</i>.”
And this is the meaning of <i>Tzedek</i> shall go (<i>yehalech</i>) before Him (<i>lefanav</i>): <i>Lefanav</i> is of the etymon of <i>pnimiyut</i>, and <i>yehalech</i> has a connotation of <i>holacha</i><sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">The active form of the causative stem of the verb הלך.</i> (leading). For it<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tzedek—</i>righteousness; charity. Psalms 85:14 is now interpreted to read: charity leads the <i>pnimiyut</i> of the heart to G–d.</i> leads the innermost (point) of the heart to G–d, and then “it sets his steps toward the way of G–d,”<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Psalms</i> 85:14 (conclusion of “<i>tzedek lefanav yehalech</i>”).</i> as it is written: “And you shall walk in His ways”;<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:9.</i> “You shall go after the L–rd your G–d,”<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid. 13:5.</i>—with every performance of the commandments, and the study of Torah, which is equivalent to them all.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Peah</i> 1:1.</i> For they all ascend to G–d through the inwardness of the heart with greater uplifting, and exceedingly surpassing, their ascent to G–d through the externality of the heart<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> II:210b.</i> [which is born of contemplation and knowledge alone, without an “illumination of the face”<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Heorat Panim</i>, in Hebrew.</i> from above, but in a state of “concealment of the face”<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hester Panim</i>, in Hebrew.</i>]. For the Supernal <i>panim</i> does not radiate downward except through an arousal from below, through the act of charity, which is called “peace.”<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Peah</i>, end of ch. 4; <i>Bava Batra</i> 10a.</i> And this is the meaning of what is written: “He has redeemed my soul in peace,”<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 55:19. Or: “through peace.”</i> stating expressly “my soul.”<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the <i>pnimiyut</i>, the innermost point.</i>
This is also the reason why charity is called “peace” (<i>shalom</i>), because according to the saying of our Sages, of blessed memory,<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Peah</i>, end of ch. 4; <i>Bava Batra</i> 10a.</i> peace is made between Israel and their Father in Heaven through the redemption of their souls [which are truly a part of G–d] from the hands of the <i>chitzonim</i>. This is especially the case with charity for the Land of Israel, for it is truly the charity of the L–rd,<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">See below, Epistle 17.</i> as it is written: “The eyes of the L–rd your G–d are constantly upon it”;<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 11:12.</i> “And My eyes and My heart will be there at all times.”<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 9:3.</i>
And it<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">This charity.</i> has stood by us to redeem the life of our soul from the counsel of those who intend to repel our steps, and it will stand by us forever to establish our soul in the true life of the Fountainhead of life,<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., the Life of life; cf. <i>Yoma</i> 71a; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 19 (41b) and 69 (115a); and see below, end of Epistle 22a.</i> to be enlightened with the light of life<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Job 33:30; cf. Psalms 56:14.</i> which the L–rd “will make His Countenance shine upon us forever,”<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 67:2; cf. above, end of Epistle 3.</i> <i>amen</i>—may this be (His) will.

Chapter 5

<b>FIVE.</b> “And David made a name.”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 8:13.</i> In the sacred <i>Zohar</i> this is interpreted in relation to the verse “And David performed justice and <i>tzedakah</i> with all his people…”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid., 15.</i>: “Rabbi Shimon wept and said: Who makes the Holy Name, every day? He who gives charity to the poor….”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:113a, b.</i>
This will be understood by first explaining the comment of our Sages, of blessed memory, on the verse<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 26:4.</i> “For by <i>Yud-Hey</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">These two letters combined form a name of G–d, reading: “For in G–d, the L–rd….”</i> the L–rd is the <i>tzur</i><sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tosafot</i> on <i>Berachot</i> 51a (s.v. <i>Zocheh</i>) enlightens this interpretation by quoting a version which does not appear in our text of the Talmud: “do not read <i>tzur</i> (rock), but <i>tzar</i> (formed, designed).” This version does appear in the <i>Zohar</i> II:22b, though emending <i>tzur</i> to <i>tzayar</i> (former, designer), an emendation that appears elsewhere in the Talmud (relating to other verses), e.g., <i>Berachot</i> 10a, etc.</i> of the worlds”: “This world was created by the <i>hey</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The letter <i>hey</i> (second letter of <i>Yud-hey</i>).</i> the World to Come was created by the <i>yud</i><sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">The letter <i>yud</i> (first letter of <i>Yud-hey</i>).</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Menachot</i> 29b; <i>Midrashim</i> on Genesis 2:4.</i> This means that the delight which the souls of the righteous derive and enjoy from the splendor of the <i>Shechinah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 1, note 21.</i> which radiates in the upper and lower Gardens of Eden, consists of their delighting in their apprehension and conception, for they conceive, know, and attain some apprehension of the light and vitality which effuses there—in a state of manifestation—from the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, to their soul and their spirit of understanding, so that each and every one can understand and attain some perception according to his level and his deeds.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:129b and 135b.</i> That is why in the sacred <i>Zohar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:158a; <i>Zohar Chadash</i> 93a (beg. of <i>Tikkunim Chadashim</i>). See below, Epistle 29.</i> the World to Come (<i>olam haba</i>) is referred to as <i>binah</i> (understanding).
And this flow issues from the plane of the Supreme <i>chochmah</i>, which is the source of the conception and apprehension referred to as <i>binah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chochmah</i> is the first, and as such the source of all succeeding <i>sefirot</i>. <i>Binah</i> is merely the elucidation and expansion of <i>chochmah</i>; the comprehensive knowledge following upon the conceptual wisdom of <i>chochmah</i>. Thus, <i>binah</i> is referred to as “understanding (or: deriving) one thing out of another” (i.e., out of <i>chochmah</i>, the original concept). See Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, s.v. <i>Chochmah-Binah</i>.</i> For <i>chochmah</i> is the primordium of the intellect, antecedent to apprehension and understanding becoming manifest, rather, still in a state of hiding and concealment,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Consciousness, and thus comprehension, is still concealed.</i> except for some trifle here and there flowing forth and issuing from it to the faculty of <i>binah</i>, making it possible to understand and to apprehend the hidden intellect. In the sacred <i>Zohar</i>, <i>chochmah</i> is, therefore, referred to as “the dot in the palace”;<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:6a; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 12b; <i>et passim</i>. Cf. also <i>Zohar</i> I:15a ff. “Dot”—<i>chochmah</i>; “palace”—<i>binah</i>; see Addendum, ibid.</i> and this is the form of the <i>yud</i> of the Name of <i>Havaya</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., a simple, nondimensional point.—The four letters of the Ineffable Name—Y-H-V-H, pronounced in conversation <i>Havaya</i>—signify the ten <i>sefirot</i>: <i>Yud</i>—<i>chochmah</i>; (the first) <i>Hey</i>—<i>binah</i>; <i>Vav</i>—<i>tiferet</i>, or/and the totality of the six attributes (<i>chesed</i> to <i>yesod</i>); (the latter) <i>Hey</i>—<i>malchut</i>. (The thorn of the letter <i>yud</i> signifies <i>keter</i>, which precedes <i>chochmah</i> and is often counted as one of the ten <i>sefirot</i> instead of <i>daat</i>; see Addendum, ibid.) Cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:17a, 258a; <i>et passim</i>. See <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 4.</i> blessed is He, and is called Eden<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:290a; see also <i>Zohar</i> II:90a.—<i>Eden</i> (<i>chochmah</i>) is to be distinguished from <i>olam haba</i> (<i>binah</i>).</i>—of which it is said:<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 64:3.</i> “No eye has seen it….”<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Berachot</i> 34b; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 12a.</i> And it is referred to as “The father (<i>abba</i>)<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chochmah</i>.</i> who founded the daughter (<i>barta</i>)<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Malchut</i>.</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:248a, 256b, and 258a (commenting on Proverbs 3:19). See Nachmanides on Genesis 1:1: “The word <i>Bereishit</i> alludes that the universe was created by the ten <i>sefirot</i>, and indicates the <i>sefirah</i> which is called <i>chochmah</i> (see below, notes 80-82)<i>—in which is the foundation of everything</i>, as it is said: “The L–rd in <i>chochmah</i> founded the earth.’” Everything thus is founded in <i>chochmah</i>, but the most immediate “agent” to the egression of the universe into substantiality and manifestation is the last <i>sefirah</i>—<i>malchut</i> (which, of course, ultimately originates in <i>chochmah</i>); cf. below, Epistle 8, note 44; Epistle 20; and <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 52. The earth, therefore, signifies <i>malchut</i>, and likewise does “<i>the word of the L–rd</i>,” the letters of speech (the Ten Fiats) wherewith the world was created. See Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>. This is “<i>abba</i> founded <i>barta</i>.” The author proceeds now to elaborate on this theme.</i>
This means: The formation of the letters of speech which issue from the five organs of articulation<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Larynx, palate, tongue, teeth, and lips.—See <i>Sefer Yetzirah</i> 2:3; cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:227b, 228a, 295b; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 70 (132a); <i>et passim</i>.</i> is not an intellectual capacity. It is also not inherent in the nature of these organs to pronounce the letters—[by means of the breath and the sound that strikes them]—by either a natural faculty or by an intellectual faculty. With the lips, for example, through which are uttered the letters <i>bet-vav-mem-pey</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">פ-מ-ו-ב.</i> neither nature nor the intellect compels the utterance of the four varying types of pronunciation of these letters in accordance with the variations in the movement of the lips—which are moved by the same breath and the same sound that strikes them equally. On the contrary: the change in the movements of the lips depends on the difference in pronunciation of the letters the soul wishes to utter by means of the lips—when it is (the soul’s) will to speak the letters <i>bet-vav-mem-pey</i>.<sup>24</sup> It is not the other way around, that it is the will and intention of the soul to make a change in the motions of the lips—as they are moving now in the utterances of these four letters, as is empirically evident that the soul does not intend or know to intend at all the change in the motions of the lips, of those changes.
This is even more evident with the utterance of the vowels. For when it is the wish of the soul to articulate the <i>kamatz</i> vowel, then, of themselves, the lips become compressed; and with the <i>patach vowel</i>—the lips are opened.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew terms for these vowels <i>(komatz</i> and <i>patach</i>) imply these very actions of the lips.</i> Thus, it is definitely not because of the will of the soul to compress or to open, and there is no need to go any further into this matter which is simple, comprehensible, and intelligible to every intelligent person, namely, that the pronunciation of the letters and vowels transcends the apprehended and comprehended intellect, and is, rather, from the hidden intellect and the primordium of the intellect, which is in the articulate soul. That is why an infant cannot speak, even though it understands everything.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">The following passage by the author’s grandson and disciple, R. Menachem Mendel of Lubavitch, will illuminate the above:<br>“With respect to the formation (i.e., coming into being) of the letters of thought and speech, we see that they are born and issue from the (emotive) attributes that are in the heart; for from the heart (a desire) ascends to the mind to meditate and think with respect to the desire and passion that are in one’s heart, or with respect to the fear and fright (that are in one’s heart), and as explained in <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, end of ch. 20. And from this it issues, afterward, in the letters of speech: to speak of that matter. On the other hand, one does not think or speak at all pertaining to something to which one has no wish and will in his heart. Conclusively we see that speech is subject to the emotive attributes, for it flows and issues from there.<br>“In fact, however, we see also a contradiction to this, viz., that the formation of speech, and its root, is not only from the emotive attributes alone. Rather, its root is of a higher (source), namely—issuing from the very intellect in the articulate soul, and as empirically evident that a suckling child is unable to speak, even though it possesses emotions; moreover, its emotive attributes are stronger than those of an adult, for when it has a desire there is no stopping whatsoever of its spirit, and it screams and becomes angry. Nevertheless, the child cannot articulate what is in its heart, but merely screams and cries with a simple voice (nonintelligible sound). Hence we see that the root of the formation of speech is not from the emotive attributes only, not even from the apprehended intellect—for the child understands everything and is yet unable to speak. Rather, it issues and is formed from the concealed intellect and the primordium of the intellect in the articulate soul (and as explained in <i>Iggeret Hakodesh</i>, Epistle 5).<br>“And this is the meaning of ‘<i>abba</i> founded <i>barta</i>.’ For from <i>abba—</i>the essence of the Supreme <i>chochmah</i>, which transcends <i>binah</i> and the apprehended intellect—is the root of speech, which is the aspect of <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, referred to as <i>barta</i>…”<br>“In fact, the formation of the nature of the letters as they are in speech originates only in the emotive attributes. But, nevertheless, it is by means of a radiation of <i>chochmah—</i>which issues into the attributes; and without the radiation from <i>chochmah</i> into the attributes, the letters would not come into being from the attributes…” “Accordingly, it is understood that though the foundation of the letters is (ultimately) only from the rank of <i>chochmah</i>, nevertheless, the letters are not born and do not issue from <i>chochmah</i>, except when it passes and issues by way of the attributes.” (<i>Or Hatorah</i>, <i>Shemot</i>, vol. 1, p. 40.) See also <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, ch. 8 and <i>Biurei Hazohar</i>, <i>Beshalach</i> 44d.</i>
However, the letters are on planes of “matter” and “form,” referred to as “internal” and “external.”<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Or Hatorah</i>, <i>Bereishit</i>, vol. 2, 445b; cf. <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 4.</i> Their source in the primordium of the intellect, and the will of the soul is but the “form” of the change in pronunciation which there is among the twenty-two letters. The aspect of the “matter” and “body” of their formation, however, i.e., the aspect of their “externality,” is the breath issuing from the heart. For from this breath is formed the simple sound that issues from the throat<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 22 (63b).</i> and is subsequently divided into the twenty-two enunciations, and the expression of the twenty-two letters through the five known organs [<i>alef-chet-hey-ayin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The letters follow this order in all the texts (see above, note 23, and also <i>Zohar</i> I:80a; II:123a; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 13b; etc.) with the <i>hey</i> following upon the <i>chet</i>, even though it comes first in the order of the alphabet. In <i>Zohar</i> II:123a and III:295b this particular sequence is interpreted to follow a distinct pattern, see there. Cf. also H. V. on this passage.</i> through the throat; <i>gimmel-yud-kaf-kuf</i> through the palate, etc.], while the breath (itself) is uttered by the letter <i>hey</i>—”the light letter…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">[30]“The light letter, to which there is no substance”; <i>Piyut Akdamut</i>, verse 6. The letter <i>hey</i> is called the light letter or the “easy letter,” because (being a mere aspirate) “its pronunciation does not demand any effort” (<i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 12:10), and, thus, involves less of the breath than all other letters.</i> which is the source of the “matter” and “body” of the letters prior to their division into twenty-two. And that is why our Sages, of blessed memory, said that “This world<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Barta-malchut</i>.</i> was created by the <i>hey</i>.”
Now, though this is the “lower <i>hey</i>” [the latter <i>hey</i> of the Name of <i>Havaya</i><sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Malchut</i>. Cf. <i>Tikkunei</i> <i>Zohar</i> 22 (63b), and above, note 16.</i>], while our Sages, of blessed memory, related this to the verse “For by <i>Yud-Hey</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">This name of G–d forms the first half of <i>Havaya</i>, thus, the <i>hey</i> wherewith this world was created would appear to be the first, the “upper” <i>hey</i>.</i> this is because its source, and the beginning of its egression into a state of manifestation from the concealment of the <i>yud</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">The first letter, <i>chochmah</i>.</i> is influenced and issued forth from the rank of the “upper <i>hey</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">The second letter (the first, or upper <i>hey</i>), <i>binah</i>.</i> This <i>hey</i> has dimensions of “length” and “width” to indicate the faculty of <i>binah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Tikkunei</i> <i>Zohar</i> 22 (63b), and see <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 4.</i> which is the expansion of the “concealed intellect”<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>yud</i>, <i>chochmah</i>.</i> into a state of manifestation and apprehension, with an extension of <i>daat</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Implementing the <i>chochmah</i> expanded by <i>binah</i> (see Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>; cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 3; below, Epistle 15).</i> and its diffusion culminates in the heart, as mentioned in the <i>Tikkunim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Introduction 17a; cf. ibid., 22 (63b).</i> that “<i>binah</i>—that is the heart, and therewith the heart understands.”<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">See Addendum, ibid., for an explanation of all these terms and concepts.</i> And from there issues the breath, the original manifestation of the “body” of the letters of speech<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 22 (63b).</i> which become revealed from the concealment of the <i>yud</i> through the five organs.
The form of the “lower <i>hey</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">The fourth letter (of <i>Havaya</i>), <i>malchut</i>.</i> which, in its written form, also has dimensions of length and width, indicates the extension of the aspect of His Sovereignty, blessed be He,<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Malchut</i>. Cf. <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 4.</i> “The sovereignty of all worlds”<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 143:13.</i>—above and below, and in the four directions, which extend and issue from the letters or the “word of the L–rd,”<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 33:6—the “Word of G–d” (<i>malchut</i>; see Addendum, ibid.) by which the universe was created; see below (esp. notes 75 ff.).</i> as it is written in Ecclesiastes:<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 8:4.</i> “Wherever the king’s word is regnant,” as explained elsewhere.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 4.</i>
[<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>As for understanding somewhat the concept and nature of “letters of speech” in relation to Divinity, inasmuch as He has no form of a body, nor of soul, Heaven forfend, this was already explained in a more or less elaborate way (<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i> in <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, chs. 11 and 12, see there)].
As for an exposition of the idea why our Sages, of blessed memory, said that <i>this</i> world was created by the <i>hey</i>: it is known to all the wise of heart that the multitude of the worlds and <i>hechalot</i><sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Shrines, palaces. Worlds, shrines, hosts, etc., all refer to the different levels of the Divine emanations that are brought about by means of <i>tzimtzum</i>. Cf. Addendum, ibid.</i> [which are innumerable, as it is written: “Is there then a number to His hosts?”<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Job 25:3.</i> and in every <i>hechal</i> and host there are a thousand thousands and myriad myriads of angels,<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">See Daniel 7:10; cf. <i>Chagigah</i> 13b and <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 46.</i> and also <i>nefesh-ruach-neshamah-chaya-yechidah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Scripture uses these five terms for the soul. (See <i>Bereishit</i> <i>Rabbah</i> 14:9; <i>Devarim</i> <i>Rabbah</i> 2:37.) They are not synonyms, but every term denotes a different gradation of soul. <i>Nefesh</i>, the lowest grade, is the natural soul, the simple life of man. <i>Ruach</i>, the next grade, is the spiritual life of man. <i>Neshamah</i>, still higher, is the soul proper, the Divine soul. Still higher grades are <i>chaya</i> (living) and <i>yechidah</i> (single, or unique). Generally we speak only of the lower three grades (<i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i>), sometimes of <i>chaya</i>, and hardly ever of <i>yechidah</i>. This will be understood by the analogy to the five worlds, the ten <i>sefirot</i> (and the letters of <i>Havaya</i>), to which these five grades correspond. <i>Yechidah</i> corresponds to <i>Adam</i> <i>Kadmon</i>, the <i>sefirah</i> of <i>keter</i> (the thorn of the <i>yud</i>). It is the actual Divine spark, thus totally concealed and hidden. <i>Chaya</i> corresponds to <i>Atzilut</i>, the <i>sefirah</i> of <i>chochmah</i> (the <i>yud</i>), thus the beginning of Divine manifestation and source of all subsequent levels, though itself inapprehensible. It is the “soul” of all subsequent levels and, therefore, called <i>neshamah l’neshamah (neshamah</i> of the <i>neshamah</i>). Just as in the creative process concrete and apprehensible manifestation begins at the level of <i>Beriah</i>, and we speak mainly of the lower three worlds, so, too, it is with the gradations of the soul. <i>Neshamah</i> corresponds to <i>Beriah</i>, the <i>sefirah</i> of <i>binah</i> (in which the point of <i>chochmah</i> is vested, expanded, and first apprehended; the upper <i>hey</i>). <i>Ruach</i> corresponds to <i>Yetzirah</i>, <i>and</i> the <i>middot</i> (the attributes of <i>chesed</i> of <i>yesod</i>; the letter <i>vav</i>). <i>Nefesh</i> corresponds to <i>Asiyah</i>, the <i>sefirah</i> of <i>malchut</i> (the latter <i>hey</i>). More specifically, in man, the <i>neshamah</i> denotes the soul’s intellect-powers; <i>ruach</i>, the soul’s emotion-powers; <i>nefesh</i>, the soul’s outer manifestations or garments, viz., the faculties of thought, speech, and action. (See <i>Zohar</i> I:79b ff.; ibid., 245a; <i>Zohar Chadash</i> 34b and 78c; <i>Etz Chaim</i> 42:1; <i>Torah Or</i>, <i>Miketz</i> 42b; cf. also below, Epistle 27b.) The higher ranks of the soul are conceived as latently present in man’s <i>nefesh</i>, just as the higher worlds and <i>sefirot</i> are latently present in the lower ones (by means of successive <i>tzimtzum</i>). By the observance of Torah and <i>mitzvot</i>, i.e., by the service of G–d as behooves, man merits to attain these higher ranks in ever increasing manifestation. (See <i>Zohar</i> I:206a; ibid., II:94b; <i>Biurei Hazohar</i>, <i>Vayigash</i> 26c ff.)<br>The different gradations in the soul thus denote different levels. These levels are prevalent within the various worlds as well, for “they all are in the likeness of man.” (See R. Chaim Vital, <i>Mevo She’arim</i>, 6 beg. of Part II; <i>Etz Chaim</i> 6:2; <i>et passim</i>.)</i> rungs to no end, and (likewise) in every world; and (moreover) <i>hechalot</i> from the multitude of the <i>hechalot</i> that are in <i>Atzilut</i>, <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>].
Now, all these multitudes, one multitude after another <i>ad infinitum</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:159a; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 14b; etc.</i> all this issues and effuses from the multitude of combinations of the twenty-two letters<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> II:151b-152a; cf. <i>Berachot</i> 55a and comment of Rashi, ad loc. (s.v. <i>Otiyot</i>; also, <i>Rashi</i> on Job 28:23.</i> of the “word of the L–rd,”<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">See above, note 45.</i> which, in turn, divide into many (more) combinations, truly <i>ad infinitum</i>, as stated in <i>Sefer Yetzirah</i>:<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer Yetzirah</i> 4:12.</i> “Seven stones build five thousand and forty houses; from here onward go and count what the mouth is not able to express….”<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">“Seven stones (= letters) build 3040 houses (= words).” Using the formula of factorial (3 letters: 3x2x1 words; 4 letters: 4x3x2x1 words; 5 letters: 5x4x3x2x1 words; etc.), the immense multitude of possible words is easily grasped. See the commentary attributed to R. Abraham ibn Daud (on this passage) for the phraseology of “stones” and “houses.”</i>
Though there are among the rungs and levels of the angels and souls so many different kinds of levels and rungs <i>ad infinitum</i>, one surpassing the other, all issues according to the permutations in combinations, and the substitutions of <i>alef-tav</i>, <i>bet-shin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">By the rules of substitution <i>alef</i> (first letter) can be substituted by <i>tav</i> (last letter), <i>bet</i> (second letter) by <i>shin</i> (second-last letter), etc. See <i>Shabbat</i> 104a and the comment by <i>Maharsha</i>, ad loc. Cf. <i>Shomer Emunim</i> 1:20-23.</i> and so on<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">There are also other schemes of substitution, e.g., of equally sounding letters; letters that have the same source of articulation; letters with certain numerical relationships; etc.</i> (<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>as mentioned in ch. 12<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Of <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II.</i>). But in a general way they all possess wisdom and knowledge, and they know their Creator, because their vivification stems from the “inwardness” of the letters which issue from the rank of the Supreme <i>chochmah</i>, as mentioned above.
This lowly world, however, with its vivification, is too small<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., too finite and limited.</i> to contain and endure the light and vivification from the aspect of the “form” of the letters and their “inwardness”—radiating and diffusing in it without any garment and concealment as they shine and effuse to the souls and angels. Rather, the radiation and diffusion comes and effuses to this world from the level of the “matter” and “body” of the letters and of their “externality” [which is the aspect of the breath which divides into the seven “breaths”<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Havalim</i>, in Hebrew (conventionally translated: vanities).</i> of Ecclesiastes<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 1:2: Vanity (1) of vanities (plural, thus 2)…vanity (1) of vanities (2), all is vanity (1), thus altogether seven. See <i>Kohelet</i> <i>Rabbah</i> on this verse, and comment., ad loc.</i> on which the world stands, as mentioned in the sacred <i>Zohar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:146b; III:47b.</i>].
And this is the “Utterance from the mouth of the L–rd”<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 8:3; cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:47b.</i> which vests itself in this world and all its hosts to animate them; but in it is vested the aspect of the “form” of the letters of speech and thought, (emanating) from His holy attributes, and His will and wisdom…, which are totally united in the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He. (<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>And this is what the Arizal stated<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Etz Chaim</i> 47:2, and <i>Yefeh Shaah</i> (comment. on the <i>Etz Chaim</i>; Tel Aviv 1960), by R. Solomon Hakohen, on this chapter; cf. also <i>Etz Chaim</i> 4:1, 2.</i> that the aspect of the <i>chitzoniyut</i> of the vessels of <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i><sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">See Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, for the meaning of this phrase and the statement in toto.</i>—[alluded to by the <i>hey</i> of the Name of <i>Havaya</i>, blessed is He]—descended and became the soul for the world of <i>Asiyah</i>). And thus it is stated in the <i>Tikkunim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 6 (23a), in the light of <i>Etz Chaim</i> 42, end of ch. 4 (where this phrase appears in these very words).</i> that the <i>yud</i><sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Supreme <i>chochmah</i>.</i> is in <i>Atzilut</i>…and the lower <i>hey</i><sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, which ultimately vests itself in <i>Asiyah</i>.</i> nests in <i>Asiyah</i>.
Now, with terrestrial man, for example, when one who is so great a sage as to comprehend the wonders of wisdom contracts his intellect and thought to a single letter of his speech, this is an immense contraction (<i>tzimtzum</i>) and a great descent for his wondrous wisdom. Metaphorically speaking, precisely so, and infinitely more so, there was an immensely great and mighty contraction (<i>tzimtzum</i>)<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">See Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>.</i> when during the six days of creation “The heavens were made by the word of the L–rd, and all their hosts by the breath of His mouth”<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 33:6; cf. note 67.</i>—i.e., by the letter <i>hey</i> of the Name of <i>Havaya</i>, blessed is He, [the “light letter”] as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 2:4.</i> “בהבראם,” (which means): בה’ בראם (“when He created them,” He created them, by the <i>hey</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">The word בהבראם (when He created them) is divisible into two parts, forming these two words.—<i>Menachot</i> 29b; <i>Midrashim</i> on Genesis 2:4.</i> It<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>hey</i>, <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, in which <i>chochmah</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> is vested.</i> is the source of the nine fiats which issued from the first fiat:<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">“The universe was created by ten fiats”—(<i>Avot</i> 5:1; cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:256b; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 10b; <i>Zohar Chadash</i>, beg. of <i>Midrash Hane’elam</i>) the first of which is generally all-inclusive.</i> <i>Bereishit</i><sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">The initial word of the Torah, <i>Bereishit</i>, may mean in, or with <i>reishit</i> (the beginning).</i>—which is also a fiat<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 32a; <i>Zohar</i> I:15a; see also <i>Zohar</i> I:16b.</i> (and identical with) the aspect of <i>chochmah</i>, which is called <i>reishit</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">[82]<i>Reishit</i>—the <i>beginning</i>, i.e., the first <i>sefirah</i>—see <i>Sefer Habahir</i> 3; <i>Zohar</i> I:3b, 31b, and 256b; <i>Zohar</i> <i>Chadash</i>, <i>Midrash Hane’elam</i>, 3a; see also <i>Targum Yerushalmi</i> on Genesis 1:1.</i>
But at that time this efflux and descent was without any arousal from below whatsoever<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Etz Chaim</i> 8: end of ch. 6; cf. <i>Moreh Nevuchim</i> 3:53.</i>—“For there was no man to work…”<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">See Genesis 2:5 (and see below, note 89).—There was no man yet to arouse and elicit the Divine <i>chesed</i> by appropriate actions (i.e., the performance of the commandments).</i>—but solely “Because He delights in <i>chesed</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Micah 7:18.</i> and “The world was built by <i>chesed</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 89:3.</i> And this is the meaning of באברהם בהבראם (when He created them—because of Abraham),<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 12:9; cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:230b.—By a slight permutation בהבראם can be changed to באברהם.</i> for “<i>chesed</i> is to Abraham.”<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Micah 7:20. Abraham signifies <i>chesed</i> (see above, Epistle 2, note 9), thus “when He created them,” He created them “because of (or: by) Abraham,” i.e., out of a motive of <i>chesed</i>. Creation is the effect of G–d’s <i>chesed</i>, to actualize the “nature of the Benevolent to do good.” (See Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>.)</i>
But after the creation of “Man to work on it…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 2:15 (see <i>Pirkei d’R. Eliezer</i>, ch. 12; <i>Targum Yerushalmi</i> and <i>Targum Yonatan</i>, ad loc.; <i>Sifrei</i> on Deuteronomy 11:13; <i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 16:5; <i>Zohar</i> I:27a; II:165b; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 21 (62a); <i>Zohar</i> <i>Chadash</i> 18c). Man was created to carry out G–d’s will, i.e., to perform the commandments of the Torah. When doing so, man elicits the Divine <i>chesed</i>.</i> every arousal from above, to arouse the attribute of the Supreme <i>chesed</i>, depends on an arousal from below,<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">See above, note 83.</i> i.e., the charity and kindness which Israelites perform in this world. That is why our Sages, of blessed memory, said:<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yevamot</i> 109b.</i> “Whoever says that he has nothing but Torah—thus no deeds of kindness—he has not even Torah”; rather, one is to busy himself with Torah and the performance of kindness.<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Yevamot</i> 105a; <i>Zohar</i> II:119a [cf. <i>Sefer Hamaamarim 5708</i> (Kehot, 1958), in the marginal notes by the Lubavitcher Rebbe, R. Menachem M. Schneerson, on p. 266, end of note 7]. See also <i>Masechet Chibut Hakever</i> (<i>Reishit Chochmah</i>, <i>Shaar HaYirah</i>, ch. 12), ch. 4 ff. and Maharal, <i>Netivot Olam</i>, s.v. <i>Gemilut</i> <i>Chasadim</i>, ch. 2.</i>
For though the “Torah derives from <i>chochmah</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:121a; etc. (see above, Epistle 1, note 37).</i> and the world subsists by virtue of the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:200a; cf. <i>Avot</i> 1:2; <i>Shabbat</i> 88a.</i> and those who discourse in it,<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:47a, III:35a.</i> because by their speech they elicit illuminations and effusions<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">V. L.: “inspirations,” or: “indwellings.”</i> from the Supreme <i>chochmah</i> [the source of Torah] to the plane of the letters of speech [wherewith the world was created, as our Sages, of blessed memory, said:<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 64a; <i>Yevamot</i> 122b; etc. Cf. above, note 58.</i> “Do not read בניך (your children) but בוניך (your builders)”], this efflux, however, is really of the category of a great descent. Therefore it is necessary to arouse the Supreme <i>chesed</i> which, like water, is drawn from a high place to a low place<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Water, the nature of which is to flow downward, is symbolic of <i>chesed</i>.—See below, Epistle 8, and notes 14 ff., ad loc.</i> by means of an arousal from below: through charity and the nether <i>chesed</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the kindness expressed and performed below, by man.</i> diffusing life and kindness “To revive the spirit of the humble and downcast.”<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 57:15.</i>
And this is the meaning of the verse: “Let not the wise glorify himself in his <i>chochmah</i>…, but in this let him glory…for I am the L–rd who does <i>chesed</i>….”<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 9:22 f.</i> For it is <i>chesed</i> that causes the vitality of <i>chochmah</i> to issue downward, and without that it is called “<i>His chochmah</i>” only—without any efflux of life from it, Heaven forfend.<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">When man performs <i>chesed</i>, he elicits the “lights and inspirations of the Supreme <i>chochmah</i>,” thus sharing, as it were, in the Supreme <i>chochmah</i>. When there is no human act of kindness, the Supreme <i>chochmah</i> remains, so to speak, passive and will not issue downward: it remains “His (i.e., G–d’s) <i>chochmah</i>” only. See <i>Maamarei Admur Hazaken—Hanachot HaRaP</i> (Kehot, 1957), p. 78 ff. Cf. <i>Taanit</i> 7a (on Proverbs 5:17), and see also <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 22 (65a).</i>
Hereby will be understood the statement of the Arizal<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Yitzchak Luria Ashkenazi, of blessed memory (1534-1572).</i> that there are two kinds of souls among Israel: the souls of Torah scholars—who occupy themselves with Torah all their lives, and the souls of those who perform the commandments—who occupy themselves with charity and the performance of kindness.<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Biurei Hazohar</i>, <i>Vayeshev</i> 25a-b (on <i>Zohar</i> I:182a).</i> Now it would seem that scholars, too, need to occupy themselves with the performance of kindness, as our Sages, of blessed memory, said that (otherwise) “He has not even Torah.”
However, as regards scholars of Torah whose study of the Torah is their principal (occupation) [and most of their time is spent in it, and but a small part of their time with the performance of kindness], the effect of their arousal from below, to arouse the Supreme <i>chesed</i> to call forth and bring downward the Light of the <i>En Sof</i> vested in the Supreme <i>chochmah</i> [the source of G–d’s Torah which is in their mouths], extends only to the realm of the souls that are in <i>Beriah</i> [through their occupation with Gemara], and to the angels that are in <i>Yetzirah</i> [through their occupation with Mishnah]. For the vivifications of the souls and angels effuse from the combinations of the letters of speech, i.e., the Oral Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">That is, the Torah which is studied and transmitted by word of mouth, referring to the Talmud and Rabbinic writings. The influence of the Oral Torah extends only as far as <i>Yetzirah</i>, Gemara as far as <i>Beriah</i>, and Mishnah as far as <i>Yetzirah</i>; see <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, end of ch. 40 and ch. 52; below, Epistle 26.</i> But the origin of the letters is in the Supreme <i>chochmah</i>, as mentioned above.
Thus in order to call forth and bring downward an illumination and vivification from the level of the Supreme Breath [the “lower <i>hey</i>”<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, the recipient and channel of the Supreme <i>chochmah</i>.</i>] to this lowly world, which implies an extremely great contraction (<i>tzimtzum</i>), the arousal from below by the scholars of Torah [who for but a small part of their time occupy themselves with charity and the performance of kindness] is not sufficient. (This is effected) only through the arousal by those who perform the commandments, i.e., they who are occupied with charity and the performance of kindness for the major part of their life<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, their principal occupation is with the performance of kindness. But they, too, have to appoint and set aside times for the study of Torah (just as the scholars of Torah have to perform commandments as well); cf. <i>Hilchot Talmud Torah</i> by the author, ch. 3 and <i>Kuntres Acharon</i>, ad loc.</i> (<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>and as explained in <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 34). That is why they are called the “supporters of Torah.”<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:8a (cf. Proverbs 3:18 and <i>Vayikra</i> <i>Rabbah</i> 25:1).</i> They are the categories and levels of <i>netzach</i> and <i>hod</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:53b.—In the “man image” of the <i>sefirot</i>, <i>netzach</i> and <i>hod</i> signify the “thighs” and the “loins”—which support the “body” (Torah); see <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 17a and above, Epistle 1. (Cf. Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>.)</i> because they cause the light of Torah to issue downward to the world of <i>Asiyah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:8a, III:53b.</i>
Now it is clear why charity is referred to as an “act,” as it is written: “And the <i>act</i> of <i>tzedakah</i> will be peace.”<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 32:17; cf. below, Epistle 12.</i> For the effect (of charity) is to elicit the light of G–d to the world of <i>Asiyah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. below, Epistle 9. <i>Asiyah</i> means an act, or deed.</i> And that is the meaning of the subtle phraseology of the sacred <i>Zohar</i>—“He who makes the Holy Name,” expressly saying “who makes.” For by an arousal from below [through charity and the nether <i>chesed</i>], one arouses the Supreme <i>chesed</i> to elicit the Light of the <i>En Sof</i> from the rank of the Supreme <i>chochmah</i> [the <i>yud</i> of the Name] to the <i>hey</i> of the Name [the aspect of “speech” and “breath” of His mouth, blessed be He]—to diffuse to the world of <i>Asiyah</i>.
And, analogously speaking, though not to be compared in the least, just as a human being speaks only to others (<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>and not when he is alone), and then [when speaking to them] he contracts his intellect and thought.<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Speech is the outer manifestation of mind, of intellect, and thought; it reveals the inner thought. Thought itself is self-containing; it exists in isolation. Speech reveals nothing to the speaker, for he knows already, he has the original thought of which speech is a mere manifestation. Thus speech reveals to others. It is a communication directed to another. At the same time, speech is of necessity a limitation on thought. On the preverbalizing level one must seek the right letters, words, and expressions to reveal the inner thought. The intuitive concept, as it is in itself in the inner thought, cannot be expressed; it is too compact and concentrated. It needs to “come down,” to be analyzed and made intelligible in all its details. The words uttered are but vessels that contain, and are able to channel and reveal, the detailed ideas of the original, germinal thought. Cf. below, Epistle 20, and note 51, ad loc.</i> And the intelligent will understand.

Chapter 6

<b>SIX.</b> “But he who sows <i>tzedakah</i> has a reward of truth.” (Proverbs 11)<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18.<i>—</i>Brackets appear in the text.</i> This means that the attribute of truth is the reward for the sowing of <i>tzedakah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">See commentaries by R. Abraham Ibn Ezra and R. Levi Gersonides, ad loc.</i>
It is also written:<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Micah 7:20.</i> “You give truth to Jacob”—and the prophet engages in extolling the Holy One, blessed is He, as mentioned in the sacred <i>Zohar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:131b.</i> This means that it is the Holy One, blessed is He, who gives the attribute of truth to Jacob.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 2, note 26.</i>
Now this needs to be understood. Is there then no truth in Jacob, Heaven forfend, until the Holy One, blessed is He, gives it to him from above? 
However, it is well known that the attribute of Jacob is the attribute of <i>rachamim</i> (compassion).<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Jacob is the “middle bar that bolts from end to end” (Exodus 26:28) that is the bolt mediating between <i>chesed</i> and <i>gevurah</i>, thus <i>rachamim</i> or <i>tiferet</i>; <i>Zohar</i> II:175b-176a; also <i>Zohar</i> II:51b; <i>et passim</i>. See Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, and below, Epistle 15.</i> And the service of G–d in a mode of compassion derives from arousing in the heart of man a great compassion for the Divine spark in his soul, which is removed from the light of G–d’s Countenance when (man) goes about in the darkness of the vanities of the world. And this arousal of compassion itself derives from the contemplation on, and cognition of, the greatness of G–d: how even the most infinitely sublime worlds are esteemed as truly naught before Him. For all their bounty and vitality is but from a gleam and reflection of a single letter of His Name, blessed be He, as it is stated:<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Menachot</i> 29b. See above, Epistle 5.</i> “The World to Come was created by the <i>yud</i>….”
Now, it is in this radiation and reflection [which is an extension of vivification from His Name, blessed be He, to animate the upper and lower beings]—that there is a distinction and difference with respect to upper and lower beings. For “This world was created by the <i>hey</i>….”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid.—The radiation from the <i>hey</i> is different than that of the <i>yud</i> (more contracted, concealed, etc.). Thus there is a difference between the “upper” world (the World to Come) and the “nether” world (this world).
