Likewise with the effects of all the other emanations.</i> Also, all the differences in the details in every world are according to the differences in the combinations of the letters.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">The letters of G–d’s fiats (by which everything was created), each of which designates a specific emanation.—See above, Epistle 5 (and note 54, ad loc.).</i> The differences in the temporal dimensions of past, present, and future, and the differences in all the events throughout the differing times, all of these, too, came about from the variations in the combinations of the letters. For (the letters) are the conduits of the vivification from His attributes, blessed be His Name (<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>as explained in <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, ch. 11).
But as for His Being and Essence, blessed be He, it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Malachi 3:6.</i> “I, the L–rd, I have not changed,” neither in terms of changes of the development from the uppermost of levels to the nethermost [for just as He, blessed be He, is found in the upper worlds, so He is in precisely that measure in the nether worlds <sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i> (and as explained in <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 51)], nor in terms of temporal changes [for just as He was alone, one and unique, before the six days of creation, so He is now after the creation]. This is so because everything is absolutely as nothing and naught in relation to His being and essence,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:11b.</i> just as, metaphorically speaking [to appease the ear,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., “to make it intelligible to man” (cf. <i>Mechilta</i>, <i>Yitro</i>, s.v. <i>Bachodesh</i>, ch. 4).</i> while in fact “There is no comparison to You,” it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 40:6.</i>], a single letter of the speech, or even of the thought of man, is in relation to the general being and essence of the rational soul; and as explained elsewhere <sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i> (in <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, ch. 9), see there.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. also <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 20.</i>
That is why we say<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, Morning Prayer.</i> “The King Who is exalted, alone from aforetime.” This means, just as aforetime, before the creation, He was alone, so now, too, “He is exalted…and elevated beyond the days of the world”;<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid. (in the same passage).</i> that is, He is exalted and elevated, transcending the dimension of time—which is referred to as “<i>the days of the world</i>.” This is so because the life-force of all the days derives solely from the aspect of “the King…,” as explained elsewhere.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, ch. 7.</i>
It follows then that the compassion for the spark that dwells in the dark and gloomy body—the “hide of the snake,”<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 10b; 58 (92b); <i>Etz Chaim</i> 49:4. Cf. <i>Pirkei d’R. Eliezer</i>, ch. 20, and <i>Midrash</i> <i>Tehillim</i>, 92:6.</i> is overwhelming. For it is liable to contract impurity and to become defiled by all the lusts, the Merciful save us, were it not for G–d being a shield to it, and giving it strength and might to wage war with, and triumph over the body and its passions.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Sukkah</i> 52b.</i> And this is the meaning of “L–rd of our strength…shield of our salvation….”<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">See above, note 18.</i>
Now it is well known that there are two types of awe and love (respectively).<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., two general types of awe: <i>yirah tataah</i>, and <i>yirah ilaah</i> (or: <i>yirat</i> <i>haromemut</i>), and two general types of love: <i>ahavah zutta</i>, and <i>ahavah rabbah</i> (or: <i>ahavah betaanugim)</i>. See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 40 ff., esp. ch. 43; below, Epistle 15 (and notes 88 ff., ad loc.); and Epistle 18. See also Author’s Introduction to <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, Part II; and <i>Hilchot Talmud Torah</i> 4:6.</i> The first ones are born from the contemplation on, and cognition of, the greatness of G–d and those matters that lead to a love of G–d and the fear of Him. The latter<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">The second sorts of awe and love.</i> ones are those that come afterward, from above, as a gift, [as explained elsewhere<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 14; see below, Epistle 18.</i> in comment on the verse<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 18:7.</i> “I will make your priesthood a rewarding service”—that it refers to the attribute of (the supreme) love; and it is likewise in regard to awe].
Now there is surely no comparison between the first ones—which are the products of the created intellect, and the latter ones—which are from the Creator, blessed be His Name.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the lower levels of awe and love are the sort of service that is earned through man’s efforts. The higher levels are the type of service that is granted as a gift from above.</i> That is why <i>these</i> (the latter) are referred to as “truth,” for the seal of the Holy One, blessed is He, is truth,<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 55a; see also <i>Zohar</i> I:2b.</i> for He is the true Truth,<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Jeremiah 10:10 and Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 1:1.</i> and all the truth among the creatures is esteemed as nothing before Him.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">See Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah</i> 1:3, 4.—G–d is <i>emet le’amito</i>, absolute truth. All other truth is but relative.</i>
But which is the way whereby man merits the “truth of G–d”? It is by arousing, before G–d, great compassion for the spark in his soul. And this is the attribute of Jacob—who<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">See above, note 6.</i> “bolts from one end to the other end,”<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 26:28.</i> that is, from the uppermost of all levels to the nethermost,<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:1b; cf. also above, note 6.</i> to cause the “truth of G–d” to issue to this lowly dark world, and as it is written: “When I sit in darkness, the L–rd is a light for me.”<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Micah 7:8.</i> And this is the meaning of “For His <i>chesed</i> has prevailed over us….”<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 117:2: “For His <i>chesed</i> has prevailed over us, and the truth of G–d (issues) to the world.”—By means of the attribute of <i>rachamim</i> (<i>tiferet</i>), <i>chesed</i> prevails over <i>gevurah</i> and issues to us, drawing forth the truth of G–d into this world. Cf. <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Additions, 139a.</i>
However, the arousal of great compassion before G–d also needs to be in truth. But even when it is true in mortal terms,<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., When one is in his own truth.</i> how can one arouse [through (relative) truth] the supernal compassion from the truth of G–d?
The advice for this is the trait of charity—which is the attribute of compassion for one who has nothing of his own, to “Revive the spirit of the humble….”<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 57:15.</i> And the arousal from below elicits an arousal from above:<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 4, note 45.</i> the L–rd arouses the sleeping and awakens the unconscious,<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Liturgy, Shabbat Morning (<i>Nishmat Kol Chay</i>).</i> that is, the concealed, great compassion and Supernal graces,<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The Supreme <i>chesed</i>.</i> to emerge from concealment into manifestation and a great illumination, to radiate with the light of life<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Job. 33:30 and cf. Psalms 56:14.</i>—“the truth of G–d into the world.”<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 117:2; see above, note 36.</i>
And this is the meaning of the idiom of “sowing” related to charity: to make sprout the Supreme truth of G–d, especially through the charity and the true kindness performed with the Holy Land [may it be built and established speedily in our days, amen] to realize the verse: “Truth shall sprout forth from the land”<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 85:12. “Land” refers to the Holy Land, the subject of this Psalm.</i>—from the sowing of charity in it.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. the comment of <i>Rashi</i>, ad loc.; cf. also below, Epistle 7, note 36.</i> And the kindness and great compassion that are gathered and gleaned into it, they arouse—correspondingly—the Supreme graces<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup> that are hidden and concealed,<sup>46</sup><i class="footnote">V. L: concealed in it.</i> as it is written: “Which You have hidden…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 31:20; see below, Epistle 13.</i> to establish it and to set it up firmly. Of this it is written: “Through <i>tzedakah</i> shall you be established.”<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 54:14.</i>

Chapter 7

<b>SEVEN.</b> “Fortunate are we, how good is our portion, how pleasant our lot….”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, Morning Prayers.</i> “The L–rd is my allotted portion and my share…. Portions have fallen to me….”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 16:5 f. Cf. <i>Sifrei</i>, Deuteronomy 53 (on Deuteronomy 11:26).</i>
To understand the phraseology “our portion” and “our lot,” it is necessary to explain properly a common expression in the sayings of our Sages, of blessed memory, viz.: “He has no part in the G–d of Israel.”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">E.g., <i>Berachot</i> 63b; <i>Zohar</i> II:3b; etc.</i> It would seem that a term like “part” cannot possibly be applied to Divinity, blessed be He, because He is not divisible into parts, Heaven forfend.
However, the idea is, as it is written about Jacob: “And he called Him <i>E-l</i>, G–d of Israel.”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 33:20; commentaries, ad loc.</i> The meaning of this is as follows. In truth, G–d, as His Name is, so is He.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">For He and His Name are entirely one (see below, note 9). G–d’s appellates are His attributes. The Divine attributes are of the Divine essence, and G–d is absolutely one with His essence. Cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, ch. 8 ff. See also <i>Kuzari</i> 2:2 and <i>Moreh Nevuchim</i> 1:51 ff.</i> Though He permeates all the upper and lower worlds, from the peak of all levels to this lowly physical world [as it is written: “Do I not fill the heavens and the earth,”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 23:24.</i> I Myself, indeed, meaning, His Being and His Essence, as it were, and not only His glory], even so, He is <i>kadosh</i> (holy)<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Denoting separateness; cf. <i>Mechilta</i>, <i>Yitro</i>, s.v. <i>Bachodesh</i>, ch. 2 (on Exodus 19:6), and <i>Sifra</i>, beg. of <i>Kedoshim</i> (on Leviticus 19:2).</i> and distinct from the upper and nether worlds, and is not at all contained in them, Heaven forfend, in the way, for example, that the soul of man is contained in the body, as explained elsewhere at length.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 42.</i>
And for this reason they could not receive their vivification from His Being and Essence in itself, as it were. Rather, the extension of the vivification wherewith the Holy One, blessed is He, animates the upper and nether worlds, is, metaphorically speaking, as a radiation shining from His Name, blessed be He, for He and His Name are One,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:7b; II:86a. See also ibid., II:90b.—Cf. <i>Pirkei d’R. Eliezer</i>, ch. 3.</i> and as it is written: “For His Name alone is exalted, [only His reflection and] His splendor are on the earth and the heavens….”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 148:13.</i>
This radiation actually vests itself in the upper and lower worlds in order to animate them. It is contained in them by means of many intermediaries and numerous, immense contractions, in a development of levels by way of cause and effect….
Now, this radiation [though above it radiates and extends itself in unlimited and infinite fashion to animate innumerable, concealed worlds, as mentioned in the <i>Idra Rabbah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:127b-145a, see there.</i> nevertheless] as it descends netherward, by way of numerous contractions, to animate those that were created, formed and made, it is generally divided into 613 in number.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> III:129a.</i> These 613 gradations correspond to the 613 commandments of the Torah, which are the 613 kinds of conduits of this radiation from the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, to illumine man’s soul [which is made up of 248 “organs” and 365 “sinews”<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The 248 operational precepts correspond to the 248 organs, and the 365 prohibitory precepts correspond to the 365 sinews. Cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:170b; <i>Makkot</i> 23b; see also <i>Zohar</i> II:25a.</i>]. For the principal aim of the descent and efflux of this radiation, netherward, to all those created, formed, and made, is for (the soul’s) sake; for the purpose of them all is man, as known.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Man—created last, was first in intent (G–d’s thought)—<i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 6a; that is, the whole creation is for the purpose of man who, in turn, is to serve G–d in, and with, the creation.—See also <i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 1:4 and comment., ad loc.; <i>Zohar</i> II:108b, 275b, and III:306b. R. Saadiah Gaon, <i>Emunot Vedeot</i> 4, Intro. and ch. 1.</i>
Now this number is in a general way. More specifically, every single commandment subdivides into infinite details, which are the essentials of the detailed rulings of every commandment [which are without number, as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 6:8.</i> “Sixty are the queens”—these are the sixty tractates…, “and maidens without number”—these are the rulings…<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:216a; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 14b; <i>Zohar Chadash</i>, <i>Tikkunim</i> 98a; <i>et passim</i>. Cf. <i>Bamidbar Rabbah</i> 18:21 and <i>Shir Hashirim Rabbah</i> 6:14.</i>]. For they are the efflux from the Supernal Will….<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. below, Epistle 29.</i>
It is precisely so with man’s soul. For all the souls in the world were contained in Adam.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Shemot Rabbah</i> 40:2, 3, and <i>Tanchuma</i>, <i>Ki Tissa</i> 12, as explained by the Arizal in <i>Shaar</i> <i>Hapessukim</i>, <i>Bereishit</i> 3; <i>et passim</i> in his other writings.</i> In a general way his soul was divisible into the number 613: 248 “organs” and 365 “sinews”; but in a more specific way his soul was divisible into innumerable sparks<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Shaar Hagilgulim</i> 6 and 11.</i>—which are the souls of all of Israel from the days of the Patriarchs and the tribes, to and including the coming of the Messiah, when Scripture will be fulfilled: “And the number of the children of Israel will be as the sand of the sea that cannot be measured nor counted”<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 2:1.</i>—“Because of the great quantity.”<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">See Genesis 16:10.</i>
Now “The beauty of Jacob is a reflection of the beauty of Adam,”<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 84a; see also <i>Zohar</i> I:35b, 168a, 222a, etc., and ref. in following note.</i> for he rectified the sin of Adam.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> III:111b; also, <i>Zohar</i> II:141b and <i>Nitzutzei Orot</i>, ad loc.; cf. further <i>Zohar</i> I:142b and <i>Derech Emet</i>, ad loc.; and <i>Zohar</i> II:275b-276a. R. Natan Nata Schapiro, in his <i>Megaleh Amukot</i>, section <i>Toldot</i> (on Genesis 27:33; ed. Lublin 1912, 41a), explains how the rectification of Adam’s sin is implied in this saying by relating the word <i>shofrei</i> (beauty) to the root <i>shapper</i> (to correct, to cleanse)—as in Job 26:13 (see Ibn Ezra, ad loc.), and in accordance with the Rabbinic interpretation of Exodus 1:5 (quoted by Rashi, ad loc.).</i> His soul, too, was composed of all the souls of Israel, in all times. And he was a vehicle for the Torah as it is above, which is referred to as <i>Adam</i>, as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 1:26.</i> “And on the likeness of the throne there was a likeness as the appearance of <i>Adam</i>…”;<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> I:71b-72a; and cf. ibid., 97a.</i> also, it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Ruth 4:7.</i> “And <i>zot</i> was within,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">The conventional translation of לפנים is aforetimes, but the author emphasizes here its etymological meaning of within (cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:180a and the commentary of R. Moses Zacuto, ad loc.; see also <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 16:4). Thus the verse now reads: “And <i>zot</i> (this, i.e., the Torah) was within, in Israel (i.e., Jacob),” i.e., engraved and marked in Israel.</i> in Israel”—and “<i>Zot</i> refers only to the Torah….”<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:81b; <i>Zohar</i> <i>Chadash</i>, <i>Rut</i> 88d; see <i>Menachot</i> 53b.</i> For the Torah was contained and vested in the soul of Israel the Patriarch<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> <i>Chadash</i>, <i>Rut</i>, 88c ff.; cf. <i>Or Hatorah</i>, <i>Nach</i> vol. 2, p. 1026 ff.—A literal translation should read: Israel the Old (<i>Yisrael Sabba</i>); a Midrashic term (cf. <i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 68:11, 74:11; etc.), apparently to distinguish between the general term Israel and Israel the Patriarch (where the Scriptural reference can be interpreted either way). In Kabbalistic writings, though, a distinction is made between <i>Yisrael Sabba</i> and what the <i>Zohar</i> calls <i>Yisrael Zutta</i> (Israel the Young, or Small); see, e.g., <i>Zohar</i> II:43a, 216a; etc. See <i>Torah Or</i>, <i>Shemot</i> 50d.</i>—which compounded all the souls.
And this is the meaning of “And he called Him <i>E-l</i>, G–d of Israel”: <i>E-l</i><sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">This Divine Name is related to <i>chesed</i>, denoting G–d’s grace and benevolence (<i>Zohar</i> III:30b-31a, 65a; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 67a; cf. also <i>Mechilta</i>, <i>Beshalach</i>, on Exodus 15:2, and see <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 1:10), <i>chesed</i> being the determinative motive “to diffuse without limit, even where compassion is not applicable at all” (see <i>below</i>, Epistle 15, and note 33, ad loc.).</i> denotes the elicitation of the radiation from the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, from concealment to manifestation, to radiate manifestly in his soul, and as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 118:27.</i> “<i>E-l</i> is the L–rd, and He gives us light.”<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> passages cited above (note 30): “<i>E-l</i> always denotes an abundant radiation from the Supreme <i>chochmah</i>” (which derives from <i>keter</i>, the supernal will, and is the source of <i>chesed</i>).</i> And after Jacob, the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, shines openly in all the upright of heart who occupy themselves with the Torah and the commandments.
Now, this manifestation in their mind and heart with an exceeding uplifting and abundant strength<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Genesis 49:3.</i> occurs at the time of prayer, as explained elsewhere.
Though this manifestation through the occupation with Torah and the commandments is, generally, equal in every one of Israel [for we all have one Torah and one law<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Numbers 15:16.</i>], nevertheless, in a more specific way not all the souls (<i>nefesh</i>) or spirits (<i>ruach</i>) and souls (<i>neshamah</i>) are equal in this regard, depending on the occurrence and time of their reincarnation and their coming into this world; and as our Sages, of blessed memory, said:<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 118b.</i> “With what was your father more heedful? He answered him—with the <i>tzitzit</i>….”<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">That is, every soul is more intimately related to one particular precept than to all the others. Since the 613 commandments are the 613 general conduits for eliciting the radiation of the Divine light (see above, and cf. below Epistle 29), there will, thus, be a difference between the various individuals corresponding to the differences in the more intimate relationships to particular precepts.</i>
Likewise, not all the generations are the same. For just as with the organs of man, every organ has its own special and particular function [the eye to see and the ear to hear], so, too, through every commandment there radiates a special and particular light from the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He.
And though every soul of Israel needs to be reincarnated in order to fulfill <i>all</i> the 613 commandments,<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 70 (132a) (in the light of ibid., p. 131), and R. Chaim Vital, <i>Shaar Hamitzvot</i>, Foreword; see also <i>Shaar Hagilgulim</i> 11; <i>et passim</i>.<i>—</i>See further on this subject: <i>Sefer Habahir</i> 38 (193); <i>Zohar</i> II:100a ff; <i>Zohar Chadash</i> 59a. Cf. also R. Menasseh ben Israel, <i>Nishmat Chaim</i> 4:6 ff.</i> even so, this special care with a particular <i>mitzvah</i> is necessary only for the sake of an increase, and prudence, and additional zeal—with exceeding uplifting and strength, doubly and manifold, surpassing the zeal for the other commandments. And that is what he meant when he said “With what was he <i>more</i> careful?”<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">The following interpretation of this Talmudic passage by the author (which he received from his master, R. Dov Ber, the <i>Maggid</i> of Mezeritch, who in turn heard it from the Baal Shem Tov) will clarify this passage: “Every soul has a particular precept and a particular attribute which it needs to perform and develop. That is the meaning of what R. Yosef asked R. Yosef the son of Rabbah: ‘With what was your father more heedful (<i>zahir</i>)?’ After all, one is not to sit and evaluate the commandments of the Torah! But R. Yosef asked ‘in what was your father more <i>zahir</i>: in what precept did he have an illumination’ (taking <i>zahir</i> as an idiom of <i>zohar</i>—to shine; to brighten); not that he observed this precept only, but that the fulfillment of the precept of <i>Tzitzit—</i>with great care—gave him power and vitality in the observance of the other precepts.” See <i>Sefer Hasichot—5700</i>, p. 22; <i>Sefer Hamaamarim 5708</i>, p. 240, and the marginal notes by the Lubavitcher Rebbe, R. Menachem M. Schneerson, ad loc. Cf. Maimonides, Commentary on the Mishnah, <i>Makkot</i> 3:16. <i>Etz Chaim</i> 49:5.</i>
Now, the advantage of this individual light to the individual souls is not in the category of apprehensible reason and knowledge, but transcends the faculty of knowledge. For thus it rose in the Mind before Him, blessed be He. And its model below is truly the notion of the “lot.”<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Which is also beyond reason and knowledge.—(This is not the conclusion of the letter. In the original there were a few more lines pleading for the support of the Torah scholars in the Holy Land. This conclusion is reproduced in <i>Igrot Kodesh Admur Hazaken</i> (Kehot, 2012), p. 201 ff.)</i>

Chapter 8

<b>EIGHT.</b> “He sows <i>tzedakot</i> and causes <i>yeshu’ot</i> to sprout.”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, Morning Prayers. Cf. <i>Maamarei Admur Hazaken Haketzarim</i>, p. 533, for an exposition of this section.</i> The usage of an idiom of “sowing” in relation to the commandment of charity [and as it is written in the verse “Sow then for yourselves for <i>tzedakah</i>…”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 10:12.</i>] will be understood by what our Sages, of blessed memory, said:<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 10a.</i> “Rabbi Eliezer gave a coin to a poor person and then prayed, as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 17:15.</i> Through <i>tzedek</i> I will see Your face.”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Torat Shmuel—5633</i>, vol. 2, p. 463 ff.</i> This means that the manifestation of His G–dliness, blessed be He, which becomes revealed in the thought of man and in his devotion during prayer,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Which is called the “service of his heart” (see below, note 11); cf. <i>Or Zarua</i>, beg. of <i>Hilchot Keriat Shema</i>, par. 7 (s.v. <i>Amar Ravin</i>; ed. Zitomir 1862, vol. 1, 11a).</i> each according to his own measure,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 70 (135b); <i>Zohar</i> I:103b.</i> is a means of “charity” and the “<i>chesed</i> of the L–rd eternally upon those who fear Him….”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 103:17.</i>
This means, the light of the L–rd, the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, which radiates with a great illumination above in the upper worlds [which are the <i>hechalot</i> with the angels and souls in them, explained in the sacred <i>Zohar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:38a ff.; ibid., 41a ff.; II:244b ff.</i> by their names according to their places in the order of prayer arranged for us by the Men of the Great Assembly] is in a state of so great and immense a manifestation that these (supernal creatures) are truly in a state of self-nullification and esteemed as truly naught before Him, absorbed in His light, blessed be He. Now, this light, which is good,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Genesis 1:4.</i> radiates from there to this lowly world, upon those that fear the L–rd and esteem His Name, who desire to worship Him by the “service of the heart—meaning prayer,”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sifrei</i>, Deuteronomy 42 (on Deuteronomy 11:13); <i>Taanit</i> 2a.</i> and as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 22:29 (Psalms 18:29).</i>: “And the L–rd will enlighten my darkness.”
Now, the descent of this illumination downward to this world is called the “<i>chesed</i> of the L–rd”<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">See above, note 7.</i>—referred to as water,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:175b; III:255a and 257a; see also <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 23:13, s.v. <i>Mayim</i>, and below, note 15.</i> which descends from a high place to a low place….<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 69 (105a) (and 13 (70b)). See <i>below</i>, Epistle 12 and <i>Torah Or</i>, <i>Vayera</i> 14c.</i>
Now it is well known that above there is also an attribute of <i>gevurah</i>, and <i>tzimtzum</i>, to contract and conceal His light, blessed be He, to prevent it from becoming revealed to the lower worlds.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>below</i>, Epistle 15.</i> However, everything depends on the arousal from below.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>above</i>, Epistle 5, note 83.</i> For if man conducts himself with kindness by bestowing life and <i>chesed</i>, and so on, he arouses the same above, as our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “With the degree that man measures, it shall be measured to him.”<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah, <i>Sotah</i> 1:7.</i>
Though it would appear that this is not of the (same) measure: (man deserves) only that the life of the World to Come be granted to him, corresponding to his bestowal of life in this world; but not that the life from the illumination of the actual light of G–d<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">V. L.: the actual light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He.</i> be diffused to him to illumine and enlighten his darkness in “the service of the heart—which is prayer.” For the latter is a grade and level of “higher repentance” (<i>teshuvah ilaah</i>),<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">For an explanation of this term see <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 8 ff. (esp. ch. 10).</i> as is well known, inasmuch as it surpasses exceedingly all the life of the World to Come , as our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “Better one hour of repentance and good deeds…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 4:17.</i> as explained elsewhere at length<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, end of ch. 4. Cf. also <i>above</i>, Epistle 1, note 22.</i> that the World to Come is but a gleam and reflection….<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Berachot</i> 17a and Maimonides, <i>Hilchot</i> <i>Teshuvah</i>, ch. 8.—See <i>above</i>, Epistle 1, note 22 and <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Derushim LiShemini Atzeret</i> 83d. While <i>teshuvah</i> <i>tataah</i> (lower <i>teshuvah</i>) corresponds to <i>malchut</i>, <i>teshuvah</i> <i>ilaah</i> transcends this level and corresponds to the higher <i>binah</i>. (See <i>Zohar</i> III:122a ff., and <i>Tikkunei</i> <i>Zohar</i> 6 (22a); <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 9.) He who stands in a mode of <i>teshuvah</i> is called <i>baal teshuvah</i>; the <i>Zohar</i> interprets this term literally as “possessed of <i>teshuvah</i>,” signifying an absolute unification with <i>teshuvah</i> and the level it represents. See <i>Zohar</i> II:106b and comm., ad loc.; cf. Maharal, <i>Derech Chaim</i> on <i>Avot</i> 4:17.</i>
However, metaphorically speaking, the idea is like sowing seeds or planting kernels: the ear that sprouts from the seed, and the tree with its fruits from the kernel, their nature and essence are not that of the seed and kernel at all. For their<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., of the seed and kernel.</i> nature and essence has been spent and is decayed in the soil. It is the vegetative property in the soil itself which brings out and makes grow the ear, the tree, and its fruit; it is merely that it does not bring out and manifest its power outwardly, from potential to actuality, except through the seed and the kernel that are decayed in the soil and whose whole power has been consumed by the vegetative property in the soil—and they united and became one. And that is how the vegetative property actualizes its potential and effuses vitality to make grow an ear of the kind of the seed, though with a very great increase in every single ear, and likewise, many fruits on every single tree. Moreover, the very nature and essence of the fruits, too, excels in a great and immense magnitude over the nature and essence of the planted kernel. And it is likewise with the produce of the earth which grows from seeds just like kernels, as cucumber, and the like.
All this is so because the stem and root of the vitality of the fruits effuses from the vegetative property in the soil—which includes the vitality of all fruits—while the kernels that are sown in the ground are but like the arousal from below, which in the writings of the Arizal<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 5, note 103.</i> is referred to as the “elevation of the <i>mayin nukvin</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 4, note 46.</i>
Now, metaphorically speaking, precisely like this, every act of charity that Jewish people perform ascends in the sense of an “elevation of the <i>mayin nukvin</i>,” upward—to the root of their souls above, which, in the phraseology of the <i>Zohar</i>, is referred to as <i>Knesset Yisrael</i> and <i>imma tataah</i>, and in the phraseology of the Talmud—as <i>Shechinah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">In the <i>Zohar</i>, the terms <i>Knesset Yisrael</i> and <i>Imma Tataah</i> are synonymous with <i>malchut</i> and <i>Shechinah</i>. (See <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 23:1 and 11, s.v. <i>Eim Habanim</i> and <i>Knesset Yisrael</i>; <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 52; below, Epistle 25.) There are some instances where this would not seem to be so, but see <i>Nitzutzei Orot</i> on <i>Zohar</i> II:85a (and on <i>Zohar</i> II:90a). See also <i>Shaarei Orah</i> (Gikatilla), end of ch. 1.</i> The <i>Shechinah</i> compounds and is totally united with all the attributes of the Holy One, blessed is He, the first of which is the attribute of <i>chesed</i>. Now, through this elevation, the actual “<i>chesed</i> of the L–rd” is aroused, i.e., a revelation of His light, blessed be He, to descend and radiate in a great and immense state of manifestation to the souls of Israel below, at least during the time of prayer.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">See above, beginning of this epistle, and cf. above, end of Epistle 4.</i> For though “His greatness is unfathomable”<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 145:3.</i>—to the extent that “all are esteemed as naught before Him,”<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:11b.</i> even so, “where you find His greatness, there you find His humility,”<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Megillah</i> 31a [according to the versions of <i>Pesikta Zutrata</i> (<i>Midrash Lekach Tov</i>) on Deuteronomy 10:17 and <i>Yalkut Shimoni</i>, Psalms 794 (on Psalms 68:5)].</i> as “waters, which descend….”<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">As waters descend from a high place to a low place; a simile signifying humility (cf. <i>Taanit</i> 7a). In relation to G–d, the whole creation, all creatures, are insignificant, truly naught and nothing. His greatness, therefore, is not expressed through creation per se. Rather, His humility, that G–d created them nevertheless and cares for them by means of an intense and particular providence, this Divine humility expresses His greatness. Therefore, in the place where you find His greatness, there you find His humility: His humility being His greatness. (See <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Shir Hashirim</i> 40d; cf. also <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 4.)</i>
And this is the meaning of the verse: “He shines in the darkness as a light to the upright, He who is gracious, and merciful, and <i>tzaddik</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 112:4.</i> For man, by being gracious and merciful and “<i>tzaddik</i>—fond of <i>tzedakot</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 11:7; see <i>Tanchuma</i>, ed. Buber, <i>Noach</i> 4 (see <i>Yalkut Shimoni</i>, Deuteronomy, end of 873).</i> causes the light of G–d to shine to his soul which is vested in his body—which stands in darkness, being the “hide of the snake.”<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 10b; above, Epistle 6, note 21.</i> And this, when darkness is converted to light, is referred to as salvation (<i>yeshu’ah</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">See above, end of Epistle 3.</i>
And this is the meaning of “He causes <i>yeshu’ot</i> to sprout.” For this salvation sprouts from [the sowing of] the charity sown in the “upper land,”<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">The celestial model of the terrestrial Holy Land (see below, note 44) signifies <i>malchut</i>, the <i>Shechinah</i>; cf. <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 23:1, s.v. <i>Eretz HaElyonah</i>.</i> “the land of delight”<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Malachi 3:12 [<i>Eretz chefetz</i> signifies <i>Knesset Yisrael</i>; cf. <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 23:1, s.v. <i>Eretz Chefetz</i>; <i>Kitzurim V’Hearot</i>, p. 99; <i>Mayim Rabbim 5636</i>, ch. 99]. (See also the commentaries of <i>Rashba</i> and <i>Maharsha</i> on <i>Eyn Yaakov</i>, <i>Taanit</i> 10a, that <i>eretz</i> without qualification refers to the Holy Land; and cf. <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 23:1, s.v. <i>Eretz</i>.)</i>—which is the <i>Shechinah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Targum Yonatan</i> on Malachi 3:12.</i> and <i>Knesset Yisrael</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Another term for <i>Shechinah</i> (see above, note 26). See above, note 37.</i> so called because it<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Malchut</i> (synonymous with <i>Shechinah</i> and <i>Knesset Yisrael</i>).</i> vests itself in the lower worlds to animate them, as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 145:13.</i> “Your sovereignty<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Malchut</i>.</i> is the sovereignty of all worlds.”<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Malchut</i> (<i>Shechinah</i>) embodies the supreme <i>chochmah</i> and causes the worlds to egress into manifest substantiality (see Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>). Though we speak of <i>malchut</i> on various levels, relating to the various worlds, it is <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> that is vested in them all. This is the meaning of “Your sovereignty (<i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>) is the sovereignty (<i>malchut</i>) of all worlds.” See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 52; <i>Siddur Im Dach</i> 53c and cf. <i>Etz Chaim</i> 3:1. See also below, Epistle 20, and <i>Maamarei Admur Hazaken Haketzarim</i>, p. 43.</i> And this applies most particularly when one sows in the nether Holy Land, which truly corresponds to it.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Everything in the celestial spheres has its corresponding model in the terrestrial world (and <i>vice versa</i>), with respect to the general, as well as to the particular parts. (See <i>Zohar</i> I:156a-b; II:20a; III:9b.) The Sages, therefore, speak of the <i>terrestrial</i> Holy of Holies and its <i>celestial</i> counterpart; the <i>terrestrial</i> Temple and its <i>celestial</i> counterpart; the <i>terrestrial</i> Jerusalem, etc.; cf. Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Berachot</i> 4:5; <i>Shir Hashirim Rabbah</i> 3:19; <i>Mechilta</i> and <i>Midrashim</i> on Exodus 15:17; <i>Tanchuma</i>, <i>Pekudei</i> 1, 2; <i>Zohar</i> I:128b; etc. The <i>terrestrial</i> Holy Land, or Land of Israel, thus corresponds to the <i>celestial</i> one; see <i>Zohar</i> III:84a; and see below, notes 45 and 46.</i> For then the seed is immediately absorbed in the upper land without any obstacle and hindrance whatsoever, because there is nothing whatsoever that divides and interrupts between the lands of life,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">The terrestrial Land of Israel is referred to as the “Land of Life” (see Jeremiah 11:19 and <i>Targum</i> <i>Yonatan</i> ad loc.; Ezekiel 26:20, <i>Targum Yonatan</i> and commentaries, ad loc., as well as <i>Avot d’R. Nattan</i>, ch. 34; <i>Ketuvot</i> 111a; etc.) and correspondingly the celestial Land of Israel likewise; see <i>Zohar</i> I:115a; I:193a, and III:84a. See <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 23:1, s.v. <i>Eretz HaChaim</i>.</i> for it is the gate of Heaven.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">“G–d will bless you out of Zion” (Psalms 128:5), “for it is the Gate of Heaven” (<i>Rashi</i>; see also the other comment., ad loc.). See also Genesis 28:17 and <i>Targum</i>, <i>Rashi</i>, ad loc. (see above, note 44). “This is none other than the House of G–d, and this is the Gate of Heaven”—the “Gate to G–d” (<i>Zohar</i> I:149b), the “Gate assuredly through which the blessings pass downward,” etc. (ibid., 150b.). Cf. also <i>Zohar</i> III:123b, and <i>Ibn Ezra</i> on Genesis 28:12.</i> It is not so, however, outside the Holy Land, and suffice this for the initiated.
And this applies most particularly when one sows in the nether Holy Land, which truly corresponds to it.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Everything in the celestial spheres has its corresponding model in the terrestrial world (and <i>vice versa</i>), with respect to the general, as well as to the particular parts. (See <i>Zohar</i> I:156a-b; II:20a; III:9b.) The Sages, therefore, speak of the <i>terrestrial</i> Holy of Holies and its <i>celestial</i> counterpart; the <i>terrestrial</i> Temple and its <i>celestial</i> counterpart; the <i>terrestrial</i> Jerusalem, etc.; cf. Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Berachot</i> 4:5; <i>Shir Hashirim Rabbah</i> 3:19; <i>Mechilta</i> and <i>Midrashim</i> on Exodus 15:17; <i>Tanchuma</i>, <i>Pekudei</i> 1, 2; <i>Zohar</i> I:128b; etc. The <i>terrestrial</i> Holy Land, or Land of Israel, thus corresponds to the <i>celestial</i> one; see <i>Zohar</i> III:84a; and see below, notes 45 and 46.</i> For then the seed is immediately absorbed in the upper land without any obstacle and hindrance whatsoever, because there is nothing whatsoever that divides and interrupts between the lands of life,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">The terrestrial Land of Israel is referred to as the “Land of Life” (see Jeremiah 11:19 and <i>Targum</i> <i>Yonatan</i> ad loc.; Ezekiel 26:20, <i>Targum Yonatan</i> and commentaries, ad loc., as well as <i>Avot d’R. Nattan</i>, ch. 34; <i>Ketuvot</i> 111a; etc.) and correspondingly the celestial Land of Israel likewise; see <i>Zohar</i> I:115a; I:193a, and III:84a. See <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 23:1, s.v. <i>Eretz HaChaim</i>.</i> for it is the gate of Heaven.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">“G–d will bless you out of Zion” (Psalms 128:5), “for it is the Gate of Heaven” (<i>Rashi</i>; see also the other comment., ad loc.). See also Genesis 28:17 and <i>Targum</i>, <i>Rashi</i>, ad loc. (see above, note 44). “This is none other than the House of G–d, and this is the Gate of Heaven”—the “Gate to G–d” (<i>Zohar</i> I:149b), the “Gate assuredly through which the blessings pass downward,” etc. (ibid., 150b.). Cf. also <i>Zohar</i> III:123b, and <i>Ibn Ezra</i> on Genesis 28:12.</i> It is not so, however, outside the Holy Land, and suffice this for the initiated.

Chapter 9

<b>NINE.</b> My beloved, brethren and friends—who are to me as my soul: I come as one who reminds and awakens those who sleep the slumber of the vanities of vanities, and to open the eyes of the blind. Let them consider and see<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 42:18.</i> that throughout their life all their striving, longing, and aiming for all in which there is the “life of their spirit”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 38:16 (see <i>Rashi</i> ad loc.).</i> be in “the source of the living waters”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Jeremiah 2:13; ibid., 17:13.</i> [the Fountainhead of all life<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Lit.: the Life of life (see above, Epistle 4, note 74).</i>], with respect to the soul, as well as to the flesh<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 10:18.</i> [i.e., all mundane matters and occupations for livelihood]. Be not like those that do everything for their own sake! Let not the House of Israel be like all the nations<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Text corrected according to L. H.</i> that feed, provide, and esteem their wives and children out of love.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., out of egocentric motivation.</i> For it is written: “Who is like Your people Israel, a unique nation on earth”;<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 17:21.</i> this means that even in mundane matters they will not, Heaven forfend, separate<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">V. L.: to become separated.</i> from the True One,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> II:155b and III:81a.</i> to bear false witness, Heaven forfend, by reciting the <i>Shema</i> every evening and morning with closed eyes: “the L–rd is One”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 6:4.</i>—in the four directions, and in the Heavens above and on earth below,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Berachot</i> 13b; <i>Zohar</i> I:12a; 158a; II:216b.</i> while, as the eyes of the blind are opened, “You cause your eyes to close upon Him, and He is no more,”<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Proverbs 23:5.</i> Heaven forfend.
Only this shall be befitting us when<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">V. L.: for… to be not.</i> all our engagements with mundane affairs are not for their <i>own</i> sake but in order to vivify the souls, the portions of G–d, and to supply what they lack out of gratuitous kindness. For thereby we give the form<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The creature (man).</i> a semblance to its Former<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The Creator.—Cf. <i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 27:1.</i>—“the L–rd is One,” for the <i>chesed</i> of G–d endures at all time<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 52:3 (cf. <i>Rashi</i>, ad loc.).</i>—a true <i>chesed </i><sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chesed shel emet</i>, in Hebrew, signifying a gratuitous kindness (cf. <i>Rashi</i> on Genesis 47:29), continuous, ceaseless, and absolute (cf. <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Massei</i> 93b-c).</i>—to animate the universe and all that fills it, every single moment. It is just that according to the Torah a man’s wife and children take precedence over all others,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, <i>Yoreh Deah</i> 251.</i> except<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">From here to end of paragraph inserted according to L. H.</i> for the saints of that generation—who take precedence over one’s children and the saints of the Land of Israel take precedence over the saints in the Diaspora,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Sifrei</i>, Deuteronomy 116; <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, <i>Yoreh Deah</i> 251 (see also <i>Pitchei Teshuvah</i>, ad loc., par. 4).</i> [aside of the fact that they did not leave anyone in the Diaspora comparable to themselves],<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">While the previous seems to be a general Halachic statement, these latter words appear to refer specifically to the Chasidic leaders (including the author’s master and colleague, R. Menachem Mendel of Vitebsk) who ascended to the Holy Land accompanied by their families and numerous followers.</i> and suffice this for the initiated.
Therefore, my beloved, my brethren: set your hearts to these words expressed in great brevity <sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i> (and, please G–d, personally I will speak to them at length)—how in these times, with the advent of the Messiah,<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">See below, note 27.</i> the principal service of G–d is the service of charity, as our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “Israel will be redeemed only through charity.”<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 139a; <i>Sanhedrin</i> 98a (see glossary notes, ad loc.).</i> Our Sages, of blessed memory, did not say that the study of Torah is equivalent to the performance of lovingkindness<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">See Mishnah, <i>Peah</i> 1:1: “The study of Torah is equivalent to them all” (including the performance of kindness).—Cf. <i>Likkutei Sichot</i>, vol. 9, p. 345, in the glossary notes.</i> except in their own days. For with them the principal service was the study of Torah and, therefore, there were great scholars: <i>Tannaim</i> and <i>Amoraim</i>. However, with the advent of the Messiah,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Be’ikvot Meshicha</i>, in Hebrew, lit. “on the heels,” or “in the footsteps of the Messiah.” See <i>Sotah</i> 49:b, and <i>Rashi</i>, ad loc., for this expression and <i>Etz Chaim</i> 3:2 for its mystical implication.</i> as “the Hut of David has fallen”<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Amos 9:11.</i> to a level of “feet” and “heels”—which is the level of “Action”—there is no way of truly cleaving to it<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The Hut of David, i.e., the <i>Shechinah</i>; cf. <i>Zohar</i> II:9a.</i> and to convert the darkness into its light, except through a corresponding category of action, namely the act of charity.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. below, Epistle 30.—See below, Epistle 12, on the notion of the “<i>act</i> of charity.”</i> For, as known to the intelligent, the plane of action with reference to Divinity is the notion of a diffusion and efflux of vitality to the nethermost—to him who has nothing of his own. And whoever sacrifices his impulse in this respect and opens his hand and heart subdues the <i>sitra achara</i><sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">The “other side,” the side of evil and impurity.</i> and “converts the darkness into the light”<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:4a.</i> of G–d, blessed be He, Who, with the advent of the Messiah, dwells over us in a state of action; and he will merit to “behold eye to eye, the L–rd returning to Zion …”<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 52:8. The original letter ends here with a concluding salutation. In some versions of this letter there appear slight variations; see <i>Igrot Kodesh Admur Hazaken</i> (Kehot, 2012), p. 44 ff.</i>

Chapter 10

<b>TEN.</b> After greetings of peace and life, “may the opening of my words rouse”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 119:130.</i> the ear that hears the admonition of life<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Proverbs 15:31.</i> which the L–rd of life<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., the living L–rd. (The translation used seeks to retain the poetic spirit of the text.)</i> admonished through His Prophets and said: “The graces of the L–rd are surely not concluded (תמנו)….”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 3:22.</i> Now, it should really have said תמו, as it is written elsewhere: “For your graces are not concluded (תמו)….”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, concluding benedictions of the <i>Amidah</i>.</i> But this will be understood when considering the statement in the sacred <i>Zohar</i>:<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> III:133b; 140b. See also <i>Zohar</i> I:219a and III:21a.</i> “There are various types of <i>chesed</i>: there is <i>chesed olam</i><sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">“Grace of the world,” or “perpetual grace.”</i>…, and there is <i>chesed ilaah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Supreme <i>chesed</i>.</i>—i.e., <i>rav chesed</i><sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Abundant, or magnanimous <i>chesed</i> (cf. Exodus 34:6).</i>….”
Now, it is well known that the Torah is called <i>oz</i> (strength),<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sifrei</i>, Deuteronomy, sect. 343 (on Deuteronomy 32:2); <i>Shir Hashirim Rabbah</i> 1, s.v. <i>Meshacheni</i> 1; <i>Tanchuma</i>, <i>Berachah</i> 4; cf. above, Epistle 1, note 10. See <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Shelach</i> 39d.</i> which is an expression of <i>gevurah</i> (might),<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 1, note 10.</i> and as our Sages, of blessed memory, said—“The 613 commandments were declared to Moses at Sinai”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Makkot</i> 23b (acc. to various versions, e.g., <i>Eyn Yaakov</i>, etc.); <i>Tanchuma</i>, <i>Shoftim</i> 9; et al.</i> from the Mouth of <i>Gevurah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., “Might,” a frequent rabbinic expression denoting Divine majesty (the L–rd) and in Kabbalistic-Chasidic literature related to the equally named attribute of <i>gevurah</i>. This term is also used with respect to the Giving of the Torah (see <i>Makkot</i> 24a; <i>et passim</i>).—Whereas I could not find any rabbinic saying as our text would seem to suggest—“the 613 commandments of the <i>gevurah</i>”—(though see <i>Zohar</i> II:116b), I divided it under the assumption that the author added it on his own to the original expression. Thus the proof-text from Deuteronomy is also not to be taken as an integral part of the preceeding, but added to support it, and the following interpretation.</i> and as it is written: “From His right side a fiery law to them.”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:2.</i> This means: The source and root of the Torah consists solely of the “graces of the L–rd,”<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> II:113a; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 11b. See also <i>Zohar</i> II:118b, III:237a, and <i>Berachot</i> 6a (especially in the light of the following note).</i> which are referred to as the “right side.”<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> I:26b; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 17a; <i>et passim</i>.</i> That is, the elicitation of His G–dliness, blessed be He, and of a radiation from the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, to the upper and lower worlds, is effected by man who elicits the light upon himself by the fulfillment of the 248 operational precepts, which are the “248 organs of the King,”<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> II:118a; <i>Tikkunei</i> <i>Zohar</i> 30 (74a); cf. <i>Zohar</i> II:83b, ibid., 163b; <i>Tikkunei</i> <i>Zohar</i> 70 (131a) ff.<i>—</i>See <i>Kitzurim V’Hearot</i>, p. 106 ff., and cf. <i>Shomer Emunim</i> 1:24 ff.</i> i.e., the 248 vessels and garments for the radiation from the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, that is vested in them (<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>and as known, with every commandment there issues forth to him awe and love from this light).<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, chs. 23 and 37; <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 1.</i>
However, this efflux was first vested in the attribute of the <i>gevurah</i> of the Holy One, blessed is He,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., though the Torah originates in <i>chesed</i>, it was given to man—“from the Mouth of <i>Gevurah</i>,” through the attribute of <i>gevurah</i>; see <i>Zohar</i> I:48b, and <i>Derech Emet</i> ad loc. Cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:240a; II:81a; etc. See further: <i>Zohar</i> II:84a and cf. <i>Tikkunei</i> <i>Zohar</i>, Introduction 6a and 11b.</i> referred to as “fire.”<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:255a; 257a; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 69 (105a).—Thus, the above-cited verse means: “<i>From His right</i>”—from <i>chesed</i>, “<i>the fire of the Law</i>”—is the Torah given through <i>gevurah</i>; cf. <i>Zohar</i> II:84a and the commentaries of Nachmanides and <i>Or Hachaim</i>, on Deuteronomy 32:2. See also <i>Zohar</i> II:206b.</i> (<i>Gevurah</i>) is the aspect of the contraction (<i>tzimtzum</i>) of the light and vivification that issue from the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">See below, Epistle 15.</i> so that it will be able to become vested in the performance of the commandments, practically all of which involve material things—as <i>tzitzit</i>, <i>tefillin</i>, sacrifices, and charity.
And even commandments that involve man spiritually—as awe and love—are in a mode of limitation and measure,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">The aspect of <i>gevurah</i>.</i> and by no means in a mode of infinitude. For not even for a moment could man sustain in his heart so intense a love of G–d as is without end and limitation and still remain in existence in his body, and as the saying of our Sages, of blessed memory, that at the time of the Giving of the Torah [which was a manifestation of His G–dliness, blessed be He, and of the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, on a plane of speech and revelation<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">See Exodus 20:15 and <i>Mechilta</i>, <i>Yitro</i>, ad loc. (s.v. <i>Bachodesh</i>, ch. 9); <i>Pirkei d’R. Eliezer</i>, ch. 41; <i>Shemot Rabbah</i> 29:3.</i>]—“their souls took flight…”<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shemot Rabbah</i> 29:3; <i>Shabbat</i> 88b.</i>
Now, because the commandments were given to us by way of investment in the attribute of <i>gevurah</i> and a contraction (<i>tzimtzum</i>) of the radiation, and so on, most commandments have a delimited measure. For instance, the length of <i>tzitzit</i> (must be) twelve times the width of the thumb;<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shulchan</i> <i>Aruch</i>, <i>Orach</i> <i>Chaim</i> 11:4; cf. <i>Shulchan Aruch HaRav</i> 11:5 (and 7).</i> the <i>tefillin</i>—two fingers by two fingers,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shulchan</i> <i>Aruch</i>, <i>Orach</i> <i>Chaim</i> 32:41, <i>Magen Avraham</i>, ad loc.; cf. <i>Shulchan Aruch HaRav</i> 32:63.</i> and necessarily square;<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Menachot</i> 35a; <i>Shulchan</i> <i>Aruch</i>, <i>Orach</i> <i>Chaim</i> 32:39; cf. <i>Shulchan Aruch HaRav</i> 32:59.</i> the <i>lulav</i>—four handbreadths;<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sukkah</i> 32b; <i>Shulchan</i> <i>Aruch</i>, <i>Orach</i> <i>Chaim</i> 650:1.</i> the <i>sukkah</i>—seven handbreadths;<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shulchan</i> <i>Aruch</i>, <i>Orach</i> <i>Chaim</i> 634:1.</i> the <i>shofar</i>—one handbreadth;<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Niddah</i> 26a; <i>Shulchan</i> <i>Aruch</i>, <i>Orach</i> <i>Chaim</i> 586:9.</i> the <i>mikveh</i>—forty <i>seah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Eruvin</i> 4b; Mishnah, <i>Mikvaot</i> 1:7; <i>Shulchan</i> <i>Aruch</i>, <i>Yoreh</i> <i>Deah</i> 201.</i> The sacrifices, too, have a delimited measure as regards age, as for instance—“sheep of one year old,” and “rams of two years old,” and “oxen….”
The same applies also to the act of charity and the performance of kindness with one’s money [even though that is one of the pillars upon which the world stands,<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pirkei</i> <i>d’R. Eliezer</i>, ch. 12.</i> and as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 89:3.</i> “The world was built by <i>chesed</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Avot</i> <i>d’R. Nattan</i>, ch. 4; <i>Yalkut</i> <i>Shimoni</i>, Psalms 839 (on Psalms 89).</i> nevertheless]—it has a set measure of preferably one-fifth, and of one-tenth for an average measure….<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Matnot Aniyim</i> 7:5; <i>Shulchan</i> <i>Aruch</i>, <i>Yoreh</i> <i>Deah</i> 249:1.</i> And this is what is called <i>chesed olam</i>: the “<i>chesed</i> of G–d enduring continually”<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 52:3.</i> that vests itself in the upper and lower worlds through the arousal from below—i.e., the precept of the charity and kindness which people perform among each other.
But because the world is in a state of finitude and measure [“From the earth to the heaven is a distance of 500 years…and [similarly] from one heaven to the next”<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chagigah</i> 13a.</i>; and “Six thousand years shall the world exist…”<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 97a.</i>], the Torah’s commandment of charity and kindness is also given a limit and measure, just like the other commandments of the Torah. 
However, this<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">The limited amount for charity.</i> applies only to one who observes the Torah and does not stray from it right or left, even as much as a hair’s breadth. But he who has strayed from the path, Heaven forfend, whereas he has perverted his way [thus causing deficiencies in the <i>kodesh ha’elyon</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:66a; also, II:85b, 155b, 162b, and III:16b; <i>et passim</i>.—קדש העליון (Supreme Holiness) refers to the <i>Supreme</i> <i>chochmah</i>; see <i>Zohar</i> II:121a; <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 19. See also below, Epistle 17, note 34.</i> that is, he has diminished his value as regards the efflux he could have elicited from the aspect of His Divinity and the radiation from the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, by observing the Torah and fulfilling her as behooves<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 1.</i>]—such perversion cannot be rectified save by an efflux of the Supreme light which transcends the worlds and does not vest itself in them. This is what is called <i>chesed ilaah</i>, and <i>rav chesed</i>, because it radiates and extends in a state of infinitude without limit and measure [whereas it is not contracted within the worlds but is in a state of encompassing over them, from aloft, from the peak of all rungs to the end…]. Now, when man draws it downward through his deeds and the arousal from below, this Supreme light will then radiate and expand within the worlds and rectify all perversions and deficiencies caused in the <i>kodesh ha’eylon</i>, renewing their light and goodness with exceeding uplifting and strength on the level of a truly new light. That is why they said that “In the place where penitents stand….”<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">In the place where penitents stand, not even the perfectly righteous can stand (<i>Berachot</i> 34b) because the penitents elicit the supreme light in greater strength and measure than the righteous. See <i>Zohar</i> I:39a and III:16b. Cf. also above, Epistle 8, note 23.</i>
Now the essence of penitence (<i>teshuvah</i>) is in the heart,<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 6:10 (<i>Megillah</i> 17b); <i>Zohar</i> II:150a; also ibid., I:41a.—Cf. also, “<i>teshuvah</i> is <i>binah</i>” (<i>Zohar</i> I:79b, III:122a and 255b), “which is the heart” (<i>Tikkunei</i> <i>Zohar</i>, Introduction 17a).</i> for through contrition from the depth of the heart one arouses the depth of this Supreme light.
But in order to elicit (this light) so that it will radiate in the upper and lower worlds, it is essential that there be truly an arousal from below, in the mode of an action, i.e., an act of charity and kindness that is without limit and measure. For just as man diffuses <i>rav chesed</i> [i.e., ח”ס דלי”ת (he is concerned with him who has not)<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Division of the word חסד into חס and the final letter ד (cf. <i>Tikkunei</i> <i>Zohar</i> 22 (67b)). The ד (which written out fully spells the word דלי”ת meaning “has not”) signifies the poor and destitute for which one is to care—see <i>Shabbat</i> 104a; <i>Zohar</i> I:3a and III:273b. See also <i>Netivot</i> <i>Olam</i>, s.v. <i>Tzedakah</i>, ch. 2.</i>]—namely to the poor and destitute who has nothing of his own, without setting a limit and measure to his giving and diffusion, the Holy One, blessed is He, likewise diffuses His light and benignity in the mode of <i>chesed ilaah</i>, referred to as <i>rav chesed</i>, which radiates within the upper and lower worlds in a mode of infinitude, without limit and measure. For in relation to Him, blessed be He, all are in a state of דלי”ת, whereas they have nothing at all of their own, and all that are before Him are esteemed as naught.<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:11b.</i> And all the blemishes that man caused above, in the upper and the lower worlds, through his iniquities, are rectified hereby.
And this is the meaning of what is written: “to the L–rd, to exercise <i>tzedakah</i> and justice is preferable to sacrifice.”<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 21:3.</i> Because the sacrifices are in a mode of quantity, measure, and limit, while charity can be dispersed without limit for the purpose of rectifying one’s iniquities.
As for the ruling<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketuvot</i> 50a.</i> that he who expends should not expend more than one-fifth, this applies only to him who has not sinned, or has rectified his sins by means of self-mortification and fasts, as behooves to rectify all the blemishes above. But he who still needs to remedy his soul, surely the healing of the soul is not inferior to the healing of the body where money does not count, “And all that a man has he will give on behalf of his soul”—states Scripture.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Job 2:4. Cf. <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, end of ch. 3. See also Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Deot</i> 11:2, and ibid., 1:5 (in which he obviously includes the disbursement of charity exceeding one-fifth, and as he states explicitly in his commentary on the Mishnah, <i>Peah</i> 1:1; according to the abovementioned, this cannot be regarded as contradicting his ruling—based on <i>Ketuvot</i> 50a and 67b—in <i>Hilchot Erchin</i> 8:13). Cf. <i>Birkei Yosef</i> on <i>Yoreh Deah</i> 249 and <i>Chomat Anach</i> on Proverbs 11. See also <i>Meah She’arim</i> 1:28 (9a) and 3:3 (18a).</i>
Now, this type of unlimited<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., without limit and measure.</i> kindness is called by the Name of the Holy One, blessed is He, “the graces of the L–rd,” as it is written: “and the <i>chesed</i> of the L–rd is everlasting….”<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 103:17.</i> For though “all of Israel are compassionate and performers of kindness,”<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yevamot</i> 79a.</i> nevertheless there is a limit and measure to man’s compassion. But the Holy One, blessed is He, is called the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He,<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Infinite.</i> and to His attributes there is no end, as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 3:22.</i> “For His compassions are not exhausted.”<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Text adds etc., but omitted according to H. V.</i>
And this is the meaning of what the prophet said, after the destruction and the exile: “The graces of the L–rd—כי לא תמנו.”<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">See note 55.</i> That is: “Because <i>we are not perfect</i><sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">לא תמנו is usually translated “they are not concluded,” but may also mean, as the author translates/interprets now, “we are not perfect.”</i> [for we are not whole and perfect without any sin and blemish in the soul and the upper worlds]—that is why we need to conduct ourselves in accordance with “<i>the graces of the L–rd</i>” which are without limit and end, in order to elicit upon ourselves<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., to arouse over us.</i> compassion and <i>chesed ilaah</i>, i.e., <i>rav chesed</i>, and unlimited, infinite compassion, as it is written: “For His compassion is not exhausted….”<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Our verse reads now: (We need to perform kindness in a mode of) “the graces of the L–rd, because we are not perfect”; (this enables us to draw forth the infinite Divine compassion) “for His compassion is not exhausted.”</i>
And this is what our Sages, of blessed memory, meant by saying: “Israel will be redeemed only through charity<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 139a; <i>Sanhedrin</i> 98a (see glossary note, ad loc.).</i>—which they will perform even when they are legally not obligated, for “The son of David will not come until….<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">“—until the <i>perutah</i> (the smallest coin) has gone from the purse, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 97a; see also <i>Pesikta Zutrata</i> on Deuteronomy 32:36.—The implication is a total disbursement, without regard to any limit or measure.</i>”<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">The original letter concludes here with a lengthy appeal for charity (see <i>Igrot Kodesh Admur Hazaken</i> (Kehot, 2012), p. 135 ff.).</i>

Chapter 11

<b>ELEVEN.</b> To make you skillful of understanding<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Daniel 9:22.</i> that this is not the way in which the light of the L–rd dwells,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Job 38:19.</i> i.e., in there being a desire for the “life of flesh,”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 14:30.</i> and children, and sustenance, for on this our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “Make naught your will….”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 2:4.</i> That is, one’s will should be nullified so that one has absolutely no will in any worldly matters that are implied by “children, life, and sustenance,”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Moed Kattan</i> 28b [<i>Zohar</i> I:43b; ibid., 181a; <i>et passim</i>. See also <i>Biurei Hazohar</i>, <i>Vayera</i> 11b (in comment on <i>Zohar</i> I:115a)].</i> and as our Sages, of blessed memory, said that “Despite yourself, do you live.”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 4:22.</i>
This means: There is to be only an absolute belief in the <i>Yotzer Bereishit</i><sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., the Former of the Beginning. The latter word, which has a cosmological connotation, is often used and translated as “creation,” or “universe.” It was left untranslated in the text because there is a play on words <i>(bereishit</i> here, <i>reishit</i> further on). (See also <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 23:10, s.v. <i>Yotzer Bereishit</i>, on this term.)</i>; that is, that the creation of being <i>ex nihilo</i> (<i>yesh meayin</i>) [which is called <i>reishit chochmah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 112:10 or Proverbs 4:7. <i>Reishit</i> (the beginning) is another term for <i>chochmah</i> (see above, Epistle 5, notes 80-82). <i>Chochmah</i> is the <i>ayin</i> (naught) out of which the creation came into being (see further on, and cf. Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>).</i> i.e., His wisdom which is not apprehensible to any creature]—this creation occurs constantly and every moment,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, ch. 1 ff. below, Epistle 25; see <i>Kuzari</i> 3:11 and cf. also <i>Chagigah</i> 12b and <i>Zohar</i> I:207a.</i> by all creatures coming into being [as a substance <i>ex nihilo</i> (<i>yesh meayin</i>)] from His wisdom, blessed be He, which animates everything.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 18 ff. and <i>Zohar</i> I:207a. See also Addendum, ibid.</i> And when man will contemplate in the profundity of his understanding, and will imagine in his mind his coming to be <i>ex nihilo</i>—truly every moment, how can he possibly think he has ever suffered, or had any afflictions related to “children, life, and sustenance,” or whatever other worldly sufferings. For the naught (<i>ayin</i>) which is His wisdom, blessed be He,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 42 (81b); 70 (127a) and 133b. See also <i>Zohar</i> I:246b; II:43b and 64b; <i>et passim</i>. Cf. <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 23:1, s.v. <i>Ayin</i>. (See <i>Kitzurim V’Hearot</i>, p. 100, par. 7.)</i> is the source of life, welfare, and delight. It<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ayin</i>, <i>chochmah</i>.</i> is the <i>Eden</i> which transcends the World to Come,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 5, and notes 17 ff., ad loc. (<i>Eden</i> is <i>chochmah</i>, and the World to Come is <i>binah</i>.)</i> except that, because it is not apprehensible, one imagines to have sufferings, or afflictions. In fact, however, no evil descends from above<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 51:3.</i> and everything is good, though it is not apprehended because of its immense and abundant goodness.
And this is the essence of the faith for which man was created: to believe that “there is no place void of Him”<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 57 (91b); ibid., 70 (122b). See <i>Shemot Rabbah</i> 2:9.</i> and “in the light of the King’s Countenance there is life,”<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 16:15.</i> and, conclusively, “strength and gladness are in His place,”<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 16:27.</i> because He is but good all the time.
Therefore, first of all, man ought to be happy and joyous at all times and truly live by his faith in the L–rd who animates him and is benignant with him every moment. But he who is grieved and laments makes himself appear as if he has it somewhat bad and (is) suffering and lacking some goodness; he is like a heretic, Heaven forfend. That is why the Kabbalists strongly rejected the trait of sadness.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 12 (cf. <i>Tanchuma</i>, <i>Yitro</i> 16; Arizal, <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, beg. <i>Ekev</i>); also, ibid., ch. 11, and <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, chs. 26 ff., 31, and 33.—With respect to the Kabbalists’ emphasis on joy and rejection of sadness, see <i>Zohar</i> II:184b and <i>Hagahot R. Chaim Vital</i>, ad loc.; <i>Zohar</i> II:218a, and the commentaries <i>Derech Emet</i>, and <i>Nitzutzei Orot</i>, ad loc.; <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 23:16, s.v. <i>Etzev VeEtzavon</i>. See also <i>Reishit Chochmah</i>, <i>Shaar HaAhavah</i>, ch. 10 (also quoting Arizal’s celebrated comment on Deuteronomy 28:47); <i>Shaarei Kedushah</i> 2:4. See further: <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Tazria</i> 20c; <i>Maamarei Admur Hazaken—5562</i>, p. 77 ff. and p. 305.</i>
The faithful, however, is not indisposed by any afflictions whatsoever, and with respect to all mundane matters “yes” and “no” are all the same to him, in a true equation.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Tzavaat Harivash</i>, beg., in comment on Psalms 16:8.</i>
But he to whom they are not the same shows of himself that he is of the <i>erev rav</i><sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">“Mixed multitude”—(Exodus 12:38), thus not of the truly faithful, the “believers, descendants of believers” (cf. also <i>Zohar</i> I:25a; 28b; <i>et passim</i>.</i> who act but for themselves and loves himself to the extent of removing himself from under the hand of the L–rd and to live the life of heathens because of his self-love; that is why he desires the “life of the flesh” and “children and sustenance”—for that is his good.
It would have been better for him had he not been created. For the purpose of man’s creation in this world is to test him by these trials, to ascertain what is in his heart:<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Deuteronomy 8:2; II Chronicles 32:31.</i> whether he will turn his heart toward the other gods, namely the passions of the body which evolve from the <i>sitra achara</i>, and desire these, or whether his desire and wish is to live the true life which evolves from the living G–d.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">In the text here follows “<i>though he is unable</i>.” A gloss inserted in the text notes the ambiguity of this phrase and states that it does not appear in some manuscripts. There is another version, which reads “<i>or whether his desire and wish—</i>though he is unable<i>—is to live the true life</i>”<i>—</i>according to which that phrase is but parenthetical.</i>
