One must believe that he really lives in it,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the “true life.”</i> and all his needs, and everything related to himself, truly evolve in all their details [not from the <i>sitra achara</i>, but] “From the L–rd by whom the steps of man are established,”<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 37:23.</i> “and there is not a word…”<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 139:4; see <i>Midrash Tehillim</i>, ad loc., and <i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 9:3.</i>; conclusively, everything is absolutely good, except that it is not apprehended.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 26.</i>
By believing this truly, everything becomes good even in appearance. For by such a faith, that one believes that the very substance of what manifestly seems to be evil is (in fact) of the Supreme Good [i.e., His wisdom, blessed be He, which is non-apprehensible and is the Eden which transcends the World to Come]; through this faith the imagined evil is truly absorbed and sublimated in the concealed Supreme Good.

Chapter 12

<b>TWELVE.</b> “And the act of <i>tzedakah</i> will effect peace, and the service of <i>tzedakah</i>—quietness and surety forever.”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 32:17.</i> The difference between “act” and “service,” and between “peace” and “quietness and surety,”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Text adds here etc., but omitted according to H. V.</i> will be understood by what our Sages, of blessed memory, said on the verse “He makes peace in His high places”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Job 25:2.</i>: “Michael is the prince of water and Gabriel is the prince of fire, yet they do not extinguish one another.”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Tanchuma</i>, <i>Vayigash</i> 6; cf. <i>Sefer Habahir</i>, par. 9 (11) (quoted in <i>Zohar</i> I:263a); <i>Zohar</i> III:225a; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 70 (132a). See also <i>Devarim Rabbah</i> 5:12.</i>
That is, Michael is the prince of <i>chesed</i>—which is called water<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:175b; etc. See above, Epistle 8, note 14.</i> because it descends from a high place to a low place,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 8, note 15.</i> i.e., the aspect of the effusion and extension of vivification from the upper to the lower worlds. The aspect of fire [the nature of which is to soar upward] is the category of <i>gevurah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:255a; ibid., 257a; <i>Tikkunei</i> <i>Zohar</i> 69 (105a).</i> of a withdrawal of the effusion of vivification [from below upward], in order not to effuse except by way of a great and immense contraction (<i>tzimtzum</i>). Now these are conflicting attributes, opposing one another, that is, when they are in a mode of separate attributes.
But the Holy One, blessed is He, makes peace between them, namely by means of a revelation, that a great illumination and an immense effusion from the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, becomes revealed in them. [For as His Name, so is He.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>En Sof</i>, Infinite.—See above, Epistle 7, note 5.</i> He is not, Heaven forfend, on the plane of a measure, but transcends exceedingly—<i>ad infinitum</i>—even the rank of <i>chabad</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Acronym for <i>chochmah</i>, <i>binah</i>, <i>daat</i>.</i> which is the source of the attributes.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, ch. 9.</i>] And thus the opposing attributes of Michael and Gabriel are absorbed in their source and root, and they become truly unified and dissolve in His light, blessed be He, which radiates to them in a manifest way.
The <i>gevurot</i>, thus, are tempered and sweetened in the <i>chasadim</i> by a mediary—the factor which harmonizes and leans toward <i>chesed</i>, i.e., the attribute of <i>rachamim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">See below, Epistle 15.</i> In the terminology of the Kabbalists<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chachmei HaEmet</i>, in the Hebrew—lit., the “sages of the truth” (i.e., of Kabbalah).</i> (this attribute) is called <i>tiferet</i>, because it is made up of the two colors white and red, which allude to <i>chesed</i> and <i>gevurah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:248b; <i>Tikkunei</i> <i>Zohar</i>, Introduction 1a (text, and the inserted gloss which appears also in <i>Zohar Chadash</i>, <i>Tikkunim</i>, 117c) and 19:39b; see also <i>Zohar Chadash</i> 34a-b and <i>Zohar</i> I:18b. <i>Pardes Rimonim</i>, 10:1 ff. Cf. <i>Sefer Habahir</i> 49 (137).</i>
The Name of <i>Havaya</i>, blessed be He, as it appears unqualified throughout the Torah, therefore, indicates the attribute of <i>tiferet</i>, as mentioned in the sacred <i>Zohar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:11a (see <i>Shaarei Orah</i> (Gikatilla), ch. 5; <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 1:10). Cf. <i>Sifrei</i>, Deuteronomy 27 (on Deuteronomy 3:24), <i>Shemot Rabbah</i> 3:6, <i>Zohar</i> III:65a: “The Name of <i>Havaya</i> always denotes <i>rachamim</i>.”</i> For here the degree of the manifestation of the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, is of an immense illumination, surpassing that of His other blessed attributes.
Now, the arousal from above [to arouse a manifestation of said great illumination and immense effusion from the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He] to bring about the said peace is effected by the arousal from below, by the act of charity and the effusion of “life, favor, kindness, and compassion”<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Liturgy, concluding benediction of the <i>Amidah</i>.</i> to him who has nothing of his own and “To revive the spirit of the humble….”<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 57:15.</i>
It is well known that our Sages, of blessed memory, said of him who busies himself with Torah <i>lishmah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">For its own sake, as a command of G–d, without any ulterior motives. See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, end of ch. 5.</i> that “he sets peace among the attendants of above and among the attendants of below.”<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 99b.</i> The “attendants of above” are the princes<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Guardian angels.</i> and attributes mentioned above. For these are the upper <i>hechalot</i><sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Shrines; realms.</i> in the world of <i>Beriah</i>, mentioned in the sacred <i>Zohar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:245a ff. (see <i>Nitzutzei Orot</i>, ad loc.).</i> The “attendants of below” are the lower <i>hechalot</i>, and especially this base world which, due to the sin of Adam, is mingled good and evil, and the evil rules over the good as it is written “While man rules in man…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 8:9; see <i>Etz Chaim</i> 49:4 (quoted in <i>Hadrat Melech</i> on <i>Zohar</i> II:95b).</i> and “Nation will overpower nation.”<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 25:23; see <i>Rashi</i>, ad loc. (<i>Pesachim</i> 42b, <i>Rashi</i>, ad loc., and cf. <i>Zohar</i> II:236a and 240a).</i>
This is empirically evident with terrestrial man who is called a microcosm,<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tanchuma</i>, <i>Pekudei</i> 3; see <i>Avot d’R. Nattan</i>, ch. 31.</i> for sometimes the good prevails, and sometimes the reverse, Heaven forfend.
Therefore there will be no peace in the world until the time of the end, when the good shall be disencumbered from the evil<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Tanchuma</i>, <i>Teitzei</i> 11 (<i>Rashi</i> on Exodus 17:16 and <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Berachot</i> 3a, s.v. <i>Veonin</i>) and <i>Zohar</i> II:67a (end of <i>Beshalach</i>).</i> to become attached to its root and source, the Source of Life, blessed is He. For then all the workers of iniquity<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">The forces of evil.</i> shall be scattered<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 92:10.</i> and the spirit of impurity shall pass from the earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Zechariah 13:2.</i> i.e., when the element of the good which sustains it shall be extracted from its midst.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">See below, Epistle 26, and cf. Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i> (s.v. <i>Shevirat Hakelim</i>).</i> 
This disencumberment (<i>birur</i>) itself will also be through a manifestation of His Divinity below, with a great illumination and immense effulgence, as it is written: “For the earth shall be full of the knowledge of the L–rd,”<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 11:9.</i> and “The glory of the L–rd shall be revealed….”<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 40:5.</i>
Now, this is as regards the future of the world, in general. But as regards terrestrial man, at every “time of finding,”<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 32:6.</i> meaning prayer,<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">See the beginning of this verse, and cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:79b.</i> or at other times designated to seclude oneself with one’s Maker, each one, commensurate to his actions, merits a reflection of this <i>birur</i> by means of engagement with Torah <i>lishmah</i>, and likewise by means of charity, as it is related:<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 10a.</i> R. Eliezer gave a coin to a poor man, and then he prayed, as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 17:45.</i> “Through <i>tzedek</i> I will behold Your Countenance”—i.e., the rank of a manifest illumination and effusion of knowledge and reason, to contemplate on the greatness of G–d, thereof to beget the intellectual awe and love, as known.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 8.</i>
And through this we extract the good for G–d, and separate the evil, as it is written: “The crucible is for silver, and the furnace for gold, and man according to his praise.”<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 27:21.</i> This means, “according to his praising G–d”<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibn Ezra</i> renders the word as “his praising of Him.” (R. Schneur Zalman uses this interpretation in several places. See <i>Torah Or</i>, <i>Beshalach</i> 65b and 111c; <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Nasso</i> 28c; <i>Siddur Im Dach</i> 30d.)</i>—with profound knowledge, to beget awe and love, that is how we disencumber the good and separate the evil, analogous to the extraction and separation of the drosses from the silver and gold in the crucible and furnace.
Now, it is well known that Israelites are by their very nature compassionate and performers of kindness.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yevamot</i> 79a. Cf. Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Kiddushin</i> 4:1; <i>Bamidbar Rabbah</i> 8:4; Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Issurei Biah</i> 9:17 and <i>Hilchot Matnot Aniyim</i> 10:2.</i> This is so because their souls issued from His attributes, blessed be He, in which <i>chesed</i> prevails over the attribute of <i>din</i>, <i>gevurah</i>, and <i>tzimtzum</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Synonymous terms; see Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>.</i> and as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 103:11.</i> “His <i>chesed</i> prevails over them who fear<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Denoting the attribute of <i>gevurah</i>.</i> Him.” The <i>neshamah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">The soul proper (see above, Epistle 5, note 53).</i> therefore, is called “daughter of the priest,”<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 22:12 ff.</i> as mentioned in the sacred <i>Zohar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:95a ff. (ibid., 101a, III:7a.—The <i>kohanim</i> (priests) are of the category of <i>chesed</i> (see <i>Zohar</i> I:256b; III:121b, and 145b).</i>
Now, the charity that issues from this aspect is referred to as “the <i>act</i> of charity,” for the term act (<i>maaseh</i>) applies to that which is already done, or which is in constant action of itself, thus, something existent and usually constant. So here, too, the trait of kindness and compassion is implanted in the souls of the whole House of Israel from aforetimes, from the time of their creation and evolution from His attributes, blessed be He, as it is written: “He breathed into his nostrils…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 2:7.</i> and “You did breathe it into me,”<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, Morning Prayers.</i> and “He who exhales….”<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 2; cf. Nachmanides on Genesis 2:7; <i>Zohar</i> III:46b; <i>Kitzurim V’Hearot</i>, p. 74.—All these quotations imply the Divine origin of the <i>neshamah</i>.</i> Furthermore, “In His goodness He renews the act of creation every day,”<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, Morning Prayers. Cf. above, Epistle 11, note 9.</i> and “They are new every morning….”<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 3:23.</i>
An idiom of <i>avodah</i> (service), however, applies only to what man does with immense toil: it is contrary to his natural inclination, but he abnegates his nature and will before the will of the Supreme One, blessed is He, as, for example, to exhaust himself in Torah and prayer “to the extent of pressing out the soul….”<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Sifrei</i>, Deuteronomy 32 (on Deuteronomy 6:5).</i> And in our case, too, as regards the commandment of charity, he gives exceedingly more than the nature of his compassion and will, and as our Sages, of blessed memory, commented<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sifrei</i>, Deuteronomy 117.</i> on the verse<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 15:10.</i> “Give, you shall give”: “even a hundred times.”<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Text adds here etc., but omitted according to H. V.</i>
And this is the meaning of “And <i>the act of charity</i> [shall be]”—i.e., even with that type of charity which is called an “act” [and not “service”], the arousal from below will elicit an arousal from above. One arouses a manifestation of the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, by way of a great illumination and immense effulgence, and peace is made in His high places and also among the attendants of below.
Though in this base world, the peace and the <i>birur</i> and separation of the evil from the good will not be manifest until the time of the end [but not during the time of the exile, as mentioned above], except in the microcosm, i.e., man, at every “time of finding”—meaning prayer, as it is written: “Through <i>tzedek</i> I will behold Your Countenance,” as mentioned above. Even so, after prayer it is possible that the evil will easily reawaken and become intermingled with the good as one walks in the darkness of this world.
But through the charity, which is in a mode of <i>avodah</i>, whereas its rank is extremely glorious and great [because one abnegates his nature and bodily will before the will of the Supreme One, blessed is He, and “subdues the <i>sitra achara</i>, and then rises the glory of the Holy One, blessed is He…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:128b.</i> and just “like the excellence of light over darkness,”<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 2:13.</i> as known<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> III:47b; see also ibid., II:187a, and <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 12.</i>], the evil can no longer reawaken so easily of itself, unless, Heaven forfend, man would arouse it and draw it upon himself.
And this is the meaning of “quietness and surety forever.” השקט (<i>quietness</i>) is of the etymon of “שוקט—(<i>he rests</i>) on his dregs,”<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 48:11 (cf. <i>Kitzurim V’Hearot</i>, p. 76 ff.).</i> meaning that the dregs are completely separated from the wine and fall completely netherward, while the wine above is wholly pure and clear. In an analogous manner it is with the <i>avodah</i> of charity: the dregs are the aspect of the mixture of evil in his soul which is gradually extricated and separated until it falls netherward to its root and source, and as it is written: “And You will cast all their sins into the depths of the sea.”<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Micah 7:19.</i>

Chapter 13

<b>THIRTEEN.</b> “How abundant is Your goodness which You have hidden for those who fear You….”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 1:20. The full verse reads: How abundant is Your good that You have hidden for those who fear You; in the presence of man, You have acted for those who take refuge in You.</i>
In the class of the “servants of the L–rd” there are two degrees and levels which, depending on the root of their souls above, are distinct in relation to the categories of the <i>right</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chesed</i>.</i> and the <i>left</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Gevurah</i>.</i>
That is, the characteristic of the <i>left</i> is the trait of contraction (<i>tzimtzum</i>) and concealment in the service of the L–rd, as it is written: “and to walk secretly…”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Micah 6:8.</i>; “in secret places cries…”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 13:17.</i>; “whoever busies himself with Torah in secret….”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Berachot</i> 5:1 (Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Talmud Torah</i> 3:12); cf. also <i>Moed Kattan</i> 16b.</i>
From this attribute derives also the aspect of contraction (<i>tzimtzum</i>) and limitation in the service of G–d; for example, with charity—to judge according to the means, “and he who expends, should not expend more than one-fifth”;<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketuvot</i> 50a (cf. above, Epistle 10, note 36).</i> and, likewise, regarding the study of Torah and the other commandments—he suffices in discharging his duty, the definite duty to which the Torah obliges him, “to appoint times….”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">See the author’s <i>Hilchot Talmud Torah</i> 3:4 ff. and 4:6; cf. <i>Tzemach Tzedek—Chidushim al Hashass</i> on <i>Peah</i> 1:1.</i> From it derives also what our Sages, of blessed memory, said<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ketuvot</i> 103b.</i>: “Cast a scare upon the pupils….”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">This last sentence appears in the text after the following one, which would render the passage rather difficult. A parenthesis inserted in the text already notes this difficulty and suggests that it might belong here (as in our translation).</i>
On the other hand, the characteristic of the <i>right</i> is the attribute of grace (<i>chesed</i>) and extension in the service of G–d by way of expansion, without any contraction and concealment whatsoever, as it is written: “And I will walk in an expanse…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 119:45.</i> without any contraction and limitation whatsoever. There is no restraint to the spirit<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Proverbs 25:28.</i> of his generosity—whether it be with respect to charity, the study of Torah, or other commandments. He does not suffice in discharging his obligation only, but to the extent of “never sufficient….”
Now, every one of Israel needs to comprise both these traits, for “there is no thing which does not have its place.”<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 4:3—Both <i>chesed</i> and <i>gevurah</i> are essential.</i>
Thus we find various matters that are of the leniencies of Bet Shammai and of the stringencies of Bet Hillel.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Eduyot</i> ch. 4; 5:1-5; <i>Oholot</i> 11:3-6.</i> This comes to teach us that Bet Shammai, the root of whose soul is of the category of the supernal <i>left</i><sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Gevurah</i>.—<i>Zohar</i> III:245a. See <i>Shaar Hagilgulim</i>, ch. 36.</i>—[that is why they always decided stringently regarding all the prohibitions of the Torah; but Bet Hillel, who were of the supernal <i>right</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chesed</i>.—See references in note 15 above.</i> would find favorable arguments to be lenient and to permit the injunctions of Bet Shammai so that these should become <i>muttarim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Permitted.</i> from their <i>issur</i><sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Prohibition.—That which is <i>assur</i> (bound) to the <i>sitra achara</i>. To be <i>muttar</i> (permitted) means to be <i>muttar</i> (released, free) from the <i>sitra achara</i>. See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 7 and below, Epistle 26.</i> and able to ascend upward. Nevertheless]—in several matters, even Bet Shammai are lenient. This is so because of the inclusiveness of their soul’s root, which compounds the <i>right</i> as well.
And, likewise, the root of Bet Hillel’s soul compounds the <i>left</i> also. For, as known of the mode and attributes of the <i>kodesh ha’elyon</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 10, note 41.</i> there is no cleavage and division there,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:70a; also ibid., 83a and 109a.</i> Heaven forfend, and all the traits compound each other. Thus, they are united one with the other,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, ch. 6.</i> as known to the students of Kabbalah.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>sefirot</i> are not truly separate and distinct from each other; they proceed from, and succeed, each other. Thus we speak of <i>chesed</i> of <i>chesed</i>, <i>gevurah</i> of <i>chesed</i>, etc.; <i>chesed</i> of <i>gevurah</i>, <i>gevurah</i> of <i>gevurah</i>, etc. Cf. Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>.</i> Thus it is written of Abraham, who is the attribute of <i>chesed</i> and love:<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 2, note 9, and see below, note 27.</i> “Now I know that you are fearful of G–d”<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 22:14.</i>—for he had donned the attribute of <i>gevurah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">See Arizal, <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Vayera</i> (on this and the preceding passage), and cf. the commentary of Nachmanides on this verse, and <i>Zohar</i> I:119b.</i> “and bound Isaac his son…and took the knife….”<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 22:10, 11.</i>
As for Scripture stating “Abraham who loved Me,”<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 41:8—distinctly relating <i>chesed</i> to Abraham; see <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 23:11, s.v. <i>Ahavah</i>.</i> and “the <i>Fright</i> of Isaac,”<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 31:42, distinctly relating <i>gevurah</i> to Isaac; see <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 23:17, s.v. <i>Pachad</i> (cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:12b, 18a, and 302b).</i> this difference and distinction is with respect to manifestation and concealment. In the attribute of Isaac, <i>fright</i> is in a state of manifestation, while <i>love</i> is hidden in a state of concealment and hiding. The opposite is with the trait of our father Abraham, peace be to him.
And this is the meaning of what King David, peace be to him, said: “How abundant is Your goodness….” That is to say that the attribute of goodness and <i>chesed</i>, which is in a state of concealment and hiding with everyone the root of whose soul is of the category of the <i>left</i>, referred to as “those that fear You”<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Bamidbar</i> 16b; <i>Mayim Rabbim 5636</i>, ch. 49: “The <i>gematria</i> (numerical value) of <i>yirah</i> (awe; fear) is equivalent to that of <i>gevurah</i>.”</i> [as is the trait of Bet Shammai], now, though this is a concealed and hidden goodness, it is nevertheless truly as abundant and immense as the attribute of <i>gedulah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">The term <i>gedulah</i> (greatness) denotes the Divine <i>chesed</i>; see <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 22 (67b); <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, ch. 4; <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Ekev</i> 17c ff.; <i>Mayim Rabbim 5636</i>, ch. 46 ff.</i> and <i>chesed</i>, which is of the <i>right</i>, and both are of the category of a manifestation that is without limit, measure, and size.    
And this is the meaning of Scripture: “How abundant is Your goodness,”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup> i.e., without limit and measure, whether it be the goodness “<i>which You have hidden for those who fear You</i>,” or that which “<i>You have wrought for those who trust in You</i>”—i.e., the hopeful who are of the category of the right,<sup>31</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> II:120b.</i> and whose kindness and goodness are also in a state of manifestation and expansion “<i>before the children of man</i>,” and by no means in a state of contraction and concealment.
(<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>The reason it says “<i>For</i> those who fear You” rather than “<i>In</i> those who fear You” is because with every soul, whatever is in a state of concealment is not vested within the body in his mind and heart. It is, rather, in a state of “encompassing from above,” and from there it radiates to his mind and heart at those times when an arousal of this aspect becomes necessary, i.e., to be aroused and to illumine his mind and heart in order to result in a real act.)
(The verse), therefore, says that whereas the “abundance of goodness of the House of Israel”<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 63:7.</i> [that which is hidden and that which is manifest] is in a state of “without limit and measure” [according to the category of their soul vested in the body], therefore “You, too, O L–rd, treat them with the attribute of Your unlimited and infinitely great <i>chesed</i> which is called <i>rav chesed</i>.”
For there are different types of <i>chesed</i>:<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 10, notes 6-9.</i> there is <i>chesed olam</i>, the corresponding opposite of which is the attribute of <i>din</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Judgment (identical with <i>gevurah</i>; see Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>).</i> Heaven forfend, which<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., <i>din</i>.</i> serves to diminish and contract His <i>chesed</i> and goodness. But the <i>chesed elyon</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Supreme <i>chesed</i>.</i> which is called <i>rav chesed</i>, does not have an attribute of <i>din</i> opposed to it [to diminish and contract the abundance of His grace from extending unlimited and infinitely]. It derives from the rank of <i>sovev kol almin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Encompassing, i.e., transcending all worlds.</i> and <i>temira dechol temirin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">The most hidden of all hidden.</i> called <i>keter elyon</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Supreme <i>keter</i>.—See <i>Zohar</i> I:147a (Toss.); also <i>Zohar</i> II:42b and III:288b; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 12a; cf. <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 5:4.</i> This, then, is the meaning of “You hide them in the covert of Your Countenance…You conceal them in a pavilion….”<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 31:21.</i>

Chapter 14

<b>FOURTEEN.</b><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">This letter appears in <i>Bonei Yerushalayim</i>, sect. 31 (repr. in <i>Igrot Kodesh Admur Hazaken</i> (Kehot, 2012), p. 167 ff.), with additional parts at the beginning and end which do not appear in our text here.</i> To arouse the ancient love and the fondness for our Holy Land,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">V. L. in <i>Bonei Yerushalayim</i>: and to renew it as aforetimes, that it….</i> that it flame as flashes of fire from the innermost of man and with a profound heart<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 64:7.</i> as if but this very day<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">V. L. in B. Y.: “as if but that very day did the L–rd begin to show us His grace and enlighten our eyes in the darkness with the light of the L–rd that radiates to the Holy Land and to those that dwell in it; and (the light) radiates and shines within our confines ever more, so that our soul be bound to (the Holy Land) with the thick ropes of a magnanimous love, and the bond becomes stronger and renewed every morning by a new light, as our Sages, of blessed memory, said on the verse ‘which I command you this day’ (Deuteronomy 6:6): ‘Every day they are to be in your eyes as truly new, as if the Torah was given but this very day.’ (<i>Pesikta Zutrata</i>, ad loc.; cf. also <i>Sifrei</i>, and <i>Rashi</i>, and <i>Tanchuma</i>, ed. Buber, <i>Yitro</i> 13.) Thus beautiful is for us the precept of strengthening and settling in the Holy Land, which is equivalent unto all the commandments, as explained in <i>Sifrei</i>, sect. <i>Re’eh</i> (80), on the verse ‘and you will dispossess them, and you will dwell in their land.’ (Deuteronomy 12:29) And “Israel will not be redeemed except through charity” (see above, Epistle 10, note 58)<i>—</i>which they perform with the L–rd and with His Holy Land to rectify the basis of the degeneracy and the blemish, (i.e.,)—“and they scorned the desirable land,” etc. (Psalms 106:24). <i>A fortiori</i>, then, it is befitting for us to uphold (this precept) with great joy and an ardent love, as if but this very day did the spirit of the L–rd begin to move us, and this very day did the L–rd set His spirit upon us….”</i> did the L–rd set His spirit upon us, a spirit of generosity, when the people volunteer to consecrate themselves for the L–rd<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Judges 3:2 and I Chronicles 29:5.</i> with a full and liberal hand, with one increase after another, from year to year, rising over the head, like unto the measure of <i>kodesh ha’elyon</i><sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Supreme <i>chochmah</i> (see above, Epistle 10, note 41).</i>—which radiates to the Holy Land and is constantly renewed and increased, as it is written: “Forever are the eyes of the L–rd your G–d upon it, from the beginning of the year to the end of the year.”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 11:12.</i>
Now, (the phrase) “<i>to the end</i>…” is apparently incomprehensible, for at the end of one year begins the second year. Thus it should have said: <i>for everlasting</i>!
However, this matter will be understood by considering the Scripture<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 3:19.</i>—“The L–rd has founded the earth with <i>chochmah</i>.” That is, the foundation of the <i>eretz</i> <i>ha’elyonah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">The “upper earth,” or “upper land,” i.e., the celestial model of the Holy Land; cf. above, Epistle 8, notes 37 and 45.</i> [i.e., the aspect <i>of memalei kol almin</i>], and of the nether (land) [i.e., the <i>eretz</i> <i>chefetz</i><sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">“Land of desire” (Malachi 3:12), cf. above, Epistle 8, note 37.</i> which truly corresponds to it and is called by its<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Of the <i>eretz ha’elyonah</i>.</i> name—<i>eretz hachayim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Land of life; see above, end of Epistle 8, and notes, ad loc.</i>] issues from the efflux and radiation from the Supreme <i>chochmah</i> which is the source of the supernal life, as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 7:12.</i> “<i>Chochmah</i> animates those who have it….”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 12:1; also 3:5.—Cf. Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, s.v. <i>Chochmah</i>.</i>
This radiation and efflux is renewed annually by a truly new light. For He, blessed be He, and His <i>chochmah</i> are one, in an absolute unity<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">See Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah</i> 2:10; <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, beg. of ch. 2.</i> and it is called the “light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed be He,” because there is no limit and no end to the quality and greatness<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">V. L. in B. Y.: the quality and increase of.</i> of the light and vitality that issues forth from Him, blessed be He, and from His <i>chochmah</i>, by way of elevation upon elevation to no end and limit, to the peak of the highest levels.
And every year there descends and radiates a new and renewed light which never yet shone, from the supreme <i>chochmah</i> to the <i>eretz ha’elyonah</i>. For the light of every year withdraws to its source on the eve of every Rosh Hashanah “When the moon is covered.”<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 8a-b.</i> Afterward, by means of the blowing of the <i>shofar</i> and of the prayers, a new, supernal light [of a yet higher rank in the sphere of the supreme <i>chochmah</i>] is elicited to radiate to the <i>eretz ha’elyonah</i> and them that dwell upon it, i.e., all the upper and lower worlds that receive their vitality from it [i.e., from the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, and<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">V. L. in B. Y.: and from His <i>chochmah</i>.</i> His <i>chochmah</i> which is vested in it, as it is written: “For with You is the source of life, in Your light we see light”<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 36:10.</i>—which refers to the light that radiates from the supreme <i>chochmah</i>, the source of life]. (<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>And as known to the students of Kabbalah, that every Rosh Hashanah there is the <i>nesirah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">V. L. in B. Y.: “<i>nesirah</i>, etc.”—<i>Nesirah</i>, of the root נסר (to saw, to plane), is the Kabbalistic term generally referring to the withdrawal of the “old light” and the egression of the “new” one. This term, abounding in (Lurianic) Kabbalistic and Chasidic literature dealing with the period of Rosh Hashanah relates to the theme of Genesis 2:21 ff. [the removal of Adam’s rib (to which the <i>Zohar</i> applies the term <i>nesirah</i>; cf. I:34b and <i>Derech Emet</i>, ad loc.; II:55a; III:19a and 44b) and the formation of Eve].</i> and it receives new, more sublime <i>mochin</i>….<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Brains, intellectual faculties, referring to <i>chochmah</i>, <i>binah</i>, and <i>daat</i>.</i>)
In a very specific way, this takes place every day. More sublime <i>mochin</i> are elicited by every morning prayer,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">See Arizal, <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, beg. of <i>Kavanat HaTefillah</i>; <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Beshalach</i> 2d; <i>Bamidbar</i> 5d.</i> and these are not the original <i>mochin</i> that withdrew after the prayer, but more sublime ones.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">V. L. in B. Y.: more sublime ones, etc.</i>
In a general way, with respect to the world as a whole during<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">V. L. in B. Y.: as regards the world of the six thousand years as a whole.</i> the six thousand years,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Of the world’s existence (<i>Sanhedrin</i> 97a).</i> this occurs every Rosh Hashanah.
And this is the meaning of the Scripture—“Forever are <i>the eyes</i> of the L–rd your G–d upon it” [for the eyes are an epithet for the efflux and radiation of the light of <i>chochmah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> II:218a; <i>Etz Chaim</i> 8:1.</i> wherefore the sages are referred to as the “eyes of the congregation”<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 15:24; <i>Shir Hashirim Rabbah</i> I, 15:2. See also Leviticus 4:13, <i>Horiyot</i> 5a, and <i>Zohar</i> III:20a. Cf. also <i>Sifrei</i>, Deuteronomy 41 and <i>Taanit</i> 24a.</i>], and “the atmosphere of the Land of Israel makes wise.”<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 158b; see <i>Zohar</i> III:245b.—I.e., it radiates <i>chochmah</i>, emanating to it from the “Eyes” of G–d.</i>
Now, this radiation and efflux, though it is continuous, nevertheless, it is not on one plane and level only since the beginning of the world. For every year there is a new, supernal light, because the light that was generated and shone on this Rosh Hashanah withdraws to its source on the eve of the following Rosh Hashanah. And this is the meaning of the Scripture “From the beginning of the year <i>to the end of the year</i>” only.
And that is why מרשית (from the beginning) is written without an <i>alef</i>, alluding to the withdrawal of the light<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Signified by the <i>alef</i> (cf. <i>Zohar</i> II:54a; 123a).</i> [which withdraws on the night of Rosh Hashanah] until after the order of the blowing of the <i>shofar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">By which the <i>alef</i>, the new sublime light, is elicited; see <i>Siddur Im Dach</i>, <i>Shaar Hateki’ot</i>, p. 244b ff.</i>—when a new, more sublime light descends, so sublime a light as has never shone yet since the beginning of the world. And it vests itself and conceals itself in the <i>eretz hachayim</i> of above and of below in order to animate all the worlds for the duration of that year.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">From the <i>eretz hachayim</i> the light effuses to all the other worlds. On the terrestrial plane it effuses from the <i>eretz hachayim</i> (the Holy Land) to all the other countries (see <i>Sifrei</i>, Deuteronomy 40, and Nachmanides on Deuteronomy 11:22; cf. <i>Taanit</i> 10a, and see also <i>Zohar</i> I:255b; II:22b and 152b; III:209a-b; <i>Zohar Chadash</i> 87d. See also <i>Shaarei Orah</i> (Gikatilla), ch. 5).</i>
However, its manifestation—from this concealment—depends on the action of those below, and on their merit and penitence during the Ten Days of Penitence, and suffice this for the initiated.

Chapter 15

<b>FIFTEEN.</b> “To understand the allegory and metaphor, the words of the wise and their riddles”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 1:6.</i>—with respect to the <i>sefirot</i>.
To make the verse “And from my flesh I shall behold G–d”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Job 19:26.—Cf. <i>Likkutei</i> <i>Torah</i>, <i>Emor</i> 31b; <i>Maamarei Admur Hazaken Haketzarim</i>, p. 264. See also <i>Pardes</i> <i>Rimonim</i> 4:6.</i> more intelligible, it is known throughout<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 12:5.</i> [in tradition from the supreme saints, may their souls rest in Eden] that it refers to understanding somewhat of His G–dliness, blessed be He, (by reflecting on) the soul which is vested in the flesh of man in accordance with the saying of our Sages, of blessed memory, on the verse “give praise, my soul…”:<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 103:1.</i> “Just as the Holy One, blessed is He…the soul also…”:<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 10a; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 13 (28a). See also <i>Midrash Tehillim</i> (ed. Buber) 103:4, 5, and notes, ad loc. Cf. <i>Shomer Emunim</i> 2:9.</i> and in accordance with the saying of the <i>Zohar</i> on the verse “He breathed into his nostrils a soul of life”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 2:7.</i>: “He who exhales, exhales from within himself.”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 12, note 48.</i> For even a soul (<i>nefesh</i>) of <i>Asiyah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">The lowest type of soul from the lowest of the cosmic realms; cf. above, Epistle 5, note 53.</i> derives from the <i>conjunctio</i> of the masculine and feminine (זיווג זו”ן)<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Kabbalistic literature abounds with allegorical anthropomorphisms and references to categories represented by symbolic terms as “masculine” (generally: the emanating, influencing aspect) and “feminine” (generally, the recipient aspect); see <i>Zohar</i> I:157b; cf. <i>Bava Batra</i> 74b; <i>Shomer Emunim</i> 1:26 ff. These terms apply generally to the <i>sefirot</i>: <i>chochmah</i> is <i>abba</i> (father), <i>binah</i> is <i>imma</i> (mother; or <i>imma ilaah</i>, superior mother), the lower <i>sefirot</i> are the “children”: <i>daat</i>, <i>tiferet</i>, or the <i>middot</i> from <i>chesed</i> to <i>yesod</i> as a whole correspond to <i>ben</i> (son) and <i>malchut</i> to <i>bat</i> (daughter; or <i>imma tataah</i>, the lower mother); see <i>Zohar</i> III:290a ff.; <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 8:17. The <i>middot (chesed</i> to <i>yesod)</i> form a configuration (<i>partzuf</i>) called <i>z’eyr anpin</i>. <i>Malchut</i> is called the configuration of <i>malchut</i>, <i>nukvah</i> (the female), or the “feminine aspect of <i>z’eyr anpin</i>.” (See Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, s.v. <i>Partzufim</i>.) When the <i>middot</i> (the masculine aspect of <i>z’eyr anpin</i>) are united with <i>malchut</i> (the feminine aspect of <i>z’eyr anpin</i>), thus forming one complete <i>partzuf</i>, this <i>zivvug</i> (<i>conjunctio</i>) results in the “birth” of the effects of the <i>sefirot</i>: the realms, levels, or creatures, emanating therefrom. Every creation or derivation from the <i>sefirot</i>, thus, presupposes a <i>conjunctio</i> of the higher levels. Because the potential creation, as it is in the upper <i>sefirot</i> <i>(chochmah</i> and <i>binah</i>), becomes realized and manifest through the lower <i>sefirot</i> (the <i>middot</i> and <i>malchut</i>); generally we speak simply of the union of the latter, in terms of <i>zivvug zu”n</i>. (See more on this subject <i>below</i>, Epistle 20, note 62.)</i> of <i>Asiyah</i> and of their <i>mochin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Their “brains”; the upper <i>sefirot</i> (<i>chochmah</i>, <i>binah</i>, <i>daat</i>) from which the lower <i>sefirot</i> proceed.</i> [which are the aspects of the <i>chaya</i> and <i>neshamah</i> of the masculine and feminine<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The second and third highest of the soul-gradations, corresponding to <i>chochmah</i> and <i>binah</i> (see <i>above</i>, Epistle 5, note 55). The <i>mochin</i> (upper <i>sefirot</i>) are the soul-forces of the <i>zu’n</i> (the lower <i>sefirot</i>).</i>]—which in turn, are the <i>achorayim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Hindersides; as opposed to <i>pnimiyut</i>, inwardness. While <i>pnimiyut</i> denotes the very essence, the innermost point, <i>achorayim</i> denotes extraneity, the point furthest removed from the essence, thus the lowest grade. (See Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>.)</i> of the <i>kelim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Vessels; as opposed to <i>atzmut</i> (essence), or <i>orot</i> (lights). <i>Atzmut</i> and <i>orot</i> refer to the infinite Divine essence, and the Divine effulgence and emanation. The <i>kelim</i>, in turn, signify the qualitatively finitized screening, contraction, and concealment (<i>tzimtzum</i>) of the Divine emanation and life-forces so that they may become vested in, and animate, the finite beings. See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, ch. 4. See also <i>Etz Chaim</i> 2:3. (Addendum, ibid.)</i> of the masculine and feminine of <i>Atzilut</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Asiyah</i>, thus, are the lowest and final rank of the sublime <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>—which are divine, etc.</i> (The latter)<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The “masculine” and the “feminine” (i.e., the <i>middot</i> and <i>malchut</i>) of <i>Atzilut</i>.</i> are truly divine, because in them radiates the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, which is vested and concealed in the <i>chochmah</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, and “He and His causations are one—in <i>Atzilut</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 3b; see below, beg. of Epistle 20 and the notes, ad loc.</i>
Thus it follows that the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, radiates in the soul (<i>neshamah</i>) of man as well, vested and concealed in the light of its <i>chochmah</i> in order to animate man.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 18 and above, Epistle 4, note 25.</i> And from (the soul) man is able to understand somewhat of the supernal <i>sefirot</i>, for they all radiate in his soul—which compounds them.
But it is necessary to state first what I heard from my master,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">R. Dov Ber, the Maggid (Preacher) of Mezeritch (disciple of and successor to the Baal Shem Tov and principal master of the author).</i> peace be to him, on the verse, “And I am dust and ashes.”<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 18:27.</i> Our father Abraham, peace be to him, said this<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">I am dust and ashes.</i> of the illumination of his soul which radiates in his body from the light of the supreme <i>chesed</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 2, note 9.</i> and that is his attribute: the attribute of magnanimous love (<i>ahavah rabbah</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 13, note 27.</i> For<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">V. L.: For therewith he loved.</i> he loved the Holy One, blessed is He, with so great and sublime a love that he became a chariot for the Holy One, blessed is He.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 47:6. This expression signifies absolute self-abnegation and submission to G–d and the Divine will (just as the chariot is totally submitted to the will of the charioteer), thereby becoming a vehicle for Divinity on earth. See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, chs. 18, 23, and 34; cf. R. Chaim Vital, <i>Shaarei Kedushah</i> 1, end of 1. See also below, Epistle 25, and notes 31 ff., ad loc.</i>
Now, one might possibly assume that the type of <i>chesed</i> and love as it is above in the supernal <i>sefirot</i> is of a similar nature to the attribute of abundant love of our father Abraham, peace be to him, though exceedingly greater and more marvelous <i>ad infinitum</i> than the (latter). [For it is known of the Supernal attributes that they are essentially without end and limit because the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, actually radiates and is vested within them, and “He and His causations are one.” As regards the soul of man, however, which is vested in matter, its attributes are finite and limited. But in any case, one might possibly assume that its attributes are of the same type as the supernal attributes.]
Therefore he said: “I am dust and ashes,” that is, just as ashes, which are the essence and substance of the burned wood. (For the wood) was composed of the four elements fire-air-water-earth, and the three elements of fire-water-air passed away and were consumed in the smoke that came about through their compound, as known. The fourth element of the wood, namely the earth which goes netherward and over which the fire has no dominion, remains in existence, and it forms the ashes.
Now the whole of the essence of the wood, its substantiality and matter, and its form in terms of length, width, and density [visible to the eye, before it was burned], was basically from its element of earth, though the fire, water, and air were contained in it. For earth is the most material of them all. It has (dimensions of) length, width, and density, which is not the case with the fire, and air, and even water, of which there is but very little in the wood. And all (the wood’s dimensions of) length, width and density, “all is of the earth, and all returns to earth”<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Ecclesiastes 3:20.</i>—i.e., the ashes that remain after the fire, water, and air have been separated from it.
Now, there is neither a quantitative nor a qualitative resemblance and proportion between the ashes and the essence of the wood [which, prior to being burned, had sizeable dimensions of length, width, and density], even though (the ashes)<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the element of earth.</i> are its very essence and substance, and of them did (the wood) come into being. Precisely so, metaphorically speaking, our father Abraham, peace be to him, said of his attribute [the attribute of grace and love radiating in him and vested in his body]: “Though it is the attribute of the love and supreme <i>chesed</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> that radiates in his soul [which was a supernal chariot], nevertheless, as (the soul) descended netherward, [by the evolution of the worlds from one level to another, by means of many contractions] in order to become vested in his body, there is no semblance and proportion between the essence of the light of the love that radiates in him and the essence of the light of the love and supreme <i>chesed</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, except of the sort of proportion and semblance as there is between the essence of the earth which became ashes, and its essence and core as it was (originally) in the “tree (that was) pleasant to the sight and good for food.”<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Genesis 2:9.</i> (But even this is only) metaphorically speaking, and, moreover, not at all comparable,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Lit.: separate by thousands of separations.</i> except that the Torah speaks in human phraseology<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 31b; <i>Sifra</i>, <i>Kedoshim</i>, <i>parshah</i> 10.</i> by way of allegory and metaphor.
Now, as regards the totality of the ten <i>sefirot</i> as they are in the soul of man, it is known to all<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">V. L.: It is known, in a general way.</i> that the attributes are generally divided into seven (emotive) attributes (<i>middot</i>),<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Generally speaking there are seven classes of <i>middot</i>: <i>chesed</i>, <i>gevurah</i>, <i>tiferet</i>, etc. More specifically, these classes subdivide into numerous details: <i>chesed</i> of <i>chesed</i>, <i>gevurah</i> of <i>chesed</i>, <i>tiferet</i> of <i>chesed</i>, etc. (Cf. above, Epistle 13, note 22.)</i> and all the detailed traits in man derive from one of these seven attributes. For they are the root of all the traits, and their generality, namely: the attribute of <i>chesed—</i>to diffuse without limit; the attribute of <i>gevurah</i>—to withhold from diffusing so much or from diffusing altogether; the attribute of <i>rachamim</i>—to pity whoever is in need of compassion. It<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rachamim</i>.</i> is the mediating attribute between <i>gevurah</i> and <i>chesed</i>, (the latter of) which seeks to diffuse to all, even where compassion is not applicable at all<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 23:8, s.v. <i>Mayim</i>, and cf. <i>Moreh Nevuchim</i> 3:53.</i> [inasmuch as he lacks nothing and is in no state of trouble whatsoever].
Because (<i>rachamim</i>) is the mediating attribute, it is called <i>tiferet</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Beauty.</i> It is, by way of analogy, like beautiful garments, that is, garments dyed<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">See H. V.</i> with many colors blended in such a way that there is beauty and embellishment.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 12, note 13.</i> To a garment dyed in one color, however, one cannot apply the term of “beauty” (<i>tiferet</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Mayim Rabbim 5636</i>, ch. 51.—<i>Chesed</i>, <i>gevurah</i>, and <i>tiferet</i> are the generality (i.e., the principal classes) of the <i>middot</i>. The other, successive attributes are branches or derivatives of these three. (Cf. Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>.)</i>
Now, afterward, as the diffusion is realized, that<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">In one version (<i>Or Hatorah</i>, <i>Bereishit</i>, vol. 1, 98b), this phrase “that is…diffusion” does not appear. See H. V.</i> is, at the time of the actual diffusion, it is necessary to deliberate how to diffuse in such a way that the recipient be able to absorb the effusion. For example, when one wishes to convey a matter of wisdom to teach it to his son, if he will tell it to him in its totality, just as it is in his own mind, the son will be unable to understand and to absorb it. Rather, one needs to arrange it in a different order and context, “every word spoken in a proper manner,”<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Proverbs 25:11.</i> gradually.
This deliberation is referred to (by the terms) <i>netzach</i> and <i>hod</i>. They<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">The attributes of <i>netzach</i> and <i>hod</i>.</i> are the kidneys that advise,<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 61a.</i> and also<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">V. L.: and they are (i.e., <i>netzach</i> and <i>hod</i>). In the <i>Zohar</i> (see next note) the passage reads: “the two kidneys and the two testicles.”</i> the two testicles that prepare the spermatozoon,<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:296a. See <i>Shaarei Orah</i> (Gikatilla), chs. 3 and 4, <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 8:24, s.v. <i>Kelayot</i>, and ibid., 11, s.v. <i>Etzah</i>; cf. <i>Mevo</i> <i>She’arim</i> 3:2:7.</i> i.e., the drop that issues from the brain.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 2.</i> That is, (they adapt) a matter of wisdom and intelligence deriving from the father’s intellect in such a way that it will not issue as it is in itself [i.e., a very subtle intellection in his brain and intellect], but that it change somewhat from the subtlety of his intelligence and become an intellection not quite so subtle, so that the son will be able to absorb it in his mind and understanding. Metaphorically speaking, it is truly as with the (seminal) drop which descends from the brain, for it is extremely tenuous, and, through the kidneys and the two testicles, it becomes truly coarse and corporeal.
<i>Netzach</i> and <i>hod</i> are also referred to as “pounders” and “grindstones,” because “they pound the <i>manah</i> for the righteous.”<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:236a (cf. <i>Chagigah</i> 12b).</i> Just as, by way of example, he who mills [<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>wheat] with grindstones crumbles the wheat into very fine parts, so, too, the father needs to taper the insight and the wisdom he wishes to convey to his son and to divide them into many parts, relating (them) to him by gradual process, with devices and knowledge.
The aspect of <i>netzach</i> also entails to prevail<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">The root of the word <i>netzach</i> means to prevail, to be enduring, victorious. See <i>Tikkunei</i> <i>Zohar</i> 13 (28b); see also <i>Zohar</i> III:223b. Cf. <i>Mayim Rabbim 5636</i>, ch. 52.</i> and stand up against anything that withholds the influence and study from his son—from within and from without; [“from within”—means to strengthen himself against the attribute of <i>gevurah</i> and <i>tzimtzum</i><sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Netzach</i> is bound to the “right side,” the side of <i>chochmah</i> and <i>chesed</i>—(<i>Tikkunei</i> <i>Zohar</i> 22 (68b); ibid., 30 (74a); see also <i>Zohar</i> III:153b)—and seeks to have “white” (<i>chesed</i>) rule over “red” (<i>gevurah</i>; to which <i>hod</i> is related); <i>Zohar</i> III:223b. Cf. <i>Mayim Rabbim</i>, ibid.</i> existent in the father himself, for it<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">The attribute of <i>gevurah</i>.</i> arouses in his will contentions against his son, saying “He is not yet fit for this”].<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">A parenthesis in the text states that according to some manuscripts there is an omission here in the text. The omission probably deals with an explanation of the function of the attribute <i>hod</i>.</i>
The aspect of <i>yesod</i> is, by way of example, the bond<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 29:11 alludes to the seven lower <i>sefirot</i> (<i>chesed</i>, or <i>gedulah</i>, to <i>malchut</i>). The allusion to the first five and the seventh of these is quite explicit. <i>Yesod</i>, the sixth, is expressed by the words כי כל בשמים ובארץ (lit.: for all that is in the heaven and in the earth). The <i>Zohar</i> quotes a <i>Targum</i> (see <i>Nitzutzei Orot</i> on <i>Zohar</i> III:257a) translating: “for it (i.e., כל, the <i>sefirah</i> of <i>yesod</i>) is united with (or unites) the heaven (<i>tiferet</i>) and the earth (<i>malchut</i>; <i>Knesset Yisrael</i>). See <i>Zohar</i> I:31a; II:116a; III:257a; <i>Tikkunei</i> <i>Zohar</i>, Introduction 9b. See also <i>Zohar</i> I:149a-b and cf. <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 23:11 and 15, <i>s.v</i>. כי כל, and סולם; <i>Mayim Rabbim</i>, ibid., ch. 54.</i> by which the father binds his intellect to the intellect of his son while teaching him with love and willingness, for he wishes his son to understand. Without this (bond), even if the son would hear the very same words from the mouth of his father [<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>as he speaks and studies to himself],<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">These words do not appear in the quotation in <i>Or Hatorah</i> (see <i>above</i>, note 38).</i> he would not understand them as well as now when his father ties his intellect to him and speaks with him face to face—with love and desire, because he desires very much that his son understand.
And the greater the desire and delight (of the father) the greater is the influence and the study, because then the son is able to absorb more and the father influences more. For through the desire and delight his (own) insight becomes greater and more abundant,<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Eliyahu Rabbah</i>, ch. 27; <i>Taanit</i> 7a (“I have learned from my disciples more than from any other”).</i> with a contented disposition<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Lit.: with an expansion of <i>daat</i>.</i> to influence and teach his son (<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>just as, metaphorically speaking, in the sphere of the truly physical, an amplification of spermatozoon derives from an abundance of desire and delight, and, thereby, he elicits much from the brain. That is why the Kabbalists drew a comparison with the physical <i>conjunctio</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">See Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, ch. 1, note 6.</i> as will be explained).
Now, these attributes are the external aspects<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>chitzoniyut</i>.</i> of the soul. In them are vested the inner attributes, i.e., the faculties of love and awe…, analogous to the father who influences his son because of his love (for the son) and withholds his influence because of his dread and fear that (his son) might come to some downfall, Heaven forfend.
The source and root of these internal and external attributes is of the <i>chabad </i><sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Acronym for the intellectual faculties: <i>chochmah</i>, <i>binah</i>, and <i>daat</i>.</i> of his soul, for corresponding to a person’s intellect are his traits. This is empirically evident, (as in the case of) a child, the <i>chabad</i> of which are in a state of pettiness (<i>katnut</i>); all its traits, too, are related to insignificant things.
With adults, too, “according to his intelligence is a man praised,”<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 12:8.</i> for corresponding to the quantity of wisdom is the quantity of his love and kindness, and also his other internal and external traits have their source from his <i>chabad</i>.
Most important is one’s <i>daat</i>, which derives from one’s <i>chochmah</i> and <i>binah</i>. This is empirically evident, for corresponding to the difference from one to the other in the opinions<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote"><i>De’ot</i> (plural of <i>daat</i>).</i> of people is the difference in their traits.
Now all this is only by way of allegory, for all this applies to the rational soul,<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">The rational soul (<i>nefesh</i> <i>hasichlit</i>) is the mediary between the natural soul (<i>nefesh</i>) and the soul proper (<i>neshamah</i>); see <i>Kitzurim V’Hearot</i>, pp. 86 ff., and the references cited there.</i> which is the lower one in man and derives from <i>kelipat nogah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Etz Chaim</i> 49:3; <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 7. (Cf. Maimonides, Intro. to Commentary on <i>Avot</i>, end of ch. 1.)—<i>Kelipat nogah</i> is the mediary between the realms of absolute evil and impurity and absolute good and holiness; see Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, s.v. <i>Kelipot</i>.</i> But in true fact,<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Lit.: In absolute truth.</i> in the higher, <i>divine</i> soul, which is a part of G–d above,<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Job 31:2; see <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, beg. ch. 2.</i> all the internal and external attributes are to G–d alone.
For because of the love of G–d and of one’s great desire to cleave to Him, “One takes delight in <i>chesed</i>”<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Micah 7:18—denoting G–d’s attribute of <i>chesed</i> which man is to imitate (see below, esp. note 68).</i> in order to cleave to His attributes, as the saying of our Sages, of blessed memory, on the verse<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 11:22.</i> “And to cleave to Him”: “cleave to His attributes.”<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Sifrei</i>, ad loc. (Deuteronomy 49); <i>Sotah</i> 14a; Maimonides, <i>Sefer Hamitzvot</i> 1:8, <i>Hilchot Deot</i> 1:6, and <i>Moreh Nevuchim</i> 1:54.—By “imitating” the Divine attributes (<i>imitatio De-i</i>), one cleaves to G–d. To practice <i>chesed</i> (kindness) is an imitation of the Divine attribute of <i>chesed</i>. Thus this practice is “to G–d alone” a service of G–d.</i>
It is likewise with the attribute of <i>gevurah</i>: to punish and chastise the wicked with the punishments of the Torah, and also to prevail over his inclination and to “sanctify himself in that which is permitted to him,”<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yevamot</i> 20a; <i>Sifrei</i>, Deuteronomy 104.</i> and to “put up a fence and a hedge for the Torah,”<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 1:1.</i> because of the dread of G–d and his fear<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. above, Epistle 13, note 29.</i> lest he might come to sin, Heaven forfend.<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">All these are modes of attitude or behavior utilizing the attribute of <i>gevurah</i> in the service of G–d.</i>
And, likewise, to glorify<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">The attribute of <i>tiferet</i> (the root of which, פאר, means to glorify, beautify).</i> G–d and His Torah by all means of glory, and to cleave to His praises with all the faculties of his soul, that is, with the contemplation of the intellect and thought even when he speaks.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">These are the modes of attitude or behavior utilizing the attribute of <i>tiferet</i> in the service of G–d.</i>
Likewise, to prevail triumphantly<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">The attribute of <i>netzach</i> (see above, note 47).</i> against anything that would restrain from the service of G–d and from cleaving to Him, and against anything that would restrain having the “glory of G–d filling all the earth,”<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 6:3.</i>just as the wars for G–d fought by King David, peace to him.<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Shaarei Orah</i> (Gikatilla), chs. 3 and 4, s.v. <i>Netzach</i>.—These are the modes of altitude or behavior utilizing the attribute of <i>netzach</i> in the service of G–d.</i>
And, likewise, to prostrate oneself and to <i>laud </i><sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">The attribute of <i>hod</i>. <i>Hod</i> is etymologically related to הודה, to laud, thank, acknowledge; see <i>Zohar</i> III:223a; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 13 (28b); <i>Shaarei Orah</i> (Gikatilla), chs. 3 and 4, s.v. <i>Hod</i>. Prostration before G–d is coupled with the expression of gratitude (see <i>Berachot</i> 34a-b; <i>Bava Kama</i> 16a; cf. <i>Shaarei Orah</i>, ad loc. cit.).—See also <i>Mayim Rabbim 5636</i>, ch. 53.</i> the L–rd who animates and makes all there is, and with Him everything is essentially nonexistent “and all that are before Him are esteemed as naught,”<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:11b.</i> truly as nothing and null. Though we cannot apprehend just how everything is truly as null before Him, nevertheless, we <i>acknowledge</i>, with a sincere admission,<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">See above, note 79.</i> that in absolute truth such is the case.
This also includes <i>to thank</i><sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid.</i> the L–rd for all the favors He has bestowed upon us, and not to be ungrateful, Heaven forfend, and this includes (further) to thank for all His praises, attributes, and workings in the emanation and creation of the upper and lower worlds, for they are praiseworthy to no end and are becoming and befitting to Him, blessed and exalted be He—which is (the sense of <i>hod</i> as) etymologically related to <i>hod vehadar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Majesty and splendor (Psalms 104:1; see <i>Shaarei Orah</i> (Gikatilla), chs. 3 and 4, <i>s.v</i>. <i>Hod</i>).<i>—Hod</i> has a connotation of majesty and splendor referring to the Divine splendor and majesty inherent in G–d’s creation. This innate splendor and beauty makes creation becoming and befitting G–d. The awareness of <i>hod</i> as the innate Divine beauty should lead to <i>hod</i> in the sense of acknowledging, praising, and thanking G–d. And these are the modes of attitude or behavior utilizing the attribute of <i>hod</i> in the service of G–d.</i>
And likewise with the attribute of <i>tzaddik yesod olam</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">The righteous is the foundation of the world (Proverbs 10:25); the attribute of <i>yesod</i>.</i> that his soul be bound up in the L–rd, the Fountainhead of life,<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Lit.: the Life of life (cf. above, Epistle 4, note 74).</i> to cleave to Him by an attachment and desire out of a wondrous love and delight.
And as for the attribute of <i>malchut</i>—to receive upon himself the yoke of His sovereignty and of His service, as the service of any servant to his master, i.e., out of awe and fear.<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Mayim Rabbim 5636</i>, ch. 55.</i>
Now, the source and root of all the attributes are of the <i>chabad</i>. That is, <i>chochmah</i> is the source of the intellect which apprehends the L–rd and His wisdom, His greatness, and His holy attributes wherewith He conducts and animates all the upper and lower worlds. <i>Binah</i> is the contemplation on this apprehension in the length, width, and depth of his understanding: “to understand one matter out of another,”<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chagigah</i> 14a; <i>Zohar</i> <i>Chadash</i> 4a. Cf. <i>Sifrei</i>, Deuteronomy 13 (on Deuteronomy 1:13; see <i>Rashi</i>, ad loc., and on Exodus 31:3).</i> and to beget from this apprehension its offsprings, i.e., the attributes of love and awe, and the other attributes born in the Divine soul which cogitates and contemplates on the greatness of the L–rd, how His greatness is unfathomable.<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 145:3.</i> There is an aspect of the greatness of the L–rd through the Divine soul’s contemplation on which a fear and dread will befall it. This (type of fear) is the <i>yirah tataah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">The “lower” or “inferior” awe. On this and the following terms see above, Epistle 6, and below, note 94.</i> an aspect of <i>malchut</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 33 (76b) f. (Cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:11b).</i>
There is another aspect of the greatness of the L–rd whereof derives the <i>yirah ilaah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">The “upper” or “superior” awe.</i> i.e., <i>yirah boshet</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">“Awed out of bashfulness”—before the infinite greatness of the L–rd (see <i>Zohar</i> III: 257a; <i>Tikkunei</i> <i>Zohar</i>, Introduction 5b, ibid., 6 (24a), 7 (24a), <i>et passim</i>). This type of awe is also called <i>yirat haromemut</i>, the awe before the majesty of G–d.</i> There is (also) an aspect whereof derives the <i>ahavah rabbah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">The “magnanimous” or “superior” love (<i>ahavah betaanugim</i>).</i> and still another aspect whereof derives the <i>ahavah zutta</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">The “small” or “inferior” love.—On the gradations of all these levels see: <i>Zohar</i> I:11b; <i>Tikkunei</i> <i>Zohar</i>, Introduction 5a ff., and 30 (73b). See also <i>Chovot</i> <i>Halevovot</i>, <i>Shaar Ahavat Hashem</i>, esp. the Intro. and ch. 2 ff.; Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah</i> 2:2 and 4:12; <i>Ikkarim</i> 3:32; <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 40 ff. (esp. ch. 43); and below, Epistle 18.</i> The same applies to the external attributes, i.e., <i>chesed</i>….
Now, with all these it is necessary that the faculty of <i>daat</i> be vested in them. For (<i>daat</i>) is the aspect of the bond of the soul which is bound and thrust into this apprehension, of apprehending some aspect of the greatness of the L–rd whereof some trait of these attributes is born in (the soul). For by a momentary removal of <i>daat</i> from this apprehension, the trait begotten thereof is also withdrawn from it, that is, from its manifestation in the soul (back) into concealment, to be there <i>in potentia</i> but not in act.
That is why the term <i>daat</i> is applied to coition,<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">E.g., Genesis 4:1, 17, 25; <i>et passim</i>.—See <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 69 (99a).</i> for it signifies a bond. Now, this is the faculty of <i>daat tachton</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">The “lower” or “inferior” <i>daat</i>. It proceeds from and succeeds <i>chochmah</i> and <i>binah</i>, channelling them to the lower <i>sefirot</i>. See note following.</i> which extends to the attributes and vests itself in them to animate and sustain them.
There is also a faculty of <i>daat</i> <i>elyon</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">The “upper” or “superior” <i>daat</i>.—In the <i>sefirot</i> scheme of <i>yosher</i>, in which the <i>sefirot</i> form three parallel triads (<i>chochmah</i>-<i>chesed</i>-<i>netzach</i>; <i>binah</i>-<i>gevurah</i>-<i>hod</i>; <i>keter</i>-<i>tiferet</i>-<i>yesod</i>; see Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, s.v. Body of the <i>Sefirot</i>), <i>daat</i> does not proceed from and succeed <i>chochmah</i> and <i>binah</i>, but <i>keter</i>. This is the faculty of <i>daat elyon</i>. <i>On</i> this level, <i>daat</i> unites the point of <i>chochmah</i> with <i>binah</i> by a radiation from <i>keter</i>. This is the essential, or original, union of these <i>sefirot</i> so that <i>chochmah</i> may be externalized in <i>binah</i>. That this union may bear offspring, i.e., that the radiation from <i>chochmah</i> and <i>binah</i> will extend into the lower <i>sefirot</i> (the <i>middot</i>) to irradiate them, this is the function or faculty of <i>daat tachton</i>. See <i>Etz Chaim</i> 8:3 f.; <i>Torah Or</i>, <i>Toldot</i> 19a ff. and <i>Mishpatim</i> 75b; <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Shir Hashirim</i> 30 ff.; Addendum, ibid., s.v. <i>Daat</i>, and Body of the <i>Sefirot</i>.</i> which is the faculty of the bond and joiner of the <i>source</i> of the intellect [which apprehends the profoundness of the apprehended notion which is a point and a flash flashing over his intellect] so that it extends downward. Thereby the profoundness of the apprehended notion will come to be understood in the expansion of the elucidation, in length and breadth, which is the faculty of <i>binah</i>, referred to as <i>rechovot hanahar</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">The widths (or expansions) of the river (<i>binah</i>); <i>Zohar</i> III:142a (on Genesis 36:37). See <i>Shaarei Orah</i> (Gikatilla), ch. 8; <i>Maamarei Admur Hazaken Haketzarim</i>, p. 266; and cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:141b.</i> as will be explained in its place.

Chapter 16

<b>SIXTEEN.</b> <i>To the members of the community of…</i>
My beloved, my brethren and friends, who are (to me) as my (own) soul. Behold, I am aware<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Lit.: the hardships of the times are not concealed from me.</i> of the hardships of these times, that the means for livelihood have declined, and especially among those known to me from your ranks whose hand has wavered; (they are) without any assistance and support, and they literally borrow in order to eat. May the L–rd show them compassion and speedily bring them respite from their straits.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Lit.: and broaden (a space) for them in the straits (cf. Psalms 4:2; 118:5).</i>
Nonetheless, they are not acting rightly unto their soul according to the reports that they close their hand which all their life long, to this very day, was open to give with a full hand and benevolence toward all essential necessities to satisfy the needs of the innocent destitutes whose eyes are lifted toward us.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Deuteronomy 15:7, 8, and Jeremiah 2:34.</i> If, Heaven forfend, we will not have mercy on them, who then will show them compassion? And it is written: “That your brother may live with you!”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 25:36. See the commentaries by Nachmanides and R. Ovadia Seforno, ad loc.</i>
(The rule that) “Your life takes precedence”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 62a, in comment on Leviticus 25:36 (“that your brother may live with you”—thus: your own life takes precedence).</i> applies only in the case when “one has a pitcher of water…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">See ibid.</i> that is, when the same thing is equally essential to both to drink in order to restore their soul from thirst. But when the poor needs bread for the mouths of babes, and wood and clothes against the cold, and the like, then all these take precedence over any fine clothes and family feasts, meat and fish, and all the delicacies of man and any members of his household. The rule that “your life takes precedence” does not apply in such a case, because all these<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The luxuries of the wealthy.</i> are not really essential to life, as are (the needs) of the poor, (to be considered) truly equal (to the needs of the poor),<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Needs, therefore, take precedence to luxuries.</i> as mentioned in <i>Nedarim</i>, folio 80.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nedarim</i> 80b. See also <i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 11:14; Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Shevi’it</i> 8:5 and <i>Nedarim</i> 11:1.</i>
