Now, (all) this is according to the strict measure of the law. In fact, however, even in the case where such reasoning does not apply, it behooves everyone not to be particular in insisting on the law, but to set aside his own life and to go far beyond the measure of the law. One should be concerned, for his own sake, with the statement of our Sages, of blessed memory, that he who is exacting in a matter “will eventually be brought to it,”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 33a; see the commentaries by Rashi and <i>Maharsha</i>, ad loc. See also <i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 11:14, and the comment. <i>Minchat Bikurim</i>, ad loc.</i> Heaven forfend.
And, after all, all of us need, at all times, the mercies of Heaven, which are (elicited) only through an arousal from below, by arousing at all times, and every moment, our compassion for those who are in need of compassion. But he who hardens his heart and suppresses his compassion [for whatever reason there may be], he causes the same above—to suppress…,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Mishnah, <i>Sotah</i> 1:7.</i> Heaven forfend.
(One should especially consider that) after all, “There is not a righteous person upon earth that does good—always—and does not sin,”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 7:20.</i> and charity atones<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Devarim Rabbah</i> 5:3 (cf. <i>Sukkah</i> 49b). See also <i>Sefer Chassidim</i>, sect. 61 and 170; <i>Netivot Olam</i>, s.v. גמ”ח, beg. of ch. 1 and ibid., s.v. <i>Tzedakah</i>, end of ch. 4. Cf. <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 3.</i> and protects against misfortune….<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Vayikra Rabbah</i> 27:1.</i> (Charity) thus is an actual cure for the body and soul,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Midrash Tehillim</i> 41:4; <i>Tanchuma</i>, <i>Mishpatim</i> 15.</i> with respect to which—“Skin for skin, and all that a man has he will give for his <i>nefesh</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Soul, or life.—Job 2:4. Cf. above, Epistle 10 (note 49).</i>
This applies especially as we are believers, the descendants of believers<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 97a.</i> (in the fact) that charity is nothing but a loan to the Holy One, blessed is He,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i>, end of 10a; see <i>Rashi</i> and <i>Chiddushei Aggadot</i> by <i>Maharal</i>, ad loc., and <i>Netivot Olam</i>, s.v. <i>Tzedakah</i>, ch. 4. See also <i>Tanchuma</i>, <i>Mishpatim</i> 15.</i> as it is written: “He who is gracious to the poor lends to the L–rd, and He will repay him his good deed”<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 19:17.</i>—manifold, in this world.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">See note following.</i> For none of the commandments is the reward given in this world except for charity, because it is beneficial to the creatures, as mentioned at the end of the first chapter of <i>Kiddushin</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kiddushin</i> 39b-40a (see <i>Rashi</i>, s.v. Rabbi Idi).</i>
Also, one should be concerned about punishment, Heaven forfend, when one’s companions are associated for the sake of a <i>mitzvah</i> and he is not associated with them, as known from the words of our Sages, of blessed memory.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chagigah</i> 9b.</i>
But it will be well with those who give heed, and upon them shall come the blessing of goodness<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Proverbs 24:25.</i>—“of the best of all things.” Do good, O L–rd, to the good and the upright,<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 125:4.</i> as is their wish and the wish of he who seeks their welfare, from the whole heart and soul.

Chapter 17

<b>SEVENTEEN.</b><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">See see <i>Igrot Kodesh Admur Hazaken</i> (Kehot, 2012), pp. 374-375, for the opening paragraph of this section.</i> It is known that an arousal from below, when man arouses in his heart the trait of kindness and compassion for all those in need of compassion, this elicits an arousal from above, i.e., an arousal of great compassion upon him from the source of compassion,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 4, note 44.</i> to effuse to him the “Fruits in this world, while the principal remains for the World to Come.”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The principal and the fruits of the good deeds.—Mishnah, <i>Peah</i> 1:1.</i>
This means: “the fruits” refers to the effluence effusing from the Source of compassion and Fountainhead of life,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., The Life of life (cf. <i>Yoma</i> 71a; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 19 (41b); ibid., 69 (115a); and see below, end of Epistle 22a).</i> blessed is He. It issues netherward, in the mode of the evolution of the worlds from above downward…, until it vests itself in this world in children, life, and sustenance….<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 11, note 5.</i>
The “principal” is, as it is written: “<i>Mitzvatecha</i> (Your commandment) is very wide.”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 119:96.</i> Now it should say <i>mitzvotecha</i>—in plural form!<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Rashi</i>, ad loc.</i> (<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>The phraseology of “is wide” is also not comprehensible.)
However, the express form of <i>mitzvatecha</i> refers to the precept of charity, which is truly the <i>mitzvah</i> of the L–rd, which the Holy One, blessed is He, Himself, in all His majesty, performs at all times by animating the worlds, and will do so in the future with exceeding uplifting and force.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Genesis 49:3.</i> And thus it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 18:19.</i> “And they shall observe the way of the L–rd, to do <i>tzedakah</i>….”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> III:113b.</i> Metaphorically speaking, like a road on which one goes from one city to another,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tzedakah</i> is called the “way of the L–rd” because it is like a roadway that enables man to travel from one place to another.</i> so, too, charity is a capacity for a manifestation and radiation of the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, which encompasses all worlds,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>or sovev</i>, or <i>or makif</i>; see above, Epistle 3, note 12.</i> so that in the future, at the Resurrection of the Dead, it will radiate, and become manifest, even to this world, through the arousal from below as an expression of charity and gratuitous kindness, [with an uplifting and force infinitely exceeding the state of manifestation of the radiation in the upper and lower Gardens of Eden]. For in the future all the souls of the <i>tzaddikim</i>, and of the <i>Tannaim</i> and the prophets that are now in the Higher Garden of Eden, at the peak of levels, will become vested in their bodies, and they will arise at the time of the resurrection to derive pleasure from the splendor of the <i>Shechinah</i>.
That is, the manifestation and the radiation as it is in the Garden of Eden is of the level of <i>memalei kol almin</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Permeating all worlds (thus the <i>or pnimi</i>); see above, Epistle 3, note 12.</i> This is a level of the evolution from one rung to another by means of immense contractions,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">This radiation of the Divine immence, the <i>or pnimi</i>, is an immensely screened derivative of the <i>or makif</i>, the radiation of the Divine transcendence. As the worlds develop from higher to lower, the <i>or pnimi</i> is contracted ever more.</i> and as the saying of our Sages, of blessed memory: “The World to Come was created by the <i>yud</i>”<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Menachot</i> 29b.—See above, Epistle 5.</i>—the sphere of the supreme <i>chochmah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Epistle 5, note 16.—The <i>yud</i>, by its very form as a simple point, indicates the immense contraction of the Divine light contained in it. The <i>or pnimi</i> thus is related to the <i>sefirah</i> of <i>chochmah</i> (cf. above, Epistle 3, note 12).</i> referred to as the upper Eden,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid., note 17.</i> and evolving and vesting itself in all the worlds, as it is written: “You have made them all with <i>chochmah</i>…”<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 104:24.</i> and “<i>chochmah</i> animates….”<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 7:12.—See Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, s.v. <i>Chochmah</i> (cf. above, beg. of Epistle 5; Epistle 11, note 10; Epistle 14, note 14).</i> In the Garden of Eden (the sphere of <i>chochmah</i>) is in a state of manifest apprehension to each according to his measure.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> I:129b; ibid., 135b (<i>Midrash Hane’elam</i>).</i> For as known, the delight of the souls in the Garden of Eden derives from the apprehension of the secrets of the Torah with which one busied oneself in this world with the revealed (parts of Torah) [as mentioned in the sacred <i>Zohar</i>, section <i>Shelach</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> III:169b; cf. ibid., 159b ff.</i> and in the Gemara<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Bava Metzia</i> 86a.</i> with reference to the occurrence with Rabbah bar Nachmeni].
The manifestation of the radiation at the time of the resurrection, however, will be from the level of <i>sovev kol almin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">“Encompassing all worlds,” thus the <i>or makif</i>; see above, Epistle 3, note 12.</i> which is not in a state of contraction (<i>tzimtzum</i>), measure, and limit, but without limit and end [as the concept of <i>sovev kol almin</i> has been explained in <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, ch. 48, not to be in its literal sense—like a circle, Heaven forfend, but only that it is not in a state of investment…, note there carefully].
And this is the meaning of what our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “And their crowns on their heads, and they take delight….”<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 17a; Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Teshuvah</i> 5:2. Cf. <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 36 (78a).</i> A crown (<i>atarah</i>) is something that encompasses and encircles and is called <i>keter </i><sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Crown; garland. Cf. <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 70 (135a) on the subtle distinction between <i>keter</i> and <i>atarah</i>.</i> [an idiom of <i>koteret</i><sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Capitol.—See <i>Etz Chaim</i> 23:2 and cf. <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 23:11, s.v. <i>Keter</i>. Cf. below, Epistle 29 (note 34, ad loc.).</i>]. It is the aspect of the intermediary which joins the radiation of the Emanator, the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, to the emanated,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Etz Chaim</i> 42:1; cf. <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 3:1 ff.—See Addendum, ibid., s.v. <i>Keter</i>.</i> and in the future it will radiate and become revealed in this world<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>or makif</i> thus is related to the <i>sefirah</i> of <i>keter</i>, transcending <i>chochmah</i> and its apprehension in Eden (cf. above, Epistle 3, note 12).</i> to all the righteous who will rise with the resurrection (<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i> “And Your people, they are all righteous…”<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 60:21.</i>).
And this is the meaning of what our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “In the future the righteous will be addressed as <i>holy</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 75b.</i> Holy is a rank of being separated;<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 7, note 7.</i> it is not subject to apprehension and knowledge, because it transcends the rank of the wisdom and knowledge which there is in the Garden of Eden.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kadosh</i>, holy, thus refers to <i>keter</i>, the <i>sefirah</i> which is separate and distinct from the <i>sefirot</i> transcending them all. (See Addendum, ibid.) <i>Chochmah</i>, in itself also distinct and inapprehensible (ibid.), is also referred to as “holy” (see above, Epistle 10, note 41). In that context <i>keter</i> is then called <i>kodesh hakedoshim</i>, the “holy of holies,” i.e., the essential, absolute holiness. See <i>Zohar</i> II:121a.</i> Thus Scripture states: “<i>Chochmah</i> shall be found from <i>ayin</i>”<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Job 28:12.</i>—i.e., (from) the rank of the supreme <i>keter</i><sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> II:42b; 121a; III:290a; and note following.</i> which, in the sacred <i>Zohar</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:end of 256b; cf. also references cited above, note 36, and above, Epistle 11, note 11.</i> is called <i>ayin</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Naught; cf. above, Epistle 13, note 40.</i> its effluence and radiation are in a state of manifestation only when [after the resurrection] the soul is vested in a pure and clear body. For “Their beginning is wedged—expressly—in their end,”<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer Yetzirah</i> 1:7.</i> and “The result of the act is first in thought…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, Hymn of <i>Lecha Dodi</i>.</i> as known.
But it is impossible to reach this level until one has been first in the Garden of Eden, to apprehend the aspect of the supreme <i>chochmah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">In the text appears here (in brackets): etc. A parenthesis suggests instead: each one.</i> according to his measure, and “the dew of Torah revives him”<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 12a; ibid., 19 (38b) (see <i>Ketuvot</i> 111b; cf. <i>Shabbat</i> 88b; <i>Chagigah</i> 12b; <i>et passim</i>).</i>—“And when you will awaken<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">At the Resurrection of the Dead.</i> it<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">The Torah, which is called <i>keter</i> (cf. <i>Avot</i> 4:13, and below, Epistle 29).</i> will speak for you…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 6:22. Enabling man to reach a level he could not attain previously; <i>Zohar</i> I:185a; and <i>Nitzutzei Orot</i>, ad loc. Set also <i>Zohar</i> I:175b; and cf. <i>Avot</i> 6:9; <i>Sotah</i> 21a; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 31 (75b-76a).</i> and suffice it for the initiated.
And this is the meaning of “<i>mitzvatecha</i> is very wide,” i.e., the precept of charity, which is a vessel and a very wide area in which the radiation from the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, is invested (<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>and as it is written: His garment is <i>tzedakah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Piyut</i> <i>Atah Hu Elokenu</i> (<i>Machzor</i>, Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur).</i>) which in the future will radiate without limit and end, because of the gratuitous kindness in the arousal from below, called “the way of the L–rd.” And that is the meaning of the phraseology “very (wide),” because it is without limit and end.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Targum</i> on Psalms 119:96; <i>Eruvin</i> 21a and <i>Rashi</i>, ad loc.</i>
But “To every <i>tichlah</i> I have seen an end”:<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Beginning of the verse (Psalms 119:96).</i> <i>tichlah</i> is an idiom of <i>kalot hanefesh</i>, the yearning of the soul in the Garden of Eden, for there it is in a mode of end, limit, and contraction, as mentioned above. And (the reason it says) “to every <i>tichlah</i>” is because there are numerous levels and rungs of <i>Gan Eden</i>, one higher than the other, to the topmost of levels,<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar Chadash</i>, <i>Bereishit</i> 18a.</i> as mentioned in <i>Likkutei Hashass</i> by the Arizal,<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 5, note 103.</i> in explanation of the saying of our Sages, of blessed memory: “Scholars (of Torah) have no rest…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 64a.</i> because they rise constantly—from level to level—in the apprehension of the Torah, which had no end…, until after the resurrection, when they will have rest….

Chapter 18

<b>EIGHTEEN.</b> It is written: “How fair and how pleasant are you, <i>ahavah</i> <i>betaanugim</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 7:7.</i>
There are two kinds of love.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:12a. See also above, Epistle 6 (notes 24 ff.) and end of Epistle 15.</i> One is <i>ahavah betaanugim</i> (love with delights), meaning that one is in a state of wondrous delight over G–d, with a great and immense joy [the joy of the soul and its yearning as it discerns that the L–rd is good<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 34:9.</i> and delightful as wondrously sweet delights]. It is truly in the mode of the World to Come where “they take delight….”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 17a; Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Teshuvah</i>, ch. 8.</i>
And of this it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 97:12.</i> “Rejoice, <i>tzaddikim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">The righteous [in the sense of saints] (see <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, for the meaning of this term, esp. chs. 1, 10, 14, 35).</i> in the L–rd,” and not everyone merits this.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">It is the love attained by the <i>tzaddikim</i> only.—See <i>Chovot Halevovot</i>, <i>Shaar Ahavat Hashem</i>, ch. 4; <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Author’s Introduction to Part II.</i> This is the rank the sacred <i>Zohar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> III:39a; ibid., 88b and 177b, in the light of <i>Zohar</i> II:25b. Cf. also <i>Zohar</i> II:57a, and see <i>Sefer Hamaamarim</i> <i>5710</i>, pp. 4 ff. and 54 ff.</i> refers to as <i>ka-hana bi’reuta</i> <i>deliba</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">(The service of) the priest is with the devotion of the heart.</i> and of which it is said:<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 18:7.</i> “A service of gift…<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., a service (<i>avodah</i>) which comes by way of a gift. See comment. of Rashi and Nachmanides, ad loc. See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 14.</i> and the stranger that comes close….”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Priesthood symbolizes the level of special proximity to and love of G–d (cf. <i>Sifrei</i>, Numbers, sect. 119), and an elevated position of sanctity (see Maharal, <i>Derech Chaim</i>, on <i>Avot</i> 4:13), thus the state of <i>ahavah rabbah</i>, or <i>ahavah betaanugim</i>, which follows as a Divine gift and reward to the <i>tzaddikim</i> that are on this level.</i> For there is no way to attain it by human efforts as (there is with) the awe (of G–d), of which it is asked “Did you labor with awe?” and “Woe to the person who did not labor with awe,” as mentioned in <i>Reishit Chochmah</i>. Of awe is also written<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 2:4; cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 42.</i>—“If you will seek it as silver…”; this shows that it requires a great and immense exertion, as when one searches for fortunes.
But this great love [<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>the <i>ahavah betaanugim</i>] comes to man by itself, from above, without him preparing and attuning himself for it; rather, only after he has exerted himself in <i>yirat haromemut</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Awe and bashfulness before the Majesty of G–d (as contrasted with the lower level of the dread of the punishment of G–d; see ref. cited above, note 2); cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:11b; Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah</i> 11:2 and 4:12; <i>Ikkarim</i> 3:32.</i> and has attained the maximum he is able to attain of that according to the level of his soul, then, of itself, the <i>ahavah betaanugim</i> comes from above to dwell and to become united with the <i>yirah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Chovot Halevovot</i>, <i>Shaar Ahavat Hashem</i>, Intro., ch. 3, and end of ch. 4.</i> For “It is the way of man to go…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The way of a man [i.e., love; according to Psalms 98:3: זכר חסדו—reading זכר (male) for זכר (remembered)] to search for a woman [i.e., fear, awe; according to Proverbs 31:30: אשה יראת ה’; cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:27a].—<i>Kiddushin</i> 2b; see next note.—Love, thus, comes where awe is to be found already. Cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:145a-b.</i> as explained in <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 43. See also <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Va’etchanan</i> 7d; <i>Siddur Im Dach</i> 188a.</i>
The second (type)<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">The inferior type: <i>ahavah zuta</i>.</i> is a love and desire that the soul desires, loves, and wishes to cleave to the L–rd, “to be bound up in the bundle of life.”<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 25:29. See <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Shelach</i> 51d (and references, ad loc.); below, Epistle 29.</i> The proximity to G–d is very dear to her, and that is what she desires.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 73:28 and Isaiah 58:2.</i> It is most grievous for her to become, Heaven forfend, removed from Him, blessed be He, by having an iron partition of the <i>chitzonim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Forces of evil. The <i>chitzonim</i>, brought about by sin, separate man from G–d; see Isaiah 59:2; <i>Zohar</i> II:116b and <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 69 (108b). Cf. <i>Sefer Habahir</i> 58 (196).</i> separating, Heaven forfend.
This love is latent in the heart of all Israel, even in the wicked ones, and from it derives their remorse.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Referring to “the wicked are full of remorse” (<i>Shevet Mussar</i>, ch. 25; cf. <i>Nedarim</i> 9b); see <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 11.</i>
Though, because it is latent and concealed, in a state of exile in the body, it is possible for the <i>kelipah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">The realm of evil (cf. below, Epistle 25, note 39).</i> to dominate over it; and that is the “spirit of folly” which causes man to sin.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Sotah</i> 3a.</i>
Therefore man’s service to his Maker needs to be in strengthening himself and to prevail over the <i>kelipah</i> by all means. That is, first to expel it completely from the body—from the (faculties of) thought, speech, and action that are in the brain,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Seat of thought.</i> tongue,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Seat of speech.</i> and the 248 organs.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Seat of action.</i> After that he will also be able to “bring out the captive from prison”<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 42:7<i>—</i>I.e., this love, from the dominion of the <i>kelipah</i>.</i> with a strong hand. That is, “his heart is strong and steadfast among the valiant,”<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Amos 2:16; cf. commentaries by R. Abraham Ibn Ezra and R. David Kimchi, ad loc.</i> so that the love will become revealed in a state of great manifestation in all the powers of the parts of the soul in his body, i.e., mainly in the mind and in the (faculty of) thought of the brain, so that corresponding to its intellect and understanding the mind will constantly think and contemplate on the Creator, Blessed be He, how He is the Fountainhead of life<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., the Life of life—(cf. above, Epistle 17, note 4).</i> in general, and of the life of his soul in particular.
Consequently, he will yearn and desire to become attached to Him, and near to Him, by an intrinsic yearning as that of a child that yearns to be constantly near his father, and as fire which by its very nature always rises upward to its source. And the more he continues to set his mind on this yearning, this yearning becomes correspondingly stronger and will extend even to his mouth and all his organs—to occupy himself with Torah and the commandments in order to truly cleave, through them, to G–d, for “the Torah and the Holy One, blessed is He, are entirely one.”<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:90b; see also ibid., 60a and <i>Kitzurim V’Hearot</i>, p. 104 f. Cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 23.</i>
Of this yearning, as it is in a state of great manifestation, it is written: “My soul thirsts…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 42:3. See <i>Hilchot Talmud Torah</i> 4:6.</i> like a person who thirsts for water, and, as yet, has no delight whatsoever.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">The thirst is so overpowering that he is unable to delight in anything.</i>
Also, of this yearning and of this love concealed in us we pray to G–d to aid us in bringing it out from imprisonment, and that the heart be full of it alone; and that its “rival-wife,” i.e., the mundane desires, do not enter its house.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Teitzei</i> 37d ff. for this homily of the “two wives” as corresponding to the divine and the natural souls.</i> Rather, (this yearning and love) be the mistress of the house, to rule over her “rival-wife” and to expel her at least from one’s thought, speech, and action. Though one cannot expel her altogether from one’s heart, she should at least be hidden, in a state of exile and servitude to the mistress of the house, her mistress to make use of her for her own essentials only, as eating and drinking, as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 3:6.</i> “In all your ways, know Him.”<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Deot</i> 3:2 ff.: “Whether engaged in commerce or in manual labor for profit, one’s heart should not be solely set on the accumulation of wealth, but he should do these things in order to obtain therewith his bodily needs…. Likewise, when he eats or drinks, his purpose should not be to secure physical gratification, etc., but solely to maintain his body in health and vigor, etc. Man should aim to maintain physical health and vigor in order that his soul may be upright, in a condition to know G–d…by all your ways know Him.”—See also the comment. by R. Levi Gersonides, and <i>Tzavaat Harivash</i>, on this verse.</i>

Chapter 19

<b>NINETEEN.</b> “He wraps (Himself with) light as (with) a garment….”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 104:2.</i> In <i>Likkutei Torah</i> by the Arizal,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 5, note 103.</i> section <i>Ki Tissa</i> and section <i>Vayikra</i>, it is stated that the apprehension of Moses our Master, peace to him, was not in the rank of <i>the pnimiyut </i><sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Inwardness, the highest and most profound levels (see Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, s.v. <i>Pnimiyut</i>).</i> of the supreme <i>chochmah</i>—which is called <i>abba </i><sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Father; i.e., the <i>partzuf</i> of <i>abba</i> (see below, note 11).</i> <i>of Atzilut</i>, and, <i>a fortiori</i>, not in the <i>sefirah</i> of <i>keter</i>, called <i>arich anpin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Macroprosopus (long or extended Countenance; see below, note 11).</i> which transcends (<i>chochmah</i>). Rather, it was in the rank of the <i>achorayim </i><sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Hinder, or extraneous sides; the lowest and most extraneous levels (see below).</i> of <i>chochmah </i><sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>partzuf</i> of <i>abba</i>.</i> which vest themselves<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Text corrected according to L. H.</i> in <i>binah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>partzuf</i> of <i>imma</i> (the supreme mother).</i> which (in turn) vests itself in the seven lower <i>sefirot</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chesed</i> to <i>malchut</i>.</i> called <i>z’eyr anpin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Microprosopus</i> (the small, or lesser Countenance).—The ten <i>sefirot</i> form a configuration (<i>partzuf</i>) analogous to the image of man (consisting of the ten general categories of the <i>sefirot</i>; 248 “organs” and 365 “sinews”). The principal, or general, <i>partzuf</i> subdivides into five configurations: 1. <i>Keter—</i>the <i>partzuf</i> of <i>arich anpin</i> (including the aspect of <i>atik yomin</i> (or <i>atika kadisha</i>), the very original emanation—see Intro., note 56); 2. <i>Chochmah—</i>the <i>partzuf</i> of <i>abba</i>; 3. <i>Binah—</i>the <i>partzuf</i> of <i>imma</i>; 4. The <i>middot (chesed</i> to <i>yesod</i>; generally referred to by the all-inclusive principle of <i>tiferet</i>)<i>—</i>the <i>partzuf</i> of <i>z’eyr anpin</i> (sometimes referred to as the masculine aspect of <i>z’eyr anpin</i>); 5. <i>Malchut—</i>the <i>partzuf</i> of <i>nukva</i> (the female; sometimes referred to as the feminine aspect of <i>z’eyr anpin</i>). Both of these <i>partzufim</i> again compounds the levels of the ten <i>sefirot</i> and the 613 aspects, though the <i>sefirah</i> by which it is called is the dominant sphere of that configuration. All five proceed from, and succeed each other, in this order as different modes of Divine manifestations. Each one has two general aspects: <i>pnimiyut</i> (analogous to the relation from soul to body), and <i>chitzoniyut</i> (analogous to the relation from body to soul).—See Addendum, ibid., s.v. <i>Partzufim</i>.</i>—the principium of the Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">The Torah as given to Moses, though originating in the supreme <i>chochmah</i>, is itself on the lower level of <i>z’eyr anpin</i>, or <i>tiferet</i>. Cf. below, Epistle 20.</i> and extends to the end of the four lowest <i>sefirot</i>: <i>netzach</i>, <i>hod</i>, <i>yesod</i>, <i>malchut</i> (<i>n.h.y.m.</i>). There the apprehension of his prophecy was in the rank of the <i>pnimiyut</i>, i.e., in the rank of the <i>pnimiyut</i> of <i>n.h.y.m</i>.
But (on the levels) beyond <i>n.h.y.m.</i> he had no apprehension in the <i>pnimiyut</i>, but only in the rank of the <i>achorayim</i> of the <i>chochmah</i> which are vested<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Text corrected according to L. H.</i> in <i>binah</i>, which (in turn) is vested and extends itself within the <i>pnimiyut</i> of <i>n.h.y.m</i>. This is the principium of “The Torah is an attenuated form<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., “withered” (see Isaiah 34:4), or “things that fall” (see comment. by <i>Maharzu</i> to <i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 17:5). A withered plant is an attenuated or weaker form of a healthy plant. Similarly, the Torah is a weaker manifestation of supreme <i>chochmah</i>, but not <i>chochmah</i> as it is itself.</i> of the supernal <i>chochmah</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 17:5; 44:17. The Midrash describes several parallels, microcosms to their original: dream to prophecy, Shabbat to the Coming World, the sun to the Light Above, and Torah to the supreme wisdom. (The latter is the Midrashic equivalent of the Zoharic statement “the Torah derives from <i>chochmah</i>”; below, note 35).</i> on the level of <i>z’eyr anpin</i>. Thus it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 33:23.</i> “You shall see <i>achoray</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">My hinderside (the aspect of <i>achorayim</i>).</i> but <i>panay</i><sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">My face (the aspect of <i>pnimiyut</i>; cf. above, Epistle 4, note 8).</i> shall not be seen”; see there, and in <i>Shaar Hanevuah</i>, ch. 1.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah</i> 1:10.</i>
Now this seems rather surprising. After all, it is said: “And there did not rise another prophet in Israel as Moses.”<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 34:10.</i> How then did the Arizal apprehend more than he and expound many themes dealing with the <i>pnimiyut</i>, even of many <i>sefirot</i> and levels that transcend <i>chochmah</i> and <i>keter</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>?
But the matter is (as follows). It is plain and clear to all that there is a great difference between the apprehension of the Kabbalists, as R. Shimon bar Yochai and the Arizal, an apprehension by wisdom and knowledge, and the prophetic apprehension of Moses our Master, peace to him, and the other prophets, to which Scripture refers as an actual vision: “You shall see <i>achoray</i>”;<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 33:23.</i> “And I saw the L–rd”;<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 6:11.</i> “And the L–rd appeared to him.”<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 18:1.</i>
Now, though this is in a metaphorical sense and does not mean actual sight by the physical eye composed of flesh, nevertheless, the subject (of a metaphor) needs to resemble the metaphor, and as the <i>Targum</i><sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">On Genesis 18:1.</i> (translates) וירא אליו ה’: “And (the L–rd) became revealed to him…, thus a mode of revelation, that G–d,<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Inserted acc. to H. V.</i> blessed is He, Who is hidden, became revealed to him in a state of manifestation. It is different, though, with the apprehension of the Kabbalists.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chachmei HaEmet</i> in the Hebrew—lit., the “sages of the truth” (i.e., of Kabbalah).</i> To them G–d<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Text reads here too: Who is hidden, but omitted acc. to L. H.</i> does not become revealed in the mode of manifestation; rather, they apprehend the secrets of wisdom, that which is hidden and concealed from them.
They<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The Sages of the Talmud.</i> therefore said:<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 12a.</i> “A wise man is better than a prophet,”<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">See Arizal, <i>Likkutei Hashass</i>, ad loc.; see also <i>Maamarei Admur Hazaken Haketzarim</i>, pp. 84 and 355.</i> because by his wisdom he can apprehend exceedingly beyond the levels that can descend netherward in a mode of revelation to the prophets in the vision of their prophecy.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. also Arizal, <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, s.v. <i>Keriah Bechochmat Hakabbalah</i>, par. 6.</i> For only the lowest ranks can descend and become revealed to them, namely <i>n.h.y.m</i>. (The ranks <i>of n.h.y.m.</i>) are the ones that always descend and become revealed from the emanator to the recipient as a faculty of <i>mochin</i> (brains) and life-force. Thus it is known to the students of Kabbalah that the <i>n.h.y.m.</i> of the higher (realm) vest themselves in the lower, in order to vivify it.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Etz Chaim</i> 8:2 and below, Epistle 20.</i> For they are the <i>kelim</i> of the effluence and of the descent of the vivification from the higher to the lower, with respect to all the worlds and levels. Hence they also become revealed to the prophets in a mode of an actual revelation. Within these is vested the light of <i>binah</i>, the aspect of the understanding of Divinity and<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">V. L.: from (instead of and).</i> the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He.
And in it are vested the <i>achorayim</i> of <i>chochmah</i>, a level transcending the conception and comprehension of Divinity, blessed is He, as the term <i>chochmah</i> denotes the source of conception and comprehension.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Thus itself beyond it.</i> That is why they said in the <i>Zohar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:121a; 85a; III:81a.</i> that “the Torah derives from <i>chochmah</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">The Torah as revealed to man only originates in supreme <i>chochmah</i>, but is not <i>chochmah</i> in itself.</i> for the reasons for the commandments were not revealed and transcend conception and comprehension.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Sanhedrin</i> 21b, <i>Beit Habechirah</i> and <i>Maharsha</i> commentaries, ad loc. (see also the latter’s comment. on <i>Pesachim</i> 119); <i>Moreh Nevuchim</i> 3:26.</i>
And even the occasional places where some apparently intelligible reason was revealed and explained, this, to our intelligible reason, is not the full and absolute reason;<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">See ref. cited above, note 37, and see <i>Berachot</i> 33b and <i>Rashi</i>, ad loc. (s.v. <i>Middotav</i>), and Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Berachot</i> 5:3.</i> rather, within it is vested the <i>pnimiyut</i> and principium of <i>chochmah</i>, transcending conception and comprehension.
It is likewise with respect to every word that was emitted from the mouth of the Holy One, blessed is He, to the prophets, as recorded in <i>Tanach</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Torah-Neviim-Ketuvim</i> (the Bible).</i> whether they be words of admonishment or tales of events. In them is vested an aspect of the Divine <i>chochmah</i> transcending conception and comprehension.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:149b; 152a; <i>Moreh Nevuchim</i> 3:50.</i> This is empirically evident from the principle of <i>kri</i> and <i>ktiv</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The textual reading of Scripture (<i>kri</i>) sometimes differs from the textual writ (<i>ktiv</i>).</i> The <i>kri</i> relates to the comprehension as revealed to us. The <i>ktiv</i> transcends conception and comprehension; that is, this word in its written form has no garment subject to comprehension, but in its oral reading form it does have a garment.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Pesachim</i> 50a and <i>Rashi</i>, ad loc.; <i>Zohar</i> III:230a.</i>
The same applies to the large letters in the <i>Tanach</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Some letters in Scripture are written larger than others. Cf. <i>Encyclopedia Talmudit</i>, vol. 1. s.v. <i>Otiyot</i>, p. 190 ff.</i> they are from a supremely sublime world and radiate from there openly, not with a garment like the other letters.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> II:132a and III:2a. See also <i>Zohar</i> I:3b and ref. cited in <i>Derech Emet</i>, ad loc.</i>
Now, the aspect of the Divine <i>chochmah</i>, blessed is He, vested in the 613 commandments of the Torah, is referred to as the category of the <i>achorayim</i> of <i>chochmah</i>. For all the <i>achorayim</i> in the <i>sefirot</i> are the external and lower levels in the gradation of that <i>sefirah</i>. That is why they can descend and extend below, to become vested in the creatures in order to vivify them. The aspect of the <i>panim</i> is the <i>sefirah</i> itself. It is united with its Emanator, the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, by an absolute union.
As, for example, the <i>sefirah</i> of <i>chochmah</i>: it is united with its Emanator, the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, in an absolute unity, for the Holy One, blessed is He, and His wisdom, are one<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah</i> 2:10; <i>Moreh Nevuchim</i> 3:20. See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 2.</i> (<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>as explained above<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">This reference (“above”) is not clear; cf. H. V., ad loc.</i>). But that which radiates and extends from His wisdom, blessed be He, below [among the limited and finite nether beings, and becomes vested in them], is called <i>achorayim</i>, and is also called the aspect of <i>Asiyah</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">The lowest realm within the world of <i>Atzilut</i>.—The four worlds (see Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>) compound not only the order of the ten <i>sefirot</i> but also the general levels denoted by the names of the worlds. Thus <i>Atzilut</i> is divisible into <i>Atzilut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, <i>Beriah</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, etc.; the same applies to the lower three realms (<i>Atzilut</i> of <i>Beriah</i>, etc.) R. Moses Cordovero illustrates this with an analogy to a silversmith who classifies his silver into four groups according to the purity of the metal: the first type is the most pure silver, free of base metals; the second type is less pure than the first; the third is about half pure and half impure; and the fourth contains more base metals than silver. Now, even the first class of silver cannot be wholly and absolutely pure. There always are some drosses that cannot be removed. Thus even this first class can be subdivided into more and less “wholly pure,” truly, into these four general categories. And the same applies also to the other three classes, one category differing from the other in the degree of purity (<i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 24:10).</i>
Metaphorically speaking, this will be understood by the analogy with terrestrial man. There are five ranks in his soul, one lower than the other. These are the faculties of the intellect, the (emotive) attributes, thought, speech, and action.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 3 ff. and Part II, ch. 8.</i> Action is the lowest of them all. For the vivification that extends from the soul and is vested in the power of action is as nothing compared to the vivification that extends from it and is vested in the power of speech. The latter (in turn) is as nothing compared to the vivification that extends from (the soul) and is vested in thought, the (emotive) attributes, and the intellect.
In a precisely like manner (with respect to) the category of His wisdom, blessed be He, that which can become extended from it to become vested<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">V. L.: to emanate.</i> in all the nether beings is<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Emended according to H. V.</i> as nothing compared to the category of the <i>panim</i>, which is united with the Emanator, blessed is He. For “All that are before Him are esteemed as naught.”<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:11b. The <i>panim</i> of <i>chochmah</i> thus is completely absorbed in the Emanator.</i> But the effluence to all limited and finite nether beings is regarded, so to speak, as a descent and contraction (<i>tzimtzum</i>) with respect to the Emanator, the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, just as, metaphorically speaking, it would be regarded as a descent and contraction for the intellect of an intelligent person to be contracted to some purely physical and material act.
Moses our Master, peace to him, who apprehended up to the <i>achorayim of chochmah</i>, therefore merited that through him was given the Torah—“an attenuated form of supernal <i>chochmah</i>,” i.e., that which sheds from it and descends netherward and becomes vested in our physical Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Etz Chaim</i>, <i>Shaar Hakelalim</i>, end of ch. 1; ibid., 32:8 and 37:1.</i> Its principal object and purpose is the upkeep of the operative and prohibitory commandments, in true actuality and performance,<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">The aspects of <i>Asiyah—</i>Action, or making.</i> in accord with the saying: “To do them this day,”<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 7:11; see <i>Eruvin</i> 22a.</i> and “Study (of Torah) is greater because it leads to performance,”<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kiddushin</i> 40b.</i> and “He who learns with the intent of not doing, it would have been better for him if his after-birth had been turned over….”<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Berachot</i> 1:2; ibid., <i>Shabbat</i> 1:2; <i>Vayikra Rabbah</i> 35:6; cf. below, Epistle 20.</i> And every person needs to become reincarnated until he has actually observed all the 613 commandments, as known from the Arizal.<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 7, note 37.</i><br>* * *
<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">This part, to the end, does not seem to be part of the preceding, though the content is somewhat related.</i>The letters that are revealed to us are in action, speech, and thought.
Pertaining to action are the forms<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Emended according to H. V.</i> of the letters as they are in the Assyrian script of the Torah scroll.
The letters pertaining to speech are engraved in the breath and voice which is divided into twenty-two parts. One differs from the other with respect to their form, i.e., the enunciation and utterance of the twenty-two letters in any language. For there is no difference between the sacred tongue and the other languages with respect to the nature of the letters’ enunciation, only as regards their combinations.
The letters pertaining to thought are [again, in any language a person may think] the words and letters of the language, which are twenty-two only.
Though, in thought there are three kinds of [the aspect of] letters. When one sees in the Torah scroll the form of the letters, they are pictured in his thought. This is referred to as the rank of “action<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Or: making (<i>Asiyah</i>).</i> of thought.” Likewise, when one hears the letters of speech, they become inscribed in his thought and he meditates upon them. This is referred to as the rank of the “speech of thought,” and as the rank of <i>Yetzirah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Formation.</i> The letters of thought only, without any meditation on the letters of speech, are referred to as the “thought of thought,” the rank of <i>Beriah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Creation.</i>
Now, the letters of actual speech come about and receive their vivification from those very same letters that are in the thought.
Though sometimes a person may speak while thinking of another matter, he can, then, speak only such words and combinations that he has already spoken (previously) and that were in his thought a great many times. Thus in those words and combinations there is left the vestige of the thought that entered into them many times.
And this is the rank of the <i>achorayim</i> and externality of the <i>n.h.y.</i> of the <i>partzuf</i> of the higher (realm), which enters into the lower one to be a faculty of <i>mochin</i> and life-force to it, as known.

Chapter 20

<b>TWENTY.</b> “He and His vivifications are one, He and His causations are one—in them”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 3b (Cf. n. 3 for full quotation).</i> (<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>that is, (in) the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">“…for in the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> (is vested) the King (the light of the <i>En Sof</i>). He (i.e., His essence) and His causations are one in them (i.e., in the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>); He and His vivifications are one in them. This is not so in the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Beriah</i>. There they are not one with their vivification, nor are they one with their causations. But the Cause of all radiates in the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, and in the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Beriah</i>; and He radiates among the ten classes of angels (i.e., the world of <i>Yetzirah</i>) and the ten heavenly constellations (i.e., the world of <i>Asiyah</i>), and does not become changed anywhere.” (<i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, ad loc. cit.)</i> “His vivifications”—these are the lights [<i>orot</i>],<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the infinite Divine effusions and emanations.</i> and “His causations”—these are the vessels [<i>kelim</i>].<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The qualitatively (but not quantitatively) finite vessels that “contain” the <i>orot</i>. See above, Epistle 15, note 13.—Elsewhere it is said that “His vivifications” (חיוהי, in Hebrew) refers to the first three <i>sefirot</i> (<i>chabad</i>) in their totality (i.e., <i>orot</i> and <i>kelim</i>), while “His causations” (גרמוהי, in Hebrew) refers to the seven lower <i>sefirot</i> in totality; see <i>Kitzurim V’Hearot</i>, p. 105, and ref. cited there, and see <i>Mayim Rabbim 5636</i>, chs. 32 and 151.</i> They are all Divinity. But this is not so in <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>, etc.). Now, it needs to be understood well how the <i>En Sof</i> is One with His causations, i.e., the <i>kelim</i>. For the <i>kelim</i> are in a mode of limitation and finitude, as mentioned in <i>Etz Chaim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Etz Chaim</i> 2:3, <i>et passim</i>.</i>
However, the intention is to say that they are Divinity with respect to creating something out of nothing (<i>yesh meayin</i>), just like the <i>En Sof</i>, and not merely by way of an evolution from cause to effect.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., they are not simply some cause from which beings evolve of themselves (in a causal process). The <i>kelim</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, though qualitatively finite, are a rank in Divinity which can be described as creative Divinity in the literal sense of the term.</i>
As for the statement of R. Moses Cordovero<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 6, esp. ch. 6 ff. See <i>Maamarei Admur Hazaken Haketzarim</i>, p. 516.</i> that the (creative) development is by way of cause and effect [and it is so stated in the sacred <i>Zohar</i>, section <i>Bereishit</i><sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:19b-20a.</i>], this refers to the evolution of the <i>sefirot</i> within the <i>sefirot</i> themselves<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., each <i>sefirah</i> is comprised of the grades of all the <i>sefirot</i> (<i>chochmah</i> of <i>chochmah</i>; <i>binah</i> of <i>chochmah</i>; etc.). Cf. above, Epistle 13, note 22.</i> (<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>with respect to the <i>kelim</i>). [Thus in <i>Sefer Yetzirah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer</i> <i>Yetzirah</i> 1:2-9, 14.</i> (the <i>sefirot</i>) are called “<i>bli-mah</i>” (without anything), because they are not in the category of a substance and apprehensible nature,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 1:1; <i>Shomer Emunim</i> 1:61.</i> just like the <i>En Sof</i> “Whom thought cannot grasp at all,”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 17a.</i> and as it is written: “And My Face shall not be seen.”<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 33:23.</i> As for the prophecy and apprehension of Moses our Master, peace to him, it was of the upper rank of <i>netzach</i> of <i>z’eyr anpin</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 19.</i>] And in the evolution the effect is encompassed by the cause, in relation to which it is essentially nonexistent, just as a ray of the sun is (absorbed) in the sun, as stated in <i>Pardes</i> by R. Moses Cordovero.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 6: end of ch. 6; see also ibid., beg. of ch. 3.</i>
Thus even numerous contractions will not avail to there being matter as dense as earth, by way of an evolution from the spirituality of the separate intelligences,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Or: abstract intelligences. This is a common term in philosophical works referring to the supernal creatures or creations, devoid of any material content. They are pure spirit and, therefore, distinguishable (or separated) from one another only by their differing degrees of intellectual apprehension. (Cf. <i>Moreh Nevuchim</i> 1:49; <i>Ikkarim</i> 2:12.)—Cf. below, notes 19 and 33.</i> (not) even (that) of the angels,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., not even the most subtle and formal matter composing the bodies of the angels could have evolved from the spirit of the abstract intelligences. According to R. Schneur Zalman, and the Kabbalists in general, the angels, too, are composed of body and soul, matter and form; see below, note 33.</i> except to there being the spirit of animal from the “face of the ox,”<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">See Ezekiel 1:10. This is the most sublime spiritual aspect, or archetype, which on the manifest level of the material world reflects itself in the form of animal-hood.</i> as explained elsewhere; see there.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> III:240b ff.; cf. Arizal, <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Vayikra</i>.</i> The coming about of substantiality <i>ex nihilo</i> (<i>yesh meayin</i>) is in Hebrew<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., the sacred tongue.</i> called “<i>Beriah</i>” (creation).<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar Chadash</i>, <i>Bereishit</i> 17b; Maimonides, <i>Moreh Nevuchim</i> 3:10; Nachmanides on Genesis 1:1; cf. <i>Sefer Habahir</i> 10 (13) [<i>Zohar</i> I:263a]. 
The word <i>Beriah</i> thus denotes an actual creation <i>ex nihilo</i>.</i> (Such) created substance, in fact, is also esteemed as naught before Him;<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:11b.</i> that is, it is essentially nonexistent in relation to the force and light that effulges in it from the <i>kelim</i> of the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i> [in which the gleam (<i>kav</i>) of the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">According to the doctrine of <i>tzimtzum</i> (see Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>) the “void” or primordial space, in which the worlds are created, is illuminated by a <i>kav</i> (gleam, or ray) of the light of the <i>En Sof</i>. This <i>kav</i> is the essence of the <i>sefirot</i> and vivifies everything within the primordial space.</i> radiates], and just as the ray of the sun in the sun, as explained in <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Chapter 3.</i> However, this is so only “before Him,” relating to His knowledge, blessed be He, from above netherward.
But in relation to the knowledge from below upward, created substance is [in such knowledge and apprehension from below] an altogether separate thing. For the force that effuses in it is not apprehended at all. Also, there is no approximation whatsoever from the one to the other, neither to the whole nor to part of the relation between the effect and cause. For the effect knows and has some apprehension of its cause and becomes nullified in relation to it through this knowledge and apprehension. Even with respect to their nature and essence, there is not such a great distinction (between cause and effect) except that one is a cause and the other is an effect, but nothing whatsoever of the distinction there is between the nature of a created substance and the nature of the force and light that effuses in it to make it <i>ex nihilo</i> into substantiality. That is why (creation) is called precisely <i>yesh meayin</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Substantiality out of nothingness. From the viewpoint of creation, these are two absolutely distinct and nonrelated categories.</i>
Now, the <i>kelim</i> of the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>, and also the <i>orot</i> [<i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i><sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nefesh</i>-<i>ruach</i>-<i>neshamah</i> are the three general categories of the soul, the animating life-force of man, and the worlds as a whole (cf. above, Epistle 5, note 53). Thus they are called <i>orot</i>.</i>] are the first stage and the beginning of created substantiality (<i>yesh</i>). They are created from the category of the <i>neshamah</i> of the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>, which is Divinity.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The five soul-categories (see above, Epistle 5, note 52), correspond to the five worlds (see Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, s.v. Worlds): <i>Adam Kadmon</i> contains all five categories, and the highest, <i>yechidah</i>, is manifest and determinative here. In <i>Atzilut</i>, <i>yechidah</i> is submerged and concealed in the lower four ranks. Thus only the four lower categories are manifest there, with the highest among these, <i>chaya</i>, determinative. (At the same time, <i>Atzilut</i>, like all the worlds, is again divisible into these five soul-categories; cf. above, Epistle 19, note 48.) In <i>Beriah</i> only the three lower categories are manifest, with <i>neshamah</i> determinative, and so forth. While in <i>Atzilut</i> the <i>orot</i> and <i>kelim</i> are still noncorporeal and, indeed, Divine, from <i>Beriah</i> downward, the <i>kelim</i> take on corporeality, but, of course, not the <i>orot</i> (the Divine effusions of a life-force). As one world serves as the conduit for the <i>orot</i> to the lower world(s), so the <i>nefesh</i>-<i>ruach</i> (of <i>Yetzirah</i> and <i>Asiyah</i>, respectively) emanate from the <i>neshamah</i> (of <i>Beriah</i>). But below <i>neshamah</i> (of <i>Beriah</i>), the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, is no longer manifest, but concealed. (See <i>Mevo</i> <i>She’arim</i> 6:2, <i>drush</i> 1 and 2).</i> And these are the thirty <i>kelim</i> of <i>malchut of Atzilut</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">The transitionary evolution from one world to the next, the lower one, is always through the lowest stage (<i>malchut</i>) of the higher, which becomes the highest stage (<i>atik</i>, or <i>keter</i>) of the lower world (see below, note 46). Thus, implicit in <i>malchut of Atzilut</i> are the <i>kelim</i> which are the conduits for the vivification from <i>Atzilut</i> to <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>. Generally speaking there are three types of <i>kelim</i>, each consisting of ten: the ten <i>pnimiyim</i> (the innermost <i>kelim</i> of <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>) become the soul for <i>Beriah</i>; the ten intermediary <i>kelim</i> become the soul for <i>Yetzirah</i>; and the ten <i>chitzoniyim</i> (the most outward <i>kelim</i> of <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>) become the soul for <i>Asiyah</i>. See <i>Etz Chaim</i> 30:2 and 44:2; <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Derushim L’Yom Kippur</i> 70c.</i> It is likewise in <i>Atzilut</i>. From the <i>chitzoniyut</i> of the <i>kelim</i> of the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> [which are Divinity] were created the <i>hechalot</i><sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Shrines; realms.</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> in which the category of the <i>iggulim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Circles.—The <i>sefirot</i>, as they emanate, follow an ordered pattern of gradual evolution, but not a singular scheme only. In the writings of the Arizal, where their evolution is intricately interwoven with the doctrine of <i>tzimtzum</i>, they are explained to egress via the <i>kav</i> which irradiates the primordial space of the <i>tzimtzum</i>, first as circles (within, throughout, and parallel to the circle of the void), one circle within the other, connected only by the <i>kav</i> (which is also their connection with the <i>En Sof</i>). These circles are called the <i>iggulim</i>. This is the scheme in which the <i>sefirot</i> proceed from, and succeed, each other. The <i>iggulim</i> are paired with the subsequent, superior scheme, called <i>yosher</i> (the scheme usually referred to in the <i>Zohar</i>, etc.). <i>Yosher</i> (straightness; evenness) is the emanation of the <i>sefirot</i> in the form of a <i>partzuf</i> (“<i>chesed</i> the right arm; <i>gevurah</i> the left arm,” etc.; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Intro. 17a), along the <i>kav</i>, and culminating in the center of the primordial space. (See <i>Etz Chaim</i> 1:2 ff.; <i>Shaar Hahakdamot</i>, <i>hakdamah</i> 4 ff.) See Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, s.v. Body of the <i>Sefirot</i>, and <i>Partzufim</i>.</i> of the ten <i>sefirot</i> vests itself, and also the bodies of the angels of <i>Atzilut</i><sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">R. Schneur Zalman, on the authority of R. Moses Nachmanides (cf. <i>Shaar HaGemul</i>, in comment on Psalms 104:4), states that the angels are composed of body and soul, matter and form. (See <i>Torah Or</i>, <i>Bereishit</i> 4b; <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Berachah</i> 98a; <i>Siddur Im Dach</i>, <i>Shaar Hachanukah</i> 273d.) The angelic body and matter are explained to consist of the root-elements of fire and air, thus extremely subtle and diaphanous and in no way comparable to the cruder forms of matter as we know it. (Cf. <i>Moreh Nevuchim</i> 2:26, and see below, the quotation from <i>Sefer Hanikud</i>.)<br>This view, opposed to that of Maimonides (see <i>Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah</i> 2:3 ff.; <i>Moreh Nevuchim</i> 1:49), finds support in the philosophy of R. Salomon ibn Gabirol (see his <i>Mekor Chaim</i>, esp. part 4; cf. <i>Abarbanel</i> on II Kings 3:3); probably in the thought of R. Judah Halevi (see <i>Kuzari</i> 4:3 and the lengthy remarks by <i>Kol Yehudah</i>, ad loc.; see also <i>Kol Yehudah</i> on <i>Kuzari</i> 3:11); <i>Ibn Ezra</i>; with R. Shem Tov ibn Shem Tov (<i>Sefer Haemunot</i> 4:1 ff., quoted partly in <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 6:6); and generally with the Kabbalists—see <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 24:11 ff., 15, and <i>Etz</i> <i>Chaim</i> 50: end of ch. 8. (See also <i>Zohar</i> III:225a, and cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:136b.) See also <i>Chovot Halevavot</i> 1:6; <i>Hassagot</i> on <i>Hilchot Teshuvah</i> 8:2; <i>Shaloh</i>, <i>Assarah Maamorot</i>, ch. 2.<br>From R. Schneur Zalman it would appear that (like Ibn Gabirol) he is of the opinion that all angels are composed thus, inasmuch as he mentions in that category even the angels of <i>Atzilut</i>. From the <i>Zohar</i>, Nachmanides, and the Arizal, it would seem that they are of the opinion that not all angels have bodies.<br>In <i>Zohar Chadash</i> 8d, the term separate intelligences (see above, note 18) is used in relation to angels, and as appears from the context, to angels of <i>Beriah</i> (though cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:225a). Nachmanides, too, makes frequent use of this term, and sometimes adds “the separate intelligences, i.e., the angels,”—see his commentary on Exodus 20:3 (cf. also ibid. Numbers 22:23); furthermore, in <i>Shaar HaGemul</i> (ad loc. cit.), he speaks of the angels that are “beneath the Divine throne” (thus beneath <i>Beriah</i>!). The Arizal, who, in <i>Etz Chaim</i> 50:8, speaks explicitly of the composite nature of the angels, states elsewhere (ibid., 26: end of ch. 1) equally explicitly that “there are angels which are not on a rank of corporeality, for they do not become vested in a body, they are a chariot (!) for the Holy One, blessed is He, and superior to the <i>neshamah</i>.”<br>According to the <i>Zohar</i> (cf. I:34a; <i>Zohar Chadash</i> 10a), Nachmanides, and the Arizal, there are, thus, two general types of angels (a distinction which can be found in Maimonides too, cf. <i>Moreh Nevuchim</i> 2:6; cf. also <i>Kuzari</i> 4:3, and comment., ad loc.), the higher one of which is referred to as “abstract intellects.”<br>On the other hand, R. Joseph Gikatilla writes that “even among the supernal abstract intelligences that are called angels, there is not one that is simple without any plurality. Though the philosophers called the angels abstract intellects and abstract forms, nevertheless, though they are devoid of such matter as our matter, they also possess a simple, diaphanous supernal form of matter which is incomparable to our matter” (<i>Sefer Hanikud</i> 3:3; quoted in <i>Torah Shelemah</i>, vol. 16, pp. 301 ff.). R. Schneur Zalman also uses the term “separate intelligences” and accepts the standard definition thereof as given by Maimonides (see <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Shelach</i> 46a), but he applies it to the supernal worlds; see ibid., 45a (cf. Maim., <i>Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah</i> 3:9, and <i>Moreh Nevuchim</i> 2:5). See further on this subject: <i>Sefer Yetzirah</i> 1:12 and the comment., ad loc.; <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 39 ff.; <i>Biurei Hazohar</i>, <i>Beshalach</i> 40b-c; <i>Maamarei Admur Hazaken—Inyanim</i>, vol. 1, pp. 224-227; <i>Igrot Kodesh</i> by the Lubavitcher Rebbe, vol. 3, p. 463; et al.</i>—which are a form of substantiality (<i>yesh</i>) [as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Job 4:18.</i> “And His angels He charges with deficiency”<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Moreh Nevuchim</i> 3, end of ch. 13, on this verse (though, unlike Maimonides, R. Schneur Zalman retains the literal sense of “angels”).</i>—because they are not wholly in a state of nullification as the effect is in relation to its cause].
But the souls of the angels that emerged by the <i>zivvug neshikin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>conjunctio</i> in a mode of kissing. This most sublime, and highest, form of a union, also called the <i>conjunctio</i> in a mode of <i>panim to panim</i>, refers to the <i>conjunctio</i> and most absolute union of the essence of the <i>partzuf</i> of <i>abba</i> with the essence of the <i>partzuf</i> of <i>imma</i>.<i>—</i>See <i>Etz Chaim</i> 15:1; 39:4 and 9.</i> and also the souls<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Text corrected according to L. H.</i> of man that emerged by the <i>zivvug zu’n</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>conjunctio</i> of the masculine and the feminine. This refers to the union of the <i>partzuf</i> of <i>z’eyr anpin</i> and the <i>partzuf</i> of <i>malchut</i>. (See Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>; and above, Epistle 15, note 9.)</i> they, prior to their descending to <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>, are not a level of substantiality (<i>yesh</i>) and a distinct entity on its own. On the contrary, they are of the category of Divinity in immense contraction. They are like the <i>kelim</i> of the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, which are in a category of limitation on account of the contraction of the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, i.e., the <i>kav</i> is vested in their <i>nefesh-ruach-neshamah</i>, and just like the original <i>tzimtzum</i> to bring about a void, and so on.
(<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>And even after the <i>nefesh-ruach-neshamah</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> descended to this world to the erstwhile <i>tzaddikim</i>, their essence possibly did not change to become an entity distinct from Divinity. That is why they withdrew when they wanted to sin, before they sinned.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">The souls withdrew, i.e., the <i>tzaddikim</i> died before they could sin. Cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:36b; II:10b; <i>Zohar</i> <i>Chadash</i> 19d ff.; <i>Kohelet Rabbah</i> 7:32, <i>Rashi</i> on Genesis 5:24, and Job 4:18.</i> It is feasible to assume that also the thousands and myriads of worlds that are in the <i>gulgalta</i> [skull] of <i>arich anpin</i> and <i>z’eyr anpin </i><sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> III:128b.—<i>Gulgalta</i>, the Skull, refers to the topmost level, the <i>sefirah</i> of <i>keter</i>. The passage thus refers to the levels of <i>keter</i> of <i>arich anpin</i> and <i>keter</i> of <i>z’eyr anpin</i>.</i> are not really worlds, like the <i>hechalot</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, and a category of substantiality, but are like the souls of the angels that emerged from the <i>zivvug neshikin</i> and are called worlds in relation to the rank of the “skull” and the “beard.”<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Skull and Beard of the supernal <i>partzuf</i> (see <i>Zohar</i> III:128b and 130 ff.). The Divine light emanates by way of the thirteen general “tufts” (corresponding to the thirteen attributes of the Divine compassion, Exodus 34:6, 7; cf. below, Epistle 28, notes 33 ff.) of the <i>dikna</i> (the Beard).</i>)
They are not, however, truly Divinity—able to create something <i>ex nihilo</i>, because they already emerged and became separated from the <i>kelim</i> of the ten <i>sefirot</i>, wherein the <i>kav</i> of the light of the <i>En Sof</i> is vested.
For the light is like its source,<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., the sort of luminary (<i>maor</i>).</i> i.e., the nature and essence of the Emanator, blessed is He, whose Being is of His essence, and He is not, Heaven forfend, caused by some other cause preceding Himself. He alone, therefore, has it in His power and ability to create something out of an absolute naught and nothingness, without this “something” having any other cause preceding it.
In order that this <i>yesh</i>, created by the power of the <i>En Sof</i>, should have a limit and measure, the light of the <i>En Sof</i> was vested in the <i>kelim</i> of the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> and becomes united in them in so absolute a unity that “He and His causations are one” to create with and through them [especially through their investment in <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>] creatures that have limitation and finitude.
However, it is known that the principal coming to be of the <i>yesh</i> and the totally distinct entity is through <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 8, note 44.</i> which becomes the <i>atik</i><sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">The highest level, also referred to as <i>keter</i>.</i> of <i>Beriah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">The lowest level of the higher realm comprises the highest level of the succeeding, lower realm; see <i>Etz Chaim</i> 3:1, <i>et passim</i> (cf. <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 11b). Cf. above, Epistle 17, note 28, and below.</i> for “there is no king without a people….”<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:271b; see <i>Pirkei d’R. Eliezer</i>, ch. 3; and cf. <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Berachot</i> 40b, s.v. <i>Amar Abbaye</i>.—Only where the king has subjects can one speak of kinghood in any real and meaningful way. Thus by the causations of <i>malchut</i>, the attribute of <i>malchut</i> realizes itself and comes in its own right; cf. Addendum, ibid.</i> The multitude of creatures, and their division, that were created by the force of the One and absolutely Unique<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., absolutely unified (as opposed to composite).</i> <i>En Sof</i>, it, too, is from the multitude of letters that issue from <i>malchut</i>—“the mouth of the L–rd” and “All their hosts by the breath of His mouth.”<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 33:6—The “Mouth of the L–rd,” the “Breath of His Mouth,” etc., through which the universe came into being, all signify <i>malchut</i> —“the architect of creation.” The issues from the mouth or the breath, i.e., the multitude of articulated letters, thus correspond to the emanations that issue into manifest being through <i>malchut</i>. (Cf. Addendum, ibid.; and above, Epistle 5, note 22.)</i> The five organs of speech<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 5, note 23.</i> are of the five <i>gevurot</i><sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">The five <i>gevurah</i> aspects limit, withhold, and differentiate the effusive outflowing. The organs of articulation, too, limit and make distinctions in the pristine breath of speech. This allows meaningful speech rather than the nonintelligible outflow of letters of speech as they are in their totality in the basic “matter” or breath of speech. —Cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, ch. 3; above, Epistle 5, note 115.</i> of <i>nukva</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">The feminine aspect, i.e., <i>malchut</i>.<i>—</i>See <i>Etz Chaim</i> 5:3.</i>
Thus (<i>malchut</i>) is called <i>alma deitgalya</i> (the manifest world), because through it is manifested the power of the light of the <i>En Sof</i> to create something out of nothing—without recourse to cause and effect.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 52; above, Epistle 5, note 22.</i> The first nine <i>sefirot</i>, however, emanated by a causal evolution, while the light of the <i>En Sof</i> is vested in <i>chochmah</i> only. And that is the meaning of “their beginning<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Of the <i>sefirot</i> and all spheres.</i> is wedged in their end.”<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer Yetzirah</i> 1:7.</i> For <i>keter</i> is the mediator between the Emanator and the emanated,<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 17, note 28, note 28.</i> and the lowest level of the <i>En Sof</i> is contained in it.
That is why (<i>keter</i>) is called <i>keter malchut</i> (crown of sovereignty),<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 17a.</i> for a crown is but for a king, and, also, the lowest level of the <i>En Sof</i> is the <i>malchut</i> of <i>En Sof</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Keter</i> thus has two aspects: that of <i>keter</i>, the Royal Crown, symbolizing the highest level of the lower realm; and that of <i>malchut</i>, the lowest level of the superior realm.</i> Consequently, from below upward,<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">From below <i>Atzilut</i>, toward <i>Atzilut</i>.</i> <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, too, is called <i>keter</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Keter</i> of <i>Beriah</i>.</i> and especially since through it is the creation of the souls which are <i>yesh</i>, separate entities [in the world of <i>Beriah</i>]. This<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">The creation of the souls in <i>Beriah</i> by <i>malchut of Atzilut</i>.</i> is referred to as <i>leidah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Before proceeding with this intricate passage, an explanation of the relevant terms and concepts is in place. It has been pointed out (above, Epistle 15, note 9) that the Kabbalah makes extensive use of anthropomorphic metaphors and analogies, using terms that describe physical objects or processes to denote spiritual ones. Such is the case in this passage as well. On the terrestrial level there are various terms and concepts related to birth. There are the categories of the <i>male</i> and the <i>female</i>, the former influencing, or emanating, to the latter. The female is impregnated by the male. A seed of the male is implanted in the <i>womb</i> of the female. This seed originates in the <i>brain</i> of the male; originally it is a most subtle, nearly spiritual substance, but as it descends to the point of actual egression it becomes ever more <i>material</i>. When the seed is implanted, <i>conception</i> takes place, and an embryo develops. During the ensuing period of <i>pregnancy</i>, the embryo grows and develops into a foetus, nourished and sustained by the mother’s nourishment and sustenance. This development continues until the moment when the foetus is ready for <i>birth</i>. With the birth of the foetus, we have the actual revelation and egression into manifest reality of the hitherto concealed foetus. Moreover, birth means the actual revelation and egression into manifest reality of the rudimentary plant contained in the seed.
