One thing more: the perfect health of both parents, the perfect condition of their reproductive organs, is not yet an assurance that conception and reproduction will actually take place. Procreation is dependent on <i>Divine intervention</i>. G–d is, as it were, a partner with the parents, and it is the Divine blessing or “participation” which makes possible the birth of the child. (See <i>Kiddushin</i> 30b; <i>Niddah</i> 31a; <i>Zohar</i> III:291b.) Analogous to the process culminating in actual birth is the coming into being of spiritual categories such as the soul. The essence of the soul is its own “soul,” the spark of Divinity, the light of the <i>En Sof</i>. This Divine “point” is posited first in <i>keter</i> and then in <i>chochmah</i>. It is the highest level of <i>chochmah</i>; the <i>mochin</i>, the brain. As <i>chochmah</i>, the configuration of <i>abba</i>, unites with <i>binah</i>, the configuration of the supreme <i>imma</i>, the seminal point of <i>En Sof</i> is posited in the “womb” of <i>binah</i> (“the dot in the palace”; cf. above, Epistle 5, note 15), where it develops by way of expansion. In <i>binah</i> it is vested with wider dimensions which simultaneously make it more “tangible” by dimming the full force of its radiation. From this <i>conjunctio</i> of <i>abba</i> and <i>imma</i> is born the configuration of <i>z’eyr anpin</i>, the <i>middot</i> of <i>chesed</i> to <i>yesod</i>. This progeny, as it is in <i>Atzilut</i>, is still absolute Divinity: <i>En Sof</i>, immensely screened and contracted, on a plane of creativity. The original seminal spark of <i>En Sof</i>, which on this plane is successively more contracted than it is on the higher planes, is then “posited” in the configuration of <i>malchut</i>, the lower <i>imma</i>. The <i>conjunctio</i> of <i>z’eyr anpin</i> and <i>malchut</i> thus leads to a new conception in the “womb” of the lower <i>imma</i>. All the creative potentialities of the higher <i>sefirot</i>, the “rudimentary plant of the seed,” the <i>alma deitkasya</i> (concealed world), are now posited in <i>malchut</i> where they develop in the process of “pregnancy” from their total concealment to the point of their manifestation or “birth.” That is why <i>malchut</i> is called the “sea into which all the rivers (the <i>sefirot</i>) stream and pour their potentialities.” In <i>malchut</i> all the possible creations are still hidden and concealed, just as the waters of the sea cover and conceal all the creatures of the sea. Within the womb of <i>malchut</i>, during the period of pregnancy, the potential creatures are “nourished and sustained” by the nourishment and sustenance of <i>malchut</i> itself, viz., the lights and emanations of the higher <i>sefirot</i> that issue into it. Now, when it comes to the point of “birth,” the point that the <i>alma deitkasya</i> (concealed world) should become an <i>alma deitgalya</i> (manifest world) that is a finite and distinct entity, this cannot be effected by a simple, progressive, and causal development of the <i>sefirot</i>. Such a development of a gradual descent from higher to lower is unable to produce so radical an effect. The “intervention” of something more than that, of a much more sublime category, is necessary. Birth, the “opening of the womb” to allow the concealed world to egress into manifestation, is made possible by an issue and radiation into <i>malchut</i> from the all-encompassing plane of <i>atik</i> (<i>keter</i>; <i>or makif</i>), the transcendent G–dhead. When the <i>or makif</i> thus unites with the <i>or pnimi</i> as it is in <i>malchut</i>, the potentialities of the <i>or pnimi</i> become actualized in manifest creation. The birth is referred to as the “splitting of the sea” (as the splitting of the sea that took place on the seventh day after the Exodus from Egypt): the sea, i.e., <i>malchut</i>, or the womb of <i>malchut</i>, is “split” to allow the egression of the foetal creatures. As the sea is split and a dry passage is produced, the hitherto hidden sea-creatures now become manifest. The conception in the womb of <i>malchut</i> is alluded to in <i>Shemini Atzeret</i>, the Festival of the eighth day since the first day of <i>Sukkot</i>. The special liturgy of <i>Shemini Atzeret</i> deals with the descent of rain, and from that day until Passover we recite the prayer <i>morid hageshem</i> (who causes the rain to descend). The term <i>Atzeret</i> means Assembly or Ingathering. The word “eighth” alludes to the eighth <i>sefirah</i> in reverse order, thus <i>binah</i>. <i>Atzeret</i> refers to the ingathering of <i>binah (alma deitkasya</i>) in <i>malchut</i>, alluded to by <i>morid hageshem</i>. Moreover, the word <i>geshem</i> means not only rain, the Heavenly downpour, but also matter; in the latter sense it alludes to the increasing materialization of the seminal drop as it descends from the <i>mochin</i> of <i>abba</i> to the womb of <i>malchut</i>, and thence into actual manifestation. Thus <i>Shemini Atzeret</i> is referred to as the point of <i>conception</i>. The period during which we say the prayer <i>morid hageshem</i> (from <i>Shemini Atzeret</i> to Passover) is the period of <i>pregnancy</i>. The time of the Splitting of the Sea, the Seventh Day of Passover, is the point of <i>birth</i>. At that point <i>Atzilut</i> gives birth to <i>Beriah</i> and the creatures therein. All this again indicates the intricate relationship between <i>keter</i> and <i>malchut</i>: “their beginning is wedged into their end, and their end into their beginning.”</i> just as the splitting of the Red Sea—which “depended on <i>atika</i>”;<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:52b.</i> also, the whole growth of the souls, throughout the seven months from the <i>conjunctio</i> of <i>Shemini Atzeret</i> to the Seventh Day of Passover, is like the growth of <i>zu’n</i><sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>middot</i>, <i>chesed</i> to <i>yesod</i>, and <i>malchut</i>.</i> in the womb of <i>imma ilaah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">The supernal mother, <i>binah</i>.</i>—by means of the supernal <i>orot</i> of the <i>imma ilaah</i>, and of yet higher, to the <i>En Sof</i> which vests itself in (<i>imma ilaah</i>) throughout the nine or seven months of pregnancy.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., months of the <i>leidah</i>.</i> Thus it is with the creation of the souls and angels in the world of <i>Beriah</i>.
Also, the very essence and root of the “(seminal) drop” which she<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">The nether mother, <i>malchut</i>.</i> receives and (through which) she is impregnated by the <i>z’eyr anpin</i> is of the <i>mochin of abba</i> and <i>imma</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Of the brains (the highest levels) of the configurations of <i>abba</i> and <i>imma</i>; thus analogous to the physical seminal drop which derives from the parental brain (cf. above, Epistle 15).</i> and issues forth to <i>abba</i> and <i>imma</i> with every <i>conjunctio</i>, from <i>arich anpin</i> and <i>atik yomin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>partzuf</i> corresponding to the sphere of the supreme <i>keter</i>.</i> and still higher—up to the <i>En Sof</i>. Everything is concealed, though, in the <i>mochin</i>, until the <i>nukva</i> gives birth to the souls, and the angels and the <i>hechalot</i> for the world of <i>Beriah</i>. Thus it follows that by means of the <i>ibbur</i> and <i>leidah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Pregnancy and birth.</i> there is truly a manifestation of the light of the <i>En Sof</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">On this profoundly mystical section see <i>Likkutei</i> <i>Torah</i>, <i>Tzav</i> 16b ff., and the discourses dealing with <i>Shemini Atzeret</i>. See also the Zoharic and Lurianic interpretations of Numbers 29:35.</i>
Now it will be clear why the <i>mitzvot</i> (commandments) are in <i>malchut</i>, the <i>hey</i> of the Name of <i>Havaya</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 5, note 16.</i> while the Torah is in <i>z’eyr anpin</i>, the <i>vav</i> of the Name of <i>Havaya</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">See ibid.; see also above, Epistle 19.—The <i>mitzvot</i>, thus, appear inferior to the Torah itself, just as <i>malchut</i> is inferior to <i>z’eyr anpin</i>.</i> Above, in <i>arich anpin</i>, the <i>mitzvot</i> are in the “whiteness of the <i>gulgalta</i>, i.e., the path (formed) by the parting of the hairs which divide into the 613 paths of the Torah as it is in <i>z’eyr anpin</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:129a; 136a (see <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 41, author’s glossary note). The “hairs of the head” refer to concealed worlds or levels which serve as conduits for the supreme emanations. Cf. <i>Zohar Chadash</i> 34a ff.; <i>Derech Emet</i> on <i>Zohar</i> II:122b; below, beg. of Epistle 29.</i> The root of the Torah [which derives from the supreme <i>chochmah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 19, note 35.</i>] is in the concealed <i>mochin </i><sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">The brain-faculties (<i>chochmah</i>, <i>binah</i>) contained within the skull, thus lower in rank than the skull (<i>keter</i>) itself. Cf. <i>Etz Chaim</i> 25:5.</i> of <i>arich anpin</i>, which is the wisdom behind the reasons for the commandments.<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>mitzvot</i> are, in fact, superior to the Torah.</i> However, it is like a seal in reverse.<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">The stamp of an engraved seal leaves an impression which is just the opposite of the way the seal is made. What is engraved in the seal (high in the seal) appears protruding (more tangible and material). What is protruding from the seal (lower in the seal) appears engraved (less tangible and material). Likewise, the more sublime the source of origin above, the lower it descends and appears inferior below and vice versa. Thus in essence the <i>mitzvot</i> are on a higher plane than the Torah; the Torah merely explains the <i>mitzvot</i>. On the revelatory plane, however, they appear lower (as <i>malchut</i>) and the Torah higher (as <i>tiferet</i>, or <i>z’eyr anpin</i>).</i>
Thus “their beginning is wedged in their end,”<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer Yetzirah</i> 1:7.</i> i.e., the power of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He,<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">The power of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, vested in <i>malchut</i> makes it possible to create <i>ex nihilo</i>.</i> in order to create substantiality <i>ex nihilo</i>. (Creation) is not by way of a causal development<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., by means of cause and effect.</i> in which the effect would be encompassed by its cause, and essentially non-subsistent, but (in such a way) that the <i>yesh</i> is an entity distinct from Divinity so that the Emanator, blessed is He, can be a King over all separate entities by their fulfilling the commandments which He enjoins upon them, and “the end result of the act is first in intent.”<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, Hymn of <i>Lecha Dodi</i>.</i>
That is why they said in the Jerusalem Talmud:<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 1:2; <i>Shabbat</i> 1:2.</i> “Is then R. Shimon not of the opinion that one interrupts<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Study of Torah.</i> for <i>lulav</i>…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Observance of a commandment.</i> and “If one learns with the intention not to practice, it were better for him had his afterbirth been turned over his face…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">See references, above, note 83; and <i>Vayikra Rabbah</i> 35:6.</i> for the afterbirth was formed first, by the (seminal) drop, and until the fortieth day, when the embryo begins to take on form, it alone was the essential substance of the embryo. In like manner, the commandments are the essence and root of the Torah, even though a commandment is corporeal<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">On the revelatory plane the commandments are related to physical objects and corporeal functions.</i> and the Torah is wisdom.<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., related to man’s mind and intellect.</i> Only one is in the <i>chitzoniyut</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">The commandments.</i> and the other is in the <i>pnimiyut</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">The Torah.—The study of Torah, thus, has a certain advantage over the <i>mitzvot</i>; see references below, note 91.</i> and as (will be explained) further on.<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Kuntres Acharon</i>, Essay 4; <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Emor</i> 33a ff., <i>Bamidbar</i> 13a ff., and 17a ff.</i>
Now, in like manner, by the <i>zivvug zu’n</i> of <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i> are created <i>ex nihilo</i> into substantiality, all that were created, formed, and made by the light of the <i>neshamah</i> within them. For (the <i>neshamah</i>) is Divinity, of the <i>kelim</i> of the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>. In it is also contained the radiation of the <i>kav</i> from the light of the <i>En Sof</i> that is vested in <i>Atzilut</i> as far as the <i>prassa</i> (curtain).<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Between <i>Atzilut</i> and <i>Beriah</i> (and likewise between the other worlds) there is a <i>prassa</i> (curtailing the higher world) which needs to be pierced in order for the light and vivification of the higher to penetrate and descend to the lower. See <i>Etz Chaim</i> 42:4 (ibid., ch. 13 ff. of <i>Klalut ABYA</i>—I); ibid., 44:1.</i> This radiation of the <i>kav</i>, that radiated in the <i>kelim</i> of the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>malchut</i>, pierced the <i>prassa</i> along with them<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">With the <i>kelim</i>.</i> and radiates in them in <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>, just as in <i>Atzilut</i> itself.
The same is also with the very <i>kav</i> that is vested in the culmination and end of the <i>n.h.y.</i> of <i>Adam Kadmon</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">The lower three <i>sefirot</i> (<i>netzach</i>, <i>hod</i>, <i>yesod</i>) of <i>Adam Kadmon</i>.</i> i.e., the end of the “feet” of its <i>yosher</i><sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the end of the scheme of <i>yosher</i>, which culminates in the center of the primordial space, the point corresponding to <i>malchut</i> of <i>Asiyah</i>. See above note 32.</i> which culminate in the <i>malchut</i> of <i>Asiyah</i>: a radiation from the <i>kav</i> radiates from there and vests itself in the light of the <i>neshamah</i> of the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>, which is Divinity. A radiation from (this) radiation vests itself in the <i>nefesh-ruach</i> of the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>, and also in all their <i>kelim</i>, while a radiation of (that) radiation of the (original) radiation is (immanent) in all that were created, formed, and made, as it is written: “The seas, and all there is in them, and You animate them all.”<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Nehemiah 9:6.</i>
Now, all this is by way of an extension of the vital force to animate them. However, the essence and nature of the light of the <i>En Sof</i> is in no way subject to space and encompasses all worlds equally: “And I fill the heavens and the earth”<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 23:24.</i> in one equal fashion, and “there is no place void of Him”<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei</i> <i>Zohar</i> 57 (91b); ibid., 70 (122b).</i> even in this physical world.<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Shemot</i> <i>Rabbah</i> 2:9.</i> However, this is by way of “encompassing” and “encircling,”<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> III:225a.</i> and the meaning of this was explained in <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 48; see above, Epistle 1, note 13.</i> It is not in a mode of extension and investment of the vital force to vivify them and make them come into being, <i>ex nihilo</i> into substantiality. (This is) only by a radiation from a radiation of the radiation, and so on, from the <i>kav</i>, as mentioned above.
Also, the radiation from the light of the <i>En Sof</i> which encircles and encompasses the four worlds <i>Atzilut</i>, <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i> and <i>Asiyah</i> in equal fashion to the inner gleam (<i>kav</i>) is by way of the <i>kelim</i> of the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>. By its radiation within the <i>kelim</i>, it confers unto them the power and force to create substantiality <i>ex nihilo</i> (<i>yesh meayin</i>).
Now, because the creation is by means of the <i>kelim</i>, the creatures are in a category of multifariousness and division, limitation and finitude, and especially so by means of the letters,<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">The letters of speech.</i> as mentioned above.
Furthermore, [in addition to all that was mentioned above,] the radiation of the radiation [and all that was said above] manifests its power and ability in the element of the physical earth in an immense manifestation, surpassing the elements transcending it, and even the hosts of heaven. For they do not have it in their power and ability constantly to bring forth something out of nothing (<i>yesh meayin</i>), like the element of earth. (The latter) constantly makes sprout something out of nothing (<i>yesh meayin</i>), namely the herbs and trees—from the vegetative property it possesses, which is non-substantial (<i>ayin</i>) and spiritual, while (the growths) are physical. (<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>As for the <i>mazal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">The individual star, or angel of destiny.</i> that strikes (the herb) and says “grow,”<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 10:6; see <i>Moreh Nevuchim</i> 2:10.</i>—this takes place after the herb has already sprouted. He does not tell it to sprout <i>ex nihilo</i> into substantiality, but only from small to big, and which kind of fruit, to bear, in all its details. For<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">See H. V.</i> prior to its sprouting, to whom would every herb’s <i>mazal</i> ordain all the details?)
Now all this is so only because the “feet” of <i>Adam Kadmon</i> culminate at the bottom of <i>Asiyah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., at the lowest level, at <i>malchut</i> of <i>Asiyah</i>; see above, notes 32 and 95.</i> and “below His feet”<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">In the other half of the primordial space.</i> radiates the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, which encircles all worlds without any great interruption between them, except for the <i>iggulim</i> of <i>Adam Kadmon</i> only.<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Unlike the <i>yosher</i>, the <i>iggulim</i> take in the whole void (see above, note 32). The central point in the primordial space is not only the endpoint of <i>yosher</i>, but also the lowest level of the <i>iggulim</i>.</i>
Also, the <i>kav</i> of the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, culminating at the ending of the “feet” of <i>Adam Kadmon</i>, radiates from below upward in a mode of <i>or</i> <i>chozer</i><sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">A returning (reflecting) light. Thus there is a constant stream of light flowing both ways: from the highest to the lowest level and back, from the lowest to the highest. See at the end of this section.</i> just as the investment in <i>arich anpin</i>, <i>abba</i> and <i>imma</i>, and <i>zu’n</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> radiates as an <i>or chozer</i> from <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, and <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, from below upward, is a category of <i>keter</i>, and “their beginning is wedged in their end.”<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Malchut</i> is an aspect of <i>keter</i>, not only relatively speaking because as the lowest stage of the higher realm it is the highest of the successive, lower realm, but the <i>keter</i> of its own realm is vested and wedged in it, and it reflects back into its own <i>keter</i>. Thus, their beginning (<i>keter</i>) is truly wedged in their end (<i>malchut</i>).</i>
It is likewise at the culmination of the <i>kav</i> of the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, culminating at the ending of the <i>yosher</i> of the “feet” of <i>Adam Kadmon</i>: it radiates from below upward<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">In a mode of <i>or chozer</i>.</i> to the category of the light of the <i>neshamah</i> of the <i>malchut</i> of <i>malchut</i> of <i>Asiyah</i>, which is actual Divinity [(originating in) the <i>chitzoniyut</i> of the <i>kelim</i> of <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>].
According to that which is stated in ch. 20 of <i>Sefer Hagilgulim</i>, cited in <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 6, author’s glossary note, ad loc.</i> this radiation from the <i>kav</i> of the light of the <i>En Sof</i> vests itself first in the light of <i>Atzilut</i> in <i>Asiyah</i>, and from there to the <i>Beriah</i> and <i>Yetzirah</i> in <i>Asiyah</i>, and from these to the category of the light of the <i>neshamah</i> of the <i>malchut</i> of the <i>malchut</i> of <i>Asiyah</i>. And hence is the (creative) power and force in the culmination of the <i>keli</i> of the <i>malchut</i> of <i>malchut</i> of <i>Asiyah</i> within the element of earth.
This is the constant and everlasting effect, throughout the earth, of the fiat “Let the earth bring forth herbs….”<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 1:11.</i>—(<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>in a mode of infinitude, and not during the six days of creation only [as is the case with the fiat “Let the waters bring forth an abundance of creeping things,”<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 1:20.</i> and the fiat “Let the earth bring forth living being”<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid. 1:24.</i>—from the <i>chochmah</i> of the <i>malchut</i> of the <i>malchut</i> of <i>Asiyah</i>]. For during the Seven Days of the Beginning there shone in this world a radiation from the light of the <i>En Sof</i> in a mode of gratuitous <i>chesed</i>, without any (prior) elevation of <i>mayin nukvin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Feminine waters—The initial stimulus of an appropriate act by man (see above, Epistle 4, note 46).</i> at all<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 5, and note 87, ad loc.</i>).
—to make herbs and trees, and fruits, sprout <i>ex nihilo</i> into substantiality, constantly, from year to year. This is a kind of degree of infinity, for if this world will subsist for myriads of myriads of years, they will still sprout forth from year to year.
There are, though, some (plants) which require a (prior) elevation of <i>mayin nukvin</i> [namely those which are sown and implanted]. But these (too, come about) like <i>yesh meayin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Not truly <i>yesh meayin</i>, for there is some initial substance. Thus strictly speaking it is <i>yesh meyesh</i> (as opposed to <i>ayin</i>, naught). But the final product is so inproportionate to its source that the vegetative process is somehow analogous to <i>creatio ex nihilo</i>.</i> for the implanted kernel is of no estimation whatsoever in relation to the fruit, nor in relation to the whole tree with the branches and leaves. The same applies to the various sorts of garden herbs and vegetables, and also to the various sorts of produce: that hundreds of kernels will come about from a single kernel is like <i>yesh meayin</i>, and <i>a fortiori</i>, with respect to the chaffs and spikes.
Now, these fruits (that come about) by means of an elevation of <i>mayin nukvin</i>, i.e., by sowing and implanting, they are, by far, superior to those that rise independently from the vegetative property in the soil only. And from this we can understand (the notion of) the elicitations of the supernal <i>orot</i> in <i>Atzilut</i>, <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i> (<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>which is the purpose for the creation of man<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Devarim</i> 2a.</i>), as explained elsewhere.<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Nitzavim</i> 50d-51a; see also above, Epistle 8.</i>
And from this we can understand clearly the subject of the order of levels pertaining to the inorganic, vegetative, animal, and articulate [which correspond to the aspects of earth, water, fire, and air]. Though the animal is more sublime than the vegetative, and the articulate is more sublime than the animal, nevertheless, the animal is nurtured and lives by the vegetative, and the articulate receives his vitality from both, even wisdom and knowledge. For “A child does not know how to call ‘father’ and ‘mother’ until it has tasted grain”;<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 40a; cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:157b and <i>Bereishit</i> <i>Rabbah</i> 15:7.</i> and “I had not yet eaten the meat of oxen….”<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">And was, therefore, unable to examine the problem properly.—<i>Bava</i> <i>Kama</i> 71b-72a; see commentaries, ad loc.</i> This is the aspect of the <i>or chozer</i>: from <i>below</i>, from the bottom<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Malchut</i>.</i> of <i>Asiyah</i> [where there is an exceedingly strong manifestation of the radiation of the radiation…from the light of the <i>En Sof</i> which encircles all worlds, and from the <i>kav</i> from the light of the <i>En Sof</i> at the culmination of the “feet” of the <i>yosher</i> of <i>Adam Kadmon</i>] <i>upward</i>, in a mode of <i>or chozer</i>, as mentioned above.
And it will be clearly understood from this, the best of discernment and knowledge, how it is that the supreme angels of the <i>Merkavah</i>—“the face of the oxen, and the face of the eagle”—<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 1:10.</i>derive great enjoyment and are nurtured and content from the spirit of the cattle and fowl that ascends to them from the sacrifices on the altar, and as the sacred <i>Zohar</i> expresses it subtly:<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:241a.</i> “And they derive enjoyment from their <i>element</i> and <i>essence</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">The form and essence, as opposed to the physical aspects of the animal sacrifices. The animal spirit, the “animalhood,” originally deriving from these angels of the <i>Merkavah</i> (see above, notes 20), thus is refracted and reflects back to its source in a mode of <i>or chozer</i>.</i>
Now, after these words and this truth,<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Par. II Chronicles 32:1.</i> knowledge comes easy to the discerning<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Proverbs 14:6.</i> to understand from all the above the great advantage of the operational commandments.<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">On the revelatory plane the <i>mitzvot</i> are but in <i>malchut</i>; their origin thus is exceedingly sublime. It is to that exceedingly high and sublime source to which the <i>or chozer</i> (effected by the fulfillment of the <i>mitzvot</i>) reflects. Hence, the elicitations effected by the performance of <i>mitzvot</i> are also that much more sublime (see below, Epistle 29; also, above, Epistle 3, note 5).</i> For they are the purpose for the descent of the souls to this physical world, as it is written: “To practice them this day”;<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 7:11; cf. <i>Eruvin</i> 22a.</i> and “Better one hour of repentance and good deeds in this world than all the life of the World to Come.”<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 4:17; see above, Epistle 1.</i>
<i>Until here we found of his holy writing</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">R. Menachem Mendel of Lubavitch, grandson and disciple of the author, writes that his grandfather wrote this discourse a few days before his passing; see <i>Derech Mitzvotecha</i> 170a and <i>Kitzurim V’Hearot</i>, p. 40.</i>

Chapter 21

<b>TWENTY-ONE.</b> Upon enquiring after their welfare, as is becoming to those who love His Name—“May my word drop and my speech trickle as dew”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Job 29:22 and Deuteronomy 32:2.</i> to those who offer themselves willingly among the people<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Judges 5:9.</i> to practice the righteousness of the L–rd (<i>tzidkat Hashem</i>) with His Holy Land<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. above, Epistles 14 and 17.</i> by giving every year a set sum of monies for our Holy Land, may it be rebuilt and re-established speedily, in our days. (I call upon you) to bestir the alert<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Makkot</i> 23a: <i>Sifrei</i>, Numbers, sect. 1.</i> and to strengthen weak hands, to contribute monies for the Land of Israel every week, or at least every month, of the amount assigned as the year’s apportionment, as well as all the “dedicated money” that one was inspired to donate annually, without a vow,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, <i>Yoreh Deah</i> 203; cf. <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Matot</i> 82b.</i> for the support of our brethren who live in the Holy Land.
For, note, besides that it is known to all the great virtue of alertness with respect to all commandments—[Thus it is mentioned repeatedly in the sayings of our Sages, of blessed memory: “At all times one should try to be first when it comes to a commandment.”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nazir</i> 22b; <i>Bava Kama</i> 38b, etc.; see below, note 10.</i> Also, it is the alertness of our father Abraham, peace to him, that stands by us and our children, for everlasting.
For the <i>akedah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The binding of Isaac for sacrificial purposes (Genesis 22).</i> itself is not really regarded as so great a test in relation to the level of our father Abraham, peace to him, especially as <i>G–d</i> said to him “Please take your son….”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 22:2.</i> After all, there are numerous saints who gave their lives for the sanctification of the L–rd, even though that G–d did not speak to them. However, our father Abraham, peace to him, did this with a wondrous alertness<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">See Genesis 22:3 and <i>Midrashim</i>, ad loc.</i> to show his joy and desire to fulfill the will of his Master and to cause gratification to his Maker.
And from him our Sages, of blessed memory, derived (the requirement of alertness) with respect to the keeping of all the commandments in general;<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pesachim</i> 4a; <i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 32b; etc.</i> and in particular with respect to the act of charity, which is superior to them all, protecting and saving by its “fruits” in this world<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Peah</i> 1:1; see above, beg. of Epistle 17.</i> from all kinds of calamities that may come about, as it is written: “And <i>tzedakah</i> saves from death,”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 10:2; see <i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 16b and <i>Zohar</i> I:104a.</i> thus, <i>a fortiori</i>, from other kinds of suffering that are lighter than death. It is, thus, certainly to our benefit, even in this world, to be as zealous with it as possible, for, after all, “Man is judged every day.”<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 16a.</i>]
Indeed, we also found and noted in the service of charity a particularly great and wondrous advantage, without parallel: the act of charity is performed in numerous times, and whoever performs it frequently is praiseworthy. This is in contrast to performing it in one time and all at once, even when the total sum is the same, as R. Moses Maimonides, of blessed memory, wrote in (his) Commentary on the Mishnah taught by the Sages, of blessed memory: “And everything according to the quantity of the act.”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 3:15; see <i>The Art of Giving</i> (Kehot 2014), pp. 24-26 ff.</i>
Now, besides that, R. Moses Maimonides, of blessed memory, explained well this reason and motive [“In order to refine the soul by means of the quantitative action”], there is an explicit verse in Scripture that “The effect of <i>tzedakah</i> is for life.”<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">See Proverbs 10:16 and 11:19.</i> This means its effect and affection is to elicit supreme life from the Fountainhead of life,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., Life of life; see above, Epistle 17, note 4.</i> the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, to the Land of Life,<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 8, note 46.</i> the Abode (<i>Shechinah</i>) of our strength,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid., note 36.</i> of which it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Nehemiah 9:6.</i> “And You animate them all.”<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 14, and note 29, ad loc.</i> It<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">The Land of Life, the <i>Shechinah</i>.</i> is the hut of David that has fallen<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 9, notes 27 ff.</i> down to the very dust, and as the saying of our Sages, of blessed memory:<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Megillah</i> 29a (v.s. of <i>Eyn Yaakov</i>, ad loc.); <i>Mechilta</i> on Exodus 12:41; see below, Epistle 25, note 48.—Cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, end of ch. 17.</i> “When they were exiled to Edom, the <i>Shechinah</i> went with them….” (This effect of <i>tzedakah</i> is brought about) because the arousal from below, to revive the spirit of the humbled who has nothing at all of his own,<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">The “poor who has nothing of his own” corresponds to the <i>Shechinah</i>, the <i>sefirah</i> of <i>malchut</i>—which has “nothing of its own but what is given to it by others” (cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:249b; <i>Etz Chaim</i> 6:5 and 8:5; <i>et passim</i>). See <i>Zohar</i> III:113b.</i> elicits an arousal from above; and especially so when the people offer voluntarily to sustain the inhabitants of the actual Land of Life,<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the terrestrial Land of Life, the Land of Israel; see above, Epistle 8, note 45.</i> and suffice this for the initiated.
Now, whoever is enlightened as to so great and wondrous a matter will find to the best of discernment and knowledge how profound are the words of the Sages, of blessed memory, when they said “Everything according to the quantity of the act.” This refers to the act of charity, which is performed at numerous times to elicit supreme life in order to bring about a supreme unification (<i>yichud</i>) many times.
This is also similar to what R. Moses Maimonides wrote “to refine the soul,” as is known from the sacred <i>Zohar</i> that the <i>Shechinah</i> is called <i>nefesh</i> (soul)<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar Chadash</i>, <i>Rut</i> 84a; 78c; <i>et passim</i>.</i>—because she is our life and our soul. And it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 44:26.</i> “Our soul is bent low, to the dust.”<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. above (note 22), and see <i>Midrash Tehillim</i> 44:2.</i> And that is why our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “Great is charity, for it brings close the redemption”<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Batra</i> 10a.</i>—to raise (the <i>Shechinah</i>) from the dust, gradually,<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">See Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Yoma</i> 3:2.</i> “until Shilo will come.”<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 49:7.</i>

Chapter 22

<b>TWENTY-TWO.</b><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">This section is but an excerpt from a lengthy epistle, the complete version of which appears in <i>Hatamim</i>, Installment 2 (Warsaw, 1935; p. 32[126] ff.) and in <i>Igrot Kodesh Admur Hazaken</i> (Kehot, 2012; p. 111 ff.). See Translator’s Introduction to <i>Iggeret Hakodesh</i>, (Addendum, p. a<?>), note 21.</i> My beloved, my brethren and friends:
An open rebuke out of a love concealed:<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Proverbs 27:5.</i> come now and let us adjudge,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 1:18.</i> remember the days of old, consider the years of every generation.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Deuteronomy 32:7.</i> Has such ever happened since the days of the world, and where, oh where have you found such a custom in any one of the books of the early and latter sages of Israel, that it should be usage and regulation to ask for advice in mundane matters<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See H. V.</i>—what one is to do in matters pertaining to the physical world. (Such was not asked) even of the greatest of the erstwhile sages of Israel as the <i>Tannaim</i> and <i>Amoraim</i>, “For whom no secret is hidden”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Daniel 4:6; see <i>Chullin</i> 59a.</i> and “All the paths of heaven are clear to them,”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 58b.</i> except for the real prophets that were aforetimes in Israel as Samuel the Seer, to whom Saul went to enquire of G–d about the donkeys that were lost to his father.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">See I Samuel, ch. 9.</i>
For in fact, all matters pertaining to man, except for the words of Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Bava Metzia</i> 59b; <i>Temurah</i> 16a; Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah</i> 9:1 and Intro. to his Commentary on the Mishnah.</i> and the fear of Heaven, are apprehended by prophecy only. “And there is no bread for the wise,”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 9:11.</i> as our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “Everything is in the hands of Heaven except for the fear of Heaven,”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 33b.</i> and “Seven things are hidden…man does not know how he will profit, and when the Kingdom of David will return….”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pesachim</i> 54b.</i> Note, these are likened one to the other!<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., “how he will profit” and “when the Kingdom of David will return” (see the commentary of <i>Maharsha</i>, ad loc.).</i>
As for what is written in Isaiah,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 3:3.</i> “A counselor and a wise one who silences all,” and also, as for the statement of our Sages, of blessed memory,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 6:1.</i> “From him<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The scholar of Torah, who studies <i>lishmah</i>, “for its own sake,” as a command of G–d, without any ulterior motives. See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, end of ch. 5. Above, Epistle 12.</i> people enjoy <i>etzah</i> (counsel) and <i>toshiyah</i> (salvation)”—this refers to matters of the Torah, called <i>toshiyah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Midrash Tehillim</i> 7:3; <i>Sanhedrin</i> 26b; <i>Zohar Chadash</i> 5d.</i> Thus the Sages, of blessed memory, said:<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chagigah</i> 14a.</i> “A counselor is he who knows to intercalcate the years and to determine the months,”<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Emended according to H. V.</i> for in Torah terminology the principium of intercalcation is called <i>etzah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Counsel.</i> and <i>sod</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Mystery.</i> as mentioned in <i>Sanhedrin</i>, folio 87;<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 87a.</i> see there in the commentary of Rashi.
However, I shall relate the truth<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Daniel 11:2.</i> to those who listen to me: “Love upsets the natural order of conduct,”<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 55:8; cf. <i>Sanhedrin</i> 105b.</i> for it is a covering of the eyes not to see the truth. Because of their great love for the life of the body [for the sake of Heaven, to worship G–d with it in a mode of flashes of fire and a great flame<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Song of Songs 8:6. Cf. above, Epistle 1, note 29.</i> because of their soul’s love for G–d],<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. above, end of Epistle 17. The author does not accuse his followers of seeking physical comfort for its own sake. He views them with compassion and judges their motives to be noble. However, he admonishes them to find a profound lesson in their hardship.</i> they are properly angry with the agony of the body, Heaven forfend; may G–d show compassion. Thus they are not able to bear it at all, to the point that it drives them out of their mind<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Eruvin</i> 41b; cf. <i>Zohar Chadash</i> 49a.</i> to tramp about from city to city to seek advice from afar, and they did not implore G–d by returning to Him with humble spirit and submission of the body to accept His chastisement with love, “for He whom He loves….”<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 3:12.</i>
It is analogous to a compassionate, wise, and righteous father who punishes his son. Surely the wise son should not “turn his back”<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Joshua 7:8.</i> to escape and find himself help, or even an intercessor before his father, who is compassionate, righteous, and merciful. Rather, he should have his face looking straight<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 11:7.</i> at his father, face to face, to endure his strikes with love, “For his lifelong benefit.”
Now, above, the aspect of <i>panim</i> (face) is that of willingness and pleasure.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">The term <i>panim</i> denotes <i>pnimiyut</i>, the inner essence, the core. Correlative it expresses willingness. To give in a mode of <i>pnimiyut</i> implies most profound willingness and favor, stemming from the very essence of the giver. Cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 22.</i> That is, our Father in Heaven effuses to His children all the good of the worlds, and life for the soul and body, out of love and willingness, pleasure and delight, through the Torah of Life,<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Proverbs 3:8.</i> His Will, blessed be He, which He gave to us, as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, concluding benediction of the <i>Amidah</i>.</i> “For in the light of <i>panecha</i> (Your Face),<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., out of love and willingness.</i> You gave us the Torah of Life…” to carry out His will with it.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">By observing the Torah and the commandments.</i> And of this it was said: “For in the light of the King’s Face there is life, and His will….”<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 16:15.</i>
To the heathens, however, He effuses the life of their bodies without willingness, pleasure, and delight. This, therefore, is referred to as <i>elohim acherim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., other gods.—G–d sustains the heathens without favor. Thus He does so by means of various intermediaries. These appear to the heathens as independent entities and forces, as “other gods”; see <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 22; below, Epistle 25. Cf. <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 32 (76b).</i> for they draw from the aspect of <i>achorayim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Achorayim</i> (hindersides; as opposed to <i>panim</i>, the face, or frontside) denotes the most extraneous aspect, as far removed from <i>pnimiyut</i> as possible. Correlative it expresses a lack of willingness. To give in a mode of <i>achorayim</i> implies a contemptuous and strictly formal gift; see <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 22.</i>
It is likewise with man: willingness and pleasure are an aspect of <i>panim</i> (face). When one does not accept<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">The chastisements of G–d.</i> with love and willingness, it is as if “he turns his neck”<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Joshua 7:8. Cf. Jeremiah 2:27; etc.</i> and <i>achor</i> (back), Heaven forfend.
The suggested advice (to be able) to accept with love is the counsel of the L–rd in the mouth of our Sages, of blessed memory: “to examine one’s conduct.”<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 5a.</i> Thus one will find with himself sins that require the purgation through afflictions.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">See ibid. and <i>Zohar</i> III:57b.</i> Then one will see clearly His great love toward himself which “upsets the natural order of conduct,” as in the simile of the great and awesome king who, out of his great love, personally washes the filth from his only son, as it is written: “When the L–rd will wash the filth off the daughters of Zion… with a spirit of justice….”<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 4:4.</i>
And “As waters (reflect) face to face,”<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 27:19; see above, Epistle 1, note 26.</i> there will be an arousal of love in the heart of everyone who perceives and understands the preciousness of the nature of G–d’s love for the nether beings; it is dearer and better than all the life of all the worlds, as it is written: “How precious is Your <i>chesed</i>…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 36:8.</i> “For Your <i>chesed</i> is better than life….”<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 63:4.</i> For <i>chesed</i> [which is the aspect of love] is the Fountainhead of the life<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., the Life of the life (cf. above, Epistle 17, note 4).</i> prevalent in all the worlds, as it is written: “He sustains life through <i>chesed</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, opening benedictions of the <i>Amidah</i>.</i>
And then<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">When a man accepts upon himself with love, etc.</i> G–d, too, will grant goodness and make His Face shine toward him in the mode of a manifestation of the love which at first was clothed and hidden in a manifestation of admonition,<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Chastisement.—Cf. above, Epistle 11, and <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 26.</i> and the <i>gevurot</i> shall be sweetened at their source and the judgments become nullified, forevermore.
(22b<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">The following is obviously not a continuation of the preceding (cf. above, note 1), but was placed here by the compilers of <i>Iggeret Hakodesh</i> as an addendum to 22—“after the first editions had been published (see list of editions)”—as the Lubavitcher Rebbe notes in <i>Shiurim B’Sefer HaTanya</i>. The connection, however, is not immediately apparent. Perhaps it lies in the opening passage of the complete version of part (a) (referenced above in note 1), in which Rabbi Schneur Zalman laments that questions on material affairs occupy too much of his time—for this theme also figures in the epistle before us.</i>). My beloved, my brethren and friends:
Due to the immensity of my preoccupations which all together surround me and “encircle me like water all day and all night, never holding their peace,”<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 88:18 and Isaiah 62:6.</i>—I am unable to bear<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Text corrected according to L. H.</i> the burden to state in writing all that is in my heart.
Briefly, however, I come as one who reminds and repeats erstwhile matters<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Keritot</i> 8a.</i> in general, and in particular to those of the people who offer themselves willingly—to stand by the (Divine) service, i.e., prayer,<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">See Judges 5:9 and commentaries, ad loc.; <i>Taanit</i> 2a; <i>Sifrei</i>, Deuteronomy, sect. 41.</i> with a loud voice:<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">See Nachmanides, end of his comment, on Exodus 13:16; cf. <i>Sefer Chassidim</i>, sect. 820. <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, <i>Orach Chaim</i> 101 and comment., ad loc.</i> to strengthen themselves very much with all might and power<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Berachot</i> 32b, <i>Rashi</i> ad loc. (s.v. <i>Tzrichin</i>).</i> against any internal or external obstacle, with, literally, a strong hand. This refers to the “will of those who fear Him”<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 145:19.</i>—transcending the wisdom and understanding G–d gave into them in order to know to exercise all that G–d commanded with intelligence and knowledge.
There should be but a simple will and a spirit of voluntary offering in every one whose heart prompts him to serve “a whole service,”<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Yoma</i> 24a.</i> thus to cause gratification to his Maker. Of this it is said: “For it is a stiff-necked people, and You pardon,”<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 34:9—Stiff-neckedness denotes simple will, will as it is in itself, transcending the faculties of reason; see below, Epistle 29, note 25. Cf. <i>Likkutei</i> <i>Torah</i>, <i>Balak</i> 67d and 71b.</i> for pardon, too, transcends wisdom, as “They asked wisdom….”<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Makkot</i> 2:6 (see comment. <i>Pnei Moshe</i>, ad loc.); <i>Pesikta d’R. Kahana</i> (ed. Buber), 25.—Wisdom demands that sins go paired with appropriate judgment. The possibility of <i>teshuvah</i> or simple pardon (thereby avoiding judgment), thus, transcends wisdom, and is due solely to Divine grace.</i> Thus Moses our Master, peace to him, invoked “measure for measure,”<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nedarim</i> 320.</i> and suffice this for the initiated.
Furthermore, I ask of you not to cast aside my words, the plea I issued for everyone to be upright and walking with integrity<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Proverbs 19:1; etc.</i> just as “G–d made man upright; not to seek numerous calculations”<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Ecclesiastes 7:29.</i> of the pretexts of man’s steps and a person’s thoughts and devices.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., to calculate on the motives of other people and to criticize them.</i> For that is the work of Heaven and not an occupation for human beings.
Rather, (every one is) to believe with absolute faithfulness in the precept of our Sages, of blessed memory:<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 4:10.</i> “And be humble of spirit before every person”—in general.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., any one.</i> For it is a set matter and an established proverb that each one becomes better through his fellow being.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Whereas all of Israel together form a single stature every one complements the other, thereby improving and perfecting him; cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:234a (also, ibid., 167b); <i>Kuzari</i> 3:19; <i>Tomer Devorah</i> 1:4.—Cf. also <i>Avot</i> 4:1; <i>Zohar</i> III:85b.</i>
Thus it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 20:11; cf. <i>Chagigah</i> 26a.</i>—“All the men of Israel…as one man associated together,”<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Mechilta d’R. Shimon bar Yochai</i> (ed. Epstein-Melamed), on Exodus 19:6 (Jerusalem, 1955, p. 139): “as one body, and one soul.”</i> just as one man is composed of many limbs; but when they become separated this affects the heart.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid. (also, <i>Mechilta d’R. Yishmael</i>, ad loc.); <i>Vayikra Rabbah</i> 4:6.—See also below, Epistle 31.</i> “For out of it are the issues of life.”<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 4:23—On the theme of the innate unity of Israel see also: Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Nedarim</i> 4:4 and comment., ad loc.; Arizal, <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, on Leviticus 19:18; <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Nitzavim</i> 44a; <i>Igrot Kodesh</i> by the Lubavitcher Rebbe, vol. 2, p. 113 ff.</i> With us, therefore, by all of us being as truly one man, the service (of G–d) will be established in the heart. And from the affirmative….<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">You may infer the negative; <i>Sifrei</i>, Deuteronomy, sect. 46.</i> That is why it was said:<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Zephaniah 3:9.</i> “To serve Him as <i>one part</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">One part (see <i>Rashi</i> on Genesis 48:22), or: one shoulder (see <i>Targum Yonatan</i>, ad loc., and <i>Likkutei</i> <i>Torah</i>, <i>Derushim L’Sukkot</i> 80d), the meaning for both being: with one consent.</i>
Therefore, my beloved and dear ones: I beg of you to make an effort with all the heart and soul to drive into the heart the love for one’s fellow man, “And none of you should consider in your hearts what is evil to his fellow man”—it is written.<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 8:17.</i> Such (consideration) should never rise in the heart, and if it does rise one is to push it away from his heart “as smoke is driven away,”<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 68:3.</i> and truly like an idolatrous thought.
For to speak evil is as grave as idolatry, incest, and shedding of blood together.<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Peah</i> 1:1; <i>Midrash Tehillim</i> 12:2. Also: <i>Arachin</i> 15b and Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Deot</i> 7:3.</i> If this be so with speech…;<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">So much the worse when in thought.</i> and the advantage of the adjustment of thought over speech, whether for the good or for the better, is already known to all the wise of heart.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 16; <i>Torah Or</i>, <i>Yitro</i> 71a; <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Shelach</i> 51d ff., <i>et passim</i>.</i>
May the good L–rd, who blesses His people with peace,<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Liturgy, <i>Amidah</i> (par. Psalms 29:11).</i> set among you peace and life, forevermore, as is the wish of him who loves you faithfully from heart and soul.

Chapter 23

<b>TWENTY-THREE.</b> “The matter is by the decree of the watch-angels and the say of the holy ones”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 4:14; cf. <i>Pesachim</i> 33a.</i>—the Sages of the Mishnah, may peace be on them, who taught in their Mishnah: “Ten that sit and busy themselves with Torah, the <i>Shechinah</i> dwells among them.”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 3:6.</i> This is the whole of man.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Ecclesiastes 12:13.</i> Moreover, (man’s) very descent to this world was for the purpose of this ascent, of which there is none higher.
For the Indwelling of His Might (<i>Shechinat Uzo</i>), which is in the heights of the upper realms<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Liturgy, prayer of <i>Aleinu</i> (cf. Isaiah 33:16).</i> and whose awesomeness the heavens and the heavens of the heavens cannot contain,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Par. I Kings 8:27; etc.</i> dwells and becomes magnified among the children of Israel. Thus it is written: “For I, the L–rd, dwell among (<i>toch</i>) the children of Israel”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 35:34.</i>—through the occupation with Torah and the commandments <i>by ten</i>, expressly, as our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “We compare <i>toch-toch</i>…”;<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">An analogy to two occurrences of the word <i>toch</i>, from which we derive the minimum often participants for a quorum; <i>Berachot</i> 21b; <i>Megillah</i> 23b.</i> of this it was said: “The Holy One in your midst,”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 12:6.</i> and “There is no matter of holiness with less than ten.”<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">See above, note 7, cf. <i>Zohar</i> II:129b; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 18 (35b); <i>et passim</i>.</i>
Therefore, too, our Sages, of blessed memory, need to derive from Scripture whence we know that even one who sits occupied with Torah….<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>Shechinah</i> dwells with him.—<i>Avot</i> 3:6; <i>Berachot</i> 6a.</i> And even so they did not find from Scripture support for that, but only for the allotment of a reward to the individual, proportionate to himself and in proportion<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">V. L. omits “and.”</i> to the many.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the reward for his singular efforts is in proportion to communal study of Torah.</i> But as to causing an indwelling (<i>hashraah</i>) of G–d’s Holiness, (the individual) cannot be compared to (the multitude) at all.
The difference between causing an indwelling (<i>hashraah</i>) and the allotment of a reward is explicit to those who discern knowledge. For the “allotment of a reward” is when G–d irradiates the soul that seeks Him with the light of Torah, which is truly the wrapping of His garment—[wherefore the Torah is called “light”<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Taanit</i> 7b; see also <i>Megillah</i> 16b and <i>Sefer Habahir</i> 50 (149).</i>], as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 104:2.</i> “He wraps (Himself in) light, as (with) a garment.”<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:245b.</i> But because the soul is limited and finite in all its powers, the light of G–d that radiates in it is also limited, contracted, and vests itself in (the soul). That is why the heart of those who seek the L–rd is in a mode of ecstasy at the time of prayer, or the like. For their heart rejoices in Him and exults “Even with exultation and song,”<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 35:2.</i> and their soul delights in the pleasantness of the L–rd<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">V. L.: over the L–rd.</i> and His light as it becomes revealed from the wrapper of His garment—the Torah; “And His arrow comes forth like lightning.”<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 9:14.</i> This is the allotment of the reward for Torah, which is always fixed in the soul that labors in (Torah).
The indwelling (<i>hashraah</i>), however, is an immense radiation from the light of G–d that radiates in (the soul) without limit and end. It cannot become vested in a finite soul, but encompasses it from above, from “its head to its foot,”<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">The totality of the soul.</i> as our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “The <i>Shechinah</i> hovers over every gathering often,”<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 39a.</i> i.e., over them, from above.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, end of ch. 11.</i> Thus it is written: “May the pleasantness of the L–rd our G–d be upon us, and the work of our hands establish upon us.”<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 90:17.</i> This is to say that the pleasantness of the L–rd which shone forth through the work of our hands in the occupation with Torah and the commandments [for “The Torah and the Holy One, blessed is He, are entirely one”<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:90b; see also 60a and III:73a. Cf. <i>Kitzurim V’Hearot</i>, p. 104 f. See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, chs. 4 and 23.</i>] become established and “dwell upon us from above,” for it is without limit and end and does not become vested in our soul and intellect.
That is why we do not apprehend with our intellect the delightfulness and sweetness of the unlimited and infinite pleasantness of the L–rd, and the splendor of the <i>Shechinah</i>, established and dwelling upon us through the work of our hands in Torah and the commandments (performed) specifically <i>en masse</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">As opposed to singular, individual activity.</i> And of this our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “In this world there is no reward for the commandments.”<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kiddushin</i> 39b.</i> For it is impossible for the world to attain it [the reward] but by divesting the soul from the body, and even then by way of grace, as it is written: “And that Yours, my L–rd, is kindness, for You repay each man according to his deeds.”<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 62:13.</i> Thus our Sages, of blessed memory, said that the Holy One, blessed is He, gives unto the righteous a capacity….<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">To receive their reward. <i>Sanhedrin</i> 100b. Cf. above, Epistle 3, note 5.</i>
It is not so, however, with the angels, as I heard from my masters that if there were an angel standing in the presence of a gathering of ten Israelites [even if there are no words of Torah between them], an unlimited and infinite fear and awe would then befall him from the <i>Shechinah</i> that dwells over them that he would become totally nullified.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Thus, unlike the soul, an angel is unable to apprehend and endure the manifestation of the <i>Shechinah</i>.</i>
Therefore, evil in my eyes is the behavior that takes place under the sun<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Ecclesiastes 2:17; etc.</i> in general, and especially among my brethren and friends that draw near to the L–rd, “drawing near means prayer”:<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tanchuma</i>, <i>Vayera</i> 8; see also <i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 49:8 and 93:6; <i>Aggadot Bereishit</i> 22:2.</i> after prayer or before it there is formed a “seat of scoffers,” the Merciful save us, as our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “Two who sit together, and there are no words of Torah between them….”<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 3:2.</i> And if a “seat of scoffers” is formed by ten, over which the <i>Shechinah</i> dwells, there is no greater insult and shaming of the <i>Shechinah</i> than that, the Merciful save us. And when our Sages, of blessed memory, said of him who commits a transgression in secret that “he repulses the feet of the <i>Shechinah</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Kiddushin</i> 31a.</i> Heaven forfend, he who commits a transgression in public repulses the whole measure of the stature of the Creator, as it were, as our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “It is impossible for Me and him…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sotah</i> 5a.</i> except that “the King is held captive in the tresses….”<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 7:6. The <i>Shechinah</i> is bound to Israel, regardless; thus, by their improper acts the <i>Shechinah</i> is drawn into exile with them, per force, as it were; see <i>Vayikra Rabbah</i> 31:4; <i>Tanchuma</i>, <i>Nitzavim</i> 3; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 6 (21b); <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 45.</i>
But woe to one who repulses the <i>Shechinah</i> when G–d will raise (the <i>Shechinah</i>) and say to her:<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 52:2.</i> “Awake, arise from the dust…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> II:7a.</i> and “For three things Israel is kept back in exile: because they repulse the <i>Shechinah</i>, and because they shame the <i>Shechinah</i>…,” as mentioned in the sacred <i>Zohar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:75b.</i>
Therefore, my beloved ones, my brethren and friends: do not commit this great evil and “Give glory to the L–rd your G–d before it grows dark,”<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 13:16.</i> i.e., between <i>Minchah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Afternoon Prayer.</i> and <i>Maariv</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Evening Prayer.</i> by studying in groups every weekday the <i>pnimiyut</i><sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The “inner part,” the “soul,” of the Torah: the esoteric teachings of the Torah.</i> of Torah, i.e., the Aggadah contained in the work <i>Eyn Yaakov</i>. For most of the secrets of the Torah are concealed in it,<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">In the Aggadah.</i> and it atones man’s sins, as explained in the writings of the Arizal.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">See Rabbi Schneur Zalman’s <i>Hilchot Talmud Torah</i> 2:2 (and notes, ad loc., in ed. N.Y., 2004); cf. Foreword to the commentary on <i>Shir Hashirim</i> attributed to Nachmanides. (On the Arizal, see above, Epistle 5, note 103.)</i> The revealed parts therein<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the nonmystical parts.</i> are the ways of G–d wherein man is to walk and (enable him) to devise counsels in his soul<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 13:3.</i> pertaining to matters of heaven<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Religious affairs.</i> and matters of the world,<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Secular affairs.</i> as is known to all the wise of heart.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Sifrei</i> on Deuteronomy 11:22; <i>Avot d’R. Nattan</i> 29:7.</i>
(They are) also to learn somewhat in <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, <i>Orach Chaim</i>, the laws that are essential to every person. Of this our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “Whoever studies <i>halachot</i> every day…”<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Megillah</i> 28b.</i>—referring to the clarified and adjudged rulings that are of practical relevance, as explained in the commentary of Rashi, ad loc.
On the holy Shabbat, toward the time of <i>Minchah</i>, they should occupy themselves with the laws of Shabbat. For “The law of Shabbat is important.”<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 12a; see <i>Rashi</i>, ad loc.</i> It is easy for man to stumble in it, Heaven forfend, even in the matter of a prohibition involving extirpation and stoning, because of a lack of knowledge, and “error in teaching amounts to intentional sin,”<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 4:13.</i> Heaven forfend. No need to mention (that the same applies to) the Rabbinic injunctions which are ever so numerous, and especially with respect to the prohibitions of <i>muktzeh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">That which is forbidden for use or handling on Shabbat and Festivals.</i> of which there are many; and as our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “The words of the <i>Soferim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">The Scribes, i.e., the Rabbis.</i> are more severe than the words of Torah.”<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Berachot</i> 1:4; <i>Eruvin</i> 21b.</i> For whoever transgresses the words of the Sages, even but a light injunction of theirs [as, for instance, he who eats before the evening prayer, and the like] is guilty of death,<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 4b.</i> just as one who transgresses the severe matters of the Torah.
And let no individual separate himself from the congregation, even to learn something else; rather, (each one is to participate) in whatever the congregation busies itself with. There is no need to mention that one should not leave if there are not ten without him; to him I apply the verse “And those that leave the L–rd shall be consumed…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 1:28.</i> as our Sages, of blessed memory, said with respect to every sacred matter.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Megillah</i> 4:4; cf. <i>Berachot</i> 8a.</i> For There is no holiness as the holiness of the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:81a.</i>—whereas “the Torah and the Holy One, blessed is He, are entirely one.”<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Above, note 23.</i>
Thus, whoever separates himself from the community…,<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Semachot</i> 2:10; Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Evel</i> 1:10.</i> but he who will listen to me shall dwell securely,<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 1:33.</i> and in his and in our own days Judah shall be saved and Jerusalem shall dwell securely<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Jeremiah 23:6 and 33:16.</i>—Amen, may this be (His) will.

Chapter 24

<b>TWENTY-FOUR.</b> My beloved, my brethren:
I beg you, do not act wickedly, friends that are beloved to their Maker and hateful to their inclination.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The inclination toward evil.—[The Hebrew passage is a play on words (יוצרי–יצרי), cf. <i>Berachot</i> 61a; <i>Rut Rabbah</i> 3:1.]</i> Let no one make himself wicked before the Omnipresent the one hour<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Par. <i>Eduyot</i> 5:6.</i> He has chosen of all day in which to gather and stand before Him [during that hour]. It is an auspicious time before Him to become revealed, to come into the miniature sanctuary<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The Synagogue; cf. <i>Megillah</i> 19a.</i> to attend to the Abode (<i>Shechinah</i>) of His Glory, “He who dwells with them in the midst of their impurity,”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 16:16; cf. <i>Yoma</i> 56b.</i> and to be available to those who seek and beseech Him and those who hope for Him.
Now, he who recounts his needs<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">He who focuses his prayers on his wants and needs.</i> shows of himself that he does not desire to contemplate and to see the manifestation of His majestic glory. Thus he becomes an impure chariot<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 15, note 24, for the connotation of the word “chariot.” This notion applies to the realm of impurity as well as to the realm of holiness; see above, Epistle 2, note 16.</i> to the “supernal fool,”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The principal aspect and source of the forces of evil; see below, note 9; <i>Torah Or</i>, <i>Hosafot Vayechi</i> 102c.</i> of whom it is said, “The fool does not desire understanding…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">“—but only that his heart may lay itself bare”; Proverbs 18:2. Cf. <i>Chovot Halevovot</i>, <i>Avodat Elokim</i>, ch. 4.</i> as mentioned in the <i>Zohar</i> and by the Arizal.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> I:179a f. and the comment. of R. Moses Zacuto, ad loc. (On the Arizal, see above, Epistle 5, note 103.)</i> This means, he does not desire to contemplate and to see the preciousness of the splendor of the greatness of the King of all kings, the Holy One, blessed is He, which becomes revealed in that hour above, and also below, to those who desire to look to His glory and greatness which wraps and vests itself in the words of the liturgy [which has been properly arranged for everyone] and becomes revealed to each according to his intellect and the root of his soul, as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 12:8.</i> “Man <i>yehulal</i> (is praised) according to his intellect,” the <i>ktiv</i><sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The textual writ, as opposed to the textual reading (cf. above, Epistle 19).</i> being: <i>yehalel</i> (praises).<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Thus reading: man praises (or prays) according to his intellect. The content of one’s prayer reflects one’s intellect and, correspondingly, the extent of revelation elicited by that prayer; cf. above, Epistle 12, and note 38, ad loc., for a similar interpretation.</i>
Now, the kingdom of heaven is similar to a kingdom on earth.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Berachot</i> 58a; <i>Zohar</i> I:197a.</i> It is customary for a king to have his might concealed in the innermost chambers, with several guards at the doors, (<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>so) that many people await for days and years to see his might and glory. And when he wishes to become revealed to all, he<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">For the allegory following, see <i>Zohar</i> II:131a-b (<i>Zohar</i> I:256a, sect. 22).</i> proclaims throughout his kingdom to gather and to stand before him in order to show them his majestic glory and the precious splendor of his greatness. Now, whoever will stand before him not caring to see him and busies himself with his needs, how inferior, foolish, and simple is he; he resembles an animal in the eyes of all<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 49:13, 21.—I.e., irrational.</i> in the eyes of all creatures.
Moreover, it is a dishonor to the king by demonstrating before him that to have pleasure and delight from looking at his glory and beauty is of no more esteem in his eyes than busying himself with his (own) needs. Also, it is a capital offense toward the king by demonstrating how he insults and dishonors the king before all who see. Of this it was said: “And the fools raise the insult.”<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 3:35.</i> This means to say that though he is a fool, he should not “raise the insult,” that the insult becomes apparent to all.
Our Sages, of blessed memory, therefore, ordained that with prayer one should be “as standing before the King.”<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 33a.</i> At least he should make himself appear as if he stands (before the king), to the sight of all who look with physical eyes at his actions and words, even though the fool has no thought. That is why all the prayers were ordained for the one who will contemplate on them properly. But he who does not show this makes himself guilty, at the risk of his life, and of him it was said in the sacred <i>Zohar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:131b; cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:256a.</i> that “he causes an insult against the supernal arrangement and shows that he is separate and has no part in the G–d of Israel,” the Merciful save us.
Therefore,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Par. <i>Bava Kama</i> 84b.</i> I come to act as an agent of our Sages, of blessed memory, to enact a decree to apply equally to every one: No idle talk is to be spoken<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">See references cited above, note 19, and commentary <i>Mikdash Melech</i>, ad loc.; <i>Sefer Chassidim</i>, sect. 18. See also <i>Mikdash Melech</i> on <i>Zohar</i> III:75b.</i> from the moment the <i>chazzan</i><sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Who leads the congregation in prayer.</i> begins to recite the prayer until the end of the last <i>Kaddish</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Prayer of sanctification of G–d’s Name.</i> at <i>Shacharit</i>, <i>Arvit</i>, and <i>Minchah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">See note to H. V. See also <i>Likkutei Levi Yitzchak</i> on this passage.</i>
