And he who will disobey wittingly shall sit on the ground and beg of three people to release him from the supernal excommunication. “As he will repent, he will be healed,”<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 6:10.</i> and fully retroactively, no excommunication will apply to him. For, from the very outset it applies only to those who rebel and revolt, who do not care at all to seek atonement from Heaven and from the creatures for this sin which calls for judgment.
Also, (this applies) only when they speak deliberately, with contempt, but not to one who forgets, or unwittingly uttered some words, for he does not require a release at all; “And G–d who is righteous examines the hearts and the kidneys.”<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 7:10.</i> Be Beneficient, O L–rd, to the good and to those who are upright in their hearts.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 125:4.</i>

Chapter 25

<b>TWENTY-FIVE.</b> “To comprehend the words of understanding”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Proverbs 1:2.</i> stated in the sacred book called <i>Tzavaat Harivash</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The Testament of R. Israel Baal Shem Tov (In English: Kehot, 1998).</i>—[though in fact it is not at all his testament,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Emended according to the glosses of the <i>Tzemach Tzedek</i> (<i>Kitzurim V’Hearot</i>, p. 40), and L. H.</i> and he did not ordain anything before his passing; they are mere gleanings of his pure sayings that were gathered, “gleanings upon gleanings,”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Par. <i>Taanit</i> 6b.</i> and (the compilers) did not know how to determine the phraseology exactly in its proper fashion. The connotation, however, is absolutely true.]
—we shall precede<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">For the passage in question see below, note 81.</i> with the saying of our Sages, of blessed memory: “Whoever is in a rage is as if he worships idols.”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:27b; III:179a, and 234b; <i>Zohar Chadash</i> 21a; Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Deot</i> 2:3. Cf. <i>Shabbat</i> 105b; <i>Nedarim</i> 22b.</i> The reason is clear to those that have understanding, because at the time of his anger faith has departed from him. For were he to believe that what happened to him is of the L–rd’s doing, he would not become angry at all.
And though it is a person possessed of free choice cursing him, or hitting him, or causing damage to his money, and therefore guilty according to the laws of man and the laws of Heaven for having chosen evil, nevertheless, as regards the person harmed—this was already decreed from Heaven, and “the Omnipresent has many agents.”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:36b; Rashi on Exodus 16:32.—See <i>Taanit</i> 18b; <i>Mechilta</i> and Rashi on Exodus 21:13; <i>Emunot Vedeot</i>, by R. Saadiah Gaon, 4:5. See also <i>Bamidbar Rabbah</i> 18:22; etc. <i>Maamarei Admur Hazaken Haketzarim</i>, p. 379 ff.</i>
And not only this, but even at that particular time when he hits or curses him, there is vested in him a force from G–d and “the breath of His mouth,”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 33:6.</i> blessed be He, which animates and sustains him, and as it is written: “For the L–rd told him: ‘curse!’”<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 16:10.</i> Now, where did He say (so) to Shimi? But this thought, that occurred in Shimi’s heart and mind, descended from G–d, and the “<i>breath of His mouth</i>—which animates—<i>all their hosts</i>” animated the spirit of Shimi at the time he spoke those words to David.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Sefer Hachinuch</i>, sect. 241 (cf. <i>Minchat Chinuch</i>, ad loc., and <i>Tanchuma</i>, <i>Vayikra</i> 7): <i>Reishit</i> <i>Chochmah</i>, <i>Shaar HaAnavah</i>, ch. 3. Cf. references cited above, note 7.</i> For if the “breath of His mouth,” blessed be He, had departed from the spirit of Shimi for a single moment, he could not have spoken at all.
(<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>And that is the meaning of “For the L–rd told him [at that very moment, indeed]: ‘curse David.’ Who then shall say…?”<sup>9</sup>
And as known what the Baal Shem Tov, of blessed memory, said<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, ch. 1, and cf. <i>Midrash Tehillim</i> 119:36. (See <i>Hayom Yom</i>, 26 Tishrei.)—See also the anthology <i>Sefer Baal Shem Tov al Hatorah</i>, section <i>Bereishit</i>, par. 48-51.</i> on the verse<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 119:89.</i> “Forever, O L–rd, Your word stands firm in the heavens”: The combinations of the letters wherewith the heavens were created, i.e., the fiat “Let there be a firmament…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 1:6; cf. <i>Mayim Rabbim 5636</i>, ch. 20.</i> stand and remain vested in the Heavens forever, to vivify and sustain them.
This is unlike the theory of the philosophers who deny individual providence.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Moreh Nevuchim</i> 3:17.</i> They, in their false imagination, compare the work of G–d, the Maker of Heaven and Earth, to the work of man and his schemes: when the metalsmith has completed a vessel, the vessel no longer needs the hands of the smith. For though his hands are removed from it, it remains intact by itself. But their eyes are bedaubed so that they cannot see<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 44:18.</i> the great difference between man’s work and schemes—[which is (the production of) something out of something (<i>yesh meyesh</i>), except that he changes the form and the image]—and the making of heaven and earth [which is <i>creatio ex nihilo</i> (<i>yesh meayin</i>)].
(The latter) is a wonder much greater than, for example, the splitting of the Red Sea—which the L–rd caused to go back “by a strong eastwind all that night…and the waters were divided.”<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 14:2.</i> If the wind had ceased but for a moment, the waters would again have flowed downward, as is their way and nature. They would not have stood upright as a wall, even though this characteristic of the water,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">To flow downward.</i> too, was created and innovated <i>ex nihilo</i> (<i>yesh meayin</i>). A wall of stones stands erect by itself, without any wind, but this is not of the nature of water. Now, <i>a fortiori</i>, and <i>a minori ad majus</i>, with respect to the creation of substantiality <i>ex nihilo</i> [which transcends nature and is more wondrous than the splitting of the Red Sea], how much more so would a withdrawal, Heaven forfend, of the force of the Creator [(bringing about) substantiality <i>ex nihilo</i>] from the creature, cause the creature to revert to absolute naught and nothingness! The operative force<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">The force of the Creator.</i> thus needs to remain constantly in the effect,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">The creature.</i> to vivify and sustain it.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Kuzari</i> 3:11.</i> This aspect is the “word of the L–rd” and the “breath of His mouth” of the ten fiats wherewith the universe was created.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 4:1; see above, Epistle 5, note 79.</i>
And even this material world, and the inorganic class in it, their vivification and sustenance is the “word of the L–rd” of the ten fiats that has become vested in them and sustains them to be inorganic matter and substantiality <i>ex nihilo</i>, so that they will not revert to the absolute naught and nothingness they had been.
And this is the meaning of the statement of the Arizal,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Etz Chaim</i> 39:3; see also ibid., 50; <i>et passim</i>. Cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 38 and Part II, ch. 1. (On the Arizal, see above, Epistle 5, note 103.)</i> that there is a type of soul and spiritual vivification even in inorganic matter as stones, and dust, and water.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">This whole section (from “what the Baal Shem Tov said” onward) is a resume of the first two chapters of <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II.</i>
Now it is known to the students of Kabbalah that the “word of the L–rd” is referred to as <i>Shechinah</i>, in the terminology of our Sages, of blessed memory, and as <i>imma tataah</i> and <i>matronita</i>, in the terminology of the <i>Zohar</i> [especially at the beginning of section <i>Vaeyra</i>], because it dwells and vests itself in the creatures to vivify them.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">See Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, s.v. <i>Malchut</i>; cf. above, Epistle 8. See also <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 23:4.</i>
In the terminology of the Kabbalists it is called <i>malchut</i>, relating to “The word of the king is regnant,”<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 8:4; see comment., ad loc.</i> because the king conducts his kingdom through his edict, and also for other reasons known to the students of Kabbalah.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. above, Epistle 20, notes 47 and 49.</i>
Now it is known that there is a rank and level of <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, and a rank of <i>malchut</i> of <i>Beriah</i>….
<i>Malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> is the “word of the L–rd” which vivifies and brings into being the great souls that are of the rank of <i>Atzilut</i>, as the soul of Adam of whom it is said, “He breathed into his nostrils a soul of life,”<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">(Emended according to <i>Kitzurim V’Hearot</i>, p. 40, and L. H.).—Genesis 2:7; see above, Epistle 12, note 48.</i> and as the souls of the patriarchs, and the prophets, and the like (<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>who were truly a “chariot for G–d” and in a state of self-abnegation in relation to Him.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 15, note 24.</i> Thus our Sages, of blessed memory, said:<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> III:232a; ibid., 306b. Cf. <i>Shemot Rabbah</i> 3:15 and comment. by R. David Luria, ad loc.; <i>Zohar</i> III:7a and 265a.</i> “The <i>Shechinah</i> speaks from the throat of Moses,”<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., Moses was but a passive tool for the speech of the <i>Shechinah</i>, as if he himself did not exist as a separate entity. Cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 34.</i> and likewise with all the prophets and those possessed of the Holy Spirit: the Supernal Voice and Speech vested itself in their actual voice and speech, as mentioned by the Arizal).
<i>Malchut of</i> <i>Beriah</i> is the “word of the L–rd” which vivifies and brings into being the souls and angels in the realm of <i>Beriah</i>, whose level is not like the level of <i>Atzilut</i>….
And <i>malchut</i> of <i>Asiyah</i> is the “word of the L–rd” which vivifies and brings into this world, in its totality, including the element of dust, and the water that is below the earth.
(<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>However, in the countries of the heathens<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">L. H. substitutes nations for this and all subsequent instances of heathens.</i> the vivification is by way of an investment of the extraneous patron-angels (<i>sarim hachitzonim</i>) that are appointed over the seventy nations.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> III: beg. of 244a (<i>Raaya Mehemma</i>); <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 24 (69a).</i> That is, a spark from the “word of the L–rd,” called <i>malchut</i> of <i>Asiyah</i>, descends and radiates over the supernal patron-angels in a way of encompassing from aloft, but does not truly vest itself in them. Rather, the vivification issues to them from this radiation shining over them from aloft, in a mode of encompassment.
And from the patron-angels vivification issues to the heathens, and to the cattle, beasts, and fowl that are in their lands, and to the physical earth, and to the physical heavens, i.e., the planets.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 32 (76b).</i> (<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>However, the heavens and the earth, and the cattle, beasts, and fowl that are pure, are influenced by the <i>kelipat nogah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">See note following.</i> The impure (animals) and the souls of the heathens, however, are (influenced) by the other <i>kelipot</i>.)<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">G–d has made one thing opposite the other (Ecclesiastes 7:14; see above, Epistle 2, note 16). Everything in one realm has a corresponding opposite in another realm. The realm of holiness, sanctity, and parity, thus, is opposed by a realm of impurity. The realm of impurity itself is subdivided into two principal classes: the three altogether impure <i>kelipot</i>, containing no good whatsoever in themselves, and <i>kelipat nogah</i>, an intermediate category between the three <i>kelipot</i> mentioned and the order of holiness. Dependent on the motives and actions of man, <i>kelipat nogah</i> is absorbed in one or the other of these two realms. It is a sort of potential <i>kelipah</i>, which can be sublimated and developed, or may fall among the wholly impure kelipot. See Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, s.v. <i>Kelipot</i>.</i>
Now, in the lands of the heathens, the heavens and the earth and all they contain, are all esteemed as truly nothing in relation to the patron-angels—which are their vivification and sustenance.
The patron-angels themselves are esteemed as truly nothing in relation to the vivification issuing to them from the spark of the “word of the L–rd,” which radiates over them from aloft. And even so, the vivification issuing to them from this radiation is in them in a state of exile. That is why they are called <i>elohim acherim</i> (other gods)<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 22, note 37.</i> [while they call <i>Him</i>—“G–d of the gods”<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Menachot</i> 110a; see comment. by <i>Maharsha</i>, ad loc.</i>], as if they, too, are in the category of Divinity.
The heathens who are influenced by them, therefore, are truly idolaters, until the time of the end when death and the <i>sitra achara</i><sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">The other side; the realm of evil.</i> will be swallowed up,<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Isaiah 23:8. See <i>Zohar</i> I:54a; also ibid., 29a and 34a; <i>et passim</i>.</i> and “then I shall turn to the nations …that they may all call by the Name of the L–rd.”<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Zephaniah 3:9.</i> This is also referred to as the “exile of the <i>Shechinah</i>.” For this vivification, in a state of exile within them, stems from the radiation issuing to them from the spark of the “word of the L–rd” called <i>Shechinah</i>. (<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>And this exile stems from the sin of the Tree of Knowledge and onward,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 19:7 (and its parallel instances).</i> and is a rank of mere <i>achorayim</i> of holiness.
But when the Israelites were exiled to be among the nations—and the attachment and root of the Israelites is in the rank of the supernal face (<i>panim</i>)<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pnimiyut</i>; see above, Epistle 4, note 9.</i>—this became a total exile. Of this our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “When they were exiled to Edom, the <i>Shechinah</i> went with them.”<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mechilta</i> on Exodus 12:41; <i>Sifrei</i> on Numbers 10:35 and 35:34; <i>Megillah</i> 29a (acc. to v.s. of <i>Eyn Yaakov</i>, ad loc.). Cf. Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Taanit</i> 1: end of 1.</i>))
Now, though “the L–rd is one, and His Name is one”<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 14:9.</i> [that is, His speech and the “breath of His mouth,” which in the sacred <i>Zohar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 22 (66b).</i> is referred to as His Name, is singularly and uniquely one], nevertheless, the radiation and efflux of vivification, issuing forth from the breath of His mouth, blessed be He, divides into four different levels. These are the four worlds <i>Atzilut</i>, <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>.
The difference is due to (<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>many) contractions and curtailments—screening and concealing the light and vivification so that it will not radiate in the world of <i>Beriah</i> as much as in the world of <i>Atzilut</i>; and in the world of <i>Yetzirah</i> it is by means of further contractions and curtailments….<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">See Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, s.v. Worlds.</i> However, there is no change whatsoever, Heaven forfend, in the essence of the <i>Shechinah</i>, i.e., the “word of the L–rd” and the “breath of His mouth.”
Also, as regards the radiation and efflux of vivification, the radiation which is in <i>Atzilut</i> pierces the curtailment and vests itself in <i>Beriah</i>. Likewise from <i>Beriah</i> to <i>Yetzirah</i>, and from <i>Yetzirah</i> to <i>Asiyah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 20, and note 92, ad loc.</i> Thus it follows that the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, which is in <i>Atzilut</i>, is also in <i>Asiyah</i> and in this material world through its investment in the <i>malchut</i> of <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>, as everything is explained in the writings of the Arizal.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">See references cited above, Epistle 20, note 92.</i>
Now, it is known to all that the soul of man is compounded of the ten <i>sefirot</i>: <i>chochmah</i>, <i>binah</i>, <i>daat</i>, and so on.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 12.</i> Though they are all of the breath of His mouth, blessed be He, [as it is written: “He breathed into his nostrils…”<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 2:7; see above, Epistle 12, note 46.</i>], nevertheless, more specifically the <i>chabad </i><sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chochmah</i>, <i>binah</i>, <i>daat</i>.</i> in his soul are analogous to the <i>chabad</i> in the ten <i>sefirot</i>, referred to as <i>abba</i> and <i>imma</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">See Addendum, ibid., s.v. <i>Partzufim</i>; above, Epistle 15, note 9; Epistle 19, note 11.</i> and the attributes of love and fear, and so forth, in his soul are analogous to the <i>middot</i> in the ten <i>sefirot</i>, referred to as <i>z’eyr anpin</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid.</i> and the faculty of speech in his soul is analogous to the Supernal Speech, referred to as <i>malchut</i>, and <i>Shechinah</i>. Hence, when speaking words of Torah one arouses the supernal speech to unify the <i>Shechinah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> III:105a; cf. ibid., 31b.</i> That is why it is established that for the reading of the <i>Shema</i>, the Blessing after a Meal, and words of Torah, one has not discharged his duty by meditation without speech.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hilchot Talmud Torah</i> 2:12; <i>Shulchan Aruch HaRav</i>, <i>Orach Chaim</i> 62:3 and 185:3. <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, <i>Yoreh Deah</i> 246:22.</i>
Now, with one opposite the other,<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 7:14; see above, Epistle 2, note 16.</i> there are “ten crowns of impurity.”<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Corresponding to the ten holy <i>sefirot</i>. <i>Zohar</i> III:41b; 70a. Cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:167a; <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 6.</i> From these issue the souls of the heathens, also comprised of precisely those ten ranks. And it is common knowledge that<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 12:5.</i> which has been stated in <i>Sefer Hagilgulim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Ch. 2; quoted by <i>Taalumot Chochmah</i> on Ecclesiastes 8:9; see also <i>Or Hatorah</i>, <i>Neviim Ketuvim</i>, vol. 2, p. 1129 ff.</i> on the verse “That man rules in man, to his evil,”<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 8:9.</i> that it refers to the mystery of the <i>Shechinah’s</i> exile in the <i>kelipot</i> in order to vivify them, and to empower them to rule, now,<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Text corrected according to L. H.</i> in the time of the exile; but it is “to his evil….” And that is why the heathens dominate now<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Text corrected according to L. H.</i> over Israel. For the souls of the heathens are of the <i>kelipot</i>, in which the <i>Shechinah</i> is vested in a state of exile. Though this requires extensive exposition (as to) how and what, it is, nevertheless, fact.
Despite this, the <i>kelipot</i> and heathens receive their nurture and vivification only from an aspect extended to them, of the <i>achorayim</i> of holiness, “as with one who casts away behind his shoulders.”<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 22, note 38; <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 22.</i> And even that is by way of numerous and immense contractions and curtailments until this radiation became vested in the materiality of this world and diffuses wealth and honor, and all physical pleasures, to the heathens.
The Israelites, however, elicit from the aspect of the supernal face,<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Panim</i> (as opposed to <i>achorayim</i>).</i> as it is written: “May the L–rd make His face shine upon you,”<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 6:23.</i> in each one according to the root of his soul, even up to the peak of levels.
After these words and this truth,<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Par. II Chronicles 32:1.</i> manifest and known to all, we shall return to our original subject with respect to anger—that one is as an idolater. This is so with respect to mundane matters, because “Everything is in the hands of Heaven except for the fear of Heaven.”<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 33b.</i> Hence, with respect to matters of Heaven, “to warn off from wrongdoing,”<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 40b.</i> the reason stated does not apply, and as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 31:14.</i>: “And Moses was enraged.”<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> I:184a; II:182a-b; <i>Zohar Chadash</i> 21a; Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Deot</i> 1:4; comment. of R. Yonah on <i>Avot</i> 5:11.</i> This is different because G–d caused him to encounter this <i>mitzvah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 19:17; see <i>Shabbat</i> 54b; Maimonides, <i>Sefer Hamitzvot</i> 1:205 and <i>Hilchot Deot</i> 6:7.</i> of “warning off from wrongdoing” in order to make him meritorious.<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Mishnah, <i>Makkot</i> 3:16.</i>
But this applies (only) when he is able to prevent<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Wrongdoing.</i> by his wrath and anger against his fellow man.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Yevamot</i> 65b, <i>Rashi</i> (s.v. <i>Lomar</i>), and comm. by <i>Maharsha</i>, ad loc.</i> However, when he is unable to prevent, as in the case of<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">The author now passes over to the original subject of the letter, i.e., the passage in <i>Tzavaat Harivash</i> §120: “Also, when you hear someone speaking while you pray, say: ‘Why did G–d bring him here to speak while I pray? All this must be by <i>hashgachah peratit</i> (Divine Providence relating to all particulars). Speech is identified with the <i>Shechinah</i>. The <i>Shechinah</i> thus is vested in the mouth of that person in order that I strengthen myself for the service [of G–d]. How much, then, must I strengthen myself in the “service, i.e., prayer,” especially if that man speaking is a gentile or a minor.’ It follows, then, that the <i>Shechinah</i> is, as it were, in that person; thus it is but appropriate for you to act with alacrity.” Cf. also <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 28.</i> the heathen speaking and disturbing him in his prayer, (the question) then (arises), what that is this that G–d has done to him? It is but in order that he prevail and strengthen himself ever more in his prayer, in the profundity of the heart, and with so great a concentration that he will not hear the words of the heathen.
However, for such a level one needs a great and immense arousal.
And the counsel suggested for such an arousal is from the subject matter itself. He should consider and contemplate on the idea of the descent of the <i>Shechinah</i>, as it were: “She descended in wondrous fashion”<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Lamentations 1:9.</i> to have a spark of her radiation invested. Thus she is in a state of exile among the <i>kelipot</i>, in a general way, in order to animate them. And now again, a spark of her radiation vests itself in a state of exile, in a particular way, in the speech of this heathen who speaks words that disturb the service of the L–rd, i.e., the devotion of prayer. And as explained above, one opposite the other…, thus the supernal speech vests itself in the nether speech…. Now this is truly “That man rules in man, to his evil”; that is, <i>because of this</i> man is aroused to pray with greater devotion, from the profundity of the heart, until he will not hear his words.
As for the compiler<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Of <i>Tzavaat Harivash</i>.</i> writing “<i>sharta</i>” (dwelled), he did not know to determine the precise term. For the Baal Shem Tov, of blessed memory, used to deliver Torah discourses in the Yiddish tongue, and not in the sacred tongue. He meant to say: “<i>nitlabsha</i>” (became vested)—that is, in a state of exile. And that is the meaning of “especially if he is a heathen…,”<sup>81</sup> for then there is so much more of a state of exile.
There is no need to wonder at a spark of the <i>Shechinah’s</i> illumination being referred to as <i>Shechinah</i>. Thus we find that even a created angel is referred to as G–d: in the section of <i>Vayera</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 18:3.</i> according to the commentary of R. Moses Nachmanides, and as it is written: “And she called the name of the L–rd who spoke to her…”;<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 16:13 (see preceding verses).</i> and many more (passages) like this.
It would seem to me that their seizing (this passage) is not because of the accuracy of the phraseology but with respect to the very idea of the investment of the <i>Shechinah</i> in the <i>kelipot</i>. For they do not believe what the Arizal wrote in <i>Sefer Hagilgulim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Above, note 65.</i> Should they want to distinguish between the spiritual <i>kelipot</i> and the physical idolaters, you have nothing more physical than the dust of the earth; nevertheless, the <i>malchut</i> of <i>malchut</i> of <i>Asiyah</i> vests itself in it, and within that the <i>malchut</i> of <i>Yetzirah</i>…, and as mentioned above.<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. also <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, chs. 6 and 51 (and references cited there).</i> And should it be because of the impurity of the souls of the heathens, verily, their souls are from the <i>conjunctio</i> of the masculine and feminine (<i>zivug zu’n</i>)<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. above, Epistle 20, note 38.</i> of the spiritual <i>kelipot</i>, as mentioned in the writings of the Arizal. Hence it follows that the spiritual (<i>kelipot</i>) are the source of their impurity!
But in truth, this requires extensive elucidation regarding this investment. But this complaint does not apply to us, but to the writings of the Arizal. And let not he who hears (this) suspect me that I imagine to have understood the words of the Arizal, to divest them from their physical connotation. I came but to explain the words of the Baal Shem Tov, of blessed memory, and of his disciples, according to the Kabbalah of the Arizal, especially since this matter is not of the science of the Kabbalah and of the things “secret to the L–rd our G–d,”<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Deuteronomy 29:28.</i> but of the “things revealed to us and to our children”<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid.</i>—to believe in full faith in the explicit verse, spoken by Scripture: “Do I, then, not fill the heavens and the earth, says the L–rd.”<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 23:24.</i> For Scripture does not lose its plain meaning.<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 63a.</i>
Also, it is a simple article of faith among the general totality of Israel, handed down to them by their saintly ancestors, who walked in wholeness with the L–rd without searching the concept of Divinity by means of the human intellect, for it is infinitely beyond the intellect to know how He fills the earth.
But new ones have recently come<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Deuteronomy 32:17.</i> to examine this problem, and it is impossible to make them understand except by means of premises taken from the writings of the Arizal, divested from their physical connotation, and according to what I heard from my masters, may their souls rest in Eden. However, it is impossible to explain this clearly in writing, only orally to “the ear that hears,”<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">See Proverbs 15:31 and 23:12.</i> to adept individuals, and to “the remnants whom the L–rd calls,”<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 3:5.</i> as it is written: “And they who seek the L–rd understand all,”<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 28:5.</i> and from the affirmative you may infer….<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">The negative (<i>Sifrei</i>, Deuteronomy, sect. 46).</i>
You have now seen an explanation of a single passage from the well known books as a sample and token that indeed all “astonishing passages” have an explanation and meaningfulness for the students of Kabbalah. However, let them not hope for me to explain everything in writing. That is a hard and extensive labor and absolutely impossible. But if you so desire, send from among you one who is “outstanding in the congregation,”<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">(Cf. <i>Sanhedrin</i> 13b).</i> and, G–d willing, I will talk to him “face to face.” And may the L–rd be with my mouth when my words will flow, and may the utterances of my mouth find favor.<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 19:15.</i>

Chapter 26

<b>TWENTY-SIX.</b> In <i>Raaya Mehemna</i>, section of <i>Nasso</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:124b-125a.</i> (it is stated): “‘And they that are wise shall shine as the splendor of the firmament’<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 12:3.</i> with this work of yours,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Of R. Shimon bar Yochai.</i> which is the Book of Splendor (<i>Sefer HaZohar</i>)—of the splendor of the <i>imma ilaah</i>, repentance;<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Imma ilaah</i> (the sphere of <i>binah</i>) corresponds to <i>teshuvah ilaah</i>; see above, Epistle 8, note 23.</i> with these no trial is needed. Because in time to come Israel will taste of the Tree of Life, which is the book of the <i>Zohar</i>, and through which they will leave their exile with mercy. And through them shall be realized that ‘The L–rd alone will lead him, and there is no strange god with Him.’<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 32:12.</i>
And the Tree of Good and Evil,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">The Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil (contrasted with the Tree of Life; cf. Genesis 2:9).</i> i.e., prohibition and permission, impurity and purity, will no longer domineer over Israel. Their sustenance will be from the side of the Tree of Life alone. There, there is no question from the side of evil and no disagreement from the spirit of impurity,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">All problems and disagreements are due to the forces of evil which becloud the issue.</i> as it is written: ‘And the spirit of impurity I shall remove from the earth.’<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 13:2.</i> Thus the scholars of Torah will no longer be sustained by illiterate persons (<i>amey haaretz</i>), but from the side of the good, by those who consume what is pure, kosher, permitted; nor<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Will they be sustained.</i> by the mixed multitude (<i>erev rav</i>)—who consume what is impure, unfit, prohibited…. But while the Tree of Good and Evil domineers…, these Sages, who are compared to Shabbat and Festivals,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> III: 29a-b.</i> have nothing save what is given to them by those profane ones, analogous to the day of Shabbat which has but what has been prepared for it on a weekday.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Avodah Zarah</i> 3a.—(Weekday; lit., a day of the profane, as opposed to holy.)</i>
“However, when the Tree of Life will dominate, the Tree of Good and Evil will be suppressed and the illiterate persons will have but what the scholars of Torah give them. They will be subjugated to them as if they did not exist in the world. Accordingly, the prohibited, the permitted, the impure, and the pure will not be removed from the illiterate persons. As regards them—‘There is no difference between the exile and the days of the Messiah, except for the (delivery from) servitude to the nations.’<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Berachot</i> 34b.—Thus merely a physical, and not a spiritual, redemption.</i> For they did not taste of the Tree of Life and will require the teachings of proscription and permission, impurity and purity.” Until here from the <i>Raaya Mehemna</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">On this quotation from the <i>Zohar</i>, and on the subject-matter which follows, see at length: R. Moses Cordovero, <i>Or Ne’erav</i>, esp. pts. 4 and 5; R. Chaim Vital’s Introduction to <i>Shaar Hahakdamot</i> (published in all recent editions as Introduction to <i>Etz Chaim</i>, and reproduced in <i>Kuntres Etz HaChaim</i>, by R. Shalom Dov Ber of Lubavitch (N.Y. 1956), p. 61 ff.); R. Dov Ber of Lubavitch’s Introduction to <i>Biurei Hazohar</i>; <i>Kuntres Etz HaChaim</i>, op. cit. above, ch. 13 ff. (pp. 41 ff.), and R. Shalom Dov Ber encyclical, ibid. (pp. 82 ff.). See also <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Vayikra</i> 3d ff.</i>
Now, at first glance, what appears evident to those unfamiliar with the subject matter<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Lit.: those lacking knowledge.</i> from the contents of this passage is that the study of [the laws of] ritual prohibition and permission,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Proscription and permission.</i> and of the Order of <i>Taharot</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The sixth order of the Mishnah, dealing with the laws of purity and impurity.</i> relates only to the Tree of Good and Evil. This is greatly surprising in itself and contradicts the plain meaning of Scripture and the expositions of our Sages, of blessed memory. For the <i>whole</i> Torah that has been revealed to us and to our children is called “A tree of life for those who hold fast to it,”<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 3:18.</i> and not only the Book of the <i>Zohar</i>. Moreover, it<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>Zohar</i>.</i> was concealed in their days; also,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., not only the <i>Zohar</i>, but etc.</i> the whole science of the Kabbalah was hidden in their days and concealed from all the scholars of Torah, except for a select few, and even then in a mode of “walking hiddenly”<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Micah 6:8.</i> and not publicly, as mentioned in the Gemara.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chagigah</i> 11b and 13a. <i>Pesachim</i> 119a; cf. <i>Kiddushin</i> 71a.</i>
Thus the Arizal<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 5, note 103.</i> wrote that it is only in these latter generations that it is permitted and a duty to reveal this science, but not so in the earlier generations.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">See Introduction to <i>Etz Chaim</i> (cit. above, note 13); <i>Shaar Hagilgulim</i>, end of <i>hakd</i>. 16; see also ibid., <i>hakd</i>. 17; Intro. to <i>Shaar Hamitzvot</i>; Arizal, <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, s.v. <i>Keriah Bechochmat Hakabbalah</i>, par. 3; <i>Hilchot Talmud Torah</i> (of the author) 1:4 and 2:10.</i> R. Shimon bar Yochai, too, stated in the sacred <i>Zohar</i> that the permission to reveal was given to him and his associates only.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:159a. See also ibid., II:149a, and III:79a; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 1a.</i>
Now, this itself, too, is a wondrous marvel. For if so, then the study of [the laws of] ritual prohibition and permission, and, <i>a fortiori</i>, of civil laws, should not defer the precept of prayer [which is arranged according to the secrets of the <i>Zohar</i> and the supreme unifications (<i>yichudim</i>)] for those who are familiar with them such as R. Shimon bar Yochai and his associates. But this is not the case, as mentioned in the Gemara<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 11a. Cf. <i>Nitzutzei Orot</i> (by R. Chaim David Azulai) on <i>Zohar</i> II:188a and <i>Hilchot Talmud Torah</i> 4:5.</i>: R. Shimon bar Yochai and his associates, and everyone whose study of Torah is his profession,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:238b.</i> do not interrupt (their study) for prayer.
(This applies) even when dealing with civil laws, like Rav Yehudah, all of whose studies dealt with <i>Nezikin</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">The fourth of the six orders of the Mishnah, dealing with torts.—<i>Berachot</i> 20a.</i> nevertheless, he prayed but every thirty days when reviewing his studies, as mentioned in the Gemara.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 35a.</i>
Also, in the Jerusalem Talmud, first chapter of <i>Berachot</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">End of sect. 2; also ibid., <i>Shabbat</i> 1:2.</i> R. Shimon bar Yochai is of the opinion that even for the reading of the <i>Shema</i> one interrupts only (the study of) Scripture, but not of Mishnah, [(the study of) which is superior to (the study of) Scripture, according to R. Shimon bar Yochai]. And he did not differentiate between the Order of <i>Zera’im</i>, <i>Moed</i> and <i>Kodshim</i>, and <i>Taharot</i> and <i>Nezikin</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">See H. V., ad loc.</i> (<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>Actually he contradicts his own opinion, given in several instances in <i>Raaya Mehemna</i>, that Mishnah is the <i>shifchah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Maidservant.</i>…and Scripture, the Torah of Moses, is surely superior to the Kabbalah, which is the <i>matronita</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Matron.</i> (as stated) in the <i>Raaya Mehemna</i>, ad loc., while the Written Torah is the <i>malkah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">King.</i> (<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>that is, the <i>yesod</i> of <i>abba</i> vested in <i>z’eyr anpin</i>, as stated by the Arizal<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shaar Hamitzvot</i>, <i>Va’etchanan</i> sect. 1.</i>).)<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> I:27b-28a; III:29b; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 14a-b. See Intro. to <i>Etz Chaim</i>.</i>
Also, we find that R. Shimon bar Yochai dealt a great deal with the argumentation of problems and solutions which are of the side of evil and of the spirit of impurity,<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">See above, note 7. See also <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Additions 9 (147a); ibid., 10 (147b), <i>et passim</i>, and cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:27b (<i>Raaya Mehemna</i>).</i> even when he was in the cave. Moreover, he merited this by virtue of the affliction of the cave, as it is stated in the Gemara<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 33b.</i> that he gave R. Pinchas ben Yair twenty-four solutions to every query, and said to him: “If you had not seen me like this….” (<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>In fact, their principal occupation in the cave must have been with the teachings of the <i>Mishnayot</i>, i.e., the six hundred Orders extant in those days,<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Chagigah</i> 14a; cf. <i>Teshuvot Hageonim</i>—<i>Shaarei Teshuvah</i>, sect. 20 and 187; <i>Machzor Vitry</i>, ed. Hurwitz, vol. 2, p. 484; <i>Yalkut Reuveni</i>, <i>Berachah</i> (s.v. <i>Mimot Moshe</i>).</i> until (the time of) our holy Master.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">R. Judah the Prince, editor of the Mishnah.</i> The <i>Zohar</i> and the <i>Tikkunim</i> he could have finished in two or three months, for surely he did not repeat the same thing twice.)
Also, our Sages, of blessed memory, said that since the day the Temple was destroyed, the Holy One, blessed is He, has but the four cubits of <i>halachah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 8a.</i>
There is yet further cause to be exceedingly amazed. How is it possible that in the days of the Messiah they will no longer need to know the laws of ritual prohibition and permission, and of impurity and purity? How will they slaughter the sacrifices, and also (the animals) for common use, when they will not know the laws of <i>drassah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Pressing, i.e., making the cut by pressing upon the knife.</i> <i>chaladah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Passing, i.e., passing the knife under cover by making the incision from behind the pipes outwardly, rather than in the reverse manner.</i> and <i>shehiyah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Pausing, i.e., pausing or interrupting the act of slaughter.</i> [which render the slaughtering unfit],<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">These are three of the five procedural invalidations of <i>Shechitah</i> against which the slaughterer must guard (the other two being <i>hagramah</i>, cutting in a slanting direction, and <i>ikkur</i>—the severing of the pipes by a tearing action); <i>Chullin</i> 9a and 27a.</i> and of a defective knife?<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Which also renders the slaughtering unfit (<i>Chullin</i> 17b; etc).</i> Will there then be born a man who by his very nature will slaughter without <i>shehiyah</i> and <i>drassah</i>? Will the knife also be the way it should be, and remain forever without a defect?
(There are) also many more laws (relating to) fat, and blood, and other prohibitions. They will also need to know about the impurity of a corpse, as it is written: “The youth of a hundred years old will die.”<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 65:20.</i> It will be further necessary to know about the impurity of a woman who has given birth, as it is written: “A pregnant woman and one who gives birth together.”<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 31:7. I.e., both of these will be restored to the Holy Land at the redemption.</i> If a woman will bear children every day, from one marital union,<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Shabbat</i> 30b. (See <i>Likkutei Sichot</i>, vol. 12, pg. 178).</i> nevertheless, the law with respect to the prohibition of her impurity does not change.
There is no need to dwell on something so obvious. The reverse<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">The reverse of the proposition that the laws will no longer be relevant.</i> is well known from throughout the Talmud and the Midrashim: [that] “An objection was raised that the law is the same for the time of the Messiah,”<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 51b.</i> and Elijah comes to clarify all doubts;<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Eduyot</i> 8:7 and commentaries, ad loc.</i> and “This section, Elijah will expound in the future….”<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Menachot</i> 45a.</i>
The statement that “the scholars of Torah will no longer be sustained by the illiterate (<i>amey haaretz</i>)…nor by the mixed multitude (<i>erev rav</i>), who consume what is unfit, impure, and prohibited,” Heaven forfend, is also not understandable. Even<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Emended according to <i>Kitzurim V’Hearot</i>, p. 40, and L. H.</i> during the time of the second Temple they were not sustained by the “illiterate persons who consume what is unfit and prohibited,” Heaven forfend. For the scholars of Torah had fields and vineyards just like the illiterate persons, but nevertheless busied themselves with the study of [the laws of] ritual prohibition and permission, and of impurity and purity [all the pairs<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">The pairs of the leading scholars (set <i>Avot</i>, ch. 1).</i> that lived at the time of the second Temple], and they raised disciples in the thousands and myriads, but the study of the esoteric was in secret….
But, in truth, when you will examine closely the above-quoted text of the <i>Raaya Mehemna</i>—“And the Tree of Good and Evil, i.e., prohibition and permission…” (you will note that) he did not say “the <i>teaching</i> of prohibition and permission” or “the <i>laws of</i> prohibition and permission.” Rather, he meant to say that “that which is prohibited,” and “that which is permitted” is of the Tree of Good and Evil, i.e., of <i>kelipat nogah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">The potential <i>kelipah</i>.</i> as stated in <i>Etz Chaim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Etz Chaim</i> 49:2 ff.</i>
That, too, is the etymological meaning of <i>assur</i>:<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Prohibited; lit., bound.</i> the <i>kelipah</i> hovers over it and it cannot rise upward like that which is <i>muttar</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Permitted; lit., released.</i> i.e., it is not tied and bound (<i>assur</i>) to the <i>kelipah</i> and is able to ascend by means of the person consuming it with his mind on G–d,<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. above, Epistle 18, note 37.</i> or by any person serving G–d.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, chs. 7 and 8; above, Epistle 25, note 39.</i> For it is with the energy from this consumption that he studies and prays to G–d. Thus, from the energy extracted from that food are formed the the letters of Torah and of the prayers which ascend to G–d.
This is so during the week. But on Shabbat, the <i>kelipat nogah</i> itself is elevated along with the <i>chitzoniyut</i> of all the worlds.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Etz Chaim</i> 50:6; ibid., 40:8 (<i>et passim</i>); the Lurianic works dealing with devotions (<i>Shaar Hakavanot</i>; <i>Pri Etz Chaim</i>; etc.), s.v. the Eve of Shabbat; cf. <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 16:4, 5. See also <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, end of ch. 10.</i> On Shabbat it is, therefore, a duty to eat all delightful things, and to consume much meat and wine,<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, <i>Orach Chaim</i> 250:2; ed. of the author 242:12.</i> even though during the week<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">When consuming much meat and wine during the week (for no sacred purpose). See <i>Sanhedrin</i> 70a ff; Proverbs 23:10 and <i>Metzudot David</i> ad loc.</i> he would be called a glutton and drunkard.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> II:218a and <i>Mikdash Melech</i>, ad loc.; <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 7 f.</i>
It is otherwise with a proscribed matter. It cannot ascend, either on Shabbat or during the weekdays, even if one were to pray and study with that energy [unless one ate to save an endangered life, which is permitted by our Sages, of blessed memory,<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yoma</i> 82a; see <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, <i>Orach Chaim</i>, sect. 617 and 618.</i> and becomes permissible (<i>hetter</i>)<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Our text reads: “(fully) permissible”—though this bracketed word does not appear in some of the earlier editions and should probably be omitted; see <i>Igrot Kodesh</i> by the Lubavitcher Rebbe, vol. 1, pp. 238-239 in the notes; <i>Likkutei Sichot</i>, vol. 3, p. 985, note 16.</i>].
But the study of Torah, even the laws of ritual prohibition and permission, impurity and purity [i.e., the <i>Mishnayot</i>, and the <i>Beraitot</i> in the Gemara, and the codifiers, which expound and clarify their words for practical application], these, precisely these are the fundamentals of the Oral Torah, which is the <i>sefirah</i> <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, as mentioned in innumerable places in the sacred <i>Zohar</i> and at the beginning of the <i>Tikkunim</i>:<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Introduction 17a.</i> “<i>Malchut</i>—the mouth, which we call the Oral Torah.” And in <i>Atzilut</i> “He and His causations are one in them,”<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 3b; see above, beg. of Epistle 20.</i> that is, the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, unites itself in <i>Atzilut</i> in an absolute unity, so that He, and His will and wisdom [vested in His speech, which is called <i>malchut</i><sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 20, note 49.</i>] are entirely one.
The Arizal, in stating<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">See Arizal, <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, s.v. <i>Kavanat Talmud Torah</i>, par. 3; <i>Shaar Hamitzvot</i>, <i>Va’etchanan</i>.</i> that the <i>Mishnayot</i> are in <i>malchut</i> of <i>Yetzirah</i>, meant to say the garment of <i>malchut</i> of <i>Yetzirah</i> in which <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> is vested.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>Mishnayot</i>, the <i>sefirah</i> <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, are vested in <i>malchut</i> of <i>Yetzirah</i>. <i>Malchut</i> of <i>Yetzirah</i> serves as a garment for <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>.</i> And <i>malchut</i> of <i>Yetzirah</i> is called <i>shifchah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Maidservant. Cf. above, note 36.</i> in relation to <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, while <i>malchut</i> of <i>Beriah</i> is called <i>ammah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Maid; a level transcending the level of <i>shifchah</i>.</i>
You can know this from what the Arizal stated<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">See above, note 73.</i> that Scripture, i.e., the Written Torah, is in <i>Asiyah</i>, even while it is explicit in innumerable places in the <i>Zohar</i> and the writings of the Arizal, that it is <i>tiferet</i>, the <i>z’eyr anpin</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>! But (this means that) it vests itself in <i>Asiyah</i>. Thus it is stated explicitly in <i>Sefer Hakavanot</i> that Scripture, Mishnah, Talmud, and Kabbalah are all in <i>Atzilut</i>, but Scripture vests itself as far as <i>Asiyah</i>, Mishnah as far as <i>Yetzirah</i>, and Talmud as far as <i>Beriah</i>.
Now, when <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> vests itself in <i>kelipat nogah</i> in order to extract the sparks<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Of holiness.</i> that fell with the sin of Adam, and also the 288 sparks that fell with the <i>shevirat hakelim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Breaking of the vessels (see Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>). The sparks of Divinity are encumbered in the fragments of the broken vessels, thus, in the <i>kelipot</i>. When these sparks are extracted, the <i>kelipot</i> are deprived of their vivification and cease to exist.</i> <i>malchut of</i> <i>Atzilut</i>, too, is then referred to as “Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil” in relation to the <i>z’eyr anpin</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> [which does not descend there and is referred to as Tree of Life].
Now, the investment of <i>malchut</i> in <i>kelipat nogah</i> is the mysterium of the “Exile of the <i>Shechinah</i>,” “That man rules in man …”<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 8:9; see above, Epistle 25 and note 65, ad loc.</i> And this is the meaning of the statement in <i>Raaya Mehemna</i>: “But at the time that the Tree of Good and Evil dominates…, they….” That is, at the time of the exile of the <i>Shechinah</i> [who effuses to the <i>chitzonim</i> that are in <i>kelipat nogah</i>, from where the mixed multitude (<i>erev rav</i>) elicits, and from their extract the scholars of Torah are supported in the exile], the principal service of man, and the purpose of the occupation with Torah and the commandments, is to disencumber the sparks, as known from the Arizal.<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">See ref. cited in the Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, s.v. <i>Shevirat Hakelim</i>; also: <i>Shaar Hamitzvot</i>, <i>Va’etchanan</i>; Arizal, <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, <i>Kavanat Talmud Torah</i>, par. 2.</i>
Therefore, the principal mode of study is in the deliberation and argumentation of the law of <i>issur</i> and <i>hetter</i>, impurity and purity, in order to disencumber the permitted and pure from the proscribed and impure by means of the deliberation and argumentation of the law—with wisdom, understanding, and knowledge. For as known, the Torah derives from <i>chochmah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:85a, 121a, III:81a.</i> Thus it is only through <i>chochmah</i> that they shall be disencumbered,<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II: end of 254b (<i>Nitzutzei Orot</i>, ad loc.) explained in <i>Etz Chaim</i> 18:5 and 39:1; <i>Mevo She’arim</i> 5:1:2. See <i>Torah Or</i>, <i>Bereishit</i> 5d and <i>Esther</i> 96b.</i> i.e., the Supreme <i>chochmah</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> which is vested in <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> [the principium of the Oral Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">See above, note 70.</i> (<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>according to the principium of <i>abba</i><sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chochmah</i>.</i> founded <i>barta</i><sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Malchut</i>.—<i>Zohar</i> III:248a; ibid., 256b, and 258a. Cf. above, Epistle 5, notes 22 and 26.</i>)]—which (in turn) is vested in <i>malchut</i> of <i>Yetzirah</i>, the<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">V. L.: and the.</i> principium of the <i>Mishnayot</i> (<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets suggested by H. V.</i>and the <i>Beraytot</i> that are vested in the <i>kelipat nogah</i> which corresponds to the world of <i>Yetzirah</i>, for there begins the aspect of the evil<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">V. L.: of the <i>daat</i>.</i> inherent in the <i>nogah</i>),<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">V. L.: and <i>Beraitot</i> that are vested in the <i>kelipat nogah</i>—which corresponds to the world of <i>Asiyah</i>—for there begins the aspect of the evil inherent in the <i>nogah</i>.</i> as known from the Arizal.
Now, the intelligent will understand something yet more amazing, namely, what happens in Heaven above through the deliberation and elucidation of an adjudged ruling (<i>halachah</i>) of the Gemara and earlier and latter codifiers [which prior to this deliberation was in a state of concealment]: by means of this (deliberation), one elevates this ruling from the <i>kelipot</i> that were hiding and concealing it in such a way that it was not known at all, or that its reasoning was not clearly understood.<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">See references cited above, note 81.</i> For the reason (of the <i>halachah</i>) is the principium of the <i>sefirah</i> of the supreme <i>chochmah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. above, Epistle 19 (note 37), and Epistle 20 (note 7).</i> whence [by the breaking of the vessels] sparks fell into the <i>kelipot</i>. (These sparks) are there in a state of exile because the <i>kelipot</i> domineer over them and hide the wisdom of the Torah from the upper and lower beings. That is why it is stated in <i>Raaya Mehemna</i> that “The problematic query is of the side of evil.”
Now, the celestial beings do not have the power to disencumber and elevate that which is in <i>kelipat nogah</i> because of the breaking (of the vessels). Only the terrestrial beings (can do that), for they are vested in a material body—“hide of the snake,” which is of the <i>kelipat nogah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Etz Chaim</i> 49:4; see above, Epistle 6, note 21.</i> They weaken its strength by crushing the passions and suppressing the <i>sitra achara</i> so that “all the workers of evil<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">The forces of evil; the <i>kelipot</i>.</i> are dispersed.”<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 92:10.</i> That is why the celestial beings come to hear novelties of Torah from the terrestrial beings,<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> III:173a; cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:46.</i> what they discover and reveal of the secrets of wisdom which until then were in bondage in the exile.
And every one of Israel is able to reveal secrets of wisdom, (<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>to reveal) and to discover a new insight, whether it be in laws<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Halachah</i>.</i> or in homiletics,<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Aggadah.</i> in the revealed or in the esoteric parts (of Torah), according to the level of his soul’s root.<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shaar Ruach Hakodesh</i>, s.v. <i>Yichudim al Kivrei Tzaddikim</i>: <i>hakdamah</i> 3 (ed. Tel Aviv 1963, p. 108b); cf. <i>Shaar Hagilgulim</i>, <i>hakd</i>. 17. See also <i>Sefer Chassidim</i>, sect. 530, and the comment of R. Chaim David Azulai, ad loc.; R. Jacob of Manege, <i>Responsa Min Hashamayim</i>, no. 32; and below, note lot.</i> Indeed, one is obliged to do so in order to perfect his soul by elevating all the sparks that fell to its part and lot, as known.<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:4b; <i>Hilchot Talmud Torah</i> 1:4 (see also ibid. 2:2).</i>
(<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>And every word of Torah, especially one of <i>halachah</i>, is a spark of the <i>Shechinah</i>, the word of the L–rd.<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 25, note 25.</i> Thus it is stated in the Gemara: “The ‘word of the L–rd’—that refers to the <i>halachah</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 138b.</i> the principium of <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> which garbs the <i>chochmah</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, and they are (both) vested in <i>malchut</i> of <i>Yetzirah</i>, and by the breaking of the vessels descended into the <i>kelipat nogah</i>.)
And to this pertains what is stated in the Gemara: “The Holy One, blessed is He, says: whoever occupies himself with Torah…I account it to him as if he had redeemed Me and My children from among the nations of the world.”<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 8a; cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:281a.</i>
But when the <i>Shechinah</i> will emerge from the <i>kelipat nogah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">V. L.: from the <i>kelipot</i>.</i> [after the extraction of the sparks shall be completed and the evil shall be separated from the good, “And all the workers of evil will be dispersed,” and the Tree of Good and Evil will not domineer because the good shall depart from it], then the occupation with the Torah and commandments will not be for the purpose of disencumbrance, but to consolidate more sublime <i>yichudim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Unifications.</i> in order to elicit more <i>orot</i>, transcending <i>Atzilut</i>, as mentioned by the Arizal.
And everything will be by means of the <i>pnimiyut</i> of Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">The inner or esoteric part of the Torah.</i> by performing the commandments with supreme devotions directed toward supreme <i>orot</i>. For the root of the commandments is ever so high, in the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He.<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">See above, latter part of Epistle 20, and the notes, ad loc.</i>
(<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>As for the statement of our Sages, of blessed memory, that the commandments will be abrogated in the future,<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Niddah</i> 61b.</i> this refers to the time of the Resurrection of the Dead. In the days of the Messiah, however, prior to the Resurrection of the Dead, they will not be abrogated.)
And that is why the principal occupation with Torah will also be with the <i>pnimiyut</i> of the commandments and their hidden reasons. The revealed aspects, however, will be manifest and known to every one of Israel, by an innate knowledge, without oblivion. Only the mixed multitude (<i>erev rav</i>) will have to deal with these, because they will not merit to taste from the Tree of Life, i.e., the <i>pnimiyut</i> of the Torah and the commandments. They will need to occupy themselves with Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">V. L.: with Torah.</i> in order to weaken (by the occupation with Torah)<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">These words, which appear in the text in brackets, do not appear in some MSS.</i> the power of the <i>sitra achara</i> which cleaves unto them, so that it will not dominate them—causing them to sin. Thus it is written: “And the sinner at the age of a hundred years old will be cursed”;<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 65:20.</i> this refers to the sinners of the mixed multitude.<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> I:114b (<i>Medrash Hane’elam</i>); cf. <i>Pesachim</i> 68a.</i>
Also, on the practical level, they will need the detailed rulings of proscription and impurity more than Israel. For (the latter) nothing shall occur that is unfit, impure, and proscribed, as “there shall not befall….”<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">No iniquity shall befall the righteous; Proverbs 12:21. See <i>Zohar</i> III:276a. Cf. Nachmanides on Deuteronomy 30:6.</i> It is also possible, and would appear so, that (the Israelites) will know all the fundamentals of the revealed part of the Torah from the <i>pnimiyut</i> of the Torah, like our father Abraham, peace be to him.<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Yoma</i> 28b; <i>Kiddushin</i> 82a (cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:264b): Abraham observed the whole Torah, etc. This statement appears rather difficult because many of the commandments are related directly to later events (e.g., the <i>tefillin</i> need contain excerpts from the Torah, dealing with the Exodus; etc.), how that could Abraham have observed the whole Torah? But this is explained to mean that he observed it with respect to the <i>pnimiyut</i> of Torah, i.e., the esoteric part composed of the deeper and sublime reasons of Torah and the commandments (as they are in their root, prior to becoming vested in directives that require specific physical objects and actions).—See <i>Torah Or</i>, <i>Lech Lecha</i> 11d; <i>Maamarei Admur Hazaken Haketzarim</i>, p. 326; cf. also <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Shemini</i> 18c.</i> Thus they will not need to occupy themselves therewith at all.
At the time of the second Temple, however, they needed to occupy themselves (therewith), not just for the practical application of the law, but, and this is the principal purpose of the Divine service, to weaken the power of the <i>sitra achara</i> and to elevate the sparks of holiness by means of Torah and worship, as explained elsewhere.<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">The period of the Second Temple was not one of Messianic redemption. The return from the Babylonian exile, and the rebuilding of the Temple, did not constitute a restoration of pre-exilic conditions (cf. <i>Yoma</i> 9a f. and 21b; <i>Sotah</i> 48b, etc.). On the contrary, there was an increasing spiritual decline which, thus, required to be countered by means of Torah and worship; see <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Behaalotecha</i> 32d. And cf. ibid. <i>Derushim L’Rosh Hashanah</i> 57c.</i>
After these words and this truth,<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">H. V.—Par. II Chronicles 32:1.</i> the above passage from the <i>Raaya Mehemna</i> dealing with “the Tree of Good and Evil…” [i.e., the <i>kelipat nogah</i>, which is basically this world, as mentioned in <i>Etz Chaim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Etz Chaim</i> 49.</i>], will be well understood with additional elucidation, and suffice this for the initiated.

Chapter 27

<b>TWENTY-SEVEN.</b> <i>What he wrote to the Chasidic community</i><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Emended according to L. H. (Text states: “what he wrote to the inhabitants of the Holy Land,” etc., but that is an obvious printing mistake; see below, note 41). Subsequent note: The Lubavitcher Rebbe later commented that this letter was written to two addressees: one “to the inhabitants of the Holy Land,” and one “to the Chasidic community” in general. See L. H. (below, p. 785), and, in English, <i>Lessons in Tanya</i>, vol 5, pp. 525-526 (Kehot, 2017).</i> <i>to console them doubly for salvation</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., doubly and helpfully.—Par. Job 11:6.</i> <i>over the passing of the Rabbi, famous</i> Gaon<i>, holy man of G–d,</i><sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Par. II Kings 4:9.</i> <i>“Lamp of Israel, pillar of the right hand, mighty hammer,” </i><sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Berachot</i> 28b.</i> <i>our master R. Menachem Mendel,</i><sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Known as R. Mendel of Vitebsk (or Horodoky), of the leading disciples of R. Dov Ber, the Maggid of Mezeritch. After the Maggid’s demise, R. Shneur Zalman accepted his former colleague as his master. In 1777 R. Mendel ascended to the Holy Land, ultimately settling in Tiberias where he founded and led the Chasidic community. There he passed away, and was buried, on the 1st day of Iyar 5548 (1788). His teachings, letters, etc., were published under the titles <i>Pri Haaretz</i>; <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>; <i>Pri Ha’etz</i>.</i> <i>may his soul rest in Eden.</i>
My beloved, my brethren and friends, who are (to me) as my soul….<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">V. L. (see below, note 41) has instead of etc.<i>—</i>“who stand on Torah, and worship, and the ‘service of <i>tzedakah</i>, quietness and surety forever….’” (Par. <i>Avot</i> 1:2; Isaiah 32:17—cf. above, Epistle 12.)</i><br>May the L–rd be over them, they should live<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 38:16.</i> a life forevermore,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 133:3.</i> and their offspring with them, a seed of truth<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">As opposed to “seed of falsehood”—Isaiah 57:4.</i>—they are the blessed of the L–rd<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 65:23.</i> from now for evermore.
Following the enquiry after their welfare as is becoming those that love His Name, I have come to comfort the smitten “that sigh and groan”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Ezekiel 9:4.</i> and to console them doubly for salvation with what my ear has heard and noted for itself<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Job 13:1.</i> on the saying of our Sages, of blessed memory, that “He has left life for all the living.”<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">A frequent expression in rabbinic literature; cf. e.g., R. Yitzchak Alfassi (Rif) and Maimonides, in their versions of document-texts (resp. <i>Yevamot</i>, end of ch. 12, and <i>Hilchot Yibum Vechalitzah</i>, end of ch. 4).</i>
The righteous lives by his faith,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Habakkuk 2:4.</i> and by the fear of the L–rd which leads to life,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 19:23.</i> and by the flashes of fire of the flame<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Song of Songs 8:6.</i> of his love (of G–d, which to him) supercedes life, to absorb therein the life of his <i>ruach</i><sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 38:16.—V. L.: of his <i>ruach</i> and his <i>neshamah</i>. See above, Epistle 5, note 53 on the terms <i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, <i>neshamah</i>.</i> all the days of his duration. And when it comes about that the L–rd takes up<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Par. II Kings 2:1.</i> (and) gathers to Himself his <i>ruach</i> and <i>neshamah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Job 34:14.</i> and he ascends from one elevation to another—to the peak of levels, he, then, leaves the life of his <i>ruach</i>, his effectuation on which he has labored<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Ezekiel 29:20.</i> previously among Israel [the labor of the righteous is for the living<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 10:16.</i>], to every living being. That is, (he leaves it to) the soul of every living being bound to his soul by the thick ropes of a magnanimous love, and an eternal love,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ahavah rabbah</i> and <i>ahavat olam</i>. On these terms see <i>Zohar</i> III:263b; <i>Torah Or</i>, <i>Vayechi</i> 47b.</i> that will not be moved forever. For he who is the man who desires life<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 34:13.</i> to become attached to the L–rd of life, his soul will become attached through his service; (his soul) will be bound up in the bundle of life with the L–rd,<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 25:29; see <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Shelach</i> 51d, and below, Epistle 29.</i> in the life of “the breath (<i>ruach</i>) of our nostrils of whom we said: in his <i>tzel</i> we shall live among the nations.”<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Lamentations 4:20. The context suggests that this is not a mere paraphrase. <i>Tzel</i> (shadow) is a term associated with the soul and related to the sublime rank of <i>chaya</i> (cf. above, Epistle 5, note 53)—the “soul of soul,” transcending not only the rank of <i>ruach</i> but also that of <i>neshamah</i>. The phrase, thus, appears to mean: in the life (or essence) of the <i>ruach</i> (of the <i>tzaddik</i>), of which we said: “in his <i>tzel</i> we shall live”…. This he left for us, etc.—On the meaning and significance of <i>tzel</i>, see <i>Tehillim Yahel Or</i> on Psalms 39:7 (pp. 148 ff.).</i>
(This) he left for us, in each and every one corresponding to the degree of his genuine alliance and his pure love, a pure love of truth from “the inward of man and a profound heart.”<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 64:7.</i> For “As waters (reflect) the face…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 27:19; see above, Epistle 1, note 26.</i> and “spirit (<i>ruach</i>) rouses spirit, and brings forth spirit.”<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:162b.</i> Thus his <i>ruach</i> remains truly in our midst, when he sees his children, the work of his hands, in his midst sanctifying His Name, blessed be He.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 29:23.<i>—</i>Disciples are regarded as their master’s “children” and the “work of his hands”; see <i>Sanhedrin</i> 19b and 99b.</i> For (His name) is magnified and sanctified when we walk in the right way that he has shown us of his ways, and we will walk in his paths<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 2:3 (also: Micah 4:2). Cf. <i>Zohar</i> II:215a and III:87b ff.</i> forevermore.
And this is the meaning of the statement in the sacred <i>Zohar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">III:71b; cf. <i>Chullin</i> 7b.</i> that “When the <i>tzaddik</i> departs, he is to be found in all worlds more than in his lifetime.” That is, he is to be found more even in this world of action [“this day to do them”<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 7:11; see <i>Eruvin</i> 22a.</i>], because the action keeps growing growths of the second degree from the “light implanted for the righteous”<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 97:11.</i> in the field which the L–rd blessed;<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">The Garden of Eden (see Genesis 27:27 and <i>Rashi</i>, ad loc.; below, note 62).<i>—</i>See <i>Chagigah</i> 12a and below, Epistle 29, note 21.</i> (this light) radiates to the earth and the outside places,<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Proverbs 8:26.</i> and also to us—those that are here this day, all of us that live in his ways, “the holy way shall it be called.”<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 35:8.</i> This is as regards the service of G–d, with respect to heavenly matters.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Religious matters.</i>
As for mundane matters, it is stated explicitly in the sacred <i>Zohar</i> that the <i>tzaddikim</i> shield the world, and after their death even more than in their life.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:71b.</i> Were it not for the prayer of the <i>tzaddikim</i> in that world, the world would not endure a single moment.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">See ibid. III:70b ff.; cf. II:16b.</i> And whoever is closer unto the habitation of the L–rd<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., to the <i>tzaddik</i>.</i> during his lifetime has precedence to the blessing.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The original letter continues with a lengthy appeal for charity in general and for the support of R. Mendel of Vitebsk’s family in particular. (Reproduced in <i>Igrot Kodesh Admur Hazaken</i> (Kehot, 2012), p. 58 ff.)</i>
(27b). <i>An elucidation of the above</i>.
It is stated in the sacred <i>Zohar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">III:71b.</i> that when the <i>tzaddik</i> departs he is to be found in all worlds more than in his lifetime…. Now this needs to be understood. For, granted that he is to be found increasingly in the upper worlds, because he ascends to there; but how can he be found more in this world?
This may be explained along the lines of what I received on the saying of our Sages, of blessed memory, that “He has left life for all the living.”<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Above, note 13.</i>
As is known, the life of the <i>tzaddik</i> is not a physical life<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Proverbs 14:30.</i> but a spiritual life, consisting of faith, awe, and love.
