Thus of faith it is written: “And the <i>tzaddik</i> lives by his faith.”<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Habakkuk 2:4.</i> Of awe it is written: “The awe of the L–rd is for life.”<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 19:23.</i> And of love it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 21:21.</i> “He who pursues <i>tzedakah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>tzaddik</i>.</i> and <i>chesed</i> will find life,” and <i>chesed</i> refers to love.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chesed</i> is synonymous with love; cf. above, Epistle 13, note 27.</i>
These three attributes are prevalent in every world to the topmost of levels, all proportionate to the levels of the worlds—one higher than the other by way of cause and effect, as known.
Now, while the <i>tzaddik</i> was alive on earth, these three attributes were contained in their vessel and garment on the plane of physical space. This is the aspect of the <i>nefesh</i> bound to his body. All his disciples receive but a radiation from these attributes and a ray [from them] radiating beyond this vessel by means of his holy utterances and thoughts. That is why our Sages, of blessed memory, said that a person cannot comprehend his master….<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rashi</i> on Deuteronomy 29:6; <i>Avodah Zarah</i> 5b; cf. <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Sotah</i> 22b (s.v. <i>Vaed</i>). I.e., only a radiation and a mere ray are apprehended.</i>
But after his passing, because the <i>nefesh</i> [which remains in the grave] is separated from the <i>ruach</i> [i.e., these three attributes] which is in the Garden of Eden,<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> I:81a; II:142a.</i> whoever is close to him can receive a part from the aspect of his <i>ruach</i> [which is in the Garden of Eden], because it is no (longer) within a vessel, nor on the plane of physical space. Thus is known the saying of our Sages, of blessed memory, with reference to our father Jacob, peace be to him, that “the Garden of Eden entered with him.”<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 65:22; <i>Tanchuma</i> (ed. Buber), <i>Toldot</i> 10, and 22. <i>Zohar</i> III:84a.</i> Likewise it is stated in the book <i>Asarah Maamarot</i> that the sphere of the Garden of Eden spreads itself around every person, and in this sphere are recorded all his good thoughts and utterings of Torah and Divine service (<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>and likewise to the contrary, Heaven forfend: they<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., evil thoughts and utterings.</i> are recorded in the sphere of <i>Gehinom</i>, which spreads itself around every person<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 65:22; <i>Tanchuma</i> (ed. Buber), <i>Toldot</i> 10 and 22.</i>).
Thus it is very easy for his disciples to receive their part of the essential aspects of their master’s <i>ruach</i>, i.e., his faith, his awe, and his love, wherewith he served the L–rd and not merely a ray thereof which radiates beyond the vessel. For the essential aspect of his <i>ruach</i> is raised, elevation upon elevation, to become absorbed in his <i>neshamah</i>, which is in the Higher Garden of Eden, in the supreme worlds.
Now it is known that something sacred is never wholly and totally uprooted from its place and original level, even after it has reached the highest point.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 14:1 (where this principle is explained at length); <i>Etz Chaim</i> 34:3; <i>Mevo She’arim</i> 6:1:1. See also <i>Etz Chaim</i> 6:5, 47:6 <i>et passim</i>.</i> Thus it is this original aspect, remaining below, in the Lower Garden of Eden, in its place and original level, which extends itself among his disciples, each one according to the level of his alliance and closeness to (the <i>tzaddik</i>) during his lifetime and after his death out of a magnanimous love. For the efflux of anything spiritual is but by means of a magnanimous love. Thus it is stated in the sacred <i>Zohar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:162b.</i> that the spirit (<i>ruach</i>) in a mode of the willingness of the heart (<i>reuta deliba</i>)<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the mode of <i>ahavah rabbah</i> (magnanimous love). See above, Epistle 18, and notes 8-9, ad loc.</i> elicits a spirit from above; thus only when he will prepare himself toward his G–d<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Amos 4:12.</i> with a great preparation and immense effort to receive these attributes<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">The faith, awe, and love of the <i>tzaddik</i>.</i> in the way that his master taught him, and as the saying of our Sages, of blessed memory: “If you have labored and (claim to have) found—believe it.”<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Megillah</i> 6b.</i>
Now, there is yet another type of radiation to his disciples. However, it does not vest itself truly in their mind—as is the case with the first one, but radiates over them, from aloft. It stems from the ascent of his <i>ruach</i> and his <i>neshamah</i> to the source from where it was hewn, that is to the “orchard of the holy apples” (<i>chakal tapuchin kadishin</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">The Garden of Eden; <i>Zohar</i> III:84a. Cf. <i>Rashi</i> on Genesis 27:27; see also <i>Zohar</i> I:142b. More on this term see <i>Aspaklarya Hameirah</i> on <i>Zohar</i> III:142b, par. 23.</i> (This ascent) effects a unification there (<i>yichud</i>) by means of the elevation of the <i>mayin nukvin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Feminine waters; see above, Epistle 4, note 46; Intro., note 199.</i> of all his doings, his Torah, and the Divine service which he served all the days of his life. And in the <i>chakal tapuchin kadishin</i> are implanted most sublime lights corresponding to the nether ones, i.e., his Torah and worship.
The illumination of these supernal lights radiates over all his disciples, who became servants of the L–rd through his Torah and worship. And this radiation, which is over them from aloft, instills in their heart thoughts of repentance and good deeds. And all the good deeds born from this radiation [radiating from the lights implanted in the orchard mentioned above] are called “growths of the second degree.”
But this radiation is in great latency and concealment, just like the sun radiating to the stars from below the earth. Thus it is stated in the <i>Tikkunim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 69 (112a); <i>Zohar</i> III:273a. See H. V., ad loc., and the ref. cited there.</i> in reference to Moses our Master, peace to him, that after his passing his radiation extends in every generation to the sixty myriad souls,<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">The sixty myriad general souls of Israel that exist in every generation; see ibid. (above, note 44) and <i>Kohelet Rabbah</i> 1:5.</i> just like the sun radiating to the sixty myriad stars from below the earth.

Chapter 28

<b>TWENTY-EIGHT.</b> <i>What he wrote to his relative by marriage, the Rabbi, famous</i> Gaon<i>, G–dly and holy man of the L–rd, “Lamp of Israel, pillar of the right hand, mighty hammer,”</i><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 27, notes 3 and 4.</i> <i>our master R. Levi Yitzchak,</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">R. Levi Yitzchak of Berdichev (1740-1810), author of <i>Kedushat Levi</i>. R. Levi Yitzchak was of the leading disciples of R. Dov Ber, the Maggid of Mezeritch, and a close friend and associate of R. Schneur Zalman.</i> <i>may his soul rest in Eden, head of the</i> Bet Din <i>of the holy community of Berdichev, to console him on the passing of his son, the pious rabbi, R. Meir,</i><sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Author of <i>Keter Torah</i>.</i> <i>may his soul rest in Eden.</i>
“Why was the section of Miriam<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 20:1.</i> adjoined to the section of the heifer?<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers, ch. 19.</i> To teach you that just as the heifer effects atonement….”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Moed Kattan</i> 28a.</i>
Now it needs to be understood why it was adjoined precisely to the “red heifer” (<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets suggested by H. V.</i>which was prepared outside the three camps;<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 19:3; <i>Rashi</i>, ad loc.; <i>Yoma</i> 68a.</i> it is just that the Torah calls it a sin-offering<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 19:9; <i>Rashi</i>, ad loc. <i>Avodah Zarah</i> 23b; <i>Chullin</i> 11a. The red heifer as such is not a sacrifice proper. It was not sacrificed on the altar but outside the camps of the Priests, Levites, and Israelites. However, Scripture terms it a sin offering, thus subjecting it to Halachic rulings applying to sacrifices.</i>),<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">V. L.: (which was prepared outside) and….</i> and it was not adjoined to the section of the sin-offering that was prepared within, on the actual altar of atonement.
However, it is known from the sacred <i>Zohar</i>, and from the Arizal,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> I:64b f.; II:268b f.; III:240a ff. Arizal, <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Vayikra</i>. (On the Arizal, see above, Epistle 5, note 103.)</i> that the principium of the sacrifices brought on the altar is that they are an aspect of the elevation of <i>mayin nukvin</i>:<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Feminine waters; see above, Epistle 4, note 46.</i> from the animal soul, which is in (the class of) <i>nogah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 15, note 63.</i> to their root and source, i.e., the forms of the four animals of the chariot bearing the throne:<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">See Ezekiel, ch. 1.</i> the face of the ox, and the face of the eagle….<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">See above, end of Epistle 20.</i> Thereby the <i>mayin duchrin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The masculine waters, the supernal effusions; see above, Epistle 4, note 46.</i> are elicited and descend from the aspect of the “man upon the throne,”<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 1:26.—See <i>Zohar</i> III:217a.</i> referred to as <i>malka</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">King.—Cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:10a.</i> and <i>z’eyr anpin</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Microprosopus (see above, Epistle 19, note 11).—Cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:66b and 227a. The emanation elicited by the sacrifices proper thus stems from <i>malka</i>, and <i>z’eyr anpin</i>, corresponding to <i>tiferet</i>.</i>
As for the burning of the red heifer, however, by throwing in the cedarwood, and the hyssop…, and the placing of running waters into the ashes, the Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Parah</i>, ch. 6; <i>et passim</i>.</i> refers to this as the <i>sanctification</i> (<i>kiddush</i>) of the waters of lustration. This is the aspect of <i>kodesh ha’elyon</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Supreme holiness.</i> referred to as <i>tala d’bedulcha</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">The Dew of Bdellium (par. Numbers 11:7), referring to the emanations from <i>arich anpin</i>. See commentary of the Arizal on <i>Sifra Detzeniyuta</i> (<i>Zohar</i> II, beg. of 176b), in <i>Shaar Maamarei Rashbi</i> (ed. Tel Aviv 1961) 111b.</i> as mentioned in the sacred <i>Zohar</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> III:49a, 128b and 135b.</i> the aspect of the supreme <i>chochmah</i> and the <i>mocha stimaah</i> of <i>arich anpin</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">The Concealed Brain; the aspect of <i>chochmah</i> in the <i>partzuf</i> of <i>arich anpin</i>.—See above, Epistle 10, note 41.</i> Of it is said in many places in the sacred <i>Zohar</i> that through <i>chochmah</i> they are disencumbered,<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 26, and the references cited there in note 82.</i> and darkness is converted to light.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:4a; <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 21 (50a).</i> That is, by means of the <i>mocha stimaah</i> of <i>arich anpin</i>, the world of <i>Tikkun</i><sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">The World of Correction (or Restitution). See Addendum, <i>Mystical Concepts in Chassidism</i>, s.v. <i>Tohu</i> and <i>Tikkun</i>.</i> is disencumbered and corrected from the world of <i>tohu</i><sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The World of Chaos (or Disorder). See Addendum, ibid.</i> and the breaking of the vessels<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">See Addendum, ibid.</i> that fell into <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>…, as known. That is why (the red heifer) purifies from the defilement by a corpse, even though such is the highest degree of impurity, and much lower than <i>nogah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">The sacrifices proper, brought on the altar, elicit from the rank of <i>z’eyr anpin</i> and sublimate the class of <i>nogah</i>. The red heifer, however, elicits from the supreme rank of <i>arich anpin</i>. Its effect, therefore, is that much greater, and it is able to sublimate even ranks far below <i>nogah</i>.</i>
Now,<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is emended according to L. H.</i> it is known that <i>abba</i><sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>partzuf</i> of <i>abba</i> (the <i>sefirah</i> of <i>chochmah</i>).</i> draws from the eighth <i>mazal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Etz Chaim</i>, <i>Shaar Hakelalim</i> 5; ibid., 14: end of ch. 3, and 8; <i>et passim</i>.<i>—Abba</i> draws from the eighth of the thirteen attributes of mercy (Exodus 34:6 ff.) Both the eighth (related to <i>abba</i>) and the thirteenth of the attributes (related to <i>imma</i>; <i>binah</i>) are referred to as <i>mazal</i>, because everything flows <i>(nozel</i>) from them. The eighth attribute is regarded as the most important one and, accordingly, termed the “superior <i>mazal</i>,” while the thirteenth attribute is termed the “inferior <i>mazal</i>.” See <i>Zohar</i> II:177a; III: 134a ff. and 289a ff. Cf. Nachmanides on Genesis 24:1.</i> which is the tuft of <i>notzer chesed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">The thirteen attributes are referred to as the “thirteen tufts of the <i>dikna</i> (beard)”; see ref. cited above, note 33 (and cf. Epistle 20, note 42). <i>Notzer chesed</i> (He guards <i>chesed</i>) is the eighth attribute according to the interpretation of the <i>Zohar</i> and the Kabbalists; see <i>Likkutei Sichot</i>, vol. 4, pp. 1348 ff., on the varying enumerations of the thirteen attributes.</i> <i>Notzer</i> is (composed of the same) letters (as) <i>ratzon</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Will; or Favor. Arizal, <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Toldot</i> (on Genesis 25:21) and <i>Ki Tissa</i> (on Exodus 34:7); cf. <i>Zohar</i> III:280a.<i>—</i>See <i>Igrot Kodesh</i> by the Lubavitcher Rebbe, vol. 2, pp. 119-120.</i> It is the <i>et ratzon</i><sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., the Time of Will (or Favor). Auspicious time.</i> that becomes revealed and radiates in a manifest way, from above downward, at the time of the passing of the great <i>tzaddikim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., the <i>tzaddikim</i> of the Most High.</i> who serve the L–rd out of love, surrendering their soul to the L–rd during their lifetime every evening and morning when reading the <i>Shema</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> I:124b; cf. <i>Tikkunei</i> <i>Zohar</i>, Introduction 10b and <i>Zohar</i> III:263b; <i>Berachot</i> 61b. See below, Epistle 32, note 18.</i> For thereby they elevate the <i>mayin nukvin</i> to <i>abba</i> and <i>imma</i>, as known. (<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>The same applies to (their) study of the Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> I:124b.</i> which derives from <i>chochmah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 19, note 35.</i>) Thus, the aspects of the <i>mayin duchrin</i> were elicited thereby and descended from the tuft of <i>notzer chesed</i>, and they, indeed, radiate in a manifest way at the time of their passing. For as known, all the effort of man, which his soul toiled<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Proverbs 16:26 (cf. Isaiah 53:11); see <i>Sanhedrin</i> 99b.</i> during his lifetime, is above in a hidden and concealed state. It becomes revealed and radiates in a manifest way from above downward at the time of his passing.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. above, Epistle 27.</i>
Now, by the manifestation of the illumination of the tuft of <i>notzer chesed</i> at the time of their passing, the <i>chesed</i> of the L–rd radiates from world to world over those who fear Him<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 103:17.</i> and effects salvations in the midst of the earth<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 74:12.</i> to atone for the sin of the generation, even for the deliberate sins which are of the three impure <i>kelipot</i> [which are inferior to <i>nogah</i>]. For the <i>mazal</i> of <i>notzer</i> is of the <i>mochin stimin</i> of <i>arich anpin</i>, the source of the extractions (<i>birurim</i>). Thus the darkness of the <i>shevirat hakelim</i> is converted into the light of the world of <i>Tikkun</i>.
This is not the case, though, with the sacrifices that are upon the altar. They atone only for inadvertent sins which come about because of the strengthening of the animal soul which is of <i>nogah</i>, as mentioned in <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, section of <i>Vayikra</i>.
That is why (the section of Miriam) was adjoined expressly to the section of the heifer: “just as the heifer….” Indeed, in the <i>Yalkut</i>, section of <i>Shemini</i>, the version is “the waters of lustration….”<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Just as the waters of lustration effect atonement, etc., thus alleviating the difficulty raised at the beginning of this later.</i>

Chapter 29

<b>TWENTY-NINE.</b> “A woman of valor is the crown (<i>atarah</i>) of her husband….”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 11:4.</i>
In the Gemara, fourth chapter of <i>Megillah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Folio 28b.</i> it is stated: “He who makes use of the crown, passes away <sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 1:13.</i>…this applies to one who makes use of a person who can repeat <i>halachot</i>, the crown (<i>keter</i>) of the Torah…. It was taught in the academy of Elijah: whoever studies <i>halachot</i> is assured….”
Now it needs to be understood why the <i>halachot</i> are referred to as “crown,” and “the crown of the Torah,” and, also, why expressly he who studies <i>halachot</i> is assured…, and not other subjects of the Torah. Furthermore, one needs to understand the saying of our Sages, of blessed memory, in the eleventh chapter of <i>Menachot</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Folio 99b.</i> that even if one studied but a single chapter in the morning…one has fulfilled one’s duty. Why is one’s duty not fulfilled by other subjects of the Torah?
However, it is well known that the Arizal<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 5, note 103.</i> stated that every person of Israel needs to be reincarnated many times until he has fulfilled all 613 commandments of the Torah in thought, speech, and action.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 7, note 37.</i> This is in order to complete the garments of his soul and to correct them, so that there will not be a missing garment….<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 3, note 5, on the “garments” of the soul.</i> [Excepted are the commandments incumbent upon the king, because he discharges all of Israel, as he is the omneity of them all.] The reason is in order to garb all the 613 aspects and powers in one’s soul, so that “Not one of them shall be lacking.”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 34:16.</i>
An explanation for the necessity and need of these garments is given in the <i>Zohar</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:210a-b and 229a-b.</i> and is understood by every intelligent person. For the <i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 5, note 53, on these terms.</i> in man are of the genre of creatures, and it is impossible for any creature to attain any apprehension of the Creator and Former of all, the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He.
Even after G–d had already radiated of His light, blessed be He, and caused an emanation in the form of an evolution of numerous levels [level upon level] by way of immense contractions and numerous, immense garments [known to the students of Kabbalah; in the <i>Idra Rabbah</i> they are referred to as “hairs,”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:128b ff. Cf. above, Epistle 20, note 74.</i> and as written in Daniel: “And the hair of his head as pure wool…”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 7:9.</i>], nevertheless, neither the <i>nefesh</i>, nor the <i>ruach</i> and <i>neshamah</i> can endure the light. For the light is good and sweet…,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Ecclesiastes 11:7.</i> as it is written: “To behold the <i>noam</i> of the L–rd.”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 27:4.</i> (<i>Noam</i>) expresses pleasantness, agreeableness, sweetness, and an infinitely immense delight, as it is written: “Then you will delight yourself in the L–rd,”<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 58:14.</i> “And He will satisfy with <i>tzachtzachot</i>…”<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid., 11. The <i>Zohar</i> (II:209a) quotes these two verses in this order.</i> an idiom of <i>tzichey tzama</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Parched with thirst (Isaiah 5:13); see comment., ad loc.</i> as stated in the <i>Zohar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:210b.</i>
It is not in (the soul’s) power to absorb the pleasantness and agreeableness of the <i>tzachtzachot</i> without leaving its husk and becoming existentially nullified just like the flame in the torch, were it not that from the aspect of this very light there will evolve and issue forth some minute radiation, by way of an evolution of level after level, with many contractions, until a single garment is created thereof, a creation like the nature of this light, to garb the <i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i>.
By way of this garment [which is like this light], (the soul) can derive enjoyment from the ray of this light, and apprehend it, without becoming existentially nullified. It is analogous to someone looking at the sun through a fine and lucid speculum. Thus it is written: “And Moses entered into the midst of the cloud, and he ascended…”;<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 24:18; see <i>Zohar</i> II:229a and I:66a.</i> that is, he vested himself in the cloud and ascended, and saw by way of the cloud…. Thus it is explained<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">The preceding discourse dealing with the garments of the soul.</i> in the <i>Zohar</i>, volume II, folios 210 and 229.
Now this light, kept concealed for the righteous in the future,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Chagigah</i> 12a; <i>Zohar</i> I:45b and II:148b, (above, Epistle 27, and notes 33 and 34 ad loc.).</i> is termed the “pleasantness of the L–rd,” and the “<i>tzachtzachot</i> to delight in the L–rd,” and the “400 worlds of longing” (<i>almin diksufin</i>)<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:123b; III:128b and 288a.</i> in which the <i>tzaddikim</i> delight… [as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 23:15.—כסף (silver) is etymologically related to לכסוף (to long; to desire).</i> “400 <i>shekalim</i> of <i>kessef</i>…”]. In (this light) there are very many rungs and levels, one superior to the other. But the minute radiation, which descends level after level to create this garment, is of the rank of the lowest level in this light. Metaphorically speaking, it is referred to as the external level, and <i>achorayim</i>, as stated in the <i>Zohar</i>, folio 208b (<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>cf. in the commentary <i>Mikdash Melech</i>), and 210b: “And that which is left….”
Now, in the soul of man there is a faculty for delight: for (the soul) delights in what is delightful to it, as, for example, in the conception of a new insight, or the like. The aspect of the <i>chitzoniyut</i> and <i>achorayim</i> of the (soul’s) capacity and state of delight is the aspect of the faculty of its will: (the soul) wills that which it wills, i.e., something that is not painful [for pain is the opposite of delight].<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">The above may be summarized as follows: In the soul there is a faculty of delight. This faculty is most deep-seated and innate to the soul, beyond any apprehension. The propensity to like or dislike, that something will appeal to a person or not, is a natural disposition and innate part of the soul. In fact, it is the most basic faculty of the soul. Based on it is man’s will. By nature man wills that which is agreeable to him; what he likes; that which realizes his capacity for delight. Will itself expresses itself on two levels. Most often it is subject to reason. Man wills what reason dictates to him as being most agreeable. First he reasons what would be in his best interest and best agrees with his natural disposition for delight. Then he focuses his will on this rational goal. This is the “lower” or “inferior” will (so called because it is dependent on, thus lower than, reason). The second type of will is not subject to reason. It does not express itself after a rational calculation but transcends it. It is supra-rational and may even act against the dictates of reason (stubbornness would be an example; see above, Epistle 22, note 60). This second type of will, the “superior” or “supreme” will, is the very basic or natural disposition of willing; the “will of will,” or the “will to will,” as it were. (Cf. also <i>Siddur Im Dach</i>, pp. 161a ff.)</i>
Metaphorically speaking, it is the same with the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, as it were. The will of the Supreme One, blessed is He, is the aspect of the <i>chitzoniyut</i> and <i>achorayim</i> of the aspect of the Supreme delight, the “pleasantness of the L–rd,” the <i>tzachtzachot</i>, and the “worlds of longing,” mentioned above.
Though these are unified in an absolute unity, for He, blessed be He, and His will, are one [and not like the will of man, Heaven forfend, neither wholly nor partially; there is no comparison whatsoever between them], nevertheless, the Torah speaks in human idiom<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 31b.</i> to appease the ear with what it is able to hear,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mechilta</i> and <i>Tanchuma</i> on Exodus 19:18.</i> with allegory and metaphor relating to the soul of man<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">See above, beg. of Epistle 15, and notes, ad loc.</i> which compounds the faculty of delight, will, wisdom, understanding…. (This composition of the soul) is empirically evident. For when a person conceives some wondrous new insight then, at least, at that very moment, there is born in his mind a wondrous delight. Thus it follows that the (faculty of) delight surpasses exceedingly the faculty of the intellect and wisdom, except that it is vested in the faculty of the intellect and wisdom. Thus when man senses the intellect and wisdom, that is, he apprehends and understands it well, he, then, also senses the faculty of delight which is vested in the wisdom.
That is why in the sacred <i>Zohar</i><sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:158a; Cf. above, Epistle 5.</i> the aspect of <i>binah</i> is referred to as <i>olam habah</i> (the World to Come). For it is the state of the manifestation of the <i>chochmah</i>, and the delight vested in it, which the righteous apprehend in the Garden of Eden and perceive in the <i>pnimiyut</i> of the Torah. For The Torah derives from <i>chochmah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:85a; see above, Epistle 19, note 35.</i> and the Torah and the Holy One, blessed is He, are entirely one.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:90b; above, Epistle 23, note 23.</i>
Now, the Kabbalists<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chachmei HaEmet</i>, in the Hebrew—lit., the “sages of the truth” (i.e., of Kabbalah).</i> term and refer to the Supernal Will as <i>keter elyon</i>, the supreme crown. In it there are 620<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">The numerical value (<i>gematria</i>) of <i>keter</i> is 620.</i> pillars of light….<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Masechet Atzilut</i>, near the end; R. Shem Tov ibn Shem Tov, <i>Sefer Haemunot</i> 4:7; R. Moses Cordovero, <i>Pardes Rimonim</i> 8:3; and <i>Shiur Komah</i>, ch. 93, s.v. <i>Keter</i> and <i>Ratzon</i>; <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 53.</i> That is, by way of analogy, just as in a large brick house there are pillars standing in the ground, and their apex is connected with the ceiling, precisely so, metaphorically speaking, the <i>keter</i> of the Supernal, blessed is He, transcends the aspect of the level of <i>chochmah</i>. (<i>Keter</i>) is an idiom of <i>koteret</i> (capitol), for it surrounds and encompasses above the brains in the head [i.e., the faculties of <i>chochmah</i>, <i>binah</i>, and <i>daat</i> (<i>chabad</i>)].<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Etz Chaim</i> 23:1, 2; ibid. 25:5; above, Epistle 17 (note 27, ad loc.).</i>
This (Supreme) Will is vested in the 613 commandments of the Torah and the seven precepts of the Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Thus 620 precepts corresponding to the 620 pillars of light.</i> practically all of which are operative commandments [even those related to speech, for we maintain that the motioning of the lips is regarded as an act,<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 65a.</i> and also those relating to thought or the heart. For the commandment is given only to physical man in this world<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Eruvin</i> 22a.</i> because he has the choice to turn his heart to good….<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Or to evil.</i> The soul without a body, however, need not be enjoined about this<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Etz Chaim</i> 26:1; <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 37.</i>].
Thus it follows that the commandments, metaphorically speaking, are as the pillars that stand from the peak of rungs, i.e., the will of the Supreme One, blessed is He, to this material world. Metaphorically speaking, they are as the hollow pillars which encompass and garb man’s <i>neshamah</i>, or <i>ruach</i>, or <i>nefesh</i>, when he fulfils the commandments. By way of these pillars his <i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i> ascend to the peak of rungs to be bound up in the bundle of life with the L–rd,<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 25:29; see <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, Shelach 51d.</i> that is, to be bound up and vested in the light of <i>keter</i>, the will of the Supreme One, blessed is He. And by means of this garment they are able to behold the “pleasantness of the L–rd,” and the <i>tzachtzachot</i>, which transcend the rank of <i>keter</i> and, metaphorically speaking, are its inner core.
(<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Brackets appear in the text.</i>Though it is explained elsewhere that the commandments are the innermost will of the Supreme One, blessed is He,<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 23.</i> the students of Kabbalah are well acquainted with the multitude of aspects and levels within every aspect and level of the levels of holiness. There are several aspects of “<i>panim</i> to <i>panim</i>,” and several aspects of “<i>achorayim</i> to <i>achorayim</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">See ref. cited above, Epistle 20, note 36.</i> to no end….)
Now, the seven precepts of the Rabbis are not regarded as commandments in themselves, for it was already said: “You shall not add.”<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 13:1; Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah</i> 9:1.</i> Rather, they derive and issue from the commandments of the Torah and are included in them, in the sum of 613, to garb the 613 aspects and powers in the <i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i> of man.
This is the meaning of the statement in the sacred <i>Zohar</i>, section of <i>Pekudei</i> (folio 229b), that “The good deeds which man does elicit a garment from the light of the supreme splendor…, and they see…the pleasantness of the L–rd….”
Though there it speaks of the Lower Garden of Eden where the garments are of the truly operational commandment, while in the Higher Garden of Eden the garments are of the love and devotion of the heart with respect to Torah and prayer [as mentioned in the Zohar, ad loc. (folio 210<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">II:210b.</i>)]; however, this devotion refers to the devotion of one’s occupation with Torah for its own sake (<i>lishmah</i>),<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 12, note 17.</i> out of the love for God. [The commandment to study Torah also belongs to the class of operational commandments, for the motion of the lips is an act, and meditation is not the same as speech;<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 65a; <i>Berachot</i> 20b.</i> thus one does not discharge his duty by meditation alone.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Hilchot Talmud Torah</i> 2:12; see <i>Eruvin</i> 54a.</i> The same applies to prayer.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 25, note 61.</i>]
And certainly so, considering that the advantage of devotion over speech and deed is not of itself…, but because of the radiation from the Supernal Will…, as explained at length in <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 38, see there.
Now, it is known that the will of the Supreme One, blessed is He, vested in the 613 commandments of the Written Torah, is hidden and covered, secreted and concealed. It is manifest only in the Oral Torah. For example, the precept of <i>tefillin</i>: in the Written Torah it is stated, “And you shall bind them for a sign on your hand, and they shall be for frontlets between your eyes.”<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 6:8.</i> This is an indistinct and concealed statement, for Scripture did not explain how, and what to bind, and what frontlets are, and where is “between your eyes” and “on your hand,” until the Oral Torah explicates that one needs to bind a single box on the hand, and four boxes on the head, and four portions of Scripture within them. Also, the boxes are to be made of prepared leather, and of necessity square, and to be tied by means of leather straps which need to be black, and all the other detailed rulings of making the <i>tefillin</i> that were said orally. Also, “on your hand” refers only to the arm, and not to the palm of the hand; and “between your eyes” refers to the scalp, and not to the forehead.
It is likewise with <i>all</i> the commandments of the Torah, whether they be operational precepts or prohibitory precepts; they are not revealed, and known, and explicated, except through the Oral Torah. For instance, the prohibitory precept that was said with respect to Shabbat—“You shall do no work”<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 20:10; Deuteronomy 5:14.</i>: it does not explain what is regarded as work. In the Oral Torah, however, it is explicated to refer to the well known 39 forms of work<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">See Mishnah, <i>Shabbat</i> 7:2.</i> and not to the carrying of stones or heavy beams.
And as it is with these, so it is with all the commandments, whether they be operational precepts or prohibitory precepts: they are indistinct and are explicated, revealed, and known only through the Oral Torah.
That is why Scripture says of the Oral Torah: “And you shall not cast off the teaching of your mother,”<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 1:8.</i> as stated in the <i>Zohar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> II:276b. See also ibid. 238b, and cf. ibid. 85a. (This verse is explicitly interpreted thus, in <i>Midrash Mishlei</i> 1:8.)</i> Metaphorically speaking, just as all the limbs of the child are included, in great concealment, in the sperm of the father,<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Zohar</i> III:93a; cf. <i>Niddah</i> 31a.</i> and the mother brings this out into a state of manifestation [when giving birth to a child that is whole, with 248 limbs and 365 sinews], so, in precisely like fashion, the 248 operational precepts and the 365 prohibitory precepts emerge from concealment to manifestation through the Oral Torah. And the beginning of the verse—“Heed my son the instruction of your father”—refers to the Written Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">See ref. cited above, note 55, and <i>Yalkut Shimoni</i> on Proverbs (ad loc.; sect. 929).</i> which derives from the supreme <i>chochmah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">See ref. cited above, note 30.</i> which is called “father.”<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 15, note 9.</i>
Now this is the meaning of “A woman of valor is the crown of her husband.” For the Oral Torah is termed the “woman of valor” who gives birth to and raises many valiant hosts, as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 6:8.</i> “And <i>alamot</i> without number”: do not read <i>alamot </i><sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Maidens.</i> but <i>olamot</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Worlds.</i> referring to the <i>halachot</i> which are without number, as stated in the <i>Tikkunim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 14b.</i>
They all are the aspect of the manifestation of the will of the Supreme One, blessed is He, concealed in the Written Torah. And the will of the Supreme One, blessed is He, is exceedingly more sublime than the rank of the supreme <i>chochmah</i>, just as a crown (<i>keter</i>) and wreath (<i>atarah</i>) is above the brains in the head.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">See above, note 35.</i> The <i>halachot</i>, therefore, are referred to as “crown,” and “crown of the Torah,” and “Whoever studies <i>halachot</i> is assured of life in the World to Come,” by investing his <i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i> in the the will of the Supreme One, blessed is He, as stated above.

Chapter 30

<b>THIRTY.</b> It is known that our Sages, of blessed memory, said<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 6b.</i>: “Whoever is accustomed to come to the synagogue and one day did not come, the Holy One, blessed is He, makes inquiry about him, for it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 50:10.</i> ‘who among you fears the L–rd….’”
The same applies to all the commandments, and especially the precept of charity, “which is balanced against all the commandments.”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Peah</i> 1:1.</i> Though it is without a vow,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Shulchan</i> <i>Aruch</i>, <i>Yoreh</i> <i>Deah</i> 203; cf. <i>Likkutei</i> <i>Torah</i>, <i>Matot</i> 82b.</i> Heaven forfend, nevertheless, it is not becoming to the divine soul of all the men of valor whose hearts the fear of the L–rd has touched<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Par. I Samuel 10:26.</i> to make a diminution in what is holy, relative to what they were accustomed to set aside, annually, from their wealth, to revive the spirit of the humble and downcast<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 57:15.</i> who have nothing of their own. It is “the Hut of David that is fallen…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Amos 9:11, referring to the <i>Shechinah</i> (see above, Epistle 9, note 29). The poor are the aspect of the Fallen Hut—the <i>Shechinah</i>, the <i>sefirah</i> of <i>malchut</i> which “has nothing of its own.” See above, Epistle 21, note 24.</i> to raise and to exalt… “that it be united in the One….”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:135a. By giving charity one raises and reinstates the Fallen “Hut,” thereby effecting the ultimate goal of the unity of the Holy One, blessed is He, and His <i>Shechinah</i>. See also <i>Zohar</i> III:113b. Cf. <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, end of ch. 50; <i>Maamarei Admur Hazaken—Ketuvim</i>, vol. 2, p. 161.</i>
And everything is according to the preponderance of [good] deeds…,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 3:15. See above, Epistle 21.</i> and according to the amount (<i>cheshbon</i>). Thus our Sages, of blessed memory, said, “Each and every coin adds up to a great amount (<i>cheshbon</i>),”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava</i> <i>Batra</i> 9b.</i> and as the saying of our Sages, of blessed memory:<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:235a; III:5a; <i>Zohar</i> <i>Chadash</i> 44a.</i> “When is the L–rd great? When He is in the city of our G–d….”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 48:2.—“In the city” may also be read “[when He is] with the city.” The “city of G–d” signifies <i>malchut</i>. The ultimate goal, the “greatness of the L–rd,” will thus be achieved when this unity is effected; see <i>Zohar</i> III:5a and <i>Zohar Chadash</i> 51d.</i> It is the aspect and place of the <i>cheshbon</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The “city of our G–d” is the aspect and place of <i>Cheshbon</i>. <i>Cheshbon</i>, too, signifies <i>malchut</i>; see <i>Zohar</i> III:220b and <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Chukat</i> 66d ff.</i> as it is written: “Your eyes are wells in <i>cheshbon</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 7:5.</i>
The meaning is that, as known, an arousal from below [the issuance of life, grace, and kindness by an act of charity out of a good will and a friendly countenance<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">See Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Peah</i> 8:9; <i>Vayikra Rabbah</i> 34:1; <i>Avot d’R. Nattan</i>, ch. 13; cf <i>Bava Batra</i> 9b. See also below, Epistle 32.</i>] elicits an arousal from above:<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Epistle 4, note 45.</i> “The L–rd will make His Countenance shine,”<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 6:25.</i> i.e., a radiation and issue of grace, <i>chesed</i>, and Supreme favor<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Signified by Countenance (<i>panim</i>); see above, Epistle 22, note 31.</i> from the Fountainhead of life,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Lit.: the Life of life (see above, Epistle 17, note 4).</i> the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, [to whose greatness<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">The aspect of <i>chesed</i>; see above, Epistle 13, note 30.</i> there is no searching and apprehension whatsoever], to the aspect of “Your <i>malchut</i> is the <i>malchut</i> of all worlds,”<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 145:13; see <i>above</i>, Epistle 8, note 44.</i> the “world of manifestation” (<i>alma deitgalya</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>above</i>, Epistle 20, and note 53, ad loc.</i> It<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Malchut</i>.</i> animates all the creatures [that are in all the upper and lower <i>hechalot</i><sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Shrines; realms.</i>] which are in a category of number and amount (<i>cheshbon</i>), as it is written: “A thousand thousands minister unto Him.”<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 7:10.</i>
This is the meaning of the “great amount,” because the quantitative act of charity brings about peace.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. above, end of Epistles 4 and 12.</i> The meaning of “peace” is to join and conciliate two opposite extremes. (In our context) these are the extremity of the superior heaven, the aspect of “And to His greatness there is no searching”<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Great is the L–rd and highly to be praised, and to His greatness there is no searching; Psalms 145:3.</i> and the extremity of the inferior heaven<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>Shechinah</i>; <i>malchut</i>.</i>—which vests itself in <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>, (that is, in) a category of limitation and number, and suffice this for the initiated.

Chapter 31

<b>THIRTY-ONE.</b> Well known throughout<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., well known in the gates; par. Proverbs 31:23.</i> is the statement in the <i>Tikkunim</i> that the “<i>Shechinah</i> is suffering in the exile”—as it were.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Zohar</i> II:189a-b.</i>
Metaphorically speaking, it is like a bodily ailment [“Who makes a distinction between holy…”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Between holy and profane; Liturgy, Havdalah (par. Leviticus 10:10). A phrase used to emphasize the essential distinction between the subject and object of the metaphorical analogy.</i>]. The cause of illness or health lies in the extension and flow of the life-force vested in the blood of life<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Leviticus 17:11.</i> which flows from the heart to all the limbs, and turning round and around goes the spirit of life<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Ecclesiastes 1:6.</i> and the blood into all the limbs, through the veins<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Emended according to H. V.</i> that are absorbed in them, and returns to the heart.
Now, when the circulation and flow of this spirit of life is always as it should be, in its proper order arranged for it by the Fountainhead of life,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., the Life of life (see above, Epistle 17, note 4).</i> blessed is He, man is perfectly healthy. For all the limbs are bound together and receive their proper vitality from the heart through this circulation.
But if there is any disorder in any place, restraining, hindering, or reducing the circulation of the blood with the spirit of life vested in it, then this bond [which binds all the limbs to the heart through this circulation] is broken or diminished and man will fall ill and sick, may the L–rd have mercy.
Precisely so, metaphorically speaking, all the souls of Israel are regarded as the limbs of the <i>Shechinah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:17a; ibid. 231b (<i>Raaya Mehemna</i>); <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 21 (52a).</i> which is called the “heart,” as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 73:26.</i> “The Rock of my heart,”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Shir Hashirim Rabbah</i> 5:2 (l); <i>Zohar</i> I:59a (cf. <i>Nitzutzei Orot</i>, ad loc.); <i>Zohar</i> II:128b. See also <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i> 21 (52a).</i> and as it is written: “And I will dwell among them.”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 25:8.</i> That is, the term <i>Shechinah</i> denotes that the light of the L–rd dwells in the worlds <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i> in order to vivify them.
The issue of this vivification is by means of a prior investment in the souls of Israel. This is so because none of the creatures are in any approximation to the Creator, blessed be He, for all that are before Him are esteemed as truly naught.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:11b.</i> Thus it is impossible for them to receive vivification from His light and effluence, blessed be He, to become creatures <i>ex nihilo</i> into substantiality, and to be living and subsisting.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. above, Epistle 20.</i> (This is made possible) only through the souls that rose in His thought<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 1:4.</i> and preceded the creation of the worlds by the aspect of Speech.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The creation of the world was by means of the Divine fiats; see <i>Avot</i> 5:1; cf. above, Epistles 5 and 25.</i> Thus our Sages, of blessed memory, said: “With whom did the Holy One, blessed is He, take counsel…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 8:7; <i>Rut Rabbah</i> 2:3.</i> as was made known elsewhere.
And it is well known throughout<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">See above, note 1.</i> that the whole issuance of vivification, and the effluence from the upper worlds to those lower than them, are as stated in the <i>Sefer Yetzirah</i>: “Their beginning is wedged in their culmination, and their culmination is wedged in their beginning.”<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sefer</i> <i>Yetzirah</i> 1:7; cf. the commentary attributed to R. Abraham ibn Daud, ad loc.—The primordial souls in the “original thought” of G–d are thus the conduit for the Divine issuance and effluence.</i> In the writings of the Arizal,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 5, note 103.</i> this is referred to as <i>or yashar</i> (direct light), and <i>or chozer</i> (reflective light),<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 20.</i> and as it is written: “And the animals advanced and retreated (<i>ratzo veshov</i>).”<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 1:14.</i>
Thus, according to these words and this truth<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Par. II Chronicles 32:1.</i>—which it is not possible to explain properly in writing—it follows that the <i>Shechinah</i> is referred to as “heart,” and the souls as “limbs.” This teaches us that when all the souls are attached and bound together, the circulation and flow of the vivification and of the effluence “turns around and around,” and “their culmination is wedged in their beginning” to bind and join them all to “the L–rd (who) is One” to be attached to Him, blessed be He. And thus it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 29:9, 10.</i> “You are standing this day, all of you, before the L–rd your G–d—[stating expressly: “all of you,” and stating expressly: “before”]—your heads…from the hewer of your wood….”<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. above, Epistle 22b, and the notes, ad loc.</i>
And hereby will be understood the saying of our Sages, of blessed memory, that the destruction of the Second Temple and the Fall of Israel into exile, and the withdrawal of the <i>Shechinah</i> and its descent to Edom,<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 25, note 48.</i> into a fate of exile, as it were; all this was because of the sin of groundless hate and a division of hearts,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yoma</i> 9b.</i> the Merciful save us. And that is why (the <i>Shechinah</i>) is referred to as ailing, metaphorically speaking. As<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Emended according to H. V.</i> for “He raises the fallen, and heals the sick,”<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, opening benedictions of the <i>Amidah</i>.</i> in plural form, these are all the limbs….

Chapter 32

<b>THIRTY-TWO.</b> May the L–rd bless their substance, and may the work of their hand be acceptable,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Deuteronomy 33:11.</i> that they may be accepted before the L–rd at all times.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Exodus 28:38.</i> So may the L–rd give and do so yet further to encourage them among the valiant.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Amos 2:16.</i> And he who is noble should ever persist by noble things,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Isaiah 32:8.</i> to be great in causing others to do<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See below, note 10.</i> in every city and congregation,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., <i>minyan</i>; see above, Epistle 1, note 55.</i> and it will be accounted to him for righteousness (<i>tzedakah</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Psalms 106:31.</i>
And of one who does (himself) it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 112:9.</i> “His <i>tzedakah omedet</i> (stands) forever”; <i>omedet</i>, in feminine gender, because he receives<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">The feminine is the recipient aspect, while the masculine is the emanating aspect; cf. above, Epistle 4, note 46, and Epistle 15, note 9.</i> the arousal of his pure heart from the one who is “greater—who causes others to do.”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">He who causes others to do is greater than the doer.—<i>Bava Batra</i> 9a. See <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, <i>Yoreh</i> <i>Deah</i> 249:5, and <i>Turei</i> <i>Zahav</i>, ad loc.</i> Nevertheless, it stands forever.
This means: All the acts of charity and kindness the Israelites perform in this world out of the generosity of their pure hearts are alive and subsist in this physical world until the time of the resurrection. Then there will be a time of manifestation of Divinity and of the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, from the rank of <i>sovev kol almin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Encompassing (transcending) all worlds. See above, Epistle 3, note 12.</i> in this world, and as explained at length in the letter of last year.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Epistle 17.</i>
But there needs to be a vessel and an abode wherein the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, can vest itself, just as the body is (a vessel) to the soul, metaphorically speaking. Thus it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 23:29.</i> “Is not My word like fire”; just as fire does not radiate in this world except when it is attached to, and vests itself in the wick…, as explained elsewhere.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, chs. 35, 52, and 53 (in comment. on <i>Zohar</i> III:187a).</i>
The body and the vessel for His light, blessed be He, is the attribute of kindness and the generosity of the heart to give and effuse vitality to one who has nothing (of his own). Thus it is stated in the <i>Tikkunim</i>:<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 17a.</i> “And many bodies You have prepared for them, and in this preparation they are called: <i>chesed</i>—the right arm,” and the whole body is included in the right side. And thus said the composer: “His garment is <i>tzedakah</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The composer of the liturgical hymn <i>You are our G–d</i> (<i>Machzor</i>, Shacharit for Rosh Hashanah and for Yom Kippur).</i>
This is the meaning of what our Sages, of blessed memory, said:<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sukkah</i> 49b; cf. ref. cited above, Epistle 30, note 15.</i> “Charity is recompensed only according to the kindness in it, as it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 10:12.</i> ‘Sow to yourselves for <i>tzedakah</i>, reap according to the kindness.’” For the harvest is the manifestation of the seed hidden in the soil. It is likewise with the charity and kindness the Israelites perform in the time of the exile: it is hidden and concealed until the time of the resurrection when the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, will vest itself and radiate in this physical world. And (when) He is one with His causations, i.e., the aspects of the <i>kelim</i> of the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 3b; see above, beg. of Epistle 20.</i> thus <i>a fortiori</i> and <i>a minori ad majus</i>, (He is one) with the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, which encompasses all worlds from exceedingly higher than the sphere of <i>Atzilut</i>.
That is why (charity) is referred to as <i>tzedakah</i>, a feminine gender [“his <i>tzedakah omedet</i> forever”]. For it receives a radiation from the light of the <i>En Sof</i> that encompasses all worlds, which vests itself in it in this physical world at the time of the resurrection.
“<i>Tzedek</i> shall go before him,”<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 85:14.</i> however, is a masculine gender. It is the attribute of kindness that is aroused in the heart of man of itself, through the arousal of the love of G–d when reading the <i>Shema</i>—to cleave to Him<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 11:22 (ibid., 30:22).</i> and to surrender his soul at <i>echad</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., to be in a mode of readiness for self-sacrifice for the sanctification of G–d’s Name, when uttering the word <i>echad</i> (the L–rd is One—Deuteronomy 6:4). See the writings of the Arizal dealing with devotions (<i>Shaar</i> <i>Hakavanot</i>; <i>Pri Etz Chaim</i>, etc.) s.v. <i>Keriat Shema</i>; cf. <i>Tikkunei Zohar</i>, Introduction 10b; <i>Bach</i> on <i>Tur</i> <i>Orach</i> <i>Chaim</i> 61 (s.v. <i>Veyikra’enah</i>). See also <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Vayikra</i> 5a, and cf. above, Epistle 28, note 38.</i> and “with all your wealth”<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">“And you shall love the L–rd with all your wealth”; Deuteronomy 6:5.</i>—in the literal sense….<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Berachot</i> 54a and 61b.</i>
And the arousal from below [“As waters (reflect) the face to face, so is the heart of—<i>the Supernal</i>—man…”<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 27:19; see above, Epistle 1, note 26. (The “Supernal Man”—see Ezekiel 1:26.)</i>] elicits an arousal from above,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Set above, Epistle 4, note 45.</i> i.e., an effulgence of the light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, that encompasses all worlds, to the nethermost in this physical world, in a state of manifestation, at the time of the resurrection, as explained at length in last year’s letter.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">See above, note 12.</i>
And this is the meaning of “<i>yehalech</i> before Him.”<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Above, note 20.</i> For (<i>tzedek</i>) leads<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yehalech</i> is an active form of the causative stem of the verb הלך; see above, Epistle 4.</i> and elicits the Supernal Countenance (<i>panim</i>) from higher than <i>Atzilut</i> to the world of <i>Asiyah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">See above, end of Epistle 4; cf. also end of Epistle 30.</i> But now is a time to be brief, and may He not restrain from them all the good.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">In Hebrew this sentence is a play on rhyming words.</i> Be beneficient, O L–rd, to the good, and to those who are upright in their heart,<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 125:4.</i> as is the wish of he who seeks it.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Par. Lamentations 3.25.</i>

Part V; Kuntres Acharon



Chapter 1

KUNTRES ACHARON ON SEVERAL CHAPTERS
To understand how reading narratives in Torah binds one with <i>chochmah ilaah</i>, the supernal wisdom.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">—It is suggested that the reader examine <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, chs. 16, 38, 39, and 44 before studying this section of <i>Kuntres Acharon</i>.<br>Torah is the expression of G–d’s will, the condensation of His thoughts, or wisdom. Mortal intelligence is dimensioned, limited, while G–d’s, as infinite as He is, is the Higher Wisdom. The profound scholarship of Torah would be the obvious means for man’s puny intelligence binding itself to G–d’s, but how can this be the case with narratives that do not strain even mortal intellect?</i>
<i>Kavanot</i> p. 16b says that just as man engages himself (in Torah study) below, so is the likeness, supernal Man,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The infinitude of G–d, in its ultimate degree, precludes any form or description; it is utter simplicity, unitary, with no composition or division. Adjectives are irrelevant; there can be no comprehending Him. In bringing about the existence of Creation with finite beings, at a certain stage aspects of G–d became discreet, at least in potential. These aspects, or attributes, reveal G–d, manifest Him. Where these aspects assume the form of intellect-emotion, or <i>sefirot</i>, we may describe them as <i>Adam HaElyon</i>, supernal man. “Man” comprises the attributes of intellect and emotion, which derive from the parallel Divine attributes. Mortal man’s configuration is “in the image” of Higher Man’s. “Higher Man” exists on each of the Four Worlds; on each plane there is the appropriate revelation of G–d. (See end of note 3 for references on Four Worlds.) <i>Adam HaElyon</i> is identical with <i>memalei kol almin</i>, the permeating Light of G–d that suffuses all existence, adapting itself to the receptivity and absorptive capacities of the existence. On the plane of “intellect” He manifests Himself and is apprehended through intellect; on the plane of “emotion” through emotion, etc. Intellect and emotion vary, and within each there are different stages—corresponding “levels” of G–d are revealed in Supernal Man. (The term “man” as applied to G–d is found in Ezekiel 1:26.) Parenthetically, in reference to Supernal Man “reflecting” mortal man, a Chasidic interpretation of the passage in <i>Avot</i> 2:1, says, “Know that what is Above is from <i>you</i>.”</i> (engaged in Torah study) above…. This might also apply (only) to contemplating the written words (of the Torah). But uttered speech, we may say, pierces and ascends to <i>Atzilut</i><sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">An innate love and fear of G–d are endowed to all Israel, concealed in the recesses of heart and mind. These are not products of his efforts, but a heritage. The love is compared to a child’s devotion to his father, and the fear to the dread of separation from G–d, as through apostacy. All of Torah and <i>mitzvot</i>, including martyrdom, may be fulfilled with the stimulus of these endowed, latent, unconscious emotions without their ever becoming felt in the heart. Only the mind is aware that a certain act divorces man from G–d or binds him to G–d. Man’s involvement in arousing this degree of intellectual awareness is minimal; his devotion and even readiness for sacrifice are “natural” in that he did not create these latent feelings of love and awe that result in his choice of good and rejection of evil. All he need do is realize the consequences of his actions and call them to mind. The Torah and <i>mitzvot</i> of this person ascend to <i>Yetzirah</i>, the world of emotion, of innate capacities. (It must be made emphatically plain here that his choice between self-gratification and devotion to G–d, between “good” and “evil,” has been unimpeded. He may as readily choose one as the other. Of his volition he chooses G–d; he chooses to awaken endowed strengths he possesses by inheritance, but <i>he</i> chooses.)<br>There is a superior state. With all the resources of mind at his command, he meditates on G–d’s greatness and infinitude, on his own insignificance. This entails tremendous intellectual effort, and his mind does eventually comprehend all it is capable of grasping of G–d’s greatness. He will even affirm, in his <i>mind</i>, that he should be filled with a profound longing, to the point of expiration, with a blazing, consuming love of G–d. But this is all in the mind, not a conscious emotion. His <i>heart</i> is not filled with love (or awe). He will observe all G–d demands of him, in thought, speech, and deed. His motivation, his stimulus, is intellectual, lodged in the mind only. The emotions are still latent, but his thought is “good,” as our Sages say (<i>Kiddushin</i> 40a), “G–d joins a good thought to deed.” The “good thought” elevates the deed of Torah study and mitzvah observance to <i>Beriah</i>, the realm of intellect.<br>There is a still higher plane of attainment available, Rabbi Schneur Zalman asserts, to all—arousing a conscious, tangible love and awe, bringing the latent emotion into a feeling manifest in the heart. What his mind understands, his heart actually feels. These emotions are not mere endowments—they are his works, results of his efforts. Chabad teaches the sequence of intellect and emotion, the latter elicited by the mind. This “intellectual” love and fear is the emotion engendered by the intellect, man’s own striving and efforts. Torah and <i>mitzvot</i> resulting from this state ascend to <i>Beriah</i>, but of their “own” accord, because they deserve that exaltation. Love and fear are the “wings” that elevate them (“before G–d”), as we shall soon see.<br>(<i>Atzilut</i> is unity with G–d. Here, there can be no “felt” emotions, sublime as they might be, for feeling posits one who loves in addition to Him Who is loved. This is not unity. Utter self-abnegation, loss of self-awareness completely, man’s becoming a “vehicle” for G–d, with no will but His—this is the province of the <i>tzaddik</i>. Not everyone can attain to this degree, as <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, explains at length. Only the rare <i>tzaddik’s</i> service of Torah and <i>mitzvot</i> ascends to <i>Atzilut</i>, perfect unity with G–d. (The Four Worlds are frequently discussed in Chasidut. See Addendum, Glossary to <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, Four Worlds; Translator’s Explanatory Notes to <i>On Learning Chassidus</i>; <i>Iggeret</i> <i>Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 1, note 3; etc.))</i> itself, or to <i>Beriah</i> through intellectual love and fear, or to <i>Yetzirah</i> through innate fear and love. Through Scripture<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 40.</i> it rises from This World to the ten <i>sefirot</i><sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See references, end of note 3.</i> of <i>Asiyah</i>, for “it pierces atmospheres….” In contrast, thought<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Performance of action <i>mitzvot</i> involves the physical body. Even speech (in prayer, Torah study, etc.) involves physical movement. Through speech and deed, the physical world is elevated. However, there is no evident physical involvement in thinking, so the Divine purpose in creating a physical world is unfulfilled.</i> (affects only) the “likeness,” the source of his soul….
But then we find in <i>Zohar</i>, vol. III, p. 105, that simply thinking achieves nothing…, meaning that it does not have even a beneficient effect;<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., even a desirable thought is ineffective in engendering good.</i> see there and page 31b. But this refers only to eliciting a reaction Above, to call forth from there downward.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">In the “lower” worlds, G–d is concealed. Through <i>mitzvot</i>, the Worlds are illuminated with Divine light. (Cf. <i>Iggeret</i> <i>Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 1, and note 3.)</i> The thought simply remains there, increasing additional great illumination there. The increase in illumination in <i>Atzilut</i> is through study and practice of <i>mitzvot</i> of action in <i>Asiyah</i>, for the Union<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">G–d transcending Creation, time, space, the Infinite for Whom all Creation is naught, becomes united with His Immanent aspect manifest in His works. This Union, resulting from mortal man’s physical observance of Torah and <i>mitzvot</i>, is effected in the Higher Worlds immediately and will be realized in the mundane world with the coming of the Moshiach.</i> is primarily above. Only the fruits reach This World, through calling forth illumination in minute measure here below by speech and deed. However, through mere thinking nothing is called forth. Hence he has not fulfilled the purpose of the soul’s descent into This World, which is only to draw into the lower world supernal illuminations, as <i>Etz Chaim</i> 26 says, “to call forth illumination.”
But to elevate, from below upward, proper thought is imperative, for without awe and love it does not fly upward,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">See above, note 3; <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, chs. 16, 39, 40, etc.</i> as explained in <i>Shaar Hanevuah</i>, ch. 2. And the good thought….<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">“...G–d joins to deed” (see above, note 3). It was explained above that the manner in which to achieve the desired result—to elevate one’s speech, even to the realm of <i>Atzilut</i>—is by actually speaking the words of Torah. Merely thinking the words of Torah, however, “achieves nothing,” i.e., there is no resultant downward flow. There is, though, an increase of light on High. Here the text identifies an additional effect of thinking words of Torah (“good thoughts”): they elevate one’s Torah and <i>mitzvot</i> from below upward, reaching <i>Beriah</i>, the realm of intellect. Hence our Sages said, “G–d joins a good thought to deed.” The “good thought” elevates the deed of Torah study and mitzvah observance to <i>Beriah</i>, the realm of intellect, but no higher, for it is “joined” to deed, but not deed itsef.</i>
But the expression “pierces firmaments…”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 40, note in the text.</i> means even without awe and love, by <i>a fortiori</i> reasoning from the case of idle words, since the measure of good is more generous.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">“…than the measure of retribution” (<i>Sotah</i> 11a).</i> This, however, refers only to “firmaments,” meaning the chambers and abodes, but not the body of Supernal Man.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">In the “likeness” of mortal man Above, Supernal Man has parallels to body and soul, to garments and abode, but of course in noncorporeal terms only. “Garments” of the embodied soul are thought, speech, and deed, and archetypal man has his appropriate “garments.” Physical domicile and environment, separate from man but affecting him profoundly, have their counterparts in Supernal Man. The reader will resist forming anthropomorphic representations of <i>Adam HaElyon</i>; mortal terminology and analogies are all we possess.</i> It certainly does not apply to <i>nefesh</i>, <i>ruach</i>, and <i>neshamah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Addendum, Glossary to <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I. The categories of the human soul are applied to the source of the soul, <i>Adam HaElyon</i>.</i> even of Man of <i>Asiyah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The plane immediately superior to the physical world is the spiritual aspect of <i>Asiyah</i>, with ten <i>sefirot</i> (divine attributes).</i> meaning the ten <i>sefirot</i>, lights, and vessels.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">“Light” refers to the Divine radiance, the revelation, while “vessel” refers to the instrument for the revelation. An analogy—the power of vision is the “light,” while the eye proper is the “vessel.” See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, end of ch. 4.</i> This is the intention of <i>Tikkunim</i>, that without fear and love it cannot ascend or stand before G–d, stressing before <i>G–d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Thus, to summarize: Torah words uttered without love and awe “rise,” to the extent of “piercing firmaments,” but not to (as high as) G–d’s presence. In order for one’s Torah study and <i>mitzvot</i> to ascend before the G–dliness of each respective world, they must be carried out with awe and love.</i>

Chapter 2

Examine <i>Etz Chaim</i>, <i>Shaar Hanekudot</i> 8:6, the statement that there can be no “turning of face to face”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Re’eh</i>, 32b, Rabbi Schneur Zalman interprets the term “face to face” (<i>panim b’fanim</i>) as “internal”: the internal aspect of G–d’s will shall illuminate the source of the souls of Israel, when man’s inner will is directed to G–d. <i>Panim</i>, face, also implies “inner.”</i> except through <i>mitzvot</i> requiring action<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., donning <i>tefillin</i>, giving charity, etc., as differentiated from <i>mitzvot</i> performed through speech and thought.</i> exclusively. The reason is that good deeds cause the supernal union….
The understanding of why <i>mitzvot</i> which require action specifically have this effect lies in the statement in <i>Shaar Man Umad</i>, that the first step must be elevation of <i>mayin nukvin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">See Addendum, Glossary to <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I. <i>Nukva</i> (pl. <i>nukvin</i>), “feminine,” describes the recipient, who must in this context take the initiative to arouse the “donor,” the “masculine,” or G–d. <i>Mayin nukvin</i> (feminine waters) in transliterated abbreviation is <i>man</i>. <i>Iggeret Hakodesh</i>, Epistle 8, notes that “arousal from below” is identical with <i>haaloat man</i>, “elevation of the feminine waters,” the term employed by the Arizal. (On the Arizal, see Introduction to <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I.)</i> of <i>nukva</i> of the Minor Visage,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">See below, Essay 3, note 8.</i> and the <i>mayin nukvin</i> of <i>nukva</i> is the state of action,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Essay 1, note 3. Only in the lower worlds, apparently from their Creator, is the labor of purification necessary.</i> as explained there, ch. 1.
Good deeds are described as trimming and hacking off the thistles that attach themselves to the hinderpart, the state of deed, as written in (<i>Etz Chaim</i>) <i>Shaar</i> 47:5. This pruning is effected through elevating the element of good concealed in them that is enclothed in <i>mitzvot</i> of action, elevating it to its source, to the sanctity of <i>Atzilut</i> that has already been purified.
The statement there that Adam made rectification through prayer as well means through the utterances of speech, for the movement of the lips is also deemed a deed.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Sanhedrin</i> 45a.</i> Utterances are from the vivifying soul<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Addendum, Glossary, <i>Nefesh ha-bahamit</i>.</i> in the body and his blood, whose source is in <i>nogah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid., <i>Kelipat nogah</i>.</i>
The purifications of <i>Asiyah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup> ascend to <i>Yetzirah</i><sup>5</sup> through the name of ב“ן,<sup>9</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, ch. 7, note 48.</i> and from <i>Yetzirah</i> to <i>Beriah</i> and <i>Atzilut</i>, as noted in <i>Shaar Man</i>, <i>Drush</i> 11:7.
Thus we can understand why mere thought accomplishes nothing,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Essay 1.</i> for without elevating <i>mayin nukvin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup> from the “kings of <i>nogah</i>,” it is impossible to draw forth drops from above to effect the union of <i>zun</i>,<sup>11</sup><i class="footnote">See below, Essay 6, note 7.</i> for its desire is to seek nurture from its “mother” rather than giving forth for the lower realms, as written in <i>Shaar Man</i>, <i>Drush 2</i>.
