See also <i>Zohar</i>, <i>Parashat Pekudei</i>, 244b, that there is an order…to gaze upon…. These are the intentions in prayer, and the supernal unions, for those who know and understand how to “gaze upon….” For their very own <i>nefesh-ruach-neshamah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Addendum, Glossary; see above, Essay 1, note 15.</i> are <i>man</i>, with selfless devotion for the Torah, and during the <i>Tachanun</i> prayer, as is known.

Chapter 3

<i>[The reader is referred to Likkutei Amarim, Part I, chs. 39 and 40.]</i><br>To understand the statement in <i>Shaar Hayichudim</i>, ch. 2, that through Torah without proper intention (<i>kavanah</i>) angels are created in the World<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">See below, Essay 6, note 3, for references to Four Worlds.</i> of <i>Yetzirah</i>: There he quotes <i>Zohar</i>, <i>Parashat</i> <i>Shelach</i>, “There is no voice lost…except the voice of Torah and prayer that ascends and pierces….” Through<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Here a contradictory statement is offered. First we learn that lack of <i>kavanah</i> does not completely inhibit Torah, for it attains to <i>Yetzirah</i>. Then we are told that prayer without <i>kavanah</i> is repelled.</i> intention in prayer angels are created in the World of <i>Beriah</i>, as with intention in Torah. Without intention it is repelled, hurled down utterly. So it is stated in <i>Zohar</i>, <i>Parashat</i> <i>Pekudei</i> 245b, “In the lowest firmament…that are called invalid prayers…” See also <i>Parashat</i> <i>Vayakhel</i> 201b, “If it is a seemly word….”
However, the difference between Torah and prayer without intention is obvious. For in the study of Torah he knows and comprehends what he is learning, for otherwise it is not called study at all. It is only that he is learning simply, without the intention “for its sake,”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 5, Torah “for its sake” is defined as the intention of binding one’s soul with G–d through comprehension of Torah, each man according to his capacities. In ch. 39 we find three categories of intention: a) improper intention, for ulterior motives like becoming a scholar, b) “neutral” intention, resulting from ingrained habit, for example, and c) “for its sake,” through arousing at least the natural love and reverence. (On “natural” love, see above, Essay 1, note 3.) The reparation of the first sort of Torah study is effected through repentance. The second is elevated when he studies again with the proper intention, but repentance is not needed.</i> out of the manifest love of G–d in his heart, but only out of the latent natural love.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Essay 1, note 3.</i> But he does not study with an actual negative purpose, for his aggrandisement….<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">This is the first category in note 3. See note 11 below.</i> “For this does not ascend higher than the sun,” as stated in <i>Parashat</i> <i>Vayechi</i> 223b. That is because his thought and intention are clothed within the utterances of speech and prevent them from ascending.
So, too, with prayer without intention, where he entertains alien thoughts. (But since his intention is for Heaven,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">His mind wanders during prayer, but he prays only to G–d.</i> therefore it is easily corrected, that it may still rise when he prays with proper intention, even one full prayer gathered piecemeal from the prayers of the entire year. Thus is written in <i>Mikdash Melech</i> on <i>Pekudei</i>.)
To return to the quotation from <i>Zohar</i>, <i>Parashat</i> <i>Pekudei</i>, “in the lowest firmament,” while in <i>Vayakhel</i> the implication is that only “if it is a seemly word does it ascend with it to the atmosphere of the firmaments above….” This seeming contradiction is no problem. The expression in <i>Parashat</i> <i>Pekudei</i>, “The inferior firmament of those firmaments that conduct the world,” refers to <i>malchut</i><sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Each of the Divine attributes (kindness, severity, etc.) has its unique nature and functions, and each manifests G–d differently. His bounty, for example, is an expression of the attribute of <i>chesed</i>, kindness. The particular attribute is the source of the bounty, to be sure, but the actual performance of the attribute is through <i>malchut</i> (the seventh of the emotive attributes, lit., “sovereignty”). The manifestation of G–d in terms apprehensible to us, i.e., the physical conduct of the world, is through the <i>malchut</i> of the World of <i>Asiyah</i>, our mundane universe. For more discussion of <i>malchut</i>, see <i>The Tzemach Tzedek and the Haskalah Movement</i>, p. 110, note 3.</i> of <i>Asiyah</i>. In <i>Parashat</i> <i>Vayakhel</i> the reference is to the Minor Visage of <i>Asiyah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">The term “visage,” like other anthropomorphic expressions, is common in Kabbalah and Chasidut. “Major Visage” (<i>arich anpin</i>) refers to the Divine will, and “Minor Visage” (<i>z’eyr anpin</i>) to the revealed emotive attributes. Generally, the latter term refers to the first six emotive attributes, while <i>malchut</i>, the last, is considered a class unto itself. The “Visages” are on all planes, in all “Worlds,” correspondingly higher or lower in accordance with the World in question.</i> This is supported by <i>Etz Chaim</i>, <i>Shaar Hashemot</i>, ch. 3, in reference to the Minor Visage of <i>Asiyah</i>, see there.
The apparent reference may be drawn from <i>Parashat</i> <i>Pekudei</i> that even invalid prayer ascends to the First Chamber,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Essay 1, note 14.</i> from where it is hurled down, and this (chamber) is in the Minor Visage of <i>Beriah</i>. This is no difficulty, for even palpable sins, minor and grave, ascend to there, even to the Fourth Chamber, as noted on page 252a. It is certain, therefore, that the ascensions are not identical, and there can be no comparison or similarity between them except for the common name. This will suffice for the knowing.
This will also aid us in grasping the passage on page 247 that in the Second Chamber are the garments that clothe the soul as a result of performance of <i>mitzvot</i>, though they are in the Lower <i>Gan Eden</i><sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">After the death of the body, the soul continues to live as a spiritual entity, quite apart from all corporeality. Its earlier mortal life did affect it profoundly though, whether his life was exemplary or not. If man sinned, G–d forbid, his soul suffers a concomitant defect or contamination and must undergo a process we call punishment or purification or correction. Any discussion of this must be cautious, for our experiences and conceptions are physical. We cannot truly conceive the nature of an abstract disembodied spiritual being, nor have we any inkling into its experience of what we would call pleasure or pain. Thus, we can declare, that the soul cannot remain in this state of imperfection, bearing the stains and scars of evil. When the purification is completed, the soul enters into <i>Gan Eden</i>. Here the soul enjoys the pleasant consequences of its good deeds in its physical life. Unconstricted by body, the soul can now have an awareness, an apprehension, of G–d’s being and propinquity, an experience the Talmud describes as “enjoying the radiance of G–d’s presence.” This consciousness of G–d will vary according to the soul and the life it led. A life of intellect, Torah study, will result in an intellectual appreciation of G–d; a life of fervent worship will establish an emotion-relationship; a life of social endeavor will bring its consonant effects, and so on. Then too the soul’s relationship with G–d is not static, for it progresses in its sensitivity to G–dliness. “They shall go from strength to strength,” says the Psalmist (84:8), and the Talmud declares that the righteous have no “rest” in This or the Coming Worlds. In broad terms we may say that there are numerous, if not an infinite, number of planes, categorized as the Higher and Lower <i>Gan Eden</i>. We have noted the existence of “Worlds” on different levels of spirituality or corporeality, ranging from virtually total unity and immersion in the Infinite to the point of nonexistence, down to our physical universe where the spiritual is subordinate and G–d so concealed that He can be denied. As the presence of G–d is concealed, the independent existence of creatures becomes possible, the ultimate being physical creatures. One step above this mundane World, called <i>Asiyah</i>, is its spiritual counterpart and antecedent, the Lower <i>Gan Eden</i> of <i>Asiyah</i>. The soul ascends to the Lower <i>Gan Eden</i> as “reward” for performance of <i>mitzvot</i> and to the Higher <i>Gan Eden</i> in accordance with its <i>kavanah</i> (intention and dedication).</i> of <i>Asiyah</i>, as stated there on page 210.
Invalid prayer is superior to Torah studied with distinctly improper intention, for such Torah attains to a position lower than the sun,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The term “under the sun” is found in Ecclesiastes 1:3<i>—</i>“What gain has man of all his striving under the sun.” The Talmud (<i>Shabbat</i> 30b) comments that man’s labors “under the sun” are vanity, for these are worldly strivings, but there is gain in striving “higher than the sun,” meaning study of Torah. In <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Ekev</i> 13d, Rabbi Schneur Zalman writes, “If one studies Torah for his own glory, wanting to achieve something, to be considered a person of worth, this study is called ‘under the sun,’ where everything is vanity….” This sort of Torah study is the first category in note 3 of this Essay.</i> while prayer is “in the firmament….” But simple Torah, without negative intention but merely of the latent innate love, is not inferior to the “breath of the mouths of school children”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 119b.</i> which ascends because it is “breath untainted by sin.” It ascends, though it may be of clearly negative intention, out of fear of punishment by the teacher. See 255b, (where it states) that the angels elevate the breath of studying children to <i>Atzilut</i>.

Chapter 4

To understand the passage in <i>Pri Etz Chaim</i>, that in the contemporary period the primary refinement<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">See Addendum, Glossary to <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, <i>Birur</i>.</i> is only through prayer, though Torah study is superior to prayer. The explanation is:
Through Torah and <i>mitzvot</i>, additional Light<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">See Addendum, Glossary, <i>Or</i>; Essay 1 and notes 3 and 9.</i> is drawn forth into <i>Atzilut</i>…. This means that through Torah study the Light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, is drawn into the vessels of <i>Atzilut</i>, into the inner aspect of the vessels. This Light is an extension and revelation of the Divine intellect.
Through mitzvah observance (the Light is drawn) into the external aspect of the vessels, meaning <i>netzach-hod-yesod</i> of the ten <i>sefirot</i> of the Minor Visage of <i>Atzilut</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Netzach-hod-yesod</i> are the penultimate attributes. On the ten <i>sefirot</i> see Addendum, Glossary. On Minor Visage see Essay 3, note 8.</i> Subsequently they clothe themselves in <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">See references in Essay 1, note 3.</i> in the physical Torah and <i>mitzvot</i> in This World.
However, prayer calls forth the Light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, specifically into <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>, not merely through “garbs,”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">“Garbs” indicate concealment, adaptation. See note 70.</i> but the Light itself, to modify the state of creatures. The ill will be cured, for example, the rain will fall earthward that vegetation may sprout forth.
On the other hand, through Torah and <i>mitzvot</i> there is no modification in the parchment of the <i>tefillin</i> through donning them on head and arm. Even those <i>mitzvot</i> that are fulfilled through making the object—that change is effected by man, and not by Heaven, as is the case with prayer. The latter calls forth the vivifying power from the Infinite, blessed is He, Who alone is all-capable.
Hence, calling forth the Light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, into the lower world is impossible without the elevation of <i>mayin nukvin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">See Essay 2, note 1. The the Light of the <i>En Sof</i> does not penetrate to the finite worlds spontaneously.</i> from below specifically.
By contrast, Torah study affects <i>Atzilut</i>, which is united in any case with the Emanator, blessed is He.
The elevation of <i>mayin nukvin</i> in the mind and heart of man is (the love of G–d in) a state of boundless flames of fire, and described as <i>meodecha</i>, to arouse the (Divine) state of Infinite.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Meodecha</i> (Deuteronomy 6:5) refers to absolute devotion, unrestrained and without reservation. It is the state of infinity in mortal terms and can thus arouse the true Infinite.</i> This is through the Severities of ס“ג,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 46, note 29. Each Name denotes another aspect of G–d.</i> which constitute the 288 sparks….<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">See Addendum, Glossary, <i>nitzotzot</i>.</i>
For this reason prayer is called “life of the moment,”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 10a.</i> for it is <i>malchut</i><sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">See Essay 3, note 7.</i> descending into <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>. Torah (by contrast is called) “eternal life,”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup> or the “Minor Visage,”<sup>12</sup><i class="footnote">See ibid., note 8.</i> for the 248 commandments divide into the ten vessels of the ten <i>sefirot</i> of the Minor Visage….
Now, in one place we find that the 248 positive commandments are (rooted) in the Five Kindnesses<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">“Severities” are limitations, withholding; “Kindnesses” are beneficence, granting. In their source, before they are translated into tangible forms of human kindness or sternness, they are quite abstract, removed from human context. Revelation proceeds by the stages of intellect, emotion, etc. Verbalization of the abstract thought is a limitation on the thought. The “Five Severities” are the five articulations (<i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, ch. 4) that clothe the disembodied thought in “letters.” This is a limitation, placing bounds on the idea. In turn, only through verbalization can the recipient, the lower plane, absorb the idea. For the inferior, then, the limitation is beneficence, or the “Five Kindnesses.” Translator’s Notes to <i>On Learning Chassidus</i>; <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 4, note 16.</i> and the 365 prohibitions in the Five Severities…. Elsewhere we find that there are 613 paths from one path…which is the pristine whiteness (<i>lavnunit</i> of supernal <i>keter</i>)….<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">The “whiteness” refers to the source of <i>mitzvot</i> in the Divine will, where there is as yet no “coloration” or inclination toward any particular deed. The emotive attributes (love, fear. etc.), intense and powerful as they may be, are defined, hence limited. Even intellect at its most abstract already has some definition. The soul proper transcends all its powers and is relatively “boundless.” Will, particularly in its state of “whiteness,” is indivisible from the soul. Since the soul and its powers are analogous to G–d and the <i>sefirot</i>, the Divine will (origin of <i>mitzvot</i>) is a state of unity with Him.</i>
The explanation is: all <i>mitzvot</i> are designed to “repair” the 248 organs<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 1.</i> of the Minor Visage through drawing the Light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, into the (Divine) intellect as contained within the Five Kindnesses and Five Severities. The source of (this) intellect is the <i>lavnunit (of keter</i>)…, which is the supreme delight and desire to bring the light down into the 248 organs of the Minor Visage. The Light drawn forth divides into 613 individual streams according to the respective level of the <i>mitzvot</i>. For instance, through charity and kindness the Light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, is drawn into the external aspect of the vessel of the Kindness of the Minor Visage while through observing a prohibition into the external aspect of Severity (of the Minor Visage), and through mercy (into <i>tiferet</i> of the Minor Visage)….
The passage of the issuing Light is through the internality of the vessels and their intellects, which are love and reverence, intellectual or innate,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">See Essay 1, note 3.</i> meaning major or minor (Divine) intellect.
This is the reason for Moses’ fervent plea to fulfill the <i>mitzvot</i> of performance contingent on the Land,<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">According to <i>Biblical</i> Law, some agricultural laws (tithes. Sabbatical year, etc.) are operative only in <i>Eretz Yisrael</i>, for example.</i> for these are the ultimate purpose in the gradual descent [i.e., Creation]—to call forth the Light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, to purify the vessels of the Minor Visage of <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">See Translator’s Explanatory Notes to <i>On</i> <i>Learning Chassidus</i>; Essay 3, note 8.</i> These worlds are the site of the 288 sparks. (The purification is effected) exclusively through Torah study and <i>mitzvot</i> requiring action in <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>.
To perform a mitzvah that cannot be delegated to another, one foregoes Torah study,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Moed Kattan 9a</i>.</i> even that of the <i>maaseh merkavah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 1.</i> and beyond question one forgoes prayer, which is the state of intellect and intellectual love and awe.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">See note 16. In prayer one arouses the appropriate emotion, following the preparation of study and contemplation.</i> The reason is as we have noted.
In addition: the magnitude of the quality of <i>mitzvot</i> requiring action and their study far transcends the quality of intellect, meaning intellectual love and fear. For though the verse declares, “to cleave to Him”<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 11:22 and <i>Rashi</i>; <i>Nedarim</i> 65a.</i> through His attributes, still one does not cleave to the essence of the Supreme attributes but only to their state of existence,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>On the Teachings of Chassidus</i>, p. 21, note 6, defining knowledge of “existence” and knowledge of “essence” or “character.”</i> in conformity with, “I am dust and ashes.”<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 18:27. See <i>Iggeret Hakodesh</i>, Epistle 15, for an explanation of the verse.</i>
This is all the more true in terms of the Light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, for no thought can apprehend Him in His radiance<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">The term “radiance” and similar expressions indicate that it is not G–d’s essence but only an emanation from Him, comparable to the body of the sun and its light (radiance) or “extension.”</i> or the extension of the life-force issuing from Him, blessed be He. One can grasp His existence, that He gives life to all, but not His essence.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup> This applies even to the supernal beings,<sup>26</sup><i class="footnote">The angels, whose intellectual comprehension far exceeds the mortal’s. <i>On the Teachings of Chassidus</i>, p. 23; <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 4, note 14.</i> as we find, “Holy holy holy is the L–rd of hosts….”<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 6:3.</i> Only emanated “effects”<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Orderly progression involves the process of cause and effect, with a measurable relationship between them. The “cause” contains the “effect” in potential; the “effect” bears the impress of the “cause.” Intellect and emotion (see note 18) are examples. Creation <i>ex nihilo</i> is not an “orderly” process. The created is a “thing,” while its antecedent is “nothing.” The gap is absolute. The final three of the Four Worlds are “creatures,” while <i>Atzilut</i> is “emanation,” united with the Emanator, G–d.</i> can conceive their “cause,” according to the order in <i>Etz Chaim</i> in the investment of the visages.
However, creatures are denied this apprehension, even the souls of <i>Atzilut</i>, as we find regarding Moses, “You may see my hinderpart….”<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 33:23. See note 33.</i>
But the performance of <i>mitzvot</i>—“these are the works of G–d.”<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">A play on Exodus 32:16, referring to the Tablets of the Ten Commandments. The Decalogue embodies all 613 precepts. See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 36; <i>Rashi</i> on Exodus 24:12.</i> In the process of gradual descent<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup> from the vessels of <i>Atzilut</i> to <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>, from the very nature<sup>23</sup> and essence<sup>18</sup> of their external aspect, as for example within the <i>etrog</i> and its “kinds,”<sup>31</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 23:40.</i> the Holy One, blessed is He, clothed of the very essence<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">The “palpability,” to use a grossly inappropriate term, of G–d’s presence in the object of a performed mitzvah (<i>etrog</i> or <i>tefillin</i>, say) is far superior to the awareness of G–d that is possible through the greatest of man’s intellectual and emotional resources. The key word in this paragraph is “essence,” and in the following contrasting paragraph the opposing term is “existence.”</i> of the internal Kindnesses of the Minor Visage, meaning from their outward state, as is known in the case of all <i>mitzvot</i> of action.
In contrast, man, even possessing a soul of <i>Atzilut</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Moses has just been mentioned as one of these. Souls share a common source (see <i>On Learning Chassidus</i>) in the Creator, but they descend through the Worlds until they enter the body. The <i>Atzilut</i> soul retains its <i>Atzilut</i> character and is impervious to the “environment” of the lower Worlds. It continues its state of unity. The “<i>Beriah</i> soul” acquires the characteristics of that World and is immune to influence in the lower, and so on. See note 70.</i> since it is clothed in a body, cannot detect and apprehend within his soul the character and essence of the inward Kindnesses of the Minor Visage of <i>Atzilut</i>. (For <i>Atzilut</i> is the state of <i>chaya</i><sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">The four names of the soul parallel the Four Worlds. <i>Nefesh</i> is <i>Asiyah</i>, deed; <i>ruach</i> is <i>Yetzirah</i>, emotion, speech; <i>neshamah</i> is <i>Beriah</i>, intellect, thought; <i>chaya</i> is <i>Atzilut</i>. A fifth, highest aspect of the soul, is <i>yechidah</i>. The lowest three are abbreviated as <i>naran</i>. See Essay 1, note 16; <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 1, note 3.</i> in the general Four Worlds, an encompassing<sup>18</sup> state from above, and does not clothe itself within any vessel at all). Man’s capacity for apprehension is limited to their existence through intellectual love and fear.
The statement, “You shall see my hinderpart,” is by means of prophecy only. (Prophecy entails divestment of the physical,<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Except for Moses, all the Prophets were granted visions or dreams; theirs was not a conscious revelation—simultaneous revelation and continued awareness by the Prophet of his body and environment. The “trance” was a “divestment of the physical.”</i> as explained in <i>Raaya Mehemna</i>, <i>Parashat Mishpatim</i>.)
This then is the reason: No creature is capable of grasping anything whatsoever of the essence<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup> of G–dliness, the Creator. Without comprehension there is no investing, or grasp,<sup>36</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 3.</i> or cleaving in the true sense.
However, the <i>etrog</i>, by way of example, its life is drawn and descends from the very essence of the outer aspect of the vessels of <i>nukva</i> of the Minor Visage of <i>Atzilut</i>, which is a state of G–dliness, as stated in <i>Etz Chaim</i> that all the fruits are (rooted) in <i>Atzilut</i>. For the thirty vessels<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">The vessels of <i>Atzilut</i> “contain” the Light of the <i>En Sof</i>, a stage in its descent into finiteness. The lower stage of the superior plane becomes the higher stage (soul) of the lower plane, roughly in the manner of a chain of links. The “thirty” vessels invest the three inferior finite worlds—the ten (analogous to the ten <i>sefirot</i>) internal vessels in <i>Beriah</i>, the ten intermediate in <i>Yetzirah</i>, the ten externals in <i>Asiyah</i>.</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> descended into <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i> (they are the Ten Utterances<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 5:1; <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 4, note 16.</i> by which the world was created) through enclothement in <i>nukva Asiyah</i>, essence in essence.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">In his Comments and Corrections to <i>Tanya</i>, the Lubavitcher Rebbe, Rabbi Menachem M. Schneerson, suggests that the parenthesis ends here.</i> For the vessels of <i>Atzilut</i> became the soul of <i>Asiyah</i>, which is actually a state of G–dliness. In <i>Atzilut</i> “He and the vessels are one,”<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Iggeret Hakodesh</i>, Epistle 20.</i> Emanator and Emanation. Through clothing, the essence of soul in the essence of the vessels of <i>nukva</i> of <i>Asiyah</i>, the <i>etrog</i> came into being.
The result is that in holding the <i>etrog</i> and waving it as the <i>halachah</i> requires, he is actually holding the life-force clothed within it of the <i>nukva</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> which is united with the Light of the <i>En Sof</i>, the Emanator, blessed is He.
The reverse is true concerning his <i>kavanah</i> (intention). Here he does not grasp and seize its essence, even though he is familiar with the mystical (meanings involved).<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sod</i>, the esoteric or mystic interpretation of Torah, including Kabbalah. The initiated may be conversant and knowledgeable with the terms and concepts, but he cannot in this manner penetrate beyond “existence” in “essence.”</i> Only the existence aspect is within reach. However, by learning the laws of <i>etrog</i> he does attain and grasp the <i>etrog</i> proper and its mitzvah appropriately, by speech and thought.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Here speech and thought are the fulfillment of the mitzvah of learning. This is not comparable to <i>kavanah</i> of a mitzvah without the mitzvah.</i> Even more so he who learns the <i>sod</i> aspect of the law. Here we speak of (studying) the <i>sod</i> aspect of the mitzvah specifically, which is not inferior to the study of its laws proper—quite the contrary…though he does not apprehend the essence. 
This does not apply to study of the order of <i>hishtalshelut</i>, the orderly downward progression.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup> Even if he does comprehend the existence state, it is not intrinsically as worthy as study of the <i>mitzvot</i>, where he comprehends and grasps the essential nature.<sup>43</sup><i class="footnote">In studying the law one can fully comprehend the theoretical, legal aspects, and the practical aspects, the nature of the subject he studies. See <i>On Learning Chassidus</i>, p. 37 ff.</i> This is considered (in certain cases) the equivalent of actual performance, as we find “This is the Torah….”<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 7:37; <i>Menachot</i> 110a.</i>
Be it noted that knowledge of existence aspects of <i>hishtalshelut</i> is also a lofty mitzvah and an exalted one. On the contrary it outweighs them all, as we find, “Know this day…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:39.</i> and “Know the G–d of your fathers…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 28:9.</i> and it develops into a “whole heart…,”<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid.</i> which is the essential thing. Comprehension of existence entails divesting (this subject) from the physical….
However, this is but one mitzvah of the 613, and man must fulfill all 613, for they descend from the essence of the external aspect of the vessels of <i>Atzilut</i>. Hence one must abundantly study all 613 and fulfill them fully in practice in thought, speech, and deed. These are parallel to <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>, to refine whatever needs refining within those worlds.
In addition: the truth is that the refinements in <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i> of the 288 sparks<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup> through Torah and <i>mitzvot</i> (that man fulfills) in thought, speech, and deed are superior in their source to the <i>nefesh-ruach-neshamah</i><sup>34</sup> of man. They are of ס“ג<sup>8</sup> of the internal aspect of <i>Adam Kadmon</i>,<sup>48</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>On Learning Chassidus</i>.</i> while the <i>nefesh-ruach-neshamah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup> that has already been corrected through מ“ה<sup>8</sup> issues from the “forehead” (of <i>Adam Kadmon</i>) in the form of a mere reflection (of it). Hence the verse, “Before a king ruled….”<sup>49</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 36:31. “Before” (not in time but on a preceding plane) the Condensation (<i>Tzimtzum</i>, see Translator’s Explanatory Notes to <i>On Learning Chassidus</i>), the Light of the <i>En Sof</i> shone forth “abundantly,” in greater measure than the absorptive capacities of the vessels. The “shattering of the vessels” took place, and the “sparks” scattered. This intolerable and unviable situation is called <i>tohu</i> (after Genesis 1:2) and refers to the period in the verse, “before a king ruled.” <i>Tikkun</i> took the place of <i>tohu</i>, a sharp diminution of Light and an increase in vessels, the process of downward progression with all the Worlds involved, culminating in our world. The mission of man is to call forth increased Divine light into the world, the “vessels.” Man is to elevate the fallen sparks by utilizing the material world for Divine purpose (performance of <i>mitzvot</i>, etc.), rather than indulgence, and by rejecting what G–d has forbidden him.</i> For this reason man sustains himself on foods of the inorganic, vegetative, and living classes, and purifies them by the מ“ה<sup>8</sup> within him, and lives through them because they are of ס“ג.<sup>8</sup>
Furthermore, as we find, “My face shall not be seen,”<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 33:23. The Hebrew word <i>panai</i> (my face) implies <i>pnimiyut</i> (inwardness).</i> meaning that the inwardness of the Most High cannot descend below, only the external and the hinderpart, which are an attenuated form of the supreme wisdom.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">See Essay 6, notes 13-14.</i>
Another point:<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">In the innate shortcoming of speech and thought. The contrast is with the seminal “drop” that has the generative power, the offspring similar to the parent. The “drop” is drawn from the brain, the seat of intellect (see <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 2). If the extension of the “brain” (supreme wisdom) is merely thought or speech, then the generative power is lacking.</i> Verbalizing any phrase of the supreme wisdom does not cause birth. The drop drawn from the vessel of the supreme wisdom has the power to cause birth and bring about existence <i>ex nihilo</i>. Besides, something of the supreme wisdom is included within it. The reason is that into it is drawn something of the essence<sup>18</sup> and nature<sup>23</sup> of the supreme wisdom.
In contrast, in thought and speech, even in intellectual conception<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Original, creative thinking, the intellectual activity closest to the source, the intellect.</i> in any field of wisdom, the thought is a mere reflection, an extension<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Every thought is of necessity a limitation of the power of intellect. The intellectual powers and the specific idea may be compared to the body of the sun and its rays. Intellect in turn is not the essence of soul, but a mere manifestation of soul. Thus the idea is several removes from the essence of the thinker.</i> of the essence of intellect of the soul. Then, too, this radiance is a mere garment for the essence of the intellect. In turn, the intellect is a radiance and a garment for the soul proper. However, the drop has drawn into it also of the very essence of the soul, which is clothed within the brain. Hence it gives birth to offspring precisely similar to itself.
This is the difference between the service of angels, who are produced by “osculation,”<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, chs. 45 and 46.</i> and that of souls, who issue from the vessels.
But the vessels of <i>Atzilut</i> become the soul of <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>, and therefore intellectual love and awe are comparable to the angels of the “osculation,” of the external aspect of <i>chabad </i><sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Chochmah-binah-daat</i>, the “intellectual” attributes of G–d or powers of the human soul.</i> in <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>.
The reason is that the inwardness of <i>chabad</i> and the essential nature of the inward Light cannot be revealed except through the radiance of the vessels exclusively that descend, as does the seminal drop of man issuing from the brain. Thus the verse, “My face cannot be seen.”<sup>50</sup>
Besides all this, even a soul (<i>neshamah</i>) of <i>Atzilut</i>, though it is of the vessels of <i>Atzilut</i>, and equally in the case of <i>nefesh-ruach</i><sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup> of the vessels of <i>Yetzirah</i>-<i>Asiyah</i>—their intellectual love [and fear] too arouse in the vessels of <i>Yetzirah</i>-<i>Asiyah</i>, the state of elevation from below upward, through an arousal from below.<sup>57</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 1, note 26.</i> However, this is the state of departure<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">The author will shortly contrast two elevations, of vessels and of lights, the former alone being desirable. He will cite examples of light-vessel relationships, like soul and body, or emotion and deed. The soul must invest the body to give it life; emotion must inspire the deed. When the vessel “rises” to receive the light, the purpose is fulfilled. When the light “rises,” it removes itself from the vessel or instrument. Then soul does not vivify body, and emotion does not engender deed. In terms of the Divine light, the ascent of the vessel is its receptive ability fulfilled; ascent of light is the obscuring of G–d.</i> alone, G–d forbid.
But eliciting from above downward is of necessity through operational <i>mitzvot</i> to draw Light into the vessels and into the external aspect of the vessels, be it emphasized. The external aspect of the higher descends, while the internal of the lower rises higher. This is the intent of <i>Zohar</i> <i>Parashat Pekudei</i> cited above, that there is an order….
Both of these are needed for the Divine purpose, the elevation,<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Of the inferior, the vessel or instrument, the recipient.</i> and the elicitation<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Drawing the light, the superior, downward.</i> through elevation of <i>mayin nukvin</i><sup>6</sup> from ס“ג<sup>8</sup> by deed and speech.
This is the ultimate purpose of the downward progression<sup>18</sup>—to reveal the Higher Light below, and not to elevate the inferior. This elevation can only be momentary. Even so specifically the elevation of the vessels to the Supernal Lights is the quality of Shabbat and Yom Kippur, but not the elevations and departure<sup>58</sup> of the Lights, G–d forbid, as written in <i>Pri</i> <i>Etz Chaim</i>.
The <i>nefesh-ruach-neshamah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup> of man compared to his physical body in This World is considered as lights compared to vessels. So, too, are intellectual fear and love compared to operational <i>mitzvot</i>. Therefore Moses offered (515) prayers, equivalent in number to <i>Va’etchanan</i>,<sup>61</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 3:23 and <i>Daat Zekenim</i>.</i> for the fulfillment of <i>mitzvot</i> requiring action specifically. So, too,<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">These, too, are considered vessels.</i> for the physical utterance of their laws.
We must understand how an <i>etrog</i>, which is of the 288 sparks that have not yet been refined, and the parchment of the <i>tefillin</i> can elicit Light into the vessels of <i>zun</i><sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">See Essay 6, note 7.</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, that have already been so refined and rectified through the Name of מ“ה<sup>8</sup> that they are a state of G–dliness.
An illustration for this could be the process of planting. The seed stimulates the power of growth within the soil, which is G–d’s command, “Let the earth sprout forth…fruit trees…”<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 1:11.</i> through elevation of <i>mayin nukvin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup> to its source. In this manner the parchment and <i>etrog</i> arouse until the loftiest heights, meaning the Name of ס“ג,<sup>8</sup> which is above the shattering of the vessels,<sup>65</sup><i class="footnote">See note 49.</i> which is the very essence of the Lights in <i>Adam Kadmon</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>On Learning Chassidus</i>, p. 15 ff.</i> and not merely a radiance,<sup>25</sup> as is the Name of מ“ה,<sup>8</sup> which issues from the “forehead.”
Similarly, the study and careful examination of their<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tefillin</i> and <i>etrog</i>, the examples cited here.</i> laws arouses the <i>chabad </i><sup>56</sup> of the ten <i>sefirot</i> of the vessels of <i>zun</i><sup>63</sup> and upward to the greatest heights, including <i>chabad</i> of ס“ג of the inner dimension of <i>Adam Kadmon</i> issuing through the “eyes (of <i>Adam Kadmon</i>)….”
All the foregoing concerns positive commandments, but not the study of particulars of the prohibitions it would seem, particularly those that do not occur in practice at all, for example, the detailed laws of <i>pigul </i><sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 7:18. See below, Essay 5.</i> and the like.
There is yet a common characteristic that all intellectual fear and love of the angels are considered created <i>ex nihilo</i> and are <i>nefesh-ruach</i> of <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>.
But the detailed laws are drawn from the supreme wisdom of the Emanator, blessed is He, which is clothed in the physical object. This investment is not similar to that of the supreme wisdom in intellectual fear and love, for there the garment conceals and completely obscures, just as the gross earth thoroughly conceals the supreme wisdom clothed within it, as it is written, “You have made them all with wisdom.”<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 104:24. “All” includes the highest stage to the lowest. <i>Chochmah</i>, the Divine wisdom, invests even the lowliest; even the most exalted is considered as trivial as the lowliest (<i>Asiyah</i>, deed) before Him.</i> This supreme wisdom is the exterior of the exterior of the vessels of <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> found in <i>Asiyah</i>, absolutely hidden in the <i>ruach-nefesh</i> of <i>Asiyah</i>. So, too, in <i>Beriah</i> it is completely hidden in the <i>ruach-nefesh</i> (of <i>Beriah</i>); they are creatures, and Creator is concealed from the created.
This is not so, however, with regard to the laws—a radiance of wisdom illuminates them openly. The garment of <i>Asiyah</i> is merely by way of passage,<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">In descent from plane to plane, there may be adaptation, acquisition of the traits of the lower. The subject manifests itself through its newly acquired “garments” in which it is now clothed. Another sort of descent involves no adaptation. It is merely a “passage” through the lower plane, without adopting “garments.” See note 33.</i> as on holy days when <i>chesed</i> of <i>Atzilut</i> which is completely clothed in <i>chesed</i> of <i>Beriah</i> vivifies the physical world through passage by way of <i>chesed</i> of <i>Yetzirah</i> and <i>Asiyah</i>. This, too, is properly called investment, for otherwise it could not affect the physical aspects of This World.
Now although the physical nature of This World unquestionably conceals completely even the <i>chesed</i> of <i>Asiyah</i>, still the law proper is not actually physical; it is the (Divine) will, drawn from the supreme wisdom for leniency or severity in the verdict. It does descend and illuminate in revealed fashion in the realm of the physical, as water descends from a high place…. The physical object itself which the law discusses really does utterly obscure, as for example the law of exchanging a cow for a donkey,<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 100a.</i> or flesh that is <i>pigul</i>,<sup>68</sup> or is not <i>pigul</i> and is kosher.
Just the law itself and its revealed rationale are <i>malchut</i> of <i>Beriah</i> and <i>Yetzirah</i>, of the state of <i>neshamah</i>, which is G–dliness that vivifies and brings into being <i>ex nihilo</i>, the <i>nefesh-ruach</i> of the <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>, which are the awe and love of angels and souls and their <i>chabad</i>.
Hence it<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">The law.</i> slakes their thirst before its descent into This World like waters falling…. Even after descending into <i>Asiyah</i> it is far above <i>chabad</i> of <i>Asiyah</i>, even the state of <i>neshamah</i> which is G–dliness.
The reason is that <i>chabad</i> of <i>Asiyah</i> of the state of <i>neshamah</i> is the source of life of <i>chabad</i> of <i>nefesh-ruach</i> and their offspring, and of <i>their</i> creation <i>ex nihilo</i> with <i>their</i> offspring, until the ultimate stage of <i>Asiyah</i>, namely the earth and all its hosts.
But <i>chabad</i> of the laws with their rationales are in <i>malchut</i> of <i>Beriah</i>-<i>Yetzirah</i>. The aim of the <i>chochmah</i> is the rectification of the visages of <i>Atzilut</i>, upon whom are dependent all the rationales of the positive commandments in the Five Kindnesses and of the prohibitions in the Five Severities. Therefore, even when they descend to be clothed in creatures, they are in <i>malchut</i> of <i>Beriah</i>-<i>Yetzirah</i> of the state of <i>neshamah</i> specifically, which is of the vessels of <i>Atzilut</i>, and not of <i>nefesh-ruach</i>.
Now although <i>chabad</i> of <i>Beriah</i>-<i>Yetzirah</i> of the <i>neshamah</i> state are far superior in quality over <i>malchut of</i> <i>Beriah</i>-<i>Yetzirah</i> of <i>neshamah</i>, still they are the source for <i>chabad</i> of <i>Beriah</i>-<i>Yetzirah</i> of the state of <i>nefesh-ruach</i>, namely the angels. This is not a question at all. The angels and souls are only of a drop drawn from <i>chabad</i> of the <i>neshamah</i> to the attribute of <i>yesod</i> in the Minor Visage, then transmitted to <i>nukva</i>, and from there going forth in a state of “birth.” For even if it is proposed that they are created from the radiance of the vessels of <i>nukva</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>, they themselves descend and become <i>neshamah</i>.
But the essence of <i>chabad</i> of <i>neshamah</i> extends into the “six sides”<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">The four compass points, above and below.</i> of <i>zun</i>,<sup>63</sup> and there they are the Six Orders of Mishnah and the Gemara.
As to the statement in <i>Etz Chaim</i> (and in <i>Shaar Hayichudim</i>) that through <i>kavanah</i> (intention) there is formed a garment of <i>neshamah</i> and through Torah study—a garment of <i>ruach</i>-of-<i>ruach</i> of <i>Yetzirah</i> through Mishnah, and for <i>ruach</i>-of-<i>neshamah</i> of <i>Beriah</i> through Gemara. This can be understood as referring only to Torah studied by man in This World that ascends above. But Talmud itself that was given on Sinai is in <i>neshamah</i>. Therefore it refines <i>ruach</i>. So, too, with Mishnah of <i>Yetzirah</i>.
If it be suggested that even what was given at Sinai is in <i>ruach</i> of <i>Beriah</i>-<i>Yetzirah</i>, it is known that every angel, as an emissary from on High, is called by the Name of G–d<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Sanhedrin</i> 38b.</i> literally, for He dwells within the angel. However, when he is not a messenger he has some other name according to his function. Then he proclaims, “Holy holy holy is G–d…,”<sup>27</sup> meaning that the name of G–d is removed, distant from him. So it is actually in the state of investment of the Talmud, in the <i>ruach</i> state of <i>Beriah</i>, and the Mishnah in the <i>ruach</i> of <i>Yetzirah</i>—they are messengers of G–d, meaning vessels of <i>nukva</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>: the external state in Talmud, the intermediate state in Mishnah.
Thus Mishnah and Talmud contain issue of <i>yesod abba</i> which receives from <i>chochmah stimaah</i> of the Major Visage, in which is clothed the Light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He. The result is that the the Light of the <i>En Sof</i>, namely the Name of G–d, dwells in <i>ruach</i> of <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i> in Scripture, Mishnah, and Talmud. When man studies he draws forth the Light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed be He, into This World, that it be included and nullified in His Light, blessed be He. For this is all of man.<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 12:13.</i>
This was the service of Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai and all the <i>Tannaim</i> and <i>Amoraim</i> in the revealed Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>On the Teachings of Chassidus</i>, p. 17.</i>—to call forth His Light, blessed be He, and to make these refinements of <i>nogah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">See Addendum, Glossary, <i>Kelipat Nogah</i>; <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 6, note 3.</i> all through the period of the exile. Exile is the time of dominion of the Tree of Good and Evil,<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">ibid. note 8.</i> as we find, “The time that man dominates man….”<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 8:89.</i> For this is the purpose of the descent, that the Higher descend below, and there be an “abode for Him among the lowly,”<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>On the Teachings of Chassidus</i>, note 13.</i> in order to elevate them to become one in one.<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> II:135a.</i>
In contrast, the service of the angels with intellectual fear and love does not call forth at all; rather there is departure<sup>58</sup> alone…. Thus we may understand how angels are created <i>ex nihilo</i> through study of Torah, even without <i>kavanah</i>, which is a state of <i>ruach</i> alone, which is not G–dliness at all. Still, nevertheless, the name of G–d does dwell…. This will suffice for the knowing.

Chapter 5

To understand the details of the laws that never occur at all, and probably never actually existed, and certainly will not come to pass in the Time To Come, for example, the detailed laws of <i>pigul </i><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 7:18.</i> and the like.
It is known that every prohibited thing in this world has a source and root of life in <i>kelipot</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">See, Addendum, Glossary to <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, <i>Kelipot</i>.</i> Otherwise, it could not exist in this world, without the flow (of life) from above. Even one who dandifies his hair, and the like, receives his life-force at that moment from the chambers of <i>kelipot</i>, as explained in <i>Zohar</i>. Therefore even the particular prohibitions that never became practical issues in this physical world, still the source of their life does actually exist in the chambers of the <i>kelipot</i>.
There are instances that possibly never did and can never actually occur, for instance errors and unwitting misdeeds like erroneously calling the ninth “tenth…”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 27:32; <i>Bechorot</i> 59a.</i> and the like, eventualities that cannot be deliberate so that the <i>kelipah</i> may inhabit it. Possibly in these circumstances, it does not exist in the chambers of the <i>kelipot</i>. [<i>Gloss by the Tzemach Tzedek</i>: It appears to me that his use of the word “possibly,” implying uncertainty, is because unwitting errors come from <i>nogah</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Note 2; <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 6, note 3.</i> Therefore it may be that their origin is in the chambers <i>of nogah</i>.] In any event, it does exist <i>lehavdil </i><sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">“To separate,” a demarcation between the sacred and the profane.</i> in the supreme wisdom and issued and descended in this detail to Moses on Sinai, [as the expression, “Whatever] any valid student will originate…”<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">“…was revealed to Moses on Sinai.” Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Peah</i> 2:4.</i> and all the detailed queries of R. Yirmiah,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Bava Batra</i> 23a.</i> and (detailed queries such as) “If she wrapped him…” in ch. 4 of <i>Chullin</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">70a.</i>
For the extension of the supreme wisdom is Infinite, since the Infinite is actually clothed in it. Every particular of the law is a “hair”<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">See Essay 6, note 10.</i> drawn from the supreme wisdom that “established the daughter,”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">“Father” is <i>chochmah</i>, wisdom. “Daughter” is <i>malchut</i> of <i>Atzilut</i>.</i> and is clothed in it, and is drawn from it to be invested in <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>.
It is known that the nurture of the <i>kelipot</i> is from the backpart of the ten sacred <i>sefirot</i>, and more precisely from the garments of the ten <i>sefirot</i> of <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>, and more precisely, from <i>Yetzirah</i>-<i>Asiyah</i> that are intermingled with <i>kelipot</i>, as is known that their nurture is from the state of garments.
Through the study of the laws, in speech and in thought, they<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>kelipot</i>.</i> become separated and distinct from the sacred. It is so stated in <i>Tikkunim</i> and <i>Raaya Mehemna</i>, “To separate […] (the <i>kelipot</i> from holiness through Torah study).” This accords with what is known from what they said, “For they did not recite the Torah blessing before….”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nedarim</i> 81a. This was in answer to the prophet’s query (Jeremiah 9:11), “Why was the land destroyed?” The meaning here is that the people of those times failed to elicit the Light of the <i>En Sof</i> into their Torah study (the Hebrew word ברך, meaning “bless,” also signifies “draw down” (see Mishnah, <i>Kilayim</i> 7:1)). Evil cannot be separated from good by the Torah on its own; the Torah must be studied in the proper manner.</i> This (separation) is effected by calling forth the Light of the <i>En Sof</i> into the supreme wisdom clothed in them (the laws). “Through <i>chochmah</i> (wisdom) are they refined”<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Iggeret Hakodesh</i>, Epistle 21, quoting <i>Zohar</i>; <i>Sefer Hamaamarim 5708</i>, p. 206, note 11.</i>—through the Light of the <i>En Sof</i> that is within it.
This (Light) is drawn into the supreme wisdom by the supernal “likeness”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">See Essay 1.</i> of man who is also occupied with these laws above in his source in <i>nukva</i> of the Minor Visage<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">See Essay 3, note 8.</i> of <i>Beriah</i>, <i>Yetzirah</i>, and <i>Asiyah</i>.
Thus we can understand the requirement that every <i>nefesh-ruach-neshamah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Addendum, Glossary; <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 7, note 1.</i> fulfill all 613 commandments in thought, speech, and deed, meaning all the details of the laws. They must again descend into the mundane world to fulfill the Torah in all four <i>Pardes</i><sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 4, note 4.</i> aspects in order to refine all that pertain to them of the 288.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Sparks. See Addendum, Glossary, <i>Nitzotzot</i>.</i> This constitutes the complete structure of man, the 613 categories, general and particular.
But in the Time to Come, when the refinement is culminated, then the study of Torah will be in the form of “Do good”<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 34:15, “Turn away from evil and do good.”</i> alone. (Its purpose will be) to elevate <i>nefesh-ruach-neshamah</i> ever and infinitely higher, and also in the 365 prohibitions, to elevate them to their source, the Sacred Severities, and to “sweeten” them with Kindnesses of the 248 positive commandments and to unite them.
Thus is the entire Torah eternal in general and in detail. Even the individual laws of the 365 prohibitions are branches of the generalities. All of them have a source above in the Five Severities<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">See Essay 4, note 13.</i> of sanctity, just as the 365 prohibitions themselves as they are above in the state of “blood” that vivifies the vessels of the Minor Visage.

Chapter 6

“David! Do you call them songs!”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">When David brought the Ark back from the Philistine captivity (II Samuel 6; I Chronicles 13) it was borne in a wagon. David had forgotten the verse. “The sacred service is theirs; on the shoulder shall they bear it” (Numbers 7:9). This forgetfulness was a rebuke for David’s declaring, “Your statutes have been my songs in the house of my wanderings” (Psalms 119:54). This derogation of Torah is the theme of this essay. The opening quotation of this essay is taken from <i>Sotah</i> 35a. Other Chabad references include <i>Likkutei Torah</i>, <i>Bamidbar</i> 18a ff., <i>Derech Mitzvotecha</i> 40b ff., and <i>Sefer Hamaamarim 5702</i>, p. 36.</i> In <i>Zohar</i> we find, “The praise of Torah and its song.” We must understand what is the praise of G–d in forbidding or permitting an object.
A similar concept is implicit in “How great are Your works, O G–d, Your thoughts are very deep.”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 92:10.</i>
It is known that all worlds,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">All stages of existence, from the purest spiritual being to the grossly mundane, are called “Worlds” in Kabbalah and Chasidic usage. See Addendum: Glossary to <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I; Introduction to <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II. See also <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 1, note 3; above, Essay 1, note 3; Translator’s Explanatory Notes to <i>On Learning Chassidus</i>, et al.</i> the exalted and the lowly, are dependent on the precise and meticulous performance of a single mitzvah. For example, if the altar offering was valid then the supernal union<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Addendum, Glossary on <i>Yichud</i> defines and lists references. The transcendent and immanent, distinct in the mundane world, are united through the <i>mitzvot</i>. See below, note 7.</i> is effected, and all worlds are elevated to receive their life-force<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The covenant with Noah (Genesis 9:16 and 8:22) assured the simple existence of Creation and the dependability of natural processes quite apart from merit. Chasidut interprets the blessings (Leviticus 26:3, Deuteronomy 11:13) conditional on conduct, as referring to supplemental spiritual beneficence—through fulfillment of G–d’s wishes even This World is “illumined” with the radiance of the Infinite. <i>Zohar</i> (II:239a; III:26b) describes the “mystery of the offering” as “rising to the mystery of the Infinite.” All Creation is “elevated” through the proper sacrificial offerings, and the Consonant Divine response of increased Light of the Infinite into finite Creation ensues. Each mitzvah elicits the relevant response. The example of donning <i>tefillin</i>, presented in the forthcoming text, calls forth a revelation of the Divine intellect, and likewise with other <i>mitzvot</i>.</i> and sustenance.
However, if there is an aberration, if the celebrant received the blood of the offering in his left hand, say, or not in the appropriate vessel, or if some foreign body separates the vessel and the blood it contains, then all the elevations of the world are nullified, as is their life-force and sustenance from the Source of Life, the <i>En Sof</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">As a result, their continued existence, their life-force, their vivifying power, would emanate from a plane inferior to the ultimate Source of Life, the <i>En Sof</i> (Infinite). In this case, the presence of Creator is concealed behind the facade of nature.</i> blessed is He.
So, too, through valid <i>tefillin</i> there is revealed the supernal intellect of <i>zun</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Z’char v’nukva</i>, masculine and feminine, indicating unity. The mission of man in this universe of the concealment of G–d is to make His presence evident by living according to His commands and utilizing the physical world for the Divine purpose. Each of the names applied to G–d describes a particular aspect of G–d. One name describes His transcendence, G–d before Whom all Creation is naught. Another name indicates power, the creative and sustaining force, G–d Whose hand may be detected in His works. The theme of <i>yichud</i>, unity, recurrent in Kabbalah and Chasidut, is the union of both aspects, that transcendence become immanent, that Creation cease to conceal Him. This unity is effected on different planes, depending on the act which produces that union. Self-immolation, latent or actual, effects one sort of union; Torah study and mitzvah observance causes another. The union called <i>zu’n</i> (noted in our text) is of the latter order. The “Supreme Intellect” in the text refers to the first steps of the revelation of G–d culminating in Creation. In its external aspects, the union of the powers of Intellect is constant, for it is the source of Creation, bringing “something” from “nothing.” A more profound revelation of G–d, a union more than external, is dependent on man’s efforts, as in note 5, above. Man’s neglect of <i>mitzvot</i>, as the paragraph continues, results in obscuring a particular revelation that should have been manifest.</i> the source of life for all worlds. Through the omission of one required detail they are invalidated, and the intellect departs. This applies as well to the requirements of the prohibitions.
The meditation then may take these lines: Consider “How great are the works” of G–d in the multiplicity of worlds and all their hosts. All of these are literally null when compared to one detail of Torah specification, for Torah requirements are the profundity of the supreme thought and His wisdom,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 4, etc., for a discussion of the origin of Torah.</i> blessed be He. Through one minor specification all worlds ascend<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., their physical nature is refined, their concealment of the spirit is less pronounced.</i> and receive their life-force and sustenance, or the opposite, G–d forbid. From this we may ponder the magnitude of the profundity of His thoughts, blessed be He, that is boundless and endless, and infinitely transcends the vitality of all Creation. The vivifying power of all worlds issues from a minor requirement of it (G–d’s thought), for each specification is drawn from its source, namely the depth of His thought, blessed be He. Analogously, man’s hair issues from his brain,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The brain is the instrument of man’s supreme faculty. “Hair,” insensitive to pain, is symbolic of man’s lowest faculty, the least evidently living aspect of man. The physical proximity of the two extremes and their qualitative distance is the point made here. All of Creation, in all its impressiveness and magnitude and complexity, issues from a minor detail of Torah and is comparable to Torah roughly as a hair is comparable to the brain.</i> as is known from <i>Tikkunim</i> and <i>Idra Rabbah</i>.
This was the delight of King David, may he rest in peace, as he sang to gladden his heart in his Torah study during his time of trouble.
However, his extolling the praise of Torah with this quality, saying, “…have been my songs…” caused his punishment. G–d reproved him saying, “Do you call them songs!” For indeed, this quality—that all worlds are nothingness compared to one detail of it—is of the hinderpart<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Indicative of the external aspect, the secondary, as opposed to the “front” or inward, internal aspect, closer to the essential reality.</i> of the profound thought. This is explained elsewhere in the name of the Arizal,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Yitzchak Luria Ashkenazi, of blessed memory (1534-1572).</i> on the passage, “The Torah is an attenuated form<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Lit., “withered” (see Isaiah 34:4), or “things that fall” (see comment. by <i>Maharzu</i> to <i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 17:5). A withered plant is an attenuated or weaker form of a healthy plant. Similarly, the Torah is a weaker manifestation of supreme <i>chochmah</i>, but not <i>chochmah</i> as it is itself.</i> of the supernal <i>chochmah</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bereishit Rabbah</i> 17:5; 44:17. The Midrash describes several parallels, microcosms to their original: dream to prophecy, Shabbat to the Coming World, the sun to the Light Above, and Torah to the supreme wisdom.</i>
However, the internal aspect of the depth, which is the inner<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>On the Teachings of Chassidus</i>, beginning.</i> aspect of Torah—<i>pnimiyut haTorah</i>—is totally united with the Light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, that is clothed within Torah. The unity is a perfect one.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup> In terms of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, all Worlds are as absolute naught,<sup>16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> I:11b.</i> sheer nothingness, nonexistent. For, “You are the same, before the world was created….”<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Yalkut Shimoni</i> 836; Liturgy, Morning Prayer.</i>
Hence, the internal aspect of Torah too is not to be lauded as being the vivifying force of all Worlds, for they are reckoned as nothingness itself.
In this inward aspect of Torah there can be no mortal joy and delight, but rather, in a manner of speaking, the heart’s joy and pleasure of the King, the Holy One, blessed is He, Who delights in it. For “G–d understands its way,”<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Job 28:23.</i> and knows its station and quality, through His self-knowledge,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah</i> 2:10.</i> as it were.
This, however, is concealed from the mortal eye, as, “My face cannot be seen”<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 33:23. <i>Panai</i>, “My face,” also implies <i>pnimiyut</i>, inwardness. I.e, G–d’s inwardness (the inner part of G–d) cannot be seen, just as His “face” cannot be seen.</i>—i.e., the inwardness, as explained there in the name of the Arizal.
Hence the verse, “I was a pleasure to Him,”<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 8:30. The verse lauds Wisdom, or Torah, as a delight, but in two contexts. In v. 30 it is G–d’s pristine delight; in v. 31 it is man’s delight, world’s delight. Rabbi Schneur Zalman’s thesis is that the first is G–d’s exclusively, for it is totally beyond man’s ken; mortals can have no comprehension or appreciation of this basic character of Torah. Man’s province is the second, as Torah is expressed in terms of the physical world—study and <i>mitzvot</i>. Even this “inferior” aspect of Torah infinitely transcends “world,” yet is in turn incomparably inferior to what Torah truly is. David lauds Torah in this second aspect, but it is only the “hinderpart” of Torah, and in reality he demeans rather than exalts it.</i> to <i>Him</i> specifically. “Playing before Him,” before <i>Him</i> specifically, meaning the inwardness. “I was reared with Him,” and (the Midrash comments)—“Do not read <i>amon</i> (reared) but <i>uman</i> (craft)….”<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tanchuma</i>, <i>Bereishit</i>, beginning.</i>
In reference to the hinderpart it says, “Playing in the world, His land, and my delights are with mortal men.”<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 8:31.</i> For the Torah is given in states of inwardness and hinderpart, as written in the “flying scroll” of Zechariah, “And it was written front and back.”<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 2:10. The “flying scroll” is found in Zechariah 5:2. Commentators explain that the scrolls are one and the same.</i>
Since David seized upon the hinderpart he was punished with forgetfulness, a product of the state of the hinderpart. Momentarily he was oblivious to the verse, “The sacred service is theirs; on the shoulder shall they carry.”<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 7:9.</i> The purpose is to combine the “shoulder,” the hinderpart, with the sacred service, the supreme wisdom,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">The initial, highest revelation.</i> in a manner of inwardness.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">A thoroughgoing unity, pervasive and penetrating, not superficial or external.</i> This state is the source of the tablets in the Ark, as we find, “Written on both their sides….”<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 32:15.</i> The Jerusalem Talmud, <i>Shekalim</i>, explains that they did not have any front and back; study that reference.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">6:1.</i>

Chapter 7

“And charity like a mighty (<i>Eitan</i>) river” (Amos, end of ch. 5). The meaning is that charity will be like a mighty river, issuing from the state of <i>Eitan</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>On Learning Chassidus</i>, p. 18.</i> the state of “point in its chamber,”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid., p. 38 and Translator’s Explanatory Notes. <i>Chochmah</i> is the “point,” <i>Binah</i>, the “chamber.”</i> and “two comrades….”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Zohar</i> III:4a; <i>chochmah</i> and <i>binah</i> are termed the “two comrades who are never separated.”</i> The letters of the word <i>Eitan</i> indicate the future tense, “I am destined to reveal myself,” as written, “See, my servant will be wise …”<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 32:13.</i> This means that at that time the Light of the <i>En Sof</i>, blessed is He, and His Unity will be revealed within the depth of the core of the heart by calling forth the River Eitan, which is a radiance of the supernal wisdom<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See Addendum, Glossary to <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, <i>Chochmah</i>.</i> that will illuminate the inwardness of the heart. Then he will be nullified utterly in His unity, blessed be He, from the depths of the heart, after removing the <i>orlah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Based on Deuteronomy 10:16. <i>Orlah</i> is the term used for the foreskin removed in the rite of circumcision.</i> of physical lusts….
At present, during the exile of this folk,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Obadiah 1:20.</i> counsel is offered to bring a mite of the illumination of the Light of G–d from the state of <i>Eitan</i> into the core of the depth of the heart, in the fashion of the Time to Come. This is through arousing the plenteous mercies above for the G–dly spark within his soul.
For in truth, so long as man does not merit the revelation of the light of G–d of the state of <i>Eitan</i> in the core of the inwardness of his heart, to become nullified in His unity, blessed be He, until the very expiration of the soul, then it is indeed a great pity on the spark within his soul. For that spark is drawn from the state of the supernal wisdom itself, and when it cannot illuminate from its own state into the internality of the heart, which is the proper place for the revelation of this Light, then it is actually in exile.
Through the plentiful mercies on high, however, it goes out of exile and imprisonment and illuminates the core of the innermost of the heart with this great love, as known from the verse, “For Jacob who has redeemed Abraham,”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 29:22.</i> and as noted in <i>Likkutei Amarim</i> I, ch. 45.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">See also ch. 32.</i>
It is known that the arousal from above<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 1, note 26.</i> is dependent on the arousal from below, meaning that through arousing great mercies in the hearts of the merciful and kindly, to grant a beneficence below physically, gold and silver…. Therefore the work of charity is actually the work of the River Eitan.
All know the verse, “Skin for skin, and all that a man has he will give on behalf of his soul,”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Job 2:4.</i> his G–dly soul, to illumine it with the light of life, the Infinite, blessed is He.

Chapter 8

I have heard with foreboding and am deeply grieved that G–d’s people are preventing a person who yearns for the life and longevity of all our brethren,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., adherents of Chasidut.</i> from leading the service in this small sanctuary<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The synagogue, so called as distinct from the Sanctuary, the <i>Beit Hamikdash</i>, in Jerusalem.</i> of our confreres. Our Sages, of blessed memory, declare, “Three things prolong the days of man,”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 54b.</i> and one of these is prolonged prayer.
Even one extremely pressed for time, who finds it impossible to tarry until the response of <i>Kedushah</i> in the Repetition of the <i>Amidah</i>—far better is it for him to forego hearing <i>Kedushah</i> and <i>Barchu</i> than to tamper with the lives of those who desire life. Torah does exonerate the compelled.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">An act performed (or neglected) under compulsion is excused. See Deuteronomy 22:25-27; <i>Nedarim</i> 27a.</i> The <i>chazzan</i> discharges his obligation for him<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Schneur Zalman, <i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, <i>Orach Chaim</i> 124:1.</i> though he did not hear<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid., 591:2.</i> the <i>chazzan</i>, just as though he had heard—and hearing is precisely like responding.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid., 124:2.</i> The Gemara<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Rosh Hashanah</i> 35a.</i> notes this in reference to those in the fields who are considered under duress. They fulfill their obligation of the <i>Shemonah Esrai</i> prayer itself with the reader’s repetition, just as if they had actually heard it. <i>Kedushah</i> and <i>Barchu</i> are also included.
This we have searched out and verified—even in the early generations of the Sages of the Mishnah and Gemara, whose Torah study was constant<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 35b.</i> and was their primary service, not their prayer.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Yet even with them, prayer was related to life and longevity.</i> It is even more emphatically true at this time, in the period just preceding the advent of Moshiach,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Lit. “the heels of the Moshiach,” a play on Psalm 89:52.</i> when our Torah study is not constant because of the difficulty of our times. The primary service in the period just prior to the coming of Moshiach is prayer, as Rabbi Chaim Vital, of blessed memory, writes in <i>Etz Chaim</i> and <i>Pri Etz Chaim</i>.
Hence, it is fit and proper, beyond any vaguest doubt, to devote ourselves utterly to (prayer). It is literally a Torah imperative to those who have knowledge of the efficacy of contemplation, of some profound meditation—each according to his measure—in the presentation of the praises of G–d, blessed is He, in <i>Pesukei d’Zimra</i><sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 9, note 10.</i> and the two pre-<i>Shema</i> blessings, <i>Yotzer</i> and <i>Ahavah</i>. Through them he can arouse the love latent in the heart of every Jew,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">See Addendum, Glossary to <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, <i>Ahavah</i> (<i>mesuteret</i>).</i> that it attain a state of revelation, in the openness of the heart during <i>Keriat Shema</i> itself.
For this is the commandment of love that is in the verse “And you shall love…with all your heart…”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 6:5.</i> that is reckoned first among the 613 <i>mitzvot</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Maimonides, <i>Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah</i> 2:1-2; 4:12; <i>Hilchot Teshuvah</i> 10:2; Commentary on the Mishnah, <i>Avot</i> 1:3.</i> Maimonides, of blessed memory, writes that it is a fundament of Torah and its root, and source of all 248 positive commands.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 4.</i> Regarding the love latent in the heart of all Israel by birth and nature, there can be no command at all.
This is apparent to the understanding. While the love is concealed, it is still lodged within the Divine soul alone. Only when it attains a state of revelation in the animating soul is it revealed in the heart in the left ventricle, the abode of the animating soul.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Ibid., ch. 9.</i>
This is the meaning of “refinement of the sparks” mentioned there in <i>Etz Chaim</i> and <i>Pri Etz Chaim</i> in reference to prayer, and for this reason prayer is the primary service in the period just preceding the coming of Moshiach—to refine the sparks…. This may be either the state of transformation<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> (54a) explains “with all your heart” (the Hebrew implies a plural) as referring to both the good and evil within man. The evil can be transformed to desire good. See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 10, which discusses the <i>tzaddik</i> who has wholly or partially achieved this transformation. Subjugation of evil, or the animal soul, leaves it potent and intact, but ineffective.</i> or of subjugation of the animal soul to the Divine soul, as is known. For the blood is the soul…<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 12:23. The synonymity of (animal or animating) soul and blood. See <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 9. The love of G–d is to permeate the heart, the left void filled with blood, the equivalent of the animal soul.</i> and the blood is renewed daily through food and drink and is affected and improved by garments and shelter….
