On the other hand, in earlier generations when the Divine souls were of a higher order,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Shabbat</i> 112b. “If our predecessors were like angels we are men; if they were men we are donkeys.”</i> the refinement was instantaneous in <i>Keriat Shema</i> alone<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Berachot</i> 13b—Rabbi Judah the Prince “accepted the yoke of Heaven” at the moment he passed his hands over his face (at <i>Shema</i>).</i> and in the blessings preceding it, and the abridged <i>Pesukei d’Zimra</i>….<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shulchan Aruch</i>, <i>Orach Chaim</i> 52.</i> And this will suffice for the knowing.

Chapter 9

“You shall reprove your comrade”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 19:17.</i>—even one hundred times.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Bava Metzia</i> 31a.</i>
Therefore I cannot contain myself and refrain from crying out again, in a voice betraying weakness.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 32:18.</i> I plead with you, out of deep compassion, have mercy on your souls. Take care, be painstaking to an extreme concerning Torah and the service of the heart, which is prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Taanit</i> 2a.</i> with <i>kavanah</i>, proper intention. All should begin in unison, as one, word by word, not one here and another elsewhere, one mute and the other idly chatting—may G–d protect us.
The main cause and instigator of damage comes from those leading the services. That office is abandoned to whoever wishes to stride forth and seize the honor, or because not even one desires it….
For this reason, this is the counsel offered, and an amendment established as law not to be violated further, G–d forbid. That is, select specified people fit for this office, by lot or by consent of the majority of the worshippers. These shall be men who pray word by word, moderately, out loud, neither overly prolonging the prayers nor racing intemperately, G–d forbid.
Theirs is the duty to lead the services, each on his day as determined. He shall assemble close around him all those who pray at least with some voice, not whispering nor rushing, G–d forbid. This is amplified in ancient amendments in many cities.
I come now to renew them, to strengthen and invigorate them, never again to be weakened, G–d forbid. (Gevald! Gevald!)<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">An exclamation of anguish. These two words appeared in the original manuscript written by Rabbi Schneur Zalman.</i> How long will this be an obstacle for us!<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 10:7.</i> Have we not sufficient reproofs and troubles that have overtaken us!—may G–d protect and console us with twofold salvation,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Job 11:6.</i> and purify our hearts to serve Him in truth.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Liturgy, Shabbat <i>Amidah</i>.</i> Strengthen and fortify your hearts, all who hope in G–d.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 31:25.</i>
Also: complete the entire Talmud every single year and in every community by apportioning the tractates by lot or by consent. In a city with numerous synagogues, each congregation shall complete (the Talmud). If a congregation is too small to implement (this program), they shall join to themselves men of some large congregation. This statute shall not be varied or violated. Each of the participants shall individually conclude Psalm 119 weekly.
Since, due to the frailty of the generation, not everyone is capable of fasting as he ought,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 2 and 3.</i> the counsel offered is the declaration of our Sages, of blessed memory, “Whoever observes Shabbat according to its <i>halachah</i> (law) is forgiven all his sins.”<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 118b.</i> Note, according to its law. Therefore it is incumbent upon every individual to master the major law of Shabbat.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Shabbat</i> 12a. The term is used there in reference to the admonition to examine one’s clothing regularly on Shabbat to ensure against unwittingly carrying.</i>
Also, be most careful not to indulge in idle chatter, G–d forbid.
For it is known to the students of Kabbalah that in all <i>mitzvot</i> there are the internal and the external aspects. The externality of Shabbat is the cessation of physical labor, just as G–d ceased making physical heaven and earth.
The internal aspect of Shabbat is the <i>kavanah</i> (intention) in the Shabbat prayers and Torah study, to cleave to the One G–d, as it is said, “It is Shabbat to the L–rd your G–d.”<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 20:10; Deuteronomy 5:14.</i> This is the state of “Remember.”<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">“Remember” appears in the Exodus text of the Ten Commandments, and “Observe” in the Deuteronomy text, in the Shabbat commandment.</i>
The state of “Observe” in the inwardness (of Shabbat) is refraining from speech about material affairs, as G–d ceased from the Ten Utterances<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Avot</i> 5:1; see <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part II, ch. 11 and <i>Iggeret Hateshuvah</i>, ch. 4 ff.</i> through which physical heaven and earth were created. For one is opposite the other….<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 7:14; see <i>Likkutei Amarim</i>, Part I, ch. 6, note 1.</i>
